## A MESSAGE FROM THE MANAGERS: ADVANCED BATTERY MATERIALS RESEARCH AND BATTERY CONSORTIA

As we close fiscal year 2023, we recognize the contributions of the Team's scientists and engineers who pushed the boundaries of advanced energy storage for electric vehicles. This year, members from the various national laboratories,  universities,  and  industry  partners  published 166 papers  in  the  open  literature  and  obtained 23 patents. A few notable achievements from BMR and Consortia investigators during this quarter, from July 1, 2023, through September 30, 2023, are summarized below:

- Justin  Connell's  group  at  Argonne  National  Laboratory  in  collaboration  with  Solid  Power  tested  their alumina-coated  argyrodite  electrolyte  (Li 7-y PS6-y Xy ,  X  =  Cl,  Br,  I)  in  cells  using  a  lithium  anode  and  an LiNi 0.6 Mn0.2 Co0.2 O2 (NMC-622) cathode produced by Solid Power. Cells assembled with the coated material exhibited  up  to  a  ~ 10%  improvement  in  discharge  capacity  (150 mAh g -1 versus 138 mAh g -1 )  and  an increased  first  cycle  efficiency  (91.4% versus 85.9%)  relative  to  uncoated  cells  at  both  C/10  and C/3 charging rates. The cells achieved 40 cycles and are still under test.
- Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (Jason Zhang's group) showed the benefit of a floatable conductive layer (FLC) on copper current collectors for anode-free lithium batteries. The ~ 1.5 Âµm thick FCL was made  of  carbon  nanoparticles  and  a  polymeric  binder  to  tune  its  binding  to  copper  substrates.  The FCL coating has a weak binding to lithium and allows lithium to be deposited underneath the protection layer with appropriate pressure control. This enables long-term protection of copper substrates and high cycling stability in an anode-free configuration.
- Gerd Ceder's  group  at  Lawrence  Berkely  National  Laboratory  constructed  a  phase  diagram  of  the pseudo-binary Li2S-P2S5 solid-electrolyte system from first-principle calculations. The theoretical approach, combined with experimental observations in the literature, suggests kinetic hindrance in some of the  synthesis  phases.  The  superionic  conductors,  Î±-Li3PS4,  Î²-Li3PS4,  HT-Li7PS6,  and  Li7P3S11,  are  all predicted  to  be  metastable  at  300 K  but  thermodynamically  accessible.  This  approach  suggests  new synthesis routes such as high-temperature heating to stabilize the high-temperature phase of Li7PS6 before a relatively rapid cooling process to bypass the phase separation to Li2S and Li3PS4.
- The Battery500 Consortium - University of California at San Diego team demonstrated &gt; 150 cycles and 650 mAh/g electrode capacity with an enhanced high-sulfur content, sulfurized polyacrylonitrile (SPAN) denoted as CS-SPAN. Capacities as high as 800 mAh/g were achieved by integrating conductive additives composed of a mixture of carbon nanotubes and poly(acrylic acid)-based binder. This value surpasses the typical SPAN capacity of 550 mAh/g electrode. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy revealed the beneficial impact of SPAN in transitioning long-chain sulfur to short-chain ones, optimizing battery performance.
- The  Battery500 Consortium  -  University  of  Texas  at  Austin  team  obtained  advanced  high-resolution three-dimensional chemical analysis on cycled Li-metal anodes using time-of-flight - secondary-ion mass spectrometry.  They  established  spatial  correlations  between  transition metals (TMs)  and  electrolyte decomposition products. Insights into the localization of various chemistries linked to crucial processes that define Li-metal battery performance, such as lithium deposition, solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) growth, and TM deposition are deduced from the precise elemental and spatial analysis of the SEI.

- The  Lawrence  Berkeley  National  Laboratory  team  of  the  Cathode-Electrolyte  Interphase  Consortium conducted an in-depth study of Li4Mn2O5 to determine the origins of the observed anomalously high charge and discharge capacity in lithium cells (&gt; 350 mA h g -1 ). They determined that electrochemical decomposition of Li2O on charge and reduction of manganese to below 3+ during discharge is responsible for the capacities that are observed, with no evidence of contributions from reversible oxygen redox using X-ray absorption spectroscopy and X-ray Raman spectroscopy.

## Summary

The U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) has made a clear goal of realizing next-generation batteries with an energy  density  greater  than  500 Wh/kg,  that  can  cycle  for  more  than  300 cycles,  and that  can  demonstrate high-rate capabilities. To achieve this step-change in battery performance, a significant change in the battery chemistry and cell design is needed. This task focuses on developing solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) that enable Li-metal anodes and high-energy cathodes to achieve just such a step change. This task includes 18 projects centered in U. S. Department of Energy national laboratories and universities across the United States. These projects span the gamut of different materials for SSEs, interfacial design strategies to enable Li-metal anodes, and high-energy cathodes. Together, they can significantly impact the successful realization of the DOE battery performance targets.

In summary, the projects focus on research and development of a range of solid electrolytes (SEs), including:

- sulfur ceramics and glasses (1.1 - 1.5, 1.18),
- oxide and halide ceramics (1.6 - 1.8),
- polymers (1.9, 1.10),
- composites (1.11 - 1.14),
- multiple electrolytes / full cells (1.15, 1.16), and
- Li-metal - SSE interface (1.17).

These projects  encompass  common research themes  essential to  achieving  high-energy  solid-state  batteries (SSBs), including:

- engineering high ionic conductivity &gt; 1 mS/cm,
- developing  electrolytes  that  are  stable  with  various  high-energy  cathodes,  including  layered  oxides, high-voltage spinels, and conversion cathodes such as sulfur and FeF3,
- developing electrolytes or interfaces that are stable with lithium metal,
- developing thin SEs 20-Âµm to 100-Âµm thick, and
- understanding the mechanics of SSBs.

## Highlights

The highlights for this quarter are as follows:

- J. Connell's group at Argonne National Laboratory (ANL) in collaboration with Solid Power tested their alumina coated Li-P-S-Cl argyrodite  electrolyte  with an  Ni-Mn-Co  (NMC)  cathode  produced  by  Solid Power.  The  coated  argyrodite  electrolyte  cells  had  an  improved  first-cycle  Coulombic  efficiency  and improved capacity at both C/10 and C/3 charging rates over 40 cycles.
- G.  Xu's  ANL team used electrospinning to  form  a mechanically  reinforcing  scaffold  for  an  argyrodite electrolyte membrane. The team found that dimethylformamide was a superior solvent for electrospinning the spandex fibers.

## TASK 1 -

## Solid-State Electrolytes

Team Lead: Andrew Westover, Oak Ridge National Laboratory

- Y. Cui's group at Stanford University tested their lithium thioborate electrolytes in symmetric cells with lithium on both sides. The cells had a large rise in impedance over the asymmetric cycling, resulting in the ultimate failure of the cells. After cycling, the impedance spectroscopy corroborated the large increase in cell resistance.
- Nanda's SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory team along with Yang's Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) team used Transmission X-ray Microscopy (TXM) to visualize the morphology change in an NMC cathode  with  sulfide  SEs  before  and  after  charging  at  C/10.  The  TXM  images  show  significant cracking in the NMC cathode after even one cycle, accounting for capacity fade.
- D. Lu's  group  at  Pacific  Northwest  National  Laboratory  reconfirmed  literature  work  with  sulfide electrolytes  that  has  determined  that  the  pressure  used  to  form  Li/sulfide  SSE/Li  cells  as  well  as  the operational pressure have a large impact on performance. In these experiments the team found that higher operational  pressures  yielded  better  results  for  their  systems  in  contrast  to  some  literature  reports, highlighting that the problem is quite complex.
- J. Ye's team at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory further investigated the Co-doped Li-La-Zr-O (LLZO) that comes from co-sintering LiCoO2 cathodes with LLZO. They found that the doping, while extremely  small  in  volume  and  having  minimal  impact  on  the  crystal  structure,  results  in  significant decreases in the Young's modulus, hardness, and ionic and electronic conductivities. The data suggest some interesting routes for improved LLZO electrolytes.
- Z. Chen and T. Li's ANL group measured the electronic conductivity of the anti-perovskite SE films under pressures ranging from 20-100 Barr and temperatures from 20-90Â°C. The increased pressure tends to reduce electronic  conductivity,  while  the  increased  temperature  causes  increasing  electronic  conductivity, especially at 90Â°C.
- R. Sacci's  team  at  ORNL  tested  full  batteries  that  use  a  lithium  anode,  an  argyrodite  separator,  and  a Li3YCl6-NMC composite cathode. The cells with the Li3YCl6 catholyte outperformed the cells with the sulfide-based catholyte, demonstrating the value of the dual-layered design.
- N. Balsara's team at the University of California, Berkeley, (UCB) demonstrated the effect of crosslinking polyester-based electrolytes. The crosslinking enables formation of freestanding membranes with enhanced mechanical properties, but results in decreased lithium diffusivity with increasing crosslinking density.
- Z. Bao  and  Y. Cui's  Stanford  University  group  tested  perfluorinated  salt-philic  solvent-phobic  (SP 2 ) electrode coatings, finding that the selectivity embodied by the natural solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation enabled an increased cycle life in both FMDB-based electrolytes and traditional carbonate-based electrolytes.
- S. Tepavcevic's  ANL  group  synthesized  a  crosslinked  LLZO  fiber  matrix  using  post-electrospinning sintering of the LLZO fibers that facilitates continuous ion percolation through the LLZO network. They also reinforced the difficulty in making the LLZO - poly(ethylene) oxide (PEO) - lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) composite with high ionic conductivity due to the resistive interphase that forms at the LLZO-PEO interfaces.
- X. C. Chen's team at ORNL compared the use of a crosslinked PEO-LiTFSI electrolyte with two different lithium sources including a lithium chip and a thin lithium foil. The thin lithium foil had a thinner surface layer after initial cycling that facilitated a slower capacity fade than the lithium chip. The result highlights that lithium metal also plays a role in full-cell capacity fade.
- B. McCloskey's UCB group further explored the use of basic solutions to remove the surface impurities from LLZO ceramics. The base treatment with 1 + cations also leached significant lithium from the samples; however, a solution using Ca 2+ resulted in minimal lithium loss, albeit a thin calcium carbonate layer still formed on the surface.
- E. Hu's Brookhaven National Laboratory team developed an in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy cell that can observe the interphase formation between SEs and high-voltage cathodes throughout a full charge and discharge cycle.

- H.  Kim's  Task  1 team  at  Lawrence  Berkeley  National  Laboratory  (LBNL)  simulated  the  alloying  and subsequent plating of lithium at a C-Ag nanoparticle buffer layer. They found that the adhesion of the current  collector  buffer  layer  interface  and  the  lower  charge  transfer  resistance  resulted  in  preferential plating of the lithium at the buffer layer-current collector interface. The Task 2 team demonstrated the cycling of a Li2.61Y1.13Cl6 with a LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1 (NMC-811) cathode and a Li-In anode with an areal capacity of 1.2 mAh/cm 2 at 0.1 C with a reasonable 181 mAh/g. The Task 3 team demonstrated the ability to make thin 80-Âµm thick LLZO sheets with improved fracture toughness by incorporating MgO fibers. Future efforts will focus on three-dimensional scaffold-supported designs. The LBNL Task 4 team tested four  different  sulfide-polymer  composite  electrolytes  with  NMC-811  cathodes.  The  best  electrolyte facilitated charge-discharge at capacities up to 90 mAh/g after 50 cycles.
- A. Burrell's National Renewable Energy Laboratory team tested a Co-free layered oxide cathode material with a Si-based anode with SE. The full cells show an initial capacity utilization of 210 mAh/g. The team also demonstrated new polymer and ceramic electrolytes with promising ionic conductivities.
- A. Westover's  ORNL  team  tested  lithium  phosphorus  oxynitride  (LiPON)-coated  lithium  metal  versus pristine  lithium  metal with a crosslinked PEO-LiTFSI electrolyte. The LiPON significantly extends the cycle life of the cells from 1200 hours for the pristine lithium to nearly 2000 hours and counting for the LiPON-coated lithium metal.
- D. Wang's  Pennsylvania  State  University team  improved  their sulfur cathodes to a capacity of 1000 mAh/gsulfur after 100 cycles. High overpotential due to poor electronic and ionic conductivity in the cathode is an ongoing challenge.

## Task 1.1 -Multifunctional Gradient Coatings for Scalable, High-Energy-Density Sulfide-Based Solid-State Batteries (Justin Connell, Argonne National Laboratory)

Objective. This task seeks to develop scalable approaches to synthesize gradient-coated sulfide solid-state electrolyte (SSE) particles to improve their air/moisture tolerance and provide chemical compatibility with Li-metal anodes and high-voltage oxide cathodes. The compositional gradient is targeted to provide the additional advantage of lower interfacial impedance due to mitigation of detrimental, spontaneously formed space-charge layers and/or elemental interdiffusion at the sulfide SSE - oxide cathode interface.

Impact. Development of coated SSE materials that provide stable, low-impedance interfaces with both anode and cathode will enable high-energy-density, all-solid-state full cells with improved cyclability at high rates relative to benchmarked, uncoated materials. Coating the SSE directly will also remove the need for separate anode and cathode coatings, significantly reducing the cost and complexity associated with materials processing while maintaining compatibility with roll-to-roll manufacturing.

Approach. The team will leverage a surface science-based, integrated experimental-theoretical approach to synthesize gradient-coated SSE powders, to characterize the structure, composition, and intrinsic stability of coated  SSEs  in  contact  with  reactive  electrodes,  and  to  directly  correlate  this  understanding  with  their electrochemical performance. Gradient coatings will be developed using atomic layer deposition (ALD) and/or physical mixing methodologies viable at the kg/ton scale, ensuring technical and commercial relevance of the final, optimized coating process. Well-characterized, model surfaces will be used to understand the electronic structure and chemical stability of the gradient coatings as a function of gradient composition and thickness to understand the effect of space-charge layers and chemical reactions on interface resistance. They will accelerate development and optimization of the gradient coatings for improved performance in full cells by establishing a tight feedback loop between materials synthesis and experimental/computational characterization of interfacial (electro)chemistry.

Out-Year Goals. The  out-year  goals  are  to  demonstrate  high-energy-density,  low-impedance  full  cells assembled from fully optimized, gradient-coated SSE powders, high-energy-density cathodes, and Li-metal anodes. The team will also significantly improve the ability to manipulate the formation of space-charge layers at sulfide SSE - oxide cathode interfaces based on mechanistic understanding of the extent to which they can be mitigated to reduce overall cell impedance.

Collaborations. This  project  funds  work  within  multiple  divisions  and  directorates  at  Argonne  National Laboratory (ANL) and includes in-kind contributions from Solid Power.

## Milestones

1. Identification of multiple gradient coating chemistries that deliver &gt; 50% reduction in weight gain during humidified air exposure. (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Assembly and assessment of Li||Li symmetric cells with coated argyrodite SSEs. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Computational assessment of stability of coated lithium argyrodite SSEs against electrodes. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Small format full-cell assembly demonstration and baseline SSE|cathode interfacial impedance assessment. (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

Sulfide-based SSEs with an argyrodite-type cubic structure and Li7-yPS6-yXy (LPSX; X = Cl, Br, I) composition are  particularly  promising  candidate  materials  for  all-solid-state  batteries  (ASSBs)  due  to  high  ionic conductivities (&gt; 1 mS cm -1 ), wide band gaps, and favorable mechanical and processing properties. However, further improvements are needed to mitigate interfacial reactivity of these SSEs. Crucial challenges in designing ASSBs  using  Li-P-S-CL  (LPSC)  electrolytes  are  performance  deterioration  on  exposure  to  atmospheric conditions, reactivity at electrode-coating interfaces, and reactivity at the electrolyte-coating interfaces, which may form decomposition products and negatively impact battery performance. In previous quarters, the team has demonstrated significant benefits from their ALD coating strategy to both environmental stability and cycle stability in symmetric Li||Li cells. This quarter, they report preliminary full-cell cycling results that compare the performance of coated and uncoated LPSC materials.

LPSC materials were synthesized at ANL as previously described, and a fraction of material from the same synthesis batch was subsequently coated with 10 cycles of ALD Al2O3, as this coating thickness exhibits the optimal enhancement in materials properties (that is, ionic/electronic conductivity and environmental stability). Coated and uncoated materials were then sent to Solid Power, where they were assembled and cycled in a full cell as a catholyte and separator material. Specifically, the powders were processed into a pelletized separator with a Li-metal anode and a sprinkled cathode composite. The cathode composite contained LiNi0.6Mn0.2Co0.2O2 (NMC-622) cathode active material, coated or uncoated SSE from ANL, and carbon. The cell was then cycled from 2.5-4.2 V at 45Â°C. A symmetrical charge/discharge rate of C/10 was used for the first six cycles and then increased to C/3 (Figure 1). Results indicate significant improvements in performance for cells assembled from coated  materials  as  compared  to  uncoated  materials, with improved  capacity,  regardless  of  rate,  as  well  as improved first-cycle efficiency (FCE, Table 1). Specifically, cells assembled from coated materials exhibit up to ~ 10% improvement in discharge capacity relative to uncoated materials (150 mAh g -1 versus 138 mAh g -1 at C/3). Equally, if not more, significant is the increased FCE (91.4 versus 85.9% for coated versus uncoated, respectively). This is consistent with the improved stability of ALD-coated LPSC against lithium metal and, in combination with the improved discharge capacity, suggests that these materials have improved stability against NMC-622 as well. This improved stability is corroborated by the observation of overall very similar total cell impedance as a function of cycle number for cells assembled using coated versus uncoated material (Figure 2). Overall, these data highlight a significant benefit to full-cell performance from the ALD-coated materials. These results are particularly significant given that the team has yet to optimize the coating chemistry to better match the chemistry of the cathode active material, suggesting that there is significant room to further improve the performance of full cells incorporating ALD-coated SSE materials as catholytes.

Efforts  in  future  quarters  will  build  on  these  results  to  further  explore  the  interplay  between  SSE  coating chemistry and full-cell performance, both from the perspective of improving accessible capacity and capacity retention,  as  well  as  improving  processability  for  scale-up.  Longer-term  cycling  measurements  will  be performed to monitor changes in cell impedance during extended cycling that may reveal additional benefits to cell lifetime and/or capacity retention. They will also explore additional coating chemistries in full-cell formats, guided by the computational screening strategy detailed last quarter, to optimize the stability/reversibility of these  SSE  materials  against  high-energy  cathode  materials.  Furthermore,  optimization  of  the  particle  size distribution  of  ANL-synthesized  LPSC  should  yield  additional  improvements  in  overall  cell  performance, regardless of coating chemistry. Finally, co-optimization of the coating chemistry to improve the processability of coated SSEs in scalable manufacturing methods (for example, slurry casting) will further enable integration of these coated materials with roll-to-roll processing capabilities at Solid Power.

## Task 1.2 -Sulfide Electrolytes for High-Energy, All-Solid-State, Lithium-Sulfur Batteries (Guiliang Xu, Argonne National Laboratory)

Objective. The project objective is to develop ultrathin (&lt; 30 ï­ m) sulfide solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) with high  room-temperature  ionic  conductivity  (&gt; 0.01 S/cm)  and  high  chemical/mechanical/electrochemical stability,  and  further  integrate  them  with  lithium  metal  and  high-loading  Se-doped  sulfur  cathodes  through rational interface engineering to develop all-solid-state Li-S batteries (ASSLSBs) with high energy density and long cycle life.

Impact. The  project  is  related  to  development  and  mass  production  of  high-performance  sulfide  SSEs  for high-energy all-solid-state Li-S pouch cells. The project's success in meeting or exceeding U. S. Department of Energy targets can promote practical implementation of Li-S batteries in electric vehicles, electric aviation, and grid energy storage, and hence significantly reduce oil dependence and emissions of carbon dioxide. It can also mitigate the domestic supply challenge on critical raw battery materials (for example, nickel and cobalt).

Approach. The thickness and chemical/interfacial stability of sulfide SSEs are the critical challenges for energy density, cycle life, and mass production of all-solid-state Li-S pouch cells. The team will combine innovative material design, electrode architecture fabrication, and advanced diagnostics tools to address these challenges. Specifically,  the  approaches  include: (1) improving  air  stability  and  ionic  conductivity  of  sulfides  through synthetic  control  and  cation/anion  doping,  (2) fabricating  flexible  thick  SeS  cathode  supported  thin  sulfide electrolytes to ensure intimate contact and increase energy density, (3) stabilizing Li-metal/sulfide electrolytes interface  via  interlayer  and  additives  design  to  increase  critical current density of  lithium stripping/plating, (4) advancing Li-S pouch-cell design, and (5) performing multiscale advanced diagnostics such as in situ X-ray diffraction,  X-ray absorption  spectroscopy,  X-ray  imaging,  and  focused  ion  beam  -  scanning  electron microscopy to understand and overcome the degradation pathways.

Out-Year Goals. The out-year goals are to scale up the optimal sulfide SSEs to develop Ah-level all-solid-state Li-S  pouch  cells  that  can  reach  a  cell  energy  density  of  &gt; 500 Wh/kg  with  80% capacity  retention  for &gt; 300 cycles at a current density of &gt; 1 mA/cm 2 .

Collaborations. The team is closely collaborating with top scientists at University of Chicago (X. Huang) and at Advanced Photon Source (C. Sun, W. Xu, D. Zhang, and J. Deng) and Center for Nanoscale Materials (Y. Liu and M. Chan) of Argonne National Laboratory for in situ diagnostics on the synthesis and aging mechanism of the proposed sulfide SSEs.

## Milestones

1. Synthesize Li1-xPS5-x-yOyBr1+x with an ionic conductivity of &gt; 1 mS/cm. (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Complete testing and understanding on moisture stability of Li1-xPS5-x-yOyBr1+x. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Optimize structure of sulfur cathode and composite cathode to achieve &gt; 1000 mAh/g and stable cycle life in solid-state Li-S cells. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Fabricate thin (thickness: 25-100 ï­ m) sulfide electrolytes membrane. (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

This quarter, the team started to explore the fabrication of thin sulfide SSEs. Their idea is to use electrospinning to fabricate polymer scaffold on top of sulfur electrode, and then infuse sulfides solution to form a thin solid electrolyte (SE) layer. The first step is to identify a polymer with high elasticity to improve the mechanical integrity of the thin SE.

Spandex has attracted the team's attention because of its extraordinary elasticity, which comes from its bimodal segments (both soft and hard). The soft segments allow the entire polymer matrix to be stretchable, while the hard  segments  mechanically  sustain  the  overall  network.  It  has  been  used  as  binder  for  various  electrode materials such as silicon anode and LiNixCoyMn1-x-yO2 cathode in Li-ion batteries. When used as scaffold in solid-state batteries, it not only improves the mechanical strength of the thin SE membrane, but also helps to improve the cohesion between SE particles and active material particles through hydrogen bonding.

The  group  has  set  up  in-house  electrospinning  capability  for  thin  SE  development.  They  started  with  the optimization of the electrospinning process (feeding rate, concentration of solutions, solvent/co-solvents) to obtain a fine nanofiber network. Spandex is dissolved into different organic solvents to prepare solutions for electrospinning. The working voltage was set to 18 kV for all electrospinning experiments.

N-Methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solution was selected as the solvent to dissolve spandex given it  has  been widely used as binder for batteries. The concentration was controlled at 5 wt%. The feeding rate has an influence on the evaporation rate of the electrospinning jet and thus significantly affects the morphology of the formed nanofibers. As shown in Figure 1a, at a lower feeding rate of 0.21 ml/h, a small amount of  solution  was  ejected  from  the  capillary  tips, leading  to  formation  of  small  droplet  size.  By increasing the feeding rate to 0.42 ml/h, the ratio of  nanofiber  was  significantly  increased.  As  a result,  the  feeding  rate  was  set  to  0.42 ml/h  for subsequent experiments.

Task  1.2 -Figure  1.  Scanning electron microscopy images of spandex prepared by electrospinning at a feeding rate of (a) 0.21 ml/h and (b) 0.42 ml/h.

Due to the higher dielectric constant, lower vapor pressure, and higher electric conductivity of dimethylformamide (DMF), the team has investigated the effect of solvents on the morphology of electrospun samples. The results show sharp contrast when they switched the solvent from NMP to DMF. As shown in Figure 2, in addition to the nanofibers, large beads formed in the case of NMP solvent, while well-dispersed nanofibers were obtained in the case of DMF solvent. DMF was not easy to volatilize during the electrospinning

Task  1.2 -Figure  2.  Scanning  electron  microscopy  images  of  spandex  by electrospinning with a feeding rate of 0.42 ml/h using different solvents: (a) NMP and (b) DMF. The concentration of solution is 10 wt%.

process, which made it easier to form a branching fiber.  The  evaporation  rate  of  the  solvent  had effects on the formation of electrospun fibers from the  polymer  jet.  A  jet  with  a  strong  dielectric ability  can  produce  a  large  electrostatic  drafting force  in  the  stable  electrospinning,  and  ultrafine fiber can be formed after solvent volatilization.

However, the solubility of spandex in DMF is low, taking up to one week for complete dissolution. To resolve this issue,  they added cosolvents such as tetrahydrofuran (THF) to increase solubility.

Meanwhile the ratio of cosolvent could also change the surface tension of the spandex solution. As shown in Figure 3, with high content (40 vol%) of THF solvent, winding and thick fibers with large pores were formed, while straight and thin nanofiber with small pores was produced in the case of low content (10 vol%) of THF.

Through optimization of electrospinning parameters, the team is able to produce fine spandex nanofiber with highly  porous  interconnected  fibrous  structures,  which  is  suitable  for  the  uptake  of  a  sufficient  amount  of liquefied argyrodite sulfide SEs. They will fabricate the cathode-supported sulfide SEs and control the thickness in the next few quarters. They will further evaluate performance in ASSLSBs.

## Task 1.3 -Thioborate Solid-State Electrolytes for Practical All-Solid-State Batteries (Yi Cui, Stanford University)

Objective. This project aims to develop novel lithium thioborates (Li-B-S, LBS) as a new class of solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) to realize high-performance all-solid-state batteries (ASSBs), with a particular focus on addressing the technical challenges in electrolyte synthesis, cell integration, failure diagnostics, and scale-up. The approach will be technologically transformative to the current solutions for ASSB development. For the final deliverables, ASSBs with the ability to reach an energy density of 500 Wh/kg and maintain 80% capacity for at least 300 cycles will be demonstrated.

Impact. The project approaches provide new directions toward developing high-conductivity and electrochemically stable sulfur-based electrolytes for ASSBs. Such high-performance electrolytes can enable the practical realization of ASSBs with high energy density and improved safety.

Approach. The  long-term  project  has  a  multistep  approach  toward  integration  of  LBS  with  high-voltage cathodes, with steps 1-3 as the focus for this year:

1. Fabricate undoped LBS powders using an all-solid-state synthesis method to achieve high ionic conductivity, low electronic conductivity, and a wide operational voltage window.
2. Integrate  LBS  SSEs  into  symmetric  Li/LBS/Li  cells  and  into  full  batteries  using  high-voltage cathodes including lithium Ni-Mn-Co (NMC) oxide.
3. Study atomic,  particle,  and  cell-scale  Li-metal-SSE  interface  development  and  dendrite  growth mechanisms  in  SSEs  using  advanced  characterization  tools.  Use  knowledge  to  better  develop SSEs and modify interfaces for stable cycling in full cells.
4. Fabricate doped LBS powders and develop particle/surface modifications to increase ionic conductivity as well as stability in full batteries and in air for glovebox-free synthesis.
5. Use density functional theory to guide development of new doped LBS materials and to explore interactions at solid-solid interfaces.

Out-Year Goals. In  the  following  year,  the  team  will  develop  solid-state  reaction  methods  to  synthesize undoped LBS powders and construct Li/LBS/Li symmetric cells to test the electrochemical performance of synthesized LBS. Meanwhile, the team will utilize advanced characterization tools [for example, cryogenic electron  microscopy  (cryo-EM)  and  X-ray  computed  tomography  (CT)]  to  resolve  the  nanostructure  of Li/LBS interphase and investigate the electrochemical stability between LBS and lithium metal.

Collaborations. This group is collaborating with W. Chueh's group (advanced characterization) and E. Reed's group (crystal structure computation) at Stanford University as well as with Y. Liu (advanced characterization) at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory.

## Milestones

1. Develop solid-state reaction methods to synthesize halide-doped LBS powders. (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Construct Li/LBS/Li symmetric cells for electrochemical characterizations. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Construct NMC/LBS/Li full cells with undoped LBS for electrochemical characterizations. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Resolve the nanostructure of Li/LBS interphase using advanced characterizations (for example, cryo-EM and CT). Achieve ionic conductivity of LBS SSE of 3.0 Ã— 10 -3 S cm -1 . (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

This quarter, the team investigated Li/LBS/Li cells with the aim of investigating the SSE-Li interface. They used LBS-LiI as the solid electrolyte, with a pellet ~ 450 microns thick and ~ 5 mAh lithium electrodes. After critical current density testing (Figure 1a; shown in the Q2 FY 2023 report), they found that the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was completely different (Figure 1b). While before cycling the team observed a singular semicircle with no diffusion tail, after cycling the semicircle had expanded significantly and a diffusion tail appeared, corresponding to new ion-blocking species grown at the interface. The spectrum became quite noisy, suggesting worse interfacial contact and increased surface roughness between the SSE and the lithium electrodes. They disassembled this cell and analyzed the Li-SSE interface under scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). SEM exposed a 30-40-Âµm thick, host-like, and porous but uniform anode after cycling (Figure 1c). XPS analysis revealed that the anode contained mostly lithium metal with LiI and Li2S and some LBS and sulfur (Figure 1d). While Li2S is electronically and ionically insulating, LiI has been shown to induce uniform plating of lithium metal, explaining the long-term stable cycling. [1-3] Other works also report the accumulation of LiI at the interface of SSEs with LiI with lithium metal during cycling and report a benefit to cycling performance. [3, 4] The LBS-LiI pellet remains dense and largely crack-free after cycling, corroborating that high interfacial impedance, rather than shorting, is the source of cell failure. The finding of Li2S, a Li + blocking species, at the anode corroborates the appearance of the Warburg impedance tail seen in the EIS after cycling.

Task 1.4 -Substituted Argyrodite Solid Electrolytes and High-Capacity Conversion Cathodes for All-Solid-State Batteries

(Jagjit Nanda, SLAC Stanford Battery Research Center; Guang Yang, Oak Ridge National Laboratory)

Objective. The project aims at synthesis and fabrication of Li-ion conducting argyrodite solid electrolytes (SEs) with  nominal  composition  Li6PS5X  (LPSX;  X  =  Cl,  Br).  The  team  will  combine  alternating  current  (AC) impedance with complementary in situ spectroscopy and microscopy to identify buried interfacial side-reaction products  and  quantify  the  voltage  losses  associated  with  these  side  reactions.  Specifically,  they  plan  to investigate  the  interfacial  reaction  between  various  LPSX  SEs  and  Li-ion  cathodes  belonging  to  different structural families [transition-metal-based sulfides and fluorides (for example, FeS2 and FeF2) and high-voltage layered oxides (for example, LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2, or NMC-811)]. New dopants such as niobium and partial substitution of sulfur with oxygen will be explored to improve stability of argyrodite SEs against lithium metal and high-voltage cathodes.

Impact. The  proposed  work  addresses  key  technical  barriers  to  achieve  solid-state  Li-metal  batteries  with energy  densities  of  &gt; 450 Wh/kg  and  1,000 Wh/L,  which  is  critical  for  next-generation  electric  vehicles. Integrating new sulfide SEs prepared through scalable, low-cost solvent-mediated routes with high capacity, earth abundant conversion cathodes (for example, sulfur, FeF3, and FeS2) will lower solid-state battery (SSB) cost to $80/kWh and eliminate use of critical materials such as cobalt and nickel.

Approach. Scalable solution-based processing routes will be developed to produce freestanding sulfide/binder solid-state  separators  with  thicknesses  &lt; 50 Âµm  and  area  specific  resistance  &lt; 50 Î© cm 2 .  These  ultrathin separators will be integrated with Li-metal anodes and high areal capacity conversion cathodes (for example, sulfur, FeS2, and FeF3) to demonstrate laboratory-scale prototype SSBs. As a cross-cut activity, various in situ and ex situ passivation  methods  will  be  combined  with  enabling  characterization  techniques  to  facilitate Li + transport across electrode/SE interfaces.

Out-Year Goals. Optimize  SSB  performance  by  the  following  methods:  (1)  identify  solvents  and  binders compatible with solid-state electrolyte (SSE); (2) optimize binder type and loading to produce free-standing films &lt; 100-Âµm thick with ionic conductivity ~ 1 mS/cm at room temperature; (3) evaluate ionic conductivity using  electrochemical  impedance  spectroscopy;  and  (4)  use  interfacial  coatings  to  stabilize  the  cathode  as needed; use various AC / direct current electroanalytical methods to identify degradation mechanisms during cycling. The targets are as follows: produce a free-standing thin-film sulfide SSE with thickness &lt; 100 Âµm and critical current density &gt; 500 ÂµA/cm 2 ,  and integrate thin-film SSE with a cathode and thin lithium anode to cycle at reduced pressure.

Collaborations. D. Hallinan and his group are funded collaborators to develop the binder system for sulfide SEs  and  evaluate  compatibility  with  cathodes  and  lithium  metal.  P. Jena  from  Virginia  Commonwealth University will be an unfunded collaborator on density functional theory modeling of bulk Li-ion transport and ab initio molecular dynamics at SE interfaces .

## Progress Report

This quarter's goal was to understand the capacity loss in NMC-811 cathodes when using argyrodite sulfide SE, LPSC. Specifically,  the  team  explored  the  changes  in  chemical  phase,  oxidation  state,  and  morphology  of NMC-811 cathode and LPSC SSE using synchrotron X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and microscopy.

Synchrotron XAS  is  instrumental  in  revealing  the  electronic  structures  and  coordination  environments  of NMC-811 cathodes due to the elemental specific nature. They performed nickel K-edge XAS at beamline 4-3 of  the  Stanford  Synchrotron  Radiation  Lightsource  (SSRL)  to  resolve  the  chemical  states  of  nickel  after charging and discharging NMC-811 using the argyrodite SEs (Figure 1). The X-rays reflect off a silicon crystal, entering the hutch through the slits. They then pass through a group of detectors, first through an I0 detector that measures  the  incident  flux,  followed  by  the  reference  detectors  I1,  and  I2.  The  fluorescence  detector  is perpendicular  to  the beam  (Figure 1a).  Figure 1b  illustrates  the  experimental  setup  of  the  XAS  instrument, specifically highlighting the portion of the sample holder that is contained within and exposed to the X-rays at a  45-degree angle. Several NMC-811 cathode samples were tested, including pristine, and those have been cycled with argyrodite SEs, with Li-In alloy as an anode. For cycled NMC-811, the team has samples charged once (denoted as 'charged') and those that have experienced a full cycle (denoted as 'charged-discharged'). The pristine sample serves as the reference. The charged sample was cycled once at C/10 and held for 1 hour. The charged-discharged sample was charged once and discharged once at C/10 and held for 1 hour. The samples were pre-prepared in an argon-filled glovebox with O2 and H2O level less than 0.1 ppm. The samples were enclosed  in  polycarbonate  films  and  are  stuck  to  the sample  holder  plates  using  double-sided  tape.  Nickel K-edge  XAS  of  pristine  (green),  charged  (blue),  and  charged-discharged  (red)  Ni-rich  NMC-811  cathodes revealed the higher oxidation states in the charged states of NMC-811 cathodes (Figure 1c). The image on the lower right shows a zoomed in section of the rising edge of the spectra for the three samples. The arrows on the image indicate the direction of energy shift. For the charged sample, the rising edge of spectra shifts to a higher energy,  indicating  the  oxidation  of  nickel  centers  owing  to  Ni 2+ /Ni 3+ and  Ni 3+ /Ni 4+ electrochemical  redox reaction. During lithiation (for charged-discharged samples), the rising edge returns to the initial energy (close to that of the pristine sample).

To  visualize  the  morphological  change  of  NMC-811  cathodes  at  different  cycling  conditions,  the  team performed transmission X-ray microscopy (TXM) at beamline 6-2 at SSRL (Figure 2). Experimental setup of the TXM instrument and the sample mounting condition are shown in Figure 2a and Figure 2b. X-rays pass through wigglers and mirrors before focusing to a spot size of a few hundred microns that acts as the source for the TXM (Figure 2a). The incident X-ray beam then goes through a monochromator, a mirror pitch feedback system and is  focused  by  a  capillary  condenser.  A  Fresnel  zone  plate  is used to  achieve  magnifications  of ~ 50Ã— depending on the energy configuration of the incident X-rays. A charge-coupled device coupled with the scintillator crystal collects the projected images. The sample is sealed in polycarbonate films to prevent further conversion with atmosphere (Figure 2b). A stack of transmission images, with a nominal spatial resolution of 30 nm, was recorded as the energy of the incoming X-rays was scanned across the nickel absorption K-edge. In  the  near-edge  region,  the  energy  step  was  set  to  0.5 eV  to  ensure  sufficient  energy  resolution.  Over  the pre-edge and post-edge regions, they scanned the energy with larger step sizes of 5 eV and 10 eV, respectively, to cover a broad energy window for normalization of the X-ray absorption spectra. The obtained images can be processed  later  using  TXM Wizard  software  for  reference  correction,  image  alignment,  and  TXM-XAS analysis. Imaging and data collection for each mosaic, acquired at a fixed energy step around the nickel K-edge, were conducted for one sample at a time. The sample holder is placed on the sample stage to intercept the

incoming  X-rays.  TXM  images  of  NMC-811  at  the  fully  charged  state  (Figure 2c)  and  after  the  first charged-discharged cycle (Figure 2d) show distinct features. The images were taken at an energy above the nickel K-edge (8333 eV). The NMC-811 particles are surrounded by argyrodite SEs, as revealed by the contrast between NMC-811 particles and their surrounding environment. A clear distinction between the charged and charged-discharged samples can be seen with visible microstructural cracking (pulverization) and degradation happening  after  discharging  the  NMC-811 cathode.  The  team's  observations  indicate  that  cracking  of NMC-811 cathodes and the overcharging of nickel are primary causes of the capacity decay for the 1 st cycle of NMC-811 cathodes using argyrodite SEs.

Task 1.5 -Stable Solid-State Electrolyte and Interface for High-Energy, All-Solid-State, Lithium-Sulfur Battery (Dongping Lu, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory)

Objective. The  project  objective  is  to  address  material  and  interfacial  barriers  of  sulfide-based  solid-state electrolyte  (S-SSE)  for  deep  cycling  of  Li-metal  anodes  in  all-solid-state  lithium  batteries  (ASSLBs).  All proposed work will be focused on the development of highly conductive sulfide Li + conductors with extremely low  lithium  /  solid-state  electrolyte  (SSE)  interfacial  resistance  and  ultrathin  multifunctional  interlayers  to enable deep and stable lithium cycling. The solid electrolytes (SEs) and interlayer assembly achieved in the project will be tested at practical conditions and validated in realistic Li-S pouch cells.

Impact. ASSLBs have the potential to  achieve  higher  energy  and  power  densities,  extending  the  range  of electric vehicles (EVs) and reducing charging time simultaneously. The success of the project would advance the  research,  development,  and  deployment  of  superionic  SEs  and  protective  Li-compatible  interlayers  to support  the  U. S. Department  of  Energy  Vehicle  Technologies  Office  target  of  developing  next-generation ASSLBs  for  EVs,  accelerating  market  acceptance  of  long-range  EVs  required  by  the  EV  Everywhere Grand Challenge.

Approach. The project proposes the following approach: (1) to develop Li-compatible superionic S-SSEs and effective coating approaches, (2) to stabilize the Li/SSE interface by employing a multifunctional interlayer, (3) to enable a robust Li + /e -mixed conduction network for a high-loading sulfur cathode, (4) to develop dry processing for SSE film, cathode, and interlayer fabrication, and (5) to advance the mechanism study of the sulfur cathode, lithium anode, and interfaces by multiscale characterization and multiscale modeling.

Out-Year Goals. This project has the following out-year goals:

- Develop Li-metal-compatible S-SSEs with Li/SSE interfacial resistance &lt; 5 â„¦ cm 2 and room-temperature Li + conductivity &gt; 5 mS/cm.
- Operate lithium anode at critical current density &gt; 1 mA/cm 2 , and lithium cycling for at least 400 cycles.
- Fabricate/demonstrate ultrathin multifunctional interlayer to enable deep lithium cycling &gt; 4 mAh/cm 2 to couple high areal-capacity cathode.
- Dry process an SSE/interlayer assembly with an overall ionic conductivity &gt; 1 mS/cm.
- Validate the S-SSE, high-areal capacity cathode, and bilayer assembly in a realistic Li-S pouch cell.

Collaborations. This project engages in collaboration with the following: D. Y. Qu (University of Wisconsin, Madison),  Z. K. Liu  (Pennsylvania  State  University),  C. M. Wang  and  J. Bao  (Pacific  Northwest  National Laboratory, PNNL), H. Du (Ampcera Inc.), and Z. Liu (Thermo Fisher Scientific).

## Milestones

1. Down-select optimal materials for the Li-metal interlayer fabrication to enable lithium stripping/plating at &gt; 2 mAh/cm 2 for  at  least  100 cycles  demonstrated  in  Li/SSE/Cu  or  Li-S full cells.  (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Gain  mechanism  understanding  of  lithium  nucleation  and  growth  in  the  presence  of  lithium  interlayer through experimental and modeling tools. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

Cycling lithium metal against an SSE under conditions of high areal capacity and/or high current density often results  in  Li/SSE  interfacial  instability.  This  instability  primarily  stems  from  the  complex  chemical, electrochemical, and mechanical interactions that occur during the dynamic processes of lithium plating and stripping. In particular, changes in lithium morphology are involved in all these processes. Nonuniform lithium stripping  can  lead  to  formation  of  voids,  while  uneven  lithium  plating  can  result  in  generation  of  lithium dendrites.  Such  nonuniformity  is  exacerbated  by  repeated  cycling  and  can  be  further  exaggerated  with  an increase in applied current densities or increased lithium stripping/plating depth (areal capacity).

To address these issues, homogenizing lithium plating/stripping along the Li/SSE interface is crucial. Starting this quarter, the team has begun work on improving the cyclability of lithium with the PNNL Li7P2S8Br0.5I0.5 (LPSBI) SE. Their focus is on two key tasks: (1) constructing a functional interlayer on the current collector to facilitate  uniform  lithium  plating  and  stripping,  and  (2)  optimizing  external  pressure  by  investigating  the impacts of pressure for pellet fabrication, lithium attaching, and cell operation on cell cycling.

Task  1.5 -Figure  1.  (a)  Photo  image  of  the  Ag-coated  copper  current  collector.  (b)  Scanning  electron microscopy image of the Ag-coated copper. (c-e) Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy of Ag-coated copper. (f)  Initial plating/stripping profiles of Li/SSE/Cu cells using copper with/without silver coating.

The  team  synthesized  carbon-coated  nanosized  silver  particles  (Ag@C)  using  a  chemical  method.  These particles were then coated onto a current collector (copper) either by in situ deposition during synthesis (direct coating) or through a slurry coating method (thin coating). Unlike the Ag/C composites prepared by mixing silver nanoparticles with carbon, this chemical synthesis approach allows for control over the morphology of silver particles, thereby making it possible to tune the kinetics of the Li-Ag alloy/de-alloy process. Additionally, the in situ carbon coating confines the silver nanoparticles and prevents them from migrating and agglomerating during the Ag-Li alloy/de-alloy processes. As shown in Figure 1a, the copper foil after silver coating appears very similar in color to pristine copper, indicating a very thin and uniform coating layer. Scanning electron microscopy characterization reveals that the Ag@C particles are not only uniform but also nanosized. X-ray diffraction analysis confirmed the formation of a silver phase through the chemical synthesis approach (not shown  here),  and  energy-dispersive  X-ray  spectroscopy  results  confirm  the  uniform  distribution  of  silver nanoparticles across the copper surface. It has been reported that using Ag/C as an interlayer between SSE and the current collector can improve conductivity and lower lithium nucleation energy, resulting in uniform lithium plating. Accordingly, they used an Ag-coated copper collector to assemble Li/SSE/Cu cells to study its effect on lithium plating/stripping. They compared three types of copper current collectors: bare copper, Ag-coated copper by direct coating, and Ag-coated copper by thin coating. Preliminary comparisons and conclusions can

be drawn from the lithium plating and stripping profiles. Compared to bare copper, the presence of Ag@C can reduce  the  lithium  nucleation  energy  at  room  temperature,  as  evidenced  by  the  reduced  lithium  plating overpotential from -24 mV to -12 mV. This is likely due to improved conductivity and the presence of nano silver. The initial Coulombic efficiency improved from 91.5% for bare copper to 93.7% for Ag-coated copper, confirming a positive effect of silver coating. A detailed study of the function mechanism of silver coating and its effect on long-term lithium cycling at various areal capacities and current densities continues.

External pressure has been reported to significantly influence lithium cycling, primarily due to its impact on Li/SSE interfacial contact and lithium creeping behaviors. The team has investigated the effect of pressure by decoupling fabrication pressure, lithium attaching pressure, and cell operation stack pressure. In addition to

Task  1.5 -Figure  2.  Impact  of  pressure  on  lithium  stripping/plating: (a/b)  Cycling of Li/SSE/Li cells with solid-state electrolyte (SSE) pellets fabricated at different pressures (cell testing is performed at a constant stack pressure of 5 MPa and room temperature, 0.5 hours for each step of plating or stripping at a current 0.5 mAcm -2 ). (c/d) Cycling of Li/SSE/Li cells at different stack pressures (SSE pellets were fabricated at constant pressure of 700 MPa).

pellet  densification,  they  found  that  pellet fabrication  pressure  plays  a  critical  role  in lithium metal cycling, specifically in plating/ stripping. A general observation is that under given cycling conditions, a higher fabrication pressure supports  a longer cycle life.  As shown in Figure 2a-b, if the pellet is fabricated at  a  relatively  low  pressure  like  300 MPa  or lower,  the  Li/SSE/Li  cell  will  easily  short circuit. However, when the fabrication pressure is increased to 700 MPa or higher, the cell can be cycled stably for over 500 hours at 0.5 mAcm -2 without any internal short circuiting. This can be explained by the correlations of lithium growth and pellet porosity.  High  pellet  porosity,  fabricated  at lower  pressure,  may  induce  lithium  filament growth into the pellet, which propagates through  the  pellets  and  leads  to  an  internal short. Decreasing porosity also increases pore tortuosity, both of which slow down the rate of lithium  propagation.  For  pellets  fabricated under  a  specific  pressure,  the  cell  operation pressure  also  plays  a  significant  role  in  cell cycling. Figure 2c-d compares the cycling of Li/SSE/Li cells at different operation pressures. All pellets used for the cell test were fabricated at 700 MPa. If the cell operation pressure is 3 MPa or lower, the cell exhibits a relatively high lithium plating/stripping overpotential, which is attributed to high interfacial contact resistance. Increasing  the  operation  pressures  to  5 MPa  or  10 MPa  significantly  reduces  the  lithium  plating/stripping voltage, indicating that an appropriate cell operation pressure is required to enhance the contact between lithium and  SSE.  A  more  significant  effect  of  cell  operation  pressure  is  observed  on  lithium  cycling.  Contrary  to previous understanding that higher stacking pressure leads to faster lithium dendrite formation and earlier cell failure, they found that low pressures such as those below 3 MPa easily induced cell failure by internal short circuit. This is because, due to insufficient stack pressure, the lithium morphology grown along the Li/SSE interface becomes porous and nonuniform, leading to inhomogeneous lithium deposits during plating or void formation after stripping. On repeated cycling, such inhomogeneous lithium deposits and void formation could lead to increased local current densities, causing dendrite formation and short circuit. This study suggests that for a given SE, in order to improve cell cycle life with a Li-metal anode, optimal pressure ranges should be identified for pellet fabrication, lithium attaching, and cell operation. The approaches of using a lithium stable SE (LPSBI), Ag@C coated copper collector, and optimized pressures have been combined in Li/SSE/Li cells to improve lithium cell cycling at practical conditions. Detailed results on this will be provided in an upcoming publication or report.

## Task 1.6 -Three-Dimensional Printing of All-Solid-State Lithium Batteries (Jianchao Ye, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory)

Objectives. The  project  has  two  primary  objectives: (1) down  select  three-dimensional  (3D)  printing  and post-processing  approaches  for  solid-state electrolyte (SSE) / cathode integration,  and  (2) understand  battery failure mechanisms via ex situ and in situ characterization.

Impact. The adoption of a thin separator layer, thick cathode structure, and metallic lithium anode will lead to electric vehicle batteries with &gt; 350 Wh/kg energy density for increased mileage per charge. The higher ionic conductivity  with  suppression  of  lithium  dendrite  growth  will  allow  high  critical  current  densities  for  fast charging  applications.  The  improved  electrode/electrolyte  contact  will  increase  battery  cycle  life  for long-term service.

Approach. The  technical  approaches  include  advanced  manufacturing  based  on  3D printing  and  related techniques, ex situ / in situ characterizations, and battery testing. Direct-ink writing 3D-printing techniques will be employed to fabricate thin-film SSEs (&lt; 100 ï­ m), gradient SSEs, and 3D interfaces for battery performance evaluation.  Three  approaches,  including  sintering-free,  hybrid,  and  co-sintering,  will  be  investigated.  The knowledge obtained from these approaches is transferable and complementary to each technique.

Out-Year Goals. The long-term vision of the team is to 3D-print all components of the all-solid-state lithium battery (ASSLB) to facilitate the scale-up of ASSLB manufacturing. In this project, the team will tackle the issues emerging from integrating solid electrolyte (SE) with electrodes. The project goal is to demonstrate a successful  3D-printing  approach  to  integrate  SSE  into  electrodes  and  show  reasonable  capacity  retention (that is, &gt; 80%) after 300 cycles at current density â‰¥ 1 mA/cm 2 .

Collaborations. The team will work closely with a computational partner (Task 3.8 led by B. Wood) to better understand battery failure mechanisms and design new battery architectures and chemistries for performance improvement. The team is collaborating with S. Kim and G. Cheng from University of Illinois, Chicago, on composite polymer electrolyte (CPE) development.

## Progress Report

Co-sintering the cathode and electrolyte together has the potential to improve interfacial contact. However, the team has previously observed a stark color change of the LLZTO SE from white to green when co-sintered with an  LiCoO2 (LCO)  cathode  using  conventional  furnace  sintering.  Consequently,  they  conducted  further experiments to determine the cause of this color change and its effect on the structure, mechanical properties, and ionic conductivity of the LLZTO.

LLZTO pellets were first pressed at ~ 3000 psi and sintered at 1100Â°C for 6 hours in argon to produce initial translucent white pellets to serve as the SE material. LCO was then mixed with a small amount of N-methylpyrrolidone to create a slurry and cast on top of the pellets to form a 50-100 Âµm layer of LCO. Tape was used to keep the LCO coating away from the edges so that the coating was only on one surface of the pellet. These LCO/LLZTO bilayer  pellets  were  then  co-sintered  at  900Â°C  for  2  hours  in  argon.  After  co-sintering,  the LLZTO pellets changed color from white to dark green (Figure 1a), suggesting that cobalt had diffused from the LCO throughout the LLZTO pellet during co-sintering. To confirm this hypothesis, these pellets were sent for inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, to measure all elements except for oxygen) and instrumental gas analysis (IGA, to measure the oxygen content). The samples were first prepared by removing the top LCO layer with a razor blade, and then successively polishing both sides of the co-sintered LLZTO pellets with SiC sandpaper (ranging from 240-1200 grit) to ensure the layer was fully removed. The samples were then sonicated in acetone 3 times for 5 minutes each to remove any residual particles and crushed with a mortar and pestle for ICP/IGA analysis. The ICP-OES and IGA results are shown in Figure 1b and confirm the  presence  of  a  very  small  amount  of  cobalt  (0.11 wt%)  in  the  LLZTO  pellet  after  co-sintering, resulting  in  a  composition  of  Li6.3La3Ta0.6Zr1.4Co0.02O11.3.  These  results  suggest  that  in  addition  to  cobalt entering the LLZTO structure, some lithium and oxygen may have been lost during co-sintering.

Task  1.6 -Figure  1.  (a) Pictures of sintered LLZTO pellets coated with a layer of LCO before and after co-sintering at 900Â°C for 2 hours in argon. (b) Inductively coupled plasma -optical emission spectroscopy (all elements except for oxygen)  and  instrumental  gas  analysis  (oxygen)  of  LLZTO  pellets  after  co-sintering  with  LCO.  The  LCO  layer  was removed before analysis.

These  Co-doped  LLZTO pellets  were  also  analyzed  by  X-ray  diffraction  (XRD)  to  identify  any  structural changes that may have taken place as a result of the cobalt diffusion into the LLZTO lattice. The XRD results are shown in Figure 2. The Co-doped LLZTO spectrum is very similar to that of the pristine LLZTO powder, although there are a few small shoulders that appear on several of the peaks. This could be due to the Co-doped LLZTO sample being run in air, while the pristine LLZTO powder was run in an air-free sample holder under argon. They plan to repeat analysis of the Co-doped sample in the same air-free sample holder under argon in the future for a more direct comparison. However, overall, the small level of Co-doping does not seem to have much of an effect on the overall structure of the LLZTO.

Task  1.6 -Figure  2.  X-ray diffraction comparison of pristine LLZTO powder and Co-doped LLZTO pellets (prepared by removing the LCO layer after co-sintering with LCO at 900Â°C for 2 hours in argon) .

Nanoindentation  tests  were  performed  on  the  Co-doped  LLZTO pellets to determine the effect of cobalt diffusion on the mechanical properties.  The  samples  were  prepared  as  described  above  for  the ICP-OES/IGA  and  XRD analyses.  Nanoindentation  tests  reveal  a decrease  of  Young's modulus  and  hardness  with  cobalt  diffusion. Pristine LLZTO pellets show a Young's modulus of 156.5 Â± 5.1 GPa and hardness of 8.81 Â± 0.75 GPa. With cobalt diffusion, the Young's modulus decreases to 139.9 Â± 4.3 GPa and the hardness to 7.31 Â± 0.41 GPa. Nanoindentation load-displacement curves (Figure 3) also show viscoplastic creep behavior changes with cobalt diffusion. The increased creep displacement for a given load holding time (10 seconds) suggests microstructural variation that introduces an  additional  deformation  mechanism  after  cobalt  diffusion.  It  is hypothesized that cobalt accumulation in the LLZTO grain and grain boundaries  (GBs)  may  lead  to  a  higher  degree  of  amorphization, weaken  the  GBs,  and  cause  grain  sliding/rotation  under  load,  but detailed atomic-scale characterization may be necessary to reveal the underlying physics.

Task  1.6 -Figure  3. Nanoindentation loaddisplacement  curves  of  dry  polished  pristine LLZTO and Co-doped LLZTO pellets. Indentation strain rate is 0.05 s -1 . Peak holding time is 10 seconds.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used to determine the effect of Co-doping on the ionic and electronic conductivities of LLZTO. The samples were prepared by polishing according to the same procedure outlined above, then applying gold paste to the two sides of the polished LLZTO pellets and drying them at 150Â°C  for  30 minutes  in  an  Ar-filled  glovebox.  EIS plots (Figure 4a)  were  fit  by  a  simple  (Q1+Q2/R2) equivalent circuit model to obtain the SSE resistance R2. The measured ionic conductivity of pristine LLZTO at room temperature was 0.35 mS/cm. After co-sintering with LCO, the conductivity decreased to 0.21 mS/cm. This  result  implies  that  co-sintering  induced  cobalt  diffusion  is  detrimental  to  the  LLZTO separator.  The electronic conductivity was measured by applying a direct current voltage bias (0.3 V) for 3 hours (Figure 4b). It was found that with cobalt doping, the electronic conductivity also decreased from 2.5 nS/cm to 1.9 nS/cm. The decrease of electronic conductivity may further reduce electron transport in the LLZTO/LCO composite cathode, which could lead to decreased performance.

Task  1.6 -Figure  4.  Electrochemical  impedance  spectroscopy  plots  (a)  and  direct  current  polarization curves  (b) of pristine and Co-doped LLZTO pellets with gold as ion-blocking electrodes.

In summary, co-sintering LLZTO/LCO using conventional furnace sintering leads to a decrease in the ionic conductivity, electronic conductivity, modulus, and hardness of LLZTO. Laser co-sintering may be used to reduce the degree of cobalt diffusion in the future. Other strategies will also be pursued, such as replacing the LLZTO catholyte with materials that can be densified at lower temperatures.

## Task 1.7 -Development of All-Solid-State Battery Using Anti-Perovskite Electrolytes (Zonghai Chen and Tao Li, Argonne National Laboratory)

Objective. The objective of this project is to develop an optimized anti-perovskite electrolyte with a stabilized interface for scalable fabrication of liquid-free solid-state batteries.

Impact. The project will lead to impact on several areas: (1) establishing a structure-property relationship of anti-perovskite electrolytes, (2) understanding and quantifying the interaction between the electrolytes and the environment, (3) understanding and mitigating the failure of all-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) at the solid-solid interface (SSI), and (4) developing a scalable process for fabrication of ASSBs.

Approach. The project  approach  is multifold:  (1) chemistry  design :  multiple  doping  at  anion  sites  will  be pursued to  improve  structural  stability,  ionic  conductivity,  and  environmental  compatibility;  (2) interfacial design :  surface  coating  will  be  deployed  to  improve the chemical and mechanical stability of  the SSI; and (3) process development :  a  scalable  fabrication  process  based  on  melt-infiltration  or  dry  lamination  will  be developed for fabrication of ASSBs.

Out-Year Goals. The project has the following out-year goals:

- Developing high-performance anti-perovskite electrolytes.
- Accessing the air stability and proton mobility of anti-perovskite electrolytes.
- Stabilizing the SSI through interfacial engineering.
- Prototyping liquid-free cells using anti-perovskite electrolytes.

Collaborations. This  project  collaborates  with  Y. Z.  Liu  and  W. Q.  Xu  (Argonne  National  Laboratory), X. H. Xiao (Brookhaven National Laboratory), L. Ma (University of North Carolina at Charlotte), H. Meng (University of Arkansas), and G. Yang (Oak Ridge National Laboratory, ORNL).

## Milestones

1. Benchmarking of Li/electrolyte interface. (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Microscopic study of lithium plating behavior. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Development of artificial Li/electrolyte interface. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Validation of impact of artificial Li/electrolyte interface. (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

The scalable process to fabricate thin  electrolyte film, below 100 microns, is crucial to enhance the energy density of ASSBs. By collaborating with the ORNL team, a wet casting process was used to fabricate thin and free-standing electrolyte film, as shown in Figure 1a. The scanning electron microscopy image (Figure 1b) of the free-standing film shows that the film is quite porous, and the morphology of the electrolyte powder is maintained.  The  energy  dispersive  spectroscopy  images  of  the  electrolyte  film  (Figure 1c-g)  show  a homogeneous distribution of electrolyte elements, showing no clear segregation of elements or phase separation after the wet-casting process.

Task  1.7 -Figure  1.  (a)  Digital  image  and  (b)  scanning  electron  microscopy  image  of  a  wet-cast,  free-standing  electrolyte  film comprising  Li2HOCl0.75Br0.25.  (c-g)  Energy  dispersive  spectroscopy  image  of  the  electrolyte  film  showing  homogeneous  distribution of elements.

To reduce the porosity of the electrolyte film, the team performed cold press, warm press, and thermal annealing to  reduce  grain  boundary  resistance.  Figure 2  shows  a  typical  image  of  the  electrolyte  film  after  thermal annealing at 250Â°C. A clear leafy structure was formed after the thermal annealing. This type of leafy structure can also be found in samples that experienced both cold press and hot press, but with a smaller domain size. Therefore,  the  transport  properties  of  the  electrolyte  film  were  also  investigated  under  different  stacking pressures.  It  was  found  that  the  Li-ion  conductivity  of  the  wet-cast  and  cold-pressed  electrolyte  film  is comparable with the pellets prepared using a warm-press approach. The electric resistance of the electrolyte film was also conducted by stacking the electrolyte film between two stainless-steel blocking electrodes, and the leakage current was collected by applying 1 V bias on the blocking electrodes. Figure 3a shows that the leakage current surprisingly decreases with the stacking pressure. Figure 3b shows that the leakage current

increases with the measuring temperature. At a temperature as high as 90Â°C, the steady leakage current is about 0.3 ï­ A/cm 2 , which is very low compared to the normal operation rate of a lithium cell (~ 1 mA/cm 2 ). They can at  least  conclude  that  the  stacking  pressure  has  no  adverse  effect  on  the  transport  properties  of  the anti-perovskite electrolyte.

## Task 1.8 -Lithium Halide-Based Superionic Solid Electrolytes and High-Voltage Cathode Interface (Robert Sacci, Oak Ridge National Laboratory [Jagjit Nanda, SLAC])

Objective. The project  aims  to  develop  a  low-temperature  solution-based  synthesis  strategy  for  high ionic conducting  halide-based  solid  electrolyte  (SE)  and  to  enable  approaches  to  develop  a  scalable  process  for integrating  halide-based  SE  within  a  porous  high-voltage  Li-ion  cathode  matrix.  Years 1 and 2  aim  at developing  low-cost,  solution-based  synthesis  routes  to  produce  a  halide  class  of  superionic  conductor belonging to Li3MX6 (where M = Sc, Y, La, Er, In, and X = Cl, Br, I) along with enabling electrochemical and structural characterization. Parallel efforts in years 2 and 3 target developing synthesis and processing methods where the high-voltage stable halide-based SEs can be readily infiltrated within the porous cathode structures such as LiNi0.6MN0.2Co0.2O2 (NMC-622), high-voltage Mn-Ni spinel (LiMn1.5Ni0.5O4), and recent fluorinated Mn-rich  disordered  rock  salt  cathodes.  Years 3 and 4  focus  on  designing  and  fabricating  thin  halide SE separators  with  a  thickness  of  50 Âµm  or  lower  and  optimizing  the  cathode  microstructure.  Finally, years 4 and  5  will target  developing  approaches  for  anode-free  lithium  plating  and  stripping  on  alloyed  or engineered copper current collectors at relatively higher current densities aimed at improving the volumetric energy density of solid-state batteries (SSBs) with a high loading cathode and thin halide SE separator.

Impact. The proposed tasks and metrics aim at addressing the long-term Vehicle Technologies Office goal for developing SSBs at ambient temperature with energy density in the range of 500 Wh/Kg and 1000 Wh/L for electric  drive  vehicles.  Advances  in  scalable  processing  of  superionic SEs,  stabilizing  electrode-electrolyte interfaces,  and  promoting  long  cycle  life  are  all  needed  to  meet  the  energy  density  and  cost  targets  for next-generation batteries for electric vehicles.

Approach. The project employs a multifaceted approach: (1) conduct solution-based synthesis of the metal halide superionic conductor as the platform to enable robust cathode-electrolyte interface processing for SSBs, (2) infiltrate pore structures using solution-based processing that deposits high-conductivity SEs within cathode pores, and (3) facilitate lithium transport and improve stability using cation doping (divalent to introduce lithium vacancies, and lanthanum to prevent indium redox).

Out-Year Goals. Demonstrate single-layer, pouch-cell SSBs containing a thin halide SE separator coupled with  high-voltage cathodes  with  70% capacity  retention  over  300 cycles  at  2 mA/cm 2 in  an  anode-free SSB configuration that can attain 1000 Wh/L in prototype cells.

Collaborations. Y. Yao  and  team  at  University of Houston  are  funded  collaborators  for  halide-based SSB fabrication, testing, and interfacial studies. The project also involves unfunded collaboration with J. Nanda at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory for X-ray absorption spectroscopy and synchrotron X-ray diffraction of SEs.

## Progress Report

This  quarter,  the  team  demonstrated  over  100  cycles  of  Li3YCl6 (LYC) - NMC  composite  cathode.  They assembled  a  cell  using  LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1 (NMC-811)  single  crystals  mixed  with  LYC  synthesized  by mechanochemical milling as the catholyte and Li-P-S-Cl (LPSC) to serve as the anolyte with lithium metal. Cathode  loading  was  50 wt%,  and  the  pressure  was  14 MPa.  This  is  significantly  lower  pressure  than  the 49 MPa previously reported for this project. The cycling parameters were three formation cycles at 0.1 mA cm -2 followed by repeated cycles at 0.33 mA cm -2 . The average particle size for the LYC was 500 nm.

Task  1.8 -Figure  1.  (a/b) Representative charge and discharge curve of NMC-LYC composite | LYC | LPSC | Li full cell cycling at 4.4 V charge limit. (c) Capacity and Coulombic efficiency as a function of cycle number of the same full cell along with an LPSC-only full cell for comparison.

Figure 1 shows that the cell achieved an initial capacity of 231 mAh/g cathode, which is an 18% improvement over typical LPSC-based cells. After 100 cycles, cell capacity remains above 185 mAh/g. The LPSC cell dies after  60  cycles,  showing  massive  capacity  loss.  Another  notable  difference  is  the  overpotential  (difference between  the  cell  potential  at  50% state of charge/discharge).  Taking  the  30 th cycle  as  representative,  the overpotential  for  the  LPSC  cell  was  0.45 V,  whereas  the  bilayer  cell  shows  0.06 V.  This suggests  that  the capacity loss for the LPSC cell is due to extensive cathode-electrolyte interphase formation that increases the resistance of the cell. Therefore, the LYC catholyte shows a chemically stable interface. That said, the cell may continue to suffer from mechanically induced cracking, which will be explored next quarter.
