## Task 1.9 -Polyester-Based Block Copolymer Electrolytes for Lithium-Metal Batteries (Nitash Balsara, University of California, Berkeley)

Objective. The project objective is to design and synthesize polyester-based block copolymer electrolytes that can  enable  full-cell  cycling  at  1 mA/cm 2 or  greater  for  300 cycles.  The  cell  comprises  Li-metal anode, 4.5 V Ni-Mn-Co (NMC) cathode, and thin separators (20-50 Âµm) cast from the block copolymer.

Impact. Polymer electrolytes offer increased stability in lithium batteries in comparison to more widely used liquid electrolytes. Block copolymer-based electrolytes containing both soft, ion-conducting domains and rigid, nonconducting domains offer the opportunity to tune both mechanical and electrical properties separately. Most block copolymer electrolytes studied thus far comprise poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) as the conducting domain. The  team  hopes  to  develop  polyester-based electrolytes  that  exhibit  much  higher  transport  properties  and limiting currents than PEO-based electrolytes. An all-solid full cell with this new block copolymer electrolyte, a Li-metal anode, and an NMC cathode will have much higher energy density than current Li-ion technology.

Approach. The  team  will  begin  by  synthesizing  several  series  of  polyester  homopolymers  and  fully characterizing their blends with lithium salts as polymer electrolytes in Li-Li symmetric cells. Next, they will make block copolymer electrolytes based on the most promising candidate and measure the electrochemical and mechanical properties thoroughly. Finally, they will assemble full cells with the optimum block copolymer electrolytes together with lithium metal and a 4.5 V NMC cathode.

Out-Year Goals. In the first year, the team will establish an efficient synthesis and characterization platform for polyester electrolytes. Several polyesters will be synthesized, and electrolytes will be made by blending each polymer with lithium salt. Transport properties (such as conductivity and current fraction) and limiting current of resulting electrolytes will be measured in Li-Li symmetric cells. The highest performing polymer electrolyte will be used as the conducting phase in the block copolymer design in the second year.

Collaborations. There are no active collaborations this quarter.

## Milestones

1. Limiting current: measure limiting current of at least one polyester electrolyte. (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Molecular weight: explore the effect of molecular weight of polyester electrolytes on Li-ion transport. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Block copolymer synthesis: try at least two approaches for synthesizing polystyrene-polyester-polystyrene (PS-PES-PS) block copolymers. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Physical  properties:  study  physical  properties  of  at  least  one  PS-PES-PS  block  copolymer,  including morphology, mechanical properties, and conductivity. (Q4, FY 2023; the team has taken an alternative path and completed the mechanical and electrical characterization of a crosslinked PES solid.)

## Progress Report

The main project goal was to make an all-solid battery with polymer electrolytes and a Li-metal anode. When the team wrote the project proposal, they had identified PES as a promising polymer electrolyte, and proposed to solidify this polymer by attaching the chain to a PS block. They made significant efforts over the past six months to synthesize the block copolymer; however, they were only able to synthesize low molecular weight samples with poor mechanical properties. They abandoned that approach and decided to pursue crosslinking PES to create the polymeric solid.

Task  1.9 -Figure  1.  Final reaction product obtained after reaction of PES with TTI in 1-methyl 2-pyrollidine at 120Â°C.

Figure 1 shows the final reaction product of the crosslinked PES polymer. Using triphenylmethane triisocyanate (TTI) as their crosslinking agent, the team was able to preliminarily synthesize several freestanding films of PES electrolyte with varying amounts of crosslinking ratios.

Task  1.9 -Figure  2.  Storage modulus ( G' ) and loss modulus ( G' ) as a function of frequency for PES (26 kg mol -1 )/ 10 wt% TTI, PEO (20 kg mol -1 ), and PEO (50 kg mol -1 ) at 90Â°C. The measurements were taken in the absence of salt. PES/TTI is shown in blue circles, PEO-20 is shown in open red triangles, and PEO-50 is shown in yellow triangles.

Figure 2a-b shows the storage modulus ( G' ) and loss modulus ( G' ) of PEO with different molecular weights and PES/10 wt% TTI at 90Â°C. G' for the PES polymer is orders of magnitude larger than for the PEO polymers with similar molecular weights. The G' values are greater than the G' for PES across the frequency range, which  indicates  more  solid-like  behavior.  The  inverse  relationship  is  observed  for  both  PEO polymers, indicating more liquid-like behavior. This shows that crosslinking is a promising route for achieving higher mechanical stability without the use of a block copolymer.

Task  1.9 -Figure  3.  Ionic conductivity ( Îº ), current fraction, ( Ï +), and restricted diffusion coefficient (D) of PES electrolyte as a function of TTI weight percent at 90Â°C. The salt concentration (r = [Li+]/[O]) was fixed to 0.08. Two data points at each weight percent represent reproducibility of the data.

Next, the team characterized the electrochemical properties of PES electrolytes with salt. The salt concentration, r = [Li + ]/[O], was fixed relative to the amount of PES polymer. Figure 3a-c shows the ionic conductivity, current fraction, and restricted diffusion coefficient as a function of TTI wt% measured using Li-Li symmetric cells. At small TTI wt%, the ionic conductivity does not change drastically; however, on significant addition of TTI, there is a drop in conductivity. While there is a slight decrease in current fraction on crosslinking, the change is  within  error  of  the  homopolymer  PES  electrolyte.  The  restricted  diffusion  coefficient  shows  a  steady reduction in magnitude with increasing TTI content, as expected with chemical crosslinked systems. In the future, they plan on implementing a purification process of the crosslinked PES electrolytes through solvent washing to remove unreacted monomer and TTI and help improve their stability toward lithium metal. They expect this will aid in reducing error in their electrochemical measurements.

## Task 1.10 -Advanced Polymer Materials for Batteries (Zhenan Bao and Yi Cui, Stanford University)

Objective. This  project  will  develop  new  polymer  materials  for  batteries.  The  team  will  develop  polymer coatings with specific mechanical properties that can accommodate the volume expansion and contraction of the Li-metal anode associated with deposition and stripping (charging and discharging).

Impact. The  cycling  stability  and  Coulombic  efficiency  (CE)  of  Li-metal  electrodes  will  be  increased  by implementation of a polymer-based protective layer that functions as an artificial solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) with desired properties. The improved performance will enable further development toward practical utilization of Li-metal anodes with higher cycling efficiency and less susceptibility to dendrite-based failure.

Approach. The project uses soft polymer coatings with dynamic crosslinking to give the resulting polymers liquid-like rheological properties and stretchable, self-healing properties. In previous work, the team has shown that such coatings resulted in uniform deposition/stripping of lithium metal and improved cycling stability of Li-metal electrodes.  To  understand  the  design  rules  for  effective  polymer  coatings,  they  chose  a  few representative polymers to systematically understand structure property relationships. Here, they investigate the correlation between surface energy of the polymer and exchange current for lithium deposition.

Out-Year Goals. Work will progress toward the correlation between dielectric constant and exchange current. These findings will enable further understanding and development of various polymer coatings for protecting Li-metal anodes.

Collaborations. The team is collaborating with J. Qin at Stanford University.

## Milestones

1. Gain fundamental understanding of an existing polymer design. Characterize the chemical composition of the coated interface with lithium metal in different electrolytes. (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Probe the lithium deposition mechanism under the polymer coating: build optical cells and conduct in situ microscopic imaging of coated copper electrode during lithium deposition. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Characterize  coating  performance  in  stringent  cycling  conditions:  high-capacity  cycling  (5 mAh cm -2 cathode loading) in the lean electrolyte condition (~ 3 g Ah -1 ). (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Coat the polymer on thin lithium anode (50 Âµm) and perform stable long-term cycling (â‰¥ 400 cycles) with novel electrolytes. The goal is to examine coating performance when pairing with high performing, instead of standardized, electrolyte. (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

With  the  performance  SP 2 perF  (Salt-Philic  Solvent-Phobic  polymer  coating  with  perfluorinated  side  chains) coating  on  the  stabilization  of  Li-metal  anode  in  standard  electrolytes  established  and  with  the  mechanism studied  in  previous  quarters,  the  team  further  examined  coating  performance  in  combination  with  recently developed, high-performing electrolytes to see if the strength of both strategies can synergistically improve the cycle life of Li-metal batteries.

When paired with 1 M lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiFSI) in fluorinated 1,4-dimethoxybutane (FDMB) electrolytes, the team found the salt-philicity and solvent-phobicity of SP 2 perF coating followed the same trend as  the  standard  electrolytes  (carbonates  and  1,2-dimethoxyethane / 1,3-dioxolane),  which  led  to  further improved CE (short-term 10-cycle 0.5 mA cm -1 , 1 mAh cm -1 cycling in Li||Cu half cells) from an already high value of 99.4% to 99.5% (Figure 1a). The improvement is likely linked to the improved SEI composition, where beneficial salt-derived components were found more dominant on coated anodes compared to bare anodes, characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy studies.

The  anode  stabilization  was  also  observed  by  the  impedance  evolution  of  coated  Li||Li symmetric  cells (Figure 1b/c). For the first 100 hours of resting in an open circuit, SP 2 perF reduced the impedance increase from 104% to 33% in carbonate electrolyte, and from 153% to 42% in FDMB electrolyte compared to bare electrodes, respectively.  This  demonstrates  the  capability  of SP 2 perF  to  further  suppress  electrolyte  degradation  even  in high-performance fluorinated ether electrolytes. This also suggests the potential to synergistically combine the molecular design strategy in liquid electrolytes and selective transport strategy in polymer coating to achieve long cycle life in Li-metal batteries.

Task  1.10 -Figure  1.  Electrochemical  characterization  of SP 2 perF with  different  electrolytes:  (a)  Coulombic  efficiency  measured  on coated copper in Li||Cu cells with 40 ÂµL of ether (1 M LiTFSI DOL/DME 1 wt% LiNO3), carbonate (1 M LiPF6 EC/DEC 10% FEC), or FDMB (1 M LiFSI FDMB) electrolyte. (b) Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy measurement overtime with coated Li||Li symmetric cell in electrolytes. (c) Calculated impedance increase (%) over 100 hours of resting procedure in an open circuit.

To  confirm  this,  the  team  tested  Li||NMC  (NMC,  lithium  nickel  manganese  cobalt  oxide;  in  this  work, Ni:Mn:Co = 8:1:1) full cells with 1 M LiFSI FDMB electrolytes with 50 Âµm SP 2 perF-coated lithium anodes. They cycled Li||NMC full cells at different C-rates (2.5 mAh cm -2 areal capacity) and found reasonable capacity (&gt; 200 mAh g -1 ) can be achieved at C/10 and C/3 for FDMB electrolytes (Figure 2a). With C/5 charging and C/3  discharging  and  2.5  mAh  cm -2 NMC  positive  electrodes  [electrolyte/cathode  ratio  (E/C),  ~ 16 g Ah -1 , 2.8-4.4 V), a cycle life of ~ 400 (till 80% capacity retention) was reached with 50 Âµm SP 2 perF-coated lithium anodes (Figure 2b), more than doubling the cycle life of bare electrodes. The charging voltage profile of the 100 th cycle  for  FDMB  electrolyte  was  shown  in  Figure  2c,  with  the  coated  sample  showing  a  higher overpotential, matching the team's observation of slightly higher overpotential in Li||Li symmetric cells, likely due to the increased mass transport hindrance as a result of the salt-over-solvent selectivity of the coating. However, the benefit of this selectivity is significant. At around the 170 th cycle, the Li||NMC full cell with bare electrode started to show unstable CE during cycling, which corresponded with the sudden drop of capacity and the subsequent cell failure (Figure 2b). This process, however, was absent in the SP 2 perF-coated lithium anodes up to &gt; 450 cycles, which significantly slowed down the capacity fading, and thus increased the cycle life over

prolonged cycling tests. The phenomenon followed the same trend as when SP 2 perF-coated lithium anodes were paired with carbonate [1 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC) / diethyl carbonate (DEC) with 10 wt% EC, DEC, fluoroethylene carbonate] electrolytes in the same cell configuration, demonstrating that the selective transport strategy is universal among different formulations of electrolytes. They further tested Li||NMC cell with a higher (5 mAh cm -2 ) areal capacity positive electrode in the 1 M LiFSI FDMB electrolyte to probe the performance of the coated cells. They found an increase (close to two-fold) in the cell cycle life (Figure 2d).

Task  1.10 -Figure  2.  Cycling  of  SP 2 perF-coated  lithium  in  Li||NMC  cells  with  1  M  LiFSI  FDMB  electrolyte:  (a)  rate capabilities, (b)  long-term cycling with 2.5 mAh cm -2  positive electrodes, (c) charging voltage curve at 100 th  cycle at C/5 charging C-rate, (d) long-term cycling with 5 mAh cm -2  electrodes, and (e) comparison of cycle life (80% capacity retention) plotted against excess lithium amount of the SP 2 perF coating with other coatings or electrolyte strategies. The x axis locations of 4, 5, 7, 11, and 12 are 10 mAh cm -2 , and they are adjusted slightly to dodge.

With the combined evidence above and reported in previous quarters, the team's SP 2 perF  polymer design is applicable to various electrolyte chemistry and configurations, and it is a marked improvement in cell cycle life versus excess lithium amount when compared with other state-of-the-art strategies (Figure 2e). The salt-philic and solvent-phobic interfacial design promoted the formation of beneficial salt-derived SEI and improved the cycling performance. Through physical interactions, they tuned the chemical reaction at the electrode-electrolyte  interface.  They  confirm  the  achievement  of  the  fourth  quarter  milestone.  They  also envision that the SP 2 design concept can be extended to other polymer chemistries and potentially pair with other emerging electrolytes.

## Task 1.11 -Synthesis of Composite Electrolytes with Integrated Interface Design (Sanja Tepavcevic, Argonne National Laboratory)

Objective. This  project  aims  to develop  well-controlled,  scalable  Li7La3Zr2O12  (LLZO)  nanofiber  and composite polymer electrolyte (CPE) synthesis processes that will address the manufacturing challenges of current solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) and demonstrate the fabrication of large-area, thin CPE membranes with outstanding electro-chemomechanical properties.

Impact. The  outcome  of  this  proposal  will  be  a  transformative  manufacturing  solution  that  can  create large-area, mechanically and (electro)chemically stable SSEs (0 V to 4.5 V versus Li/Li + ) with Li + conductivity of â‰¥ 10 -3 S/cm at room temperature enabling â‰¥ 1C charging rates.

Approach. To  commercialize  all-solid-state  Li-ion  battery  technology,  further  advances  will  require  the application  of  knowledge,  concepts,  and  tools  from  several  fields  including  materials  science,  physics, engineering,  theory,  and  interfacial  electrochemistry.  The  team's  research  philosophy  is  to  establish  a synthesis-material  characterization-computation  cycle  that  advances  synthesis,  chemistry,  microstructure, interfaces, and transport in CPEs by a coordinated, interdisciplinary approach. The team's diverse expertise will allow them to understand, create, and rapidly scale up composite electrolytes to meet ambitious conductivity, energy, and power density targets.

Out-Year Goals. The innovative design and synthesis of integrated SSE interfaces include the following goals: (1)  achieve  high  room-temperature  conductivity  by  optimizing  composite  microstructures,  synthetically modifying the LLZO-polymer interface, and reducing CPE membrane thicknesses down to 20 Âµm; (2) create a stable and effective interface between the CPE and metallic lithium that yields low charge transfer resistance and enables high critical current density (&gt; 3 mA/cm 2 ); and (3) modify the CPE-cathode interface to enable the use of different cathodes (that is, lithium iron phosphate, LiCoO2, and Ni-Mn-Co) and achieve high energy and power density in batteries.

Collaborations. Computational  researchers  will  further  help  the  team  to  understand  and  design  better all-solid-state  batteries.  They  will  work  closely  with  L. A. Curtiss,  P. Barai,  K. Chavan,  and  V.  Srinivasan (Argonne National Laboratory) to understand the molecular and mesoscopic characteristics and performance of the team's CPEs.

## Milestones

1. Employ experimental and computational modeling to investigate the combined impact of conductivity and mechanical  properties  of  the  solid-electrolyte  interphase  layer  in  stabilizing  lithium  deposition.  (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Optimize nanofiber and composite electrolytes  chemistry  and  processability  for  ambient  stability.  (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Use experimental and computational methods at the continuum level to understand ion transport mechanism through LLZO / poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) composites and determine optimal chemistries for LLZO-PEO interfacing. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Optimize LLZO processing and investigate with computational modeling how to achieve good percolation, improve conduction pathways, and reach CPE conductivity of 5 Ã— 10 -4 S/cm  at  room  temperature. (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

In previous milestones, the team successfully modified the surface of LLZO nanoparticles and nanofibers with functional silane chemistries. This simultaneously added surface moieties that increase Li + transference number through the interaction with the polymer matrix and protect the LLZO surface from continual Li2CO3 formation. This quarter, they confirmed the high intrinsic conductivity of their LLZO nanofibers, demonstrated crosslinked composite membranes with functionalized LLZO nanofillers, and modeled ionic transport in composites. These efforts  led  to  perspectives  on  Li + percolation  through  the  connected  ceramic  fiber  scaffolds  within  the electrolytes, which will be their next focus.

Since ionic conductivity in CPEs mainly relies on the LLZO nanofiller conductors, it is necessary to verify conductivity of their nanofibers. Previously, this determination was challenging because of the low density of the cold pressed nanofiber pellets. This technical difficulty has been solved by sintering the LLZO nanofiber pellet at elevated temperatures above 1000Â°C in collaboration with Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. Recently, an ionic conductivity of 3 Ã— 10 -4 S/cm was measured for the Al-doped LLZO nanofiber pellet that was densified into 80% density (Figure 1a/ b). The Arrhenius activation energy for Li + transport was consistent across two different nanofiber syntheses and pellet densification tests, with an Ea ~ 0.39 eV (Figure 1c). This bulk conductivity and activation energy are close to those of bulk Al-doped LLZO pellets with micron-sized grains  (typically  2-5  Ã— 10 -4 S/cm  and  0.34-0.38  eV,  respectively)  processed  at  higher  temperatures, demonstrating the advantage of their low-temperature cubic LLZO nanofiber synthesis. There was an order of magnitude loss in conductivity of the nanofiber pellets over time due to air exposure of the high-surface area LLZO nanofibers,  leading  to  proton  exchange  and  carbonate  formation  (compare  Figure 1b  and  Figure 1c conductivities). This highlights the importance of their surface-protective silane treatment of LLZO nanofillers.

Task  1.11 -Figure  1.  (a)  Scanning electron micrograph of the cross-section of the 83% dense pellet made with Al-doped LLZO nanofibers. (b) Impedance spectrum of the pellet (photo inset) with sputtered gold blocking electrodes. (c) Arrhenius plots of two different densified Al-doped LLZO nanofiber pellets.

They  next  sought  to  incorporate their surface  modification  of  LLZO  nanofillers  into  a  crosslinked PEO - lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) composite membrane. To expedite the synthesis and  testing  process,  they  used  commercial  Al-doped  LLZO  nanoparticles  (NPs),  which  have  similar conductivity to their nanofibers. Treating the LLZO NPs with APTES, a silane with a primary amine end-group, allows initiation of PEO crosslinking from the particle surface. Ethylene oxide oligomers of trimethylolpropane ethoxylate triacrylate 912 (T) and Jeffamine ED-2003 (J) were mixed with LiTFSI, PEO (Mw ~ 600 kDa), and APTES-treated LLZO NPs, and then casted by slot-die coating, followed with a curing step at 80Â°C for up to 24 hours. The aza-Michael addition reaction between acrylates and amines led to a highly crosslinked structure (xTJ, Figure 2a) that is mechanically stronger than the standard PEO-LiTFSI. The ionic conductivity of these crosslinked composites was tested and compared to non-crosslinked electrolytes using PEO alone (Figure 2b/c). An order of magnitude improvement in the room-temperature conductivity (~ 2 Ã— 10 -5 S/cm) was observed for the crosslinked electrolytes regardless of LLZO content (~ 2 Ã— 10 -6 S/cm). The apparent activation energy is also lower after crosslinking. They attribute these improvements to the lack of PEO chain crystallization in xTJ,

which  can  only  be  achieved  in  normal  PEO  by  adding  plasticizing  additives  or  increasing  operating temperatures.  However,  adding  pristine  or  functionalized  LLZO  to  the  crosslinked  electrolyte  does  not appreciably increase conductivity, especially at 25Â°C (Figure 2b). This disproves their hypothesis that covalent linking  of  the  polymer  matrix  to  the  ceramic  LLZO  fillers  would  activate  their  interface  and  increase Li + conductivity by facilitating Li + transport between the polymer and ceramic phases.

Task  1.11 -Figure 2. (a)  Schematic of crosslinked xTJ composite membrane chemistry, where PEO oligomers with acrylate end-groups (T) covalently bond to the amines on APTES@LLZO and the end-groups of other PEO oligomers (J). (b) Arrhenius plots  of  this  crosslinked  membrane  with  no  LLZO  (xTJ-LiTFSI)  and  with  10  wt%  and  50  wt%  APTES@LLZO  nanoparticles. (c)  Arrhenius plots of linear PEO (600 kDa) and LiTFSI with 0%, 10%, and 50 wt% APTES@LLZO nanoparticles to compare the effects of crosslinking.

Computational  modeling  has  shed  some  light  on  this  observation.  The  team  modeled  their  composite electrolytes with two Li + -conductive phases (PEO and LLZO) and two interphases, one conductive and one resistive  (Figure 3a).  This two interphase layer model was able to capture the change in experimental ionic conductivity  with  variable  LLZO  content  (Figure 3b).  The  conductive  interphase  is  attributed  to  the LLZO nanofiller's disruption of PEO crystallization, essentially acting as a plasticizer. The resistive interphase is attributed to the adsorption of PEO on LLZO and the limited segmental motion of the polymer chains when near the LLZO surface. At small LLZO contents (&lt; 20 wt%), the plasticizing effect improves conductivity by removing crystallinity in the PEO matrix. At higher LLZO contents, the volume fraction of resistive interphases increases significantly, which hinders ion transport through the bulk of the composite and lowers conductivity, sometimes even below that of normal PEO-LiTFSI. Their current estimation is that the resistive interphase limits conductivity by an order of magnitude more than the conductive interphase aids conductivity (Figure 3b) leading to a net loss with high LLZO fractions.

These revelations led to their new design of composite structures where Li + percolation is  achieved among conductive  LLZO  nanofibers  alone,  without  the  hindrance  of  PEO.  This  requires  direct  contact  among LLZO crystals, which are free of surface contaminants (Li2CO3, LiOH, and PEO) and grain-to-grain resistance. They are developing LLZO scaffolds made of highly interconnected, sintered nanofibers. Figure 3c shows the transformation of typically prepared LLZO nanofibers (annealed at 750Â°C) into well connected flakes through modified thermal treatment conditions, which utilized small heating rates and higher annealing temperatures (for example, up to 950Â°C). The average fiber diameter more than doubles, and the inter-fiber contact is greatly increased as fibers are sintered together instead of just physically contacting. Importantly, they can achieve this transformation at temperatures that are still below those used for regular powder sintering of LLZO (usually ~ 1100Â°C). The next step is to infiltrate polymers into the ceramic scaffolds to generate freestanding membranes with good electrode contact for cell testing.

The model uses multiple  interphases  in  the  composite  that  enhance  or  disrupt  Li +   transport.  (b)  Fit  of  experimental  data  with  unmodified LLZO  nanoparticles in PEO-LiTFSI to the model, showing that the improvement in PEO conductivity from small LLZO contents is outweighed by the more resistive interphases at higher LLZO contents. ## Task 1.12 -Polymer Electrolytes for Stable, Low-Impedance, Solid-State Battery Interfaces (X. Chelsea Chen, Oak Ridge National Laboratory)

Objective. The overall project objective is to develop stable polymer/cathode and polymer/anode interfaces with low interfacial impedance for integration of a thin solid composite electrolyte into a battery, to achieve chemical stability at the electrodes, high energy density (500 Wh/kg), high rate (1 mA/cm 2 ), and long cycle life (80% capacity retention for 300 cycles), demonstrated in pouch cells.

Impact. Achieving stable, low-impedance interfaces at both the cathode and anode sides is critical to achieve high energy density with excellent safety, lifetime, and cycling efficiency. This project will identify key design strategies needed to prepare a polymer electrolyte (PE) to achieve stable, low-impedance polymer/cathode and polymer/Li interfaces and to develop processing procedures to integrate a thin composite electrolyte into a solid-state battery. Success will enable U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) technical targets: energy density of 500 Wh/kg with 80% capacity retention for at least 300 cycles.

Approach. The team's main design principle is to use an oxide ceramic as the main ion transporting phase in the electrolyte and a fluorinated polyether-based PE to form optimized interfaces as well as to provide flexibility to the electrolyte membrane. Compared with inorganic electrolytes, PEs are soft and flexible and capable of maintaining good contact at interfaces. However, several technical barriers remain. On the Li-metal side, the interface  between  PEs  and  thin-Li  and  Li-free  anodes  is  still  at  an  early  stage  of  investigation.  Interface optimization using thin-Li and Li-free designs is crucial to reaching the DOE 500 Wh/kg target. On the cathode side, studies on the polymer/cathode interface are scarce. The interface resistance between polymer (catholyte) and cathode active material is not well understood. In addition, with a target voltage stability of 0-4.5 V versus Li/Li + , a polymer with oxidative stability up to 4.5 V is needed. Fluorinated polyethers have the potential to form  stable  and  low  impedance  interfaces  at  both  the  cathode  side  and  the  anode  side.  By  systematically examining  the  effects  of  fluorine  content,  polymer  chain  length  and  structure,  and  plasticization  on  the interfacial  resistance  with the  cathode and the anode, a balance between the desolvation kinetics of Li + and diffusion rate will be achieved to optimize the interface ion transport. A fundamental understanding of the origin of  interfacial  impedance  with  the  cathode  as  well  as  Li-metal  anode  will  be  developed  alongside  the optimization  process  to  generate  design  rules  for  polymers  with  optimized  interfaces.  The  team  will  also develop a processing procedure to integrate a thin composite electrolyte that was previously developed into a full cell. The composite electrolyte features an interconnected ceramic structure with a thickness of 20 Âµm. It will  be  backfilled  with  the  newly  developed  fluorinated  PEs.  The  mechanical  properties  of  the  composite electrolytes will be optimized to accommodate roll-to-roll processing.

Out-Year Goals. In  the  second  and  third  year  of  this  project,  the  team  will  focus  on  optimizing  the cathode/polymer as well as the Li-anode/polymer interface with maximized stability and minimized interfacial impedance. A fundamental understanding of parameters that determine the interfacial impedance and strategies to minimize the interfacial impedance will be developed. The fourth and fifth year of the project will be focused on integration of a thin composite electrolyte into a full cell to achieve high energy density, high rate, and long cycle  life,  as  stated  in  the  overall  project  objectives.  Processing  techniques  and  procedures  for  electrolyte integration will be investigated to achieve this goal.

Collaborations. Work  is  being  conducted  by  B. Armstrong,  S. Kalnaus,  R. Sahore,  K. Owensby,  J. Ock, A. Ullman, and X. C. Chen.

2. Develop  processing  protocol  to  form  interconnected  composite  electrolyte  with  SIC polymer.  (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

In  a  previous  work, [1] the  team  examined  lithium  morphology  evolution  during  cycling  in  full  cells  made with  a  semi-solid-state  gel  composite  electrolyte  consisting  of  crosslinked poly(ethylene oxide) electrolyte (xPEO) - lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI), lithium aluminum titanium phosphate ceramic particles, and tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether plasticizer. The results show that severe surface pitting occurs as early as the second stripping cycle. Pit formation and continuous dissolution during the stripping process are the main cause of the lithium surface roughening and dendrite growth mechanism in this gel composite electrolyte.

This quarter, the team's goal was to understand lithium stripping/plating morphology, dendrite growth, and cell failure mechanisms in dry solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) full cells. To do this, they fabricated full cells made with  dry PE,  xPEO-LiTFSI,  similar  to  that  in  the  gel  composite  electrolyte  but  without  ceramic  fillers  or plasticizers.  The  cathode  is  a  solid-state  LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2  (NMC-622)  cathode  with  linear  PEO-LiTFSI electrolyte as the binder. The areal loadings are from 4.6 mg/cm 2 to 6.0 mg/cm 2 (two batches). Two types of lithium anodes were used: a lithium chip with 600-Âµm thickness from MTI corp., and a lithium foil that is 40-Âµm thick on a copper substrate from MSE Supplies. The cell configurations are shown in Figure 1a. The

team refers to these two configurations as the lithium chip cells and lithium foil cells, respectively. In the lithium foil cells, an additional stainless-steel spacer with thickness of 500 Âµm was added to make the pressure within the coin cell consistent with that made with the thicker lithium chip.

In this work, 12 cells were assembled for long-term cycling assessment. The cells were first conditioned at 70Â°C for  48 hours,  followed  by  cycling  at  70Â°C  between  2.8 V  and  4.2 V  at  a  current  density  of  50 ÂµA/cm 2 . Representative voltage profiles are shown in Figure 1b. The time to complete each cycle decreases as cycling goes on, indicating capacity decay of the cells. It is worth mentioning that none of the 12 cells shorted; rather, all 12 of the long-term cycling cells died due to capacity fade. Figure 1c shows average charge and discharge capacity of Li-chip and Li-foil cells, each averaged over six cells. The 1 st cycle discharge capacity of lithium chip cells is higher (106 mAh/g) than that with lithium foil (88 mAh/g). However, the capacity of the Li-chip cells  on  average  faded  much  faster  than  that  of  the  Li-foil  cells.  To  better  visualize  capacity  decay,  they normalized the capacities to the discharge capacity of the 1 st cycle (Figure 1d). They considered a cell to be dead once 90% of the initial capacity was lost. On average, Li-foil cells (56 cycles) were able to cycle for almost 20 cycles longer than Li-chip cells (37 cycles). This difference is statistically significant, as shown by Figure 1d. Figure 1 demonstrates that given the same cathode and the same electrolyte, but with different lithium anodes, the cell's cycle life can be different. While unoptimized cathode-electrolyte interface (CEI) is known to cause capacity decay, their results indicate that lithium anode also plays a role in a cell's capacity fade and failure mechanisms.

The team has conducted extensive characterizations on these cells to understand the role of lithium anodes in cell failure mechanisms. These characterizations include in situ impedance spectroscopy, post-mortem scanning electron microscopy (SEM; secondary electron) imaging and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) depth profiling. The interface impedance evolution was monitored by taking impedance measurements after each charge and discharge half cycle, shown in Figure 2. Figure 2a-d shows the overlay of the impedance spectra after the completion of plating (charge to 4.2 V) or stripping (discharge to 2.8 V) for Li-chip and Li-foil cells, respectively. The signature frequencies are tracked by the dashed lines on the impedance spectra. For both Li-chip and Li-foil cells, the highest two frequencies are associated with the anode interface, and the lowest two frequencies are associated with the cathode interface. The impedance spectra indicate that the cathode interface and charge transfer resistances are not only higher than the anode counterpart, but also that they grew much more quickly.

The interface resistance at the anode interface was obtained by fitting the high-frequency semicircle of the impedance spectra (Figure 2e). After the first charge, the anode interface impedance for Li-chip and Li-foil cells was similar (48 â„¦â€§cm 2 and 43 â„¦â€§cm 2 , respectively). Slowly, the interface impedance grew. At the end of 15 cycles,  the  interface  impedance  grew  to  be  94 â„¦â€§cm 2 and  83 â„¦â€§cm 2 ,  respectively.  The  anode  interface impedance grew faster in Li-chip cells. The team performed XPS depth profiling experiments on the cycled lithium anodes and discovered that the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer on the Li-chip anode was thicker than that of the Li-foil anode; the thickness of the SEI grew faster in Li-chip cells than in Li-foil cells. For brevity, XPS results are not shown in this report. The elemental analysis also indicates that the SEI composition of Li-chip anode differed from that of the Li-foil anode. Li-foil anode has a more fluorine-rich SEI.

The cathode interface impedance, including interface resistance and charge transfer resistance, was obtained by fitting the low-frequency semicircle (with equivalent circuits of one or two semicircles depending on the shape of the spectra), as shown in Figure 2f. Similar to the initial anode interface, the cathode interface impedance after first charge was similar, with 206 â„¦â€§cm 2 for the Li-chip cell and 250 â„¦â€§cm 2 for the Li-foil cell. However, the  cathode  interface  impedance  in  the  Li-chip  cell  grew  by  over  an  order  of  magnitude  in  15 cycles,  to 2921 â„¦â€§cm 2 , while that of the Li-foil cell grew by sixfold to 1593 â„¦â€§cm 2 . The substantial increase in the cathode interface impedance correlates well with the capacity fade of the cells. This analysis shows that even with the same CEI, the lithium anode has profound impact on the cathode charge transfer process.

Lithium morphology evolution was monitored via post-mortem SEM. For this experiment, another 12 cells were assembled and cycled to the specified cycling stage and stopped. Then, the cells were disassembled in an argon glovebox, and the xPEO-LiTFSI electrolytes were carefully peeled away from the lithium anode. Figure 3 compares the lithium anode morphologies before cycling and at different stages of cycling for each lithium source. The pristine uncycled lithium chip has smooth areas and rough areas but is overall rougher than lithium  foil  (Figure 3a).  This  has  been  confirmed  with  atomic  force  microscopy measurements  (results not shown). The lithium foil surface morphology, on the other hand, is uniform with striations across its surface. After conditioning in an assembled cell at 70Â°C for 48 hours, SEI formed on the surface of both the lithium chip and  lithium  foil  (Figure 3b).  The  morphology  of  the  conditioned  lithium  chip  surface  appears  to  be  very different from the pristine surface. Grains with an approximate size of 5 Âµm have formed. Conditioned lithium foil, in contrast, is similar to pristine lithium foil.

As cycling proceeded,  the  team  did  not  observe  significant  roughening  on  either  Li-chip  anodes  or  Li-foil anodes. In their previous study investigating the lithium electrodeposition morphology of the gel composite electrolyte paired with lithium chip, they observed severe pitting as early as the second stripping cycle. This indicates much better chemical stability between the dry xPEO-LiTFSI with lithium. Taking a closer look at the plating morphology, there is a noticeable difference between the 5 th plating and the 1 st plating morphology for lithium chip. While the 1 st plating is homogenous with a new layer of lithium covering the entire surface uniformly (Figure 3c, i/ii), the 5 th plating appears to be less uniform (Figure 3e, i/ii). There are areas that look very similar to the grains first seen in the conditioned lithium. This can also be seen in the SEM image after cell death (Figure 3g, i/ii). This leads the team to believe that there are parts of the lithium chip that did not participate in cycling. It is possible that the lithium chip gradually lost contact with the xPEO-LiTFSI. This is further supported by the lack of lithium chip lodged in the polymer (results not shown) as they peeled them apart. For lithium foil, plating morphology remains uniform throughout cycling. The lithium morphology study results seem to indicate that lithium foil has better adhesion with xPEO-LiTFSI than the lithium chip has.

In summary, this quarter the team studied lithium stripping/plating morphology and cell failure mechanisms in dry SPE full cells made with xPEO-LiTFSI electrolyte, NMC-622 cathode, and two forms of lithium (chip and foil). The two forms of lithium are from two vendors, and they have different thickness and surface roughness. The long-term cycling assessment with 12 cells demonstrated that the primary failure mode from these cells is capacity fade (instead of dendrite growth), as none of the cells shorted. The Li-foil cells lasted longer (56 cycles) than Li-chip cells (37 cycles). This difference is statistically significant. Impedance analysis suggested that the anode interface resistance slowly grew for both cells, but not nearly as much as the cathode interface impedance growth. They believe that the capacity decay originates primarily from unoptimized CEI. However, the two forms of lithium sources lead to different decay rates. The lithium morphology study seems to indicate that lithium foil has better adhesion with the PE than the lithium chip has. XPS analysis shows that lithium foil has a thinner SEI layer richer in fluorine. They also note that although dry xPEO-LiTFSI and the gel composite electrolyte have very similar mechanical modulus and ionic conductivity at their respective cycling conditions, the failure modes are drastically different. In dry xPEO-LiTFSI, polymer-cathode interface drives cell failure; in the gel composite electrolyte, dendrite growth is the primary cell failure mode. Next fiscal year, the team will investigate failure mechanism in the SIC PEs developed in the first half of this fiscal year.

## Task 1.13 -Ion Conductive High Li +  Transference Number Polymer Composites for Solid-State Batteries (Bryan McCloskey, University of California, Berkeley)

Objective. This project seeks to develop polymer-inorganic composites that have an optimal combination of conductivity, processability, and low  interfacial resistance at both a Li-metal anode and a porous Li[Ni, Mn, Co]O2 (NMC) cathode. To enable Li-metal anodes, mechanically rigid solid-state Li + conductors, such as Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO), Li1+xAlxTi2-x(PO4)3 (LATP), and Li2S-P2S5 (LPS) glasses, have been employed due to their high Li + ion conductivity and, when engineered to eliminate interfacial defects, appropriate stiffness to suppress Li-metal dendrite formation. However, for these materials to result in batteries that compete against current commercial cells in terms of energy density and cost per kWh, they would need to be manufactured at no more than 50-Âµm thickness and cost no more than $5 per square meter. These metrics are daunting for pure thin-film inorganic ion conductors, particularly when a porous, thick cathode also needs to be used to achieve competitive cell energy densities. To overcome these challenges, this project aims to develop polymer-inorganic composites, where high Li + transference number polymer electrolytes (PEs) serve as a binder for inorganic ion conducting particles.

Impact. By optimizing the composition of this composite electrolyte, the team aims to marry the processability and  interfacial  mechanical  compliance  of  polymers  with  the  impressive  transport  properties  of  inorganic composites, thereby enabling roll-to-roll manufacturing to allow thin (&lt; 50 Âµm) layers of high-conductivity solid-state conductors to be cost-effectively incorporated into batteries.

Approach. The project approach relies on the following key steps: (1) using monomers with (trifluoromethanesulfon)imide  (TFSI)  anions  appended  to  them,  synthesize  and  characterize  polyanionic PEs with high Li + transference number and conductivity; (2) through systematic material structure-property characterization,  understand  how  to  reduce  interfacial  ion  transport  impedance  between  inorganic  ion conductors  (specifically,  thin-film  inorganic  conductors  such  as  Li-La-Zr-Ta-O,  LATP,  and  LPS)  and  high Li + transference  number  PEs;  and  (3)  characterize  electrode-polymer  and  electrode-inorganic  conductor interfacial resistances at a Li-metal anode.

Out-Year Goals. The overall project goal is to develop an optimized polymer-inorganic Li-ion conductor with superior  conductivity  (&gt; 1 mS/cm),  thin-film  processability,  and  low  electrode  interfacial  impedance.  Of particular interest in the out years is development of a process to fabricate thick, porous, and electrochemically stable NMC cathodes using the polymer-inorganic composite as both the binder and electrolyte. The team aims to integrate the optimized high-loading cathode with a 25-Âµm thin-film polymer-inorganic electrolyte to create an 'anode-less' battery with 500 Wh/kg and 80% capacity retention after 300 cycles.

Collaborations. While this project has a single principal investigator (PI), B. McCloskey will leverage the collaborative battery research environment at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL) and coordinate with other LBNL PIs in the BMR Program for materials and experimental development.

## Progress Report

Last quarter, the team began examining how to control the removal of lithium carbonate from LLZO particles to facilitate ion transport and decrease interfacial resistance between ceramic and polymer phase. They saw that acid  washes  resulted  in  extreme  protonation  of  the  LLZO  structure,  rendering  this  solution  unviable. Additionally, they made initial attempts at developing a trilayer cell architecture to isolate interfacial resistance. This quarter, they continued examining different washing agents to remove lithium carbonate without impacting the LLZO structure. They also have begun working with solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) to understand the transport mechanism in different electrolyte compositions.

The  team  used  inductively  coupled  plasma  (ICP)  to  measure  the  lithium  content  in  the  supernatant  after washing. The ICP data show that even for basic solutions there is excess lithium after washing, suggesting that protons are not the only ions capable of exchanging with the lithium in LLZO. Increasing the cation size (from Na + to K + ) was found not to impact the lithium exchange significantly; however, increasing the cation oxidation state (from Na + to Ca 2+ ) led to lower lithium exchange, although it was still present. They intend to continue exploring  how  different  salt  and  solvent  combinations  may  lead  to  effective  removal  of  Li2CO3 without compromising the underlying ceramic structure. Table 1 shows preparation conditions, Li + concentration from ICP, and the extent of Li + exchange. They suspect that while Ca(OH)2 washes show carbonate is still present, it is CaCO3 rather than Li2CO3 given the limited solubility of calcium carbonate in organic solvents.

Additionally, the team has begun developing solid-state NMR capabilities to directly examine how Li + ions move in composite films. They can distinguish between the lithium in the polymer and ceramic phase, and plan to use 6 Li isotopic labeling experiments to track how these peaks change during cycling. This will allow them to see what fraction of Li + moves in the polymer phase when compared to the ceramic. They also plan to see how composition will impact this transport. Figure 1 shows an NMR spectrum with the ceramic and polymer peaks labeled in a pre-cycled composite electrolyte.

The team also plans to fabricate trilayer cells from the last quarter and test them using pressure cells to ensure they are accurately measuring the interfacial resistance between the polymer and ceramic layers. They intend to develop a series of experiments that allows them to systematically study how different changes to both polymer and ceramic phases impact interfacial resistance (for example, ceramic type and singleion conducting polymer versus lithium salt).

Additionally, last quarter, the team showed that the addition  of  LATP  with  a  particle  size  of  5 ~ 15 Î¼m  to  a highly concentrated liquid electrolyte (LE), ethylene carbonate (EC) / lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) = 2/1, increased the ionic conductivity  of the electrolyte. This quarter, they comprehensively studied this system at different temperatures and LATP content. Figure 2a shows that the single semicircle of pure LE in the

Task  1.13 -Figure  1.  A solid-state nuclear  magnetic resonance spectrum  for a 25  wt%  LLZO  composite electrolyte.

Nyquist plot is replaced by two semicircles after adding LATP. The Nyquist plots after adding LATP are fitted using a R1/C1+R2/Q1 equivalent circuit, where R1/C1 fits the semicircle at higher frequency and R2/Q1 fits the  semicircle  at  lower  frequency.  R1  decreases  when  increasing the  LATP content,  and  the inverse  of  R1 (1/R1) shows almost a linear relationship with the volume fraction of LATP (Figure 2b) within the studied region. In contrast, R2 increases with LATP content. They believe that R1 likely corresponds to ion translational motions at higher frequency both in the liquid phase and inside the LATP particles, while R2 corresponds to the slow Li + exchange process at the liquid/ceramic interface. When increasing LATP content, more Li + in the liquid phase is involved in the exchange process due to increased ceramic/liquid contact area, and thus this process dominates the overall resistance of the sample at high LATP content. To gain more insight into this Li + exchange  process,  they  demonstrate  the  Arrhenius  plots  of  1/R2  in  Figure 2c.  Within  the  studied 10-30Â°C temperature range, an activation energy of 76 ~ 81 kJ/mol was obtained. This activation energy agrees with the Li + de-solvation energy from the literature, further supporting that R2 is related to the Li + exchange process on the ceramic/liquid surface.

To further study whether the two-semicircle phenomenon also occurs in other systems, the team first replaced the LiTFSI in the LE with lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiFSI), which leads to a higher conductivity of the LE. Figure 3a shows the Nyquist plots of concentrated LE EC/LiFSI = 2/1 with 0 wt% and 30 wt% LATP at 0Â°C. Without LATP, the electrolyte shows only one semicircle. After adding 30 wt% LATP, the Nyquist plot demonstrates two semicircles, and the plot can be fitted with the same equivalent circuit as shown in Figure 2a. They then further replaced LATP with Li6PS5Cl. Again, a similar two-semicircle phenomenon was obtained, as  shown  in  Figure  3b.  Overall,  their  study  suggests  that  in  concentrated  electrolyte-ceramic  mixtures,

the ion transport behavior includes two sections: ion transport at higher frequency that can be ascribed to a combination  of  transport  in  the  liquid  phase  and  inside  the  ceramic  particles,  and  ion  transport  at  lower frequency that is likely a result of the Li + exchange at the liquid/ceramic interface.

## Task 1.14 -Inorganic-Polymer-Composite Electrolyte with Architecture Design for Lithium-Metal Solid-State Batteries

(Enyuan Hu, Brookhaven National Laboratory)

Objective. This  project  targets  the  following  goal:  the  composite  electrolytes  will  be  thin  (&lt; 100 Î¼m)  and have high Li-ion conductivity (â‰¥ 10 -3 S/cm at room temperature), low interfacial impedance, and desirable mechanical properties. When used in the solid electrolyte (SE) Li-metal battery, a current density &gt; 1 mA/cm 2 and an areal capacity of 2-3 mAh/cm 2 can be achieved with more than 300 cycles. The constructed LiNixMnyCo1-x-yO2 (NMC) / LiCoO2 || composite electrolyte || Li-metal cell  can  be  operated  at  up  to  4.5 V versus Li + /Li. The SE will also be compatible with high loading cathodes in achieving high energy density at the coin-cell or pouch-cell level.

Impact. The results of this project will lead to advancement of solid-state batteries (SSBs), a beyond Li-ion battery option with better safety characteristics and higher energy density. The project will also provide valuable knowledge to U. S. industries in scaling up SSB production for vehicle applications, thus providing solutions to the clean energy strategy.

Approach. The project  approaches  are  as  follows:  (1)  design  and  synthesize  polymer  with  an  anion-tether strategy  for  high  transference  number,  (2)  through  theories  and  experiments,  design  hierarchical  inorganic electrolyte for suppressing lithium dendrite penetration, (3) optimize the composite electrolyte composition and structure,  (4)  use  additives  for  Li-metal  anode  and  NMC  cathode  protection,  and  (5)  use  synchrotron  and cryogenic electron microscopy characterization to understand the bulk electrolyte and interphases.

Out-Year Goals. The  out-year  goals  are  to  synthesize  single  ion  conducting  solid  polymer  electrolyte (SIC-SPE) with high transference number and conductivity; to design hierarchical inorganic electrolyte with high ionic conductivity and good mechanical/electrochemical stability; and to use synchrotron total scattering to study the structure of ceramic/polymer electrolyte.

Collaborations. The  principal  investigator  (PI)  will  work  closely  with  co-PIs  H. Xin  of  University  of California, Irvine, and X. Li of Harvard University.

## Milestones

1. Optimize the composition of SIC-SPE to achieve interfacial resistance &lt; 200 â„¦ cm 2 , limiting current density &gt; 1 mA/cm 2 ,  and  membrane  thickness  &lt; 20 Î¼m  under  stacking  pressure  &lt; 0.1 MPa.  (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Complete synchrotron-based characterization of polyvinylidene (di)fluoride polymer-based SE to understand its stability against lithium metal and NMC cathode. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Increase  cathode  loading  in  NMC || hierarchical ceramic electrolyte || lithium cells  to  8 mg/cm 2 ,  and  test performance of cells using various electrolytes. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Complete synchrotron-based in situ / ex situ studies  of  ceramic-based  solid-state  cells  to  understand  the stability of electrode-electrolyte interphases. (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

This quarter, the team completed the corresponding milestone. They first designed and fabricated an in situ solid-state cell to study the interphase between solid-state electrolyte (SSE) and the cathode. The cell design was done in collaboration with F. Han from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. As shown in Figure 1a, catholyte, SSE, and anode are sandwiched between two stainless-steel plates. Catholyte is a composite of LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 cathode and ceramic SSE. The anode is LiIn alloy, which has good stability with most of the SSE to be studied. Gold coating is applied on the top of catholyte to serve as both current collector and an X-ray window. To strike a balance between electric conductivity and X-ray signal, the thickness of the gold coating was optimized to be ~ 100 nm. The whole system is sealed with rubber rings and pressured through the screws through the holes. The incoming X-ray shines on the catholyte, and resulting fluorescence spectroscopy reveals information about the interphase between the cathode and the SSE in the catholyte.

At National Synchrotron Light Source II of Brookhaven National Laboratory, two in operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) experiments were carried out for two in situ solid-state cells. In the first cell, argyrodite Li6PS5Cl SSE was used (Figure 1b). Probably due to its high ionic conductivity, the in situ cell was able to be charged  even  at  room  temperature.  The  charging  curve  is  shown  in  Figure  1c.  As  the  voltage  of  LiIn  is ~ 0.6 V versus Li + /Li, the voltage of the in situ cell is ~ 0.6 V lower than that of the conventional cell using lithium metal as the anode. Therefore, charging the in situ cell to 3.7 V is equal to charging a conventional cell to  4.3 V  from the perspective of the depth of delithiation. At this voltage, most of the lithium is extracted. During discharge (not shown here), much less capacity was delivered. This is likely because charging induces a  higher  pressure than discharging, as the former process involves lithium plating while the latter involves stripping. The higher pressure means better physical contact among cell components and better overall kinetics. Even though a full charge-discharge cycle was not successful, in situ data for the charging part were obtained. Results are shown in Figure 1d/e, corresponding to the data from point 1 and point 2 in the in situ cell. Different locations were selected to test the homogeneity of the reaction. The in situ data from both points suggest that nickel is oxidized to the fully charged state, indicating that at the current density (70 Î¼A/cm 2 )  used  for the experiment, the reaction is, in general, homogeneous.

The second in situ solid-state cell the team tested was that in which Li3YCl6 is used as the SSE (Figure 1f). Because the energy of yttrium K-edge is within the accessible range of the beamline, XAS of yttrium K-edge was measured for the in situ cell at the pristine state; results are shown in Figure 1g/h, corresponding to the X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) and the Fourier transformed extended X-ray absorption fine structure (ft-EXAFS). The XANES data are consistent with those in the literature report. In the ft-EXAFS, the first peak corresponds to the Y-Cl bond in the YCl6 octahedra in Li3YCl6. There are no additional peaks in the ft-EXAFS because the YCl6 octahedra are far apart from each other, as shown in the inset graph of Figure 1h. Attempts to charge the in situ cell failed. likely because the ionic conductivity of the used Li3YCl6 is not high enough to guarantee charge-discharge at room temperature. A possible remedy may be adding a heating element to the in situ cell, which is part of the continuing effort to improve the in situ solid-state cell.

In summary, the team has tested the feasibility of the in situ solid-state cell to study the interphase between the SSE  and  cathode  as  in  the  catholyte.  High-quality  XAS  data  can  be  obtained  for  both  three-dimensional transition metal and those elements whose energies are accessible, such as zirconium, yttrium, and bromine. These are important elements for oxide, sulfide, and halide SSE. They have realized that kinetics may be an issue for the in situ solid-state  cells  and  that  heating  elements  may  need  to  be  added  to  guarantee charge-discharge for all cells with various SSEs. They will continue improving the in situ cell to achieve a fully successful XAS experiment in the future.

## Task 1.15 -Solid-State Batteries with Long Cycle Life and High Energy Density through Materials Design and Integration (Haegyum Kim, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory)

Objective. This project aims to create solid-state Li-metal batteries (SSLMBs) with high specific energy, high energy  density,  and  long  cycle  life  using  scalable  processing  techniques.  The  team  will  achieve  this  by addressing fundamental  challenges associated with (1) interfacial reactivity, (2) Li-metal plating, and (3) cathode loading. Addressing these challenges supports the broader Vehicle Technologies Office goal of solid-state batteries (SSBs) with increased cycle life and energy density.

Impact. Ultimately, this project will develop an understanding of how to prevent interfacial reactions, make uniform Li-metal plating, and increase cathode loading significantly. The knowledge obtained from this project will be used to design SSLMBs with high specific energy of 500 Wh/kg, 80% capacity retention for at least 300 cycles, and critical current density (CCD) &gt; 1 mA/cm 2 .

Approach. This  project  addresses  several  fundamental  challenges  and  makes  the  SSLMB  competitive, surpassing the specific energy, energy density, and cycle life of Li-ion batteries:

- Create  homogeneous lithium deposition  on  the  anode  without  penetration  of  lithium  metal  through the separator to achieve high cycle life and high safety. The team will achieve this with the use of an active buffer layer (BL) that combines active and inactive components to homogenize lithium plating and to keep the lithium plating potential away from the solid electrolyte (SE) separator.
- Limit chemical reactivity and mechanical decohesion between the SE, carbon, and cathode material in the composite cathode so that  high  cycle  life  can  be  achieved.  The  team  will  limit  chemical  reactivity  by protecting the carbon from the SE, by using novel cathode coatings designed to be stable to high voltage and  that  do  not  react  with  the  SE,  by  using  novel  solid  halide  catholyte  conductors,  and  by  using inorganic/organic solid composite electrolytes in the cathode.
- Achieve high volumetric loading of the active cathode material in the composite cathode to achieve high energy density and high specific energy. The team will achieve high volumetric cathode loading by creating thin highly porous conductor scaffolds that are infiltrated with cathode, by tailored particle size distributions of deformable lightweight conductors, and by the use of organic/inorganic hybrids.
- Create inexpensive materials and processes to fabricate SSBs so that they can be cost-competitive with Li-ion  batteries.  The  team  will  create  solution-processable  organic/inorganic  hybrids  to  be  used  as separators and to blend in the composite cathode; they will use inexpensive, scalable ceramics processing techniques to create high loading composite cathodes.

Out-Year Goals. The  ultimate  project  goal  is  to  develop  SSLMBs  that  achieve  high  specific  energy  of 500 Wh/kg, 80% of capacity retention after 300 cycles, and &gt; 1 mA/cm 2 of CCD.

Collaborations. The principal  investigator's  (PI's)  team  collaborates  with  the  following  co-PIs:  G. Ceder, V. Battaglia,  G. Chen,  M. M. Doeff,  G. Liu,  M. Scott,  M. Tucker,  and  J. Urban,  all  at  Lawrence  Berkeley National Laboratory.

## Milestones

1. Li6PS5Cl  (LPSCl)  polymer  composite  glass  with  ionic  conductivity  of  0.1-1 mS/cm. (Q1,  FY 2023; Go/No-Go : Completed)
2. Demonstration of 100 cycles without noticeable lithium dendrite growth. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)

3. 1 st discharge capacity in cell with graphite or indium anode &gt; 90% of liquid cell. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Scaffoldless cathode design with thin, dense Li-La-Zr-O (LLZO) separator. Stop if too fragile or scale-up too difficult. (Q4, FY 2023; Go/No-Go: Completed)

## Progress Report

## Buffer Layers to Stabilize Lithium/SE Interface and Create Uniform Lithium Plating (H. Kim, G. Ceder, V. Battaglia, and M. Scott)

This  quarter,  the  team  has  embarked  on  an  in-depth  exploration  of  the  intricate  microscopic  processes within SSBs  featuring  an  Ag-C  composite BL.  Employing  first-principle  thermodynamic  calculations,  they have been able to precisely gauge the free energy profiles of Ag-Li alloy systems. Their investigation also encompasses continuum modeling, focusing on the mechanisms governing lithium transport within the BL. Additionally, they have conducted detailed simulations to examine the electrochemical and mechanical factors dictating the direction of lithium plating during lithiation.

The analysis of lithium transport within the Ag-C BL is illustrated in Figure 1. Figure 1a offers a schematic view  of  the  BL model,  showcasing  a  silver  particle  embedded  within  an  amorphous  carbon  matrix. Figure 1b tracks the progression of the silver particle's potential throughout the lithiation process. To delve deeper  into  lithium  transport,  they  performed  continuous  simulations  under  two  conditions:  (1) assuming equivalent interfacial charge-transfer area specific resistance (ASR) at both BL/SE and BL/current collector (CC)  interfaces,  with  a  focus  on  the  influence  of  Ag-Li  alloying,  and  (2)  considering  nonequivalent charge-transfer ASR, emulating real-world conditions where the ASR at the BL/CC interface is lower than at the BL/SE interface. In the scenario of equal ASRs at both interfaces (Figure 1c), they observe a balanced deposition of lithium on both. However, in a more realistic scenario (Figure 1d), lithium predominantly deposits at the BL/CC interface, aligning with the expected behavior in an actual BL environment. This analysis provides invaluable  insights into  the  complex  dynamics  of  lithium  transport  within  the  Ag-C BL,  shedding  light  on critical factors influencing the preferential plating of lithium at the BL/CC interface.

Task  1.15 -Figure  1.  (a)  Schematic of continuum simulation  model. (b)  Simulated electrochemical potential of silver particle (black  dashes) and equilibrium bulk potential (solid blue) as functions of lithiation time. (c/d) Ratio of lithium current flowing into silver particle, depositing on buffer layer  (BL)  /  current collector (CC) and on BL  /  solid electrolyte (SE) interfaces as functions of lithiation  time,  assuming  (c)  equal  area  specific resistance  (ASR)  on both  interfaces  and  (d)  lower ASR on BL/CC interface.

To further enhance their understanding of the preferential plating of lithium at the BL/CC interface, the team conducted additional simulations, detailed in Figure 2, to ascertain the extrusion behavior of  lithium within the BL and gain insight into the favored extrusion direction. Figure 2a presents the relative volume percentage that Ag-Li occupies within the BL over time, at a charge rate of 0.68 mA/cmÂ². It is evident that silver particles

are expected to expand and fill the pores within the BL after approximately 15 minutes. With the BL completely densified, any excess lithium plated must be deposited either at the BL/SE or BL/CC interface as represented in Figure 2b. Figure 2c quantifies the evolution of internal hydrostatic pressure within the BL as a function of lithiation  time.  Under this assumption, the internal pressure can reach a maximum of  ~ 8 MPa. It becomes evident that once this internal stress becomes substantial enough to counterbalance the adhesion strength of the BL/CC  interface,  estimated  at  ~ 2 MPa,  in  addition  to  the  externally  applied  1 MPa  stack  pressure,  the BL/CC interface will separate, causing Li-Ag  to extrude toward the  CC.  Figure 2d combines  both electrochemical factors (ASR) and mechanical factors (volume expansion, surface adhesion, plastic flow) to portray the evolution of the lithium deposition thickness at the BL/CC and BL/SE interfaces. The lithiation of silver  particles  and  densification  of  the  BL  occur  within  the  initial  20 minutes  of  the  lithiation  process, accompanied by the formation and volume expansion of Ag-Li alloy. Subsequently, the Ag-Li alloy extrudes toward the CC for the remainder of the lithiation time due to the lower adhesion strength of the BL/CC interface compared to the BL/SE interface.

In summary, the preference for lithium metal to deposit on the BL/CC interface can be attributed to both the lower interfacial charge transfer resistance and the lower adhesion strength at the BL/CC interface.

(b)  Mechanism  for  interface  separation between  the  BL  /  current  collector  (CC) and the BL  /  solid  electrolyte (SE). (c)  Calculated internal stress as a function of lithiation time in an anode-free setup. (d) Calculated evolution of deposited lithium thickness as a function of  lithiation  time  on  BL/CC  and  BL/SE interfaces combining electrochemical and mechanical effects.

Composite Cathode: High Voltage Stability, and Chemical and Mechanical Degradation Issue (G. Chen, H. Kim, J. Urban, G. Ceder, and M. Scott)

Last  quarter,  the  team  investigated  the  effects  of  the  synthesis  condition  and  chemical  composition on  the properties of halide SEs. This quarter, they evaluated their electrochemical performance in all-solid-state battery (ASSB) cells equipped with an uncoated 4 V class cathode material. Figure 3 shows results obtained on a cell with  a  LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2  (NMC-811)  composite  cathode,  a  non-stoichiometric  Li2.61Y1.13Cl6  SE  separator synthesized  using  the solid-state  method  (SS-nLYC), and  a  Li-In  alloy  anode.  The  cathode  composite  was composed of NMC-811, SS-nLYC, and a carbon additive (Super C65) in a weight ratio of 58:38:5 (Figure 3a). The mass loading of the active material was 8 mg cm -2 , significantly higher than that in typical liquid electrolyte (LE) cells with an NMC-811 composite cathode (~ 6 mg cm -2 ). Figure 3b shows 1 st and 2 nd charge-discharge profiles of the ASSB cell cycled between 3.0 V and 4.3 V versus Li + /Li at room temperature (~ 25Â°C) with 8 MP of stacking pressure. At 0.1 C rate (1 C = 200 mA g -1 ), the cell delivered an initial discharge capacity of

171 mAh g -1 and  a  Coulombic efficiency (CE) of ~ 82%. The relatively low CE is attributed to the in  situ formation of Li-In alloy on the anode as well as the initial 'break-in' process or the establishment of solid-state Li + diffusion pathways in the cathode composite. After that, the CE increased to ~ 95% in the 2 nd cycle, and the cell  delivered  a  discharge  capacity  of  181 mAh g -1 ,  corresponding to an areal capacity of 1.45 mAh cm -2 at 0.1 C.  They  note  that  although  discharge  capacities  up  to  ~ 200 mAh g -1 (at  0.1 C)  were  reported  on  the equivalent NMC-811 LE cells, the areal capacity is often much lower (~ 1.2 mAh cm -2 ). In the following cycles, the  CE  further  increases  to  ~  99%.  The  ASSB cell  also  showed  good  rate  capability,  delivering  discharge capacities of 176 mAh g -1 , 142 mAh g -1 , and 105 mAh g -1 at 0.2 C, 0.5 C, and 1 C, respectively (Figure 3c). In future work, they will optimize cathode composite formulation as well as cell configuration to further improve ASSB cell performance.

(b/c) Charge-discharge profiles of the ASSB cell during the first two cycles at 0.1 C and the subsequent cycles at 0.2 C, 0.5 C, and 1 C, respectively. ## High-Loading Composite Cathodes (M. Tucker, M. Doeff, G. Chen, and G. Ceder)

This task aims to achieve high energy density and specific energy by investigating thick cathodes with good rate  capability  and  developing scalable processing techniques. This quarter,  the team tested the mechanical properties of the thin and large-area LLZO electrolytes.

Improving Mechanical Properties of the Thin LLZO Electrolyte. In this quarter, the mechanical properties of LLZO were further improved by adding MgO fiber (5 wt%) and sintering together at 1100Â°C. Figure 4a shows the surface of the MgO fiber / LLZO composite after sintering. The MgO fibers survived the sintering, and they were well-attached to the LLZO grains. The mechanical property of this MgO fiber / LLZO composite was tested using 3-point bending and compared with previous results in Figure 4b. The fracture strength of MgO  fiber / LLZO  composite  is  ~ 260.5  MPa,  which  is  ~ 13%  higher  than  MgO  nanopowder / LLZO composite. Using MgO-enhanced LLZO, solid-state cells were also fabricated and tested, as shown in Figure 4c. This cell used single-crystal NMC-811 as the cathode active material, succinonitrile - lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide - lithium bis(oxalate)borate mixture as a solid-catholyte, conductive cathode  reinforcement,  and  lithium  metal  as  the  anode.  The  cell  showed  stable  cycling  with  a  capacity  of ~ 180 mAh/g on the 4 th cycle.

Task  1.15 -Figure  4.  (a)  Scanning  electron  microscopy  image  of  MgO  fiber  /  LLZO  composite  electrolyte. (b)  Fracture strength comparison. (c) Charge/discharge curve of solid-state cell using MgO powder / LLZO composite.

Scale-Up to Large Area and Mechanical Testing. As shown in Figure 5, large-area MgO powder-modified LLZO composite electrolytes were prepared, and mechanical testing was carried out. The LLZO area was scaled up from 1.1 cm 2 to 8.4 cm 2 (Figure 5a-c) with a fixed thickness of 80 Î¼m. The team's conventional tape-casting process was used for this scaling-up, but some modifications were necessary, including extending the binder burning time and using large-area sintering furnace. Mechanical properties of large-area and small-area LLZOs were compared using 3-point bending (Figure 5d). The small-area LLZO (~ 1 cm 2 ) showed a fracture strength of 223.3 MPa, and the large-area LLZO (~ 4.8 cm 2 ) exhibited a relatively lower strength of 206.2 MPa. The strength of the largest area LLZO (~ 8.4 cm 2 ) could not be tested because it was too fragile to handle, as shown in Figure 5c. They could observe that the larger area LLZO is more fragile than the smaller area LLZO, and further  scaling up  would  be  too  difficult.  Through  their  work,  they  successfully  improved  the  mechanical properties of LLZO, increasing the fracture strength by almost 75%. However, it was still not enough to make robust, thin, and large-area LLZO sheets in a free-standing configuration. Therefore, they will continue working with a new approach discussed below.

Task  1.15 -Figure  5.  Prepared thin (80 Î¼ m) LLZO electrolytes with area of (a) 1 cm 2 , (b) 4.8 cm 2 , and (c) 8.4 cm 2 . (d) Stress/strain curve for the small-area and large-area LLZOs.

Go/No-Go Decision on Thin Free-Standing LLZO. The thin free-standing LLZO separator was mechanically feasible in small cells for testing, but it was too fragile for large cells. As shown in Figure 6, the team's decision is to stop developing free-standing thin LLZO (Figure 6d) and proceed to use supports on either (Figure 6a/b) or both sides (Figure 6c) of the thin LLZO. The support can be a porous LLZO or other porous material such as aluminum mesh and carbon forms and is expected to provide enough mechanical strength for holding the thin LLZO. For these supported cell designs, one challenge is to infiltrate the anode and/or cathode active material into the porous supporting structure. The lithium metal should be infiltrated into the anode side porous structure (Figure 6a/c), and first attempts will use lithium melt infiltration facilitated by a coating to enhance wetting.  Infiltrating  the  cathode  materials  into  the  cathode  porous  structure  (Figure 6b/c)  will  require sufficiently large and low-tortuosity pores to accept slurry containing carbon and cathode powders. They will fabricate porous structures with scalable methods based on tape-casting, assess infiltration behavior into the porous structure, and select a cell design for further optimization. Regarding porous structures, the appropriate porosity, pore size, and pore shape in terms of facile infiltration and mechanical strength will be a key focus of future work.

In-Progress Work and Plan. Briefly, the team has found a method to texturize the LLZO surface, leading to increased  CCD.  In  addition,  they  are  exploring  mechanical  reinforcement  of  the  cathode  layer,  leading  to enhanced capacity and stability. In upcoming quarters, they will optimize these structures and cell conditioning methods. They will fabricate porous or textured LLZO electrolytes and characterize their porosity. They will also  test  the  infiltration  of  lithium  metal  and  cathode  into  the  porous  LLZO.  Although  they  made  a  no-go decision for the scale-up of thin LLZO without support, they will continue to use it temporarily in small cells for their cathode development effort.

## Glass Composite SE by Low-Temperature Solution-Phase Synthesis (G. Liu)

This effort aims to develop a sulfide separator that is both thin and resistant to lithium dendrite penetration from the  Li-metal anode.  Solution  processable  separators  would  be  more  easily  integrated  with  SSBs  through low-cost processing. In addition, solution processable SEs could be directly integrated with cathode materials to form a composite cathode through the conventional slurry coating process. The team's objective is therefore to  develop  the  processes  to  synthesize  hybrid  SEs  from  inorganic  conductors  and  polymers  through solution-based processes, which combine high ionic conductivity (&gt;10 -3 S cm -1 ) and high fracture toughness (&gt; 10 MPa m 1/2 ).  As  reported  last  quarter,  the  processed  LPSCl  tends  to  have  higher  crystallinity  and  ionic conductivity than those of the as-received sample. Polymer LPSCl composites were made by mixing 1:1 weight ratio  of  poly(ethylene glycol) dimethacrylate (PEGDMA)  and  LPSCl  together,  followed  by  a  polymer crosslinking  reaction  to  form  the  composites.  Although  the  ionic  conductivities  are  lower  for  the  polymer composites compared to the LPSC samples, the processed LPSCl with PEGDMA shows much higher ionic conductivity than that of the as-received LPSCl polymer composite.

This  quarter,  the  team  fabricated  and  performed  full-cell  battery  testing. The  battery  performance  of  the prepared  electrolytes  was  examined  using  an  all-solid-state  cell  that  had  a  coated  NMC-811//SE//Li-In configuration at a temperature of 25Â°C. The choice of coated NMC-811 as the cathode material was based on

its high energy density, cycling performance, and theoretical capacity. Figure 7a illustrates the charge-discharge (CD) plots of the cells at 0.1 C, up to a potential of 4.2 V; Figure 7b/c shows the changes in discharge specific capacity (Csp) and CE as the number of CD cycles increases at 0.1C. At a rate of 0.1C, the Csp values of the solid-state cells with ALPSCl,  BLPSCl,  ALPSCl-P,  and  BLPSCl-P  electrolytes were approximately 115 mAh/g,  125 mAh/g,  134 mAh/g,  and  138 mAh/g,  respectively  (Figure 7a;  See  Table 1  for  acronym definitions). These values are comparable to or higher than those reported for other SEs. Furthermore, after 50 CD cycles, the cells with these electrolytes exhibited Csp values of around 65 mAh/g, 73 mAh/g, 87 mAh/g, and  90 mAh/g  for  ALPSCl,  BLPSCl,  ALPSCl-P,  and  BLPSCl-P  electrolytes,  respectively,  at  0.1 C.  The capacity was decreased by approximately 44%, 42%, 37%, and 38% of the initial Csp (Figure 7b). The CEs of the  half-cell  using  ALPSCl,  BLPSCl,  ALPSCl-P,  and  BLPSCl-P  electrolytes  were  approximately  94.05%, 95.82%, 99.85%, and 99.97%, respectively, during the 1st CD cycle (Figure 7c). These efficiencies significantly improved to approximately 98.08%, 99.80%, 99.98%, and 99.99%, respectively, after 50 CD cycles, owing to the enhanced interfacial contact between the electrode and electrolyte. More importantly, both at the initial and following  50 cycles,  the  cells  utilizing  composite  electrolytes,  specifically  ALPSCL-P  and  BLPSCL-P, demonstrated higher CEs compared to cells employing individual ALPSCl and BLPSCL electrolytes. These observations strongly suggest that the composite electrolytes exhibit substantial electrochemical stability and enduring cycling performance within the potential range of up to 4.2 V. Additionally, the rate capability of the cells  was  investigated at various current densities from 0.1 C to 0.5 C. The cell with BLPSCl-P electrolyte delivered a capacity of over 59 mAh/g at a high current density of 0.5C, and no short circuit was observed. In conclusion, the BLPSCl-P electrolyte demonstrated excellent cycling and electrochemical stability, showing promise for development of high-voltage SSBs.
