## Task 3.3 -Modeling of Amorphous Solid-State Conductors (Gerbrand Ceder, University of California, Berkeley)

Objective. Solid-state  batteries  are  promising  to  achieve  high  energy  density.  The  project  objective  is  to determine the design principles needed to create solid-state electrolytes with high Li-ion conductivity, while also achieving stability against common Li-ion cathodes and Li-metal anodes.

Impact. The  project  will  lead  to  understanding  the  factors  that  control  Li-ion  motion  in  crystalline  and amorphous solids and will develop strategies to create stable interfaces against lithium metal and high-voltage cathode materials. The understanding of such processes is necessary to determine design principles to develop reliable all-solid-state batteries (ASSBs).

Approach. High-throughput  computation  is  used  to  screen  suitable  solid  electrolytes  (SEs)  with  high electrochemical  stability  and  high  ionic  conductivity, by  incorporating  nudged elastic band  and  an ab initio molecular dynamics method. Meanwhile, density functional theory is used to calculate bulk elastic constants of materials, surface energies, and interface decohesion energies of grain boundaries. Thermodynamic interface stability is assessed from ab initio computed grand potential phase diagrams in which the lithium voltage can be controlled. Kinetic limits for SE decomposition are assessed by topotactic lithium insertion and removal from the SE.

Out-Year Goals. Future goals include the following: (1) gain insight into what creates high Li-ion conduction in  sulfide  and  oxide  solids,  and  (2)  develop  stable,  processable  solid-state  conductors  that  can  be  applied in ASSBs.

Collaborations. There are no collaborative activities this quarter.

## Milestones

1. Computationally explore novel Li-ion conductors in the space of overlithiated rocksalts. (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Design and synthesize novel overlithiated ionic conductor. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Computationally investigate phase stability of Li3PS4 superionic conductors. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Computationally investigate  phase  stability  of  sulfide  superionic  conductors  in  the  Li2S-P2S5  chemical space. (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

The Li2S-P2S5 pseudo-binary system has been a rich source of promising lithium superionic conductors. Several crystalline compounds can be synthesized by combining Li2S and P2S5 precursors in varying ratios, with the notable phases being the Î±, Î², and Î³ polymorphs of Li3PS4, high temperature (HT) and low-temperature (LT) Li7PS6, and Li7P3S11. [1] Among these, Î±-Li3PS4, Î²-Li3PS4, HT-Li7PS6, and Li7P3S11 are superionic conductors with lithium conductivity &gt; 0.1 mS/cm at ambient temperature. [1-3] According to previous experimental and computational studies, these superionic conductor phases are all metastable at ambient temperature. [1] Their metastability  motivates  the  team's ab initio study  with  the  objective  to  quantify  their  thermodynamic accessibility  at  finite  temperature,  rationalize  experimental  trends,  and  potentially  propose  new  synthesis procedures.  To  model  the  free  energy  of  each  phase,  the  team  considers  contributions  from  the  electronic structure, configurational disorder, and vibrational modes. Configurational Li-vacancy disorder, which they assume to be significant in the superionic conductors only, is treated with the cluster expansion and Monte Carlo sampling approach. The vibrational free energy is computed with harmonic phonon calculations on the ground-state of each phase.

Task  3.3 -Figure  1.  Phase diagram of the Li2S-P2S5 system at 0 K, 700  K, and 1000 K. Solid lines denote the convex hull. Stable phases are marked with green squares and unstable phases with gold stars.

Using these free energy contributions for each phase, the team constructs the pseudo-binary Li2S-P2S5 phase diagram, which is shown in Figure 1; the energies above the hull (Ehull) as a function of temperature are shown in Figure 2. The convex hull is a typical construction to obtain stable phases and represents the collection of thermodynamic ground states into which all other phases have a driving force to convert. At 0 K, the only stable phases on the convex hull are Î³-Li3PS4 and the endpoints, Li2S and P2S5 (Figure 1). At 700 K, HT-Li7PS6 is stabilized and appears on the hull. Since reported synthesis procedures for LT- and HT-Li7PS6 typically do not require mechanical milling or quenching, [4] it  may  be  surprising  that  they are  unstable  at  300  K  (13 meV/atom  and 12 meV/atom  above  the  hull,  respectively; Figure 2). It is likely that the thermodynamically  favored  phase  separation  of HT-Li7PS6 to Li2S and Li3PS4 is kinetically hindered at room temperature. Instead, HT-Li7PS6 is found to transform to LT-Li7PS6  on  cooling,  a  potentially  more facile process as it merely involves shifting

Task  3.3 -Figure  2.  Free energy above the hull (Ehull) for all phases from 0  K to 1000 K.

the PS4 locations. Thus, an appropriate solid-state synthesis procedure would be to perform sufficiently high temperature (T &gt; 600 K) synthesis to stabilize HT-Li7PS6, before a relatively rapid cooling process to bypass the phase separation to Li2S and Li3PS4.

For the Li3PS4 composition, the team's calculations in Figure 2 predict phase transformations from Î³ â†’ Î² â†’ Î± with increasing temperature, which is consistent with experiments. Since Î²-Li3PS4 is less than 1 meV/atom above the hull at 300 K (Figure 2), it is plausible that nanoporous synthesis and mechanical milling techniques can lead to its stabilization at room temperature. [5] The Î±-Li3PS4 polymorph is only slightly less stable than Î² at 300 K (Ehull = 4 meV/atom), which explains why Î± can also be stabilized at ambient temperature through a rapid heating and quenching procedure. [6] Rapid heating of the Li3PS4 glass to temperatures in the stability range of Î² enables nucleation of metastable Î± particles that are only slightly less stable than Î², which is possible by the Ostwald step rule. Rapid quenching can then obstruct the commonly observed direct transition from Î± to Î³, [7] which is possible as their energy difference is only 4 meV/atom at 300 K.

Li7P3S11 (red curve in Figure 2) is metastable across all temperatures as its energy is never low enough to be on the convex hull, which agrees with prior experimental studies. [8] At 300 K, it is 4 meV/atom above the convex hull. As temperature increases to 500 K, its Ehull decreases to a minimum of 1.4 meV/atom. Further increases in temperature lead to greater Ehull. Thus, an ideal synthesis temperature should be ~ 500 K, corresponding to the minimum Ehull. This temperature is remarkably close to its experimentally observed glass transition temperature and helps rationalize why heat treatments near this temperature have been successful for recrystallization. [8] The increasing instability with respect to temperature helps explain the experimentally observed tendency to phase separate  to  Li3PS4 and  Li4P2S6  at  temperatures  greater  than  800 K.  The  source  of  this  instability  is  the competition  with  Î±-Li3PS4,  its  neighboring  stable  point,  which  lowers  its  free  energy  more  with  increasing temperature, therefore increasing the convex hull depth (Figure 2).

In summary, the team has computed the phase diagram of the Li2S-P2S5 pseudo-binary system, which recovers key trends observed from experiment. They quantified the thermodynamic accessibility of promising Î±-Li3PS4, Î²-Li3PS4, HT-Li7PS6, and Li7P3S11 superionic conductors as a function of temperature. At ambient temperature, they predict them to be metastable but thermodynamically accessible due to their relatively small energies above the hull. New synthesis procedures are proposed that can assist experimental efforts to stabilize these phases.

## Task 3.4 -In Situ and Operando Thermal Diagnostics of Buried Interfaces in Beyond Lithium-Ion Cells (Ravi Prasher, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory)

Objective. Transport  at  various  interfaces  in beyond Li-ion cells  will  play  a  major  role  in  electrochemical performance and reliability. It has not yet been possible to thermally profile a Li-metal cell during operation to provide  a  spatially  resolved  map  of  thermal  transport  properties  throughout  the  cell.  The  objective  of  this research is to create a metrology capable of spatially resolved in operando thermal property profiling, and then to relate thermal property to the quality of electrodes and interfaces, and to use the developed thermal metrology to understand electrochemical processes in Li-metal batteries, such as dendrite growth, interface kinetics, and ionic transport.

Impact. Characterizing electrochemical processes in Li-metal cells  such  as  lithium  deposition  and  dendrite growth at interfaces is of great significance for understanding and enhancing their electrochemical performance and reliability. In situ and operando micro electrothermal sensors can provide significant information regarding the impact of buried interfaces as a function of time, material, voltage, current, temperature, etc. Therefore, it is important to develop operando micro electrothermal sensors and develop models relating those signals to electrochemical  performance  for  beyond  Li-ion cells. The  physics-based model  relating thermal and electrochemical properties based on these measurements can facilitate future design of Li-metal batteries.

Approach. To accomplish project goals, the team will utilize an in-house adapted 3-omega (3Ï‰) technique to probe thermal properties of a Li-metal cell while it is in operation, without affecting the operation of the cell. The 3Ï‰ sensors will be deposited and fabricated on Li-metal cells based on previous learning on 3Ï‰ sensor fabrication.  The  characteristic  depth  of  the  thermally  probed  region  is  defined  by  the  wave's 'thermal penetration depth,' 2 p D ï¤ ï· = , where D is the sample's thermal diffusivity, and 2 Ï‰ is the heating frequency of the thermal wave. By depositing the project's 3 Ï‰ sensors on the battery's outer surface and adjusting Ï‰ , the team controls Î´p to  span the  full  range  from the top  to  the  bottom  layer,  thereby  noninvasively  probing the thermal transport in subsurface layers and interfaces within the bulk of the battery. Thermal transport can be related to quality of the interfaces. By doing concurrent thermal transport and electrochemical performance measurements, the team plans to relate thermal transport to electrochemical performance. As frequency-based thermal measurement techniques provide excellent spatial resolution within the cell, the team also plans to study heat generation at the electrolyte/Li-metal interface and to relate the thermal signals to the interface kinetics and ionic transport. The frequency dependence of heat generated due to transport resistance is different from that due to kinetic resistance. The team plans to utilize this difference to separate the contributions of kinetic and transport resistance at the interface, which will enable understanding of interface kinetics and transport at the Li-metal / solid-state electrolyte (SSE) interface.

Out-Year Goals. The project will design, build, and implement the adapted 3Ï‰ metrology to examine thermal properties and a general frequency-dependent thermal metrology to examine heat generation. This will involve developing and testing  the  metrology  itself  along  with  accompanying  theory,  designing  compatible  battery samples, and applying the technique to live cells. The team will measure thermal transport properties of battery materials provided by collaborators. Combined with the electrochemical performance measurement, this will provide significant information relating the thermal signal to the electrochemical process.

Collaborations. This  project  collaborates  with  two  Lawrence  Berkeley  National  Laboratory  groups: V. Battaglia's for cell assembly for 3Ï‰ studies, and R. Kostecki's for pristine battery active material growth for studies of thermal signals related to electrochemical process.

## Progress Report

The team continued the study of self-heating/temperature rise on the solid-state cells. As in last quarter, they conducted experiments using the single-layer cell. The temperature rise curves at different frequencies and at different thermal boundary conditions were recorded. As with last year's report, they chose lithium aluminum germanium phosphate (LAGP) instead of LLZO as the electrolyte since it is easier to fabricate and deal with. Additionally, they simulated the LAGP-Li cells to obtain the appropriate model and perform future prediction. This quarter, they continued the work and performed simulations for the cell-level to pack-level electrochemical-thermal simulation. They have developed an understanding of the heat generation rate, heat loss, and temperature rise. This information helps them quantify how the electrochemical interface resistance decays after the temperature increase caused by high frequency alternating current heating.

## Task 3.5 -Multiscale Modeling of Solid-State Electrolytes for Next-Generation Lithium Batteries (Anh Ngo, Larry A. Curtiss, and Venkat Srinivasan, Argonne National Laboratory)

Objective. This  project  is  part  of  a  multiscale  modeling  effort  to  obtain  an  in-depth  understanding  of  the interaction  of  the  electrode  and  the  solid  electrolyte  (SE)  aimed  at  developing  highly  efficient  solid-state electrolyte (SSE) batteries for vehicle applications. Input parameters needed for mesoscale (continuum) level calculations  are  being  obtained  from  atomistic  calculations  including  density  functional  theory  (DFT)  and classical molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. This atomistic input will enable a multiscale computational procedure for SSEs that is capable of successfully capturing the physicochemical aspects during charge and discharge  process,  including lithium transport  mechanisms,  interfacial  phenomena  during  the  insertion  and extraction of lithium ions, and mechanical deformation of SSE.

Impact. A major safety concern experienced with commercially available Li-ion batteries under some scenarios is leakage of the liquid electrolyte (LE), which can potentially catch fire. Replacement of the LE is necessary to decrease the fire hazard and improve safety associated with present-day Li-ion batteries. In addition, use of SEs provides a path to prevent dendrites in Li-metal anodes, thereby leading to batteries with significantly higher energy density. The impact of this project will be to help in development of good SSEs as a replacement for the commercially used organic LEs to improve safety and energy density in Li-ion batteries.

Approach. Parameters  needed  for  mesoscale  modeling  of  grain  interior,  grain  boundary  (GB),  and electrode-electrolyte interface will be calculated by DFT-based calculations along with Monte Carlo and MD simulations. The calculations will be used to determine properties of the electrode with the SE as well  as  in  GB regions  of  the SE.  This  will  include  calculations  of  structure,  stability,  ionic  conductivity, Young's modulus, fracture toughness, exchange current density, and other properties.

Out-Year Goals. The out-year goals of this work are to calculate other properties such as fracture toughness and include other SSEs and coatings in the multiscale modeling.

Collaborations. This project collaborates with Y. Cui at Stanford University.

## Progress Report

## Mesoscale Calculations for Interdiffusion of TM Ions between Cathode and SEs

A computational framework is developed at the mesoscale level to decipher the extent of ionic interdiffusion occurring at the interface between LCO cathode and LGPS SE (LCO||LGPS). The corresponding impact on cathode voltage and capacity is also elucidated using another mesoscale-level model, which is implemented at a  larger  length  scale.  The  interdiffusion  model  captures  the  transport  of  species  due  to  the  formation  of concentration  gradients  at  the  LCO||LGPS  interface.  Charge  neutrality  conditions  are  also  satisfied  while developing the governing equations. The relative interdiffusion coefficients are functions of the self-diffusivities of the individual ions (ð·ij = ð·ij (ð·i, ð· j )) . The self-diffusivities of the individual species, such as, cobalt, sulfur, phosphorous, and germanium, etc., in both the cathode (LCO) and SE (LGPS) domains are estimated from the atomistic simulations. In the present analysis, the diffusion of species is assumed to be much faster in the LGPS SEs as compared to the LCO cathode materials. Under this assumption, the evolution of the various species at the interphase region over 275 hours is simulated, and the obtained results are shown in Figure 1. It is evident that due to the faster movement of cobalt from the LCO cathode to the LGPS SEs, the interface moves toward LCO. This results in a loss of cathode active materials, which is denoted as 'LAM' in the  present  context.  The  interface  moves  into  the  LCO cathode  at  a  constant  velocity  of  0.25 nm/hour, approximately, which indicates the continuous loss of cathode active materials due to the interdiffusion process.

Task  3.5 -Figure  1.  Computationally  modeled  interdiffusion of  ion-induced  movement  of  the  cathode/solid-electrolyte interface. (a)  Shifting of the LCO||LGPS interface into the cathode side during a simulation run for 275 hours. (b) Model predicted increase in interphase layer thickness (black line) and shift of the interphase. The velocity associated with the movement of the interphase region is estimated to be ~ 0.25 nm/hour. (c) Distribution of various cathode (cobalt) and solid electrolyte (phosphorus, sulfur, germanium) species at the beginning (dashed line) and end (solid line) of simulation. The simulations were run for 275 hours.

The other mesoscale-level model, which is implemented at a higher length scale, is capable of estimating the voltage  versus  capacity  performance  curves  while  considering  the  two  possible  degradation  mechanisms observed at the cathode/SE interface, namely, interfacial delamination, and interdiffusion-induced LAM (introduced  in  the  earlier  portion  of  this  report  and  summarized  in  Figure 2a).  Impact  of  these  two degradation mechanisms on the overall voltage versus capacity curve is shown in Figure 2b. It is evident that the experimentally observed decrease in voltage and capacity in LCO||LGPS cells after 300 cycles is definitely a combination of both the fracture and interdiffusion induced LAM induced degradation mechanisms.

Task 3.6 -Tackling Solid-State Electrochemical Interfaces from Structure to Function Utilizing High-Performance Computing and Machine-Learning Tools (Shinjae Yoo, Feng Wang, and Deyu Lu, Brookhaven National Laboratory; Nongnuch Artrith and

Alexander Urban, Columbia University)

Objective. This  project  aims  at  elucidating  the  structural  evolution  and  other  dynamic  properties  of  the interphases at the solid-state ions (SSIs) in solid-state batteries (SSBs) under processing and electrochemical cycling conditions that strongly impact cell performance. By leveraging synergies of first-principles theory, high-performance  computing,  machine  learning  (ML),  and  computational/experimental  spectroscopy,  this project involves a comprehensive investigation of solid electrolyte (SE) systems and SSIs that may enable the practical use of lithium anodes and high-Ni Ni-Mn-Co (NMC) cathodes in SSBs. Specific project objectives are as follows: (1) develop realistic atomic-scale structure models of the heterostructural SSIs, (2) determine the  impact  of  structural  evolution  on  stability  and  transport  properties  of SSIs,  and  (3) identify  the coating/doping chemistry that may stabilize SSIs during formation and electrochemical cycling.

Impact. Interfacial properties and the dynamical evolution of interphase structures are crucial for the stability and performance of SSBs. This project will lead to fundamental understanding of current materials limits and will identify key materials parameters for optimizing the performance of SSBs. By corroborating atomic-scale theory with experiment, the project will identify structure-property relationships of the heterostructural SSIs in SSB systems that are relevant for electric vehicles (EVs). The outcomes of this project will therefore accelerate development of high-energy-density, safe SSBs for EVs.

Approach. Accurate ML potentials will be trained on an extensive database from density functional theory (DFT) calculations  to  simulate  the  structure  evolution  and  electrochemical  properties  of  the  SSIs.  Using  a second ML model, key physical descriptors will be extracted from electron energy loss spectroscopy and X-ray absorption  spectroscopy  (XAS)  measurements.  This  spectral  fingerprinting  will  enable  the  automated interpretation of spectroscopy measurements, thereby bridging between atomistic modeling and experiment. An  experimental  platform  will  be  developed  to  integrate  experimental/computational  spectroscopy  and modeling of SSIs. In combination, the two ML models and the spectroscopic data will facilitate the construction of a physics-based model to unravel the structure-property relationships of the SSIs.

Out-Year Goals. The  project  will  progress  toward  establishing  dynamic  composition-structure-property relationships  for  interface  stability  and  transport  within  and  across  the  electrochemical  SSIs  in  SSBs.  The ML approach  will  be  further  developed  to  a  general  model  for  thermodynamic  and  transport  properties  of dynamic heterostructural electrochemical interfaces and will eventually be applied to the practical SSB systems.

Collaborations. The project is collaborating with Y. Du at Brookhaven National Laboratory and with K. Sun and D. Steingart at Columbia University.

## Progress Report

This  quarter,  the  team  analyzed  the  hard  X-ray  photoelectron  spectroscopy  (HAXPES)  data  measured  on argyrodite-structured electrolytes LPSX (X = Cl, Cl0.5Br0.5, Br). HAXPES is a surface-sensitive technique that can provide quantitative compositional information on the SSI as well as the oxidation states of the absorber elements. By comparing the ratios of oxidized sulfur and phosphorus, they have found that LPSBr is the least oxidized of the three electrolytes, suggesting that it has a higher stability on delithiation. This study reflects the effect of different halide doping on the stability of sulfide electrolytes. Based on these efforts and the results of previous  quarters  (Q2 FY 2022;  Q4 FY 2022;  Q1 FY 2023),  they  have  developed  a  manuscript  on  the delithiation process of argyrodite-structured sulfide SEs.

## HAXPES

The  team  measured  lithium 1s,  phosphorus 2p,  sulfur 2p,  chlorine 2p,  and  bromine 3d HAXPES data  for LPSX samples at the SST2 beamline of the National Synchrotron Light Source II. For each electrolyte, they measured the pristine sample, the samples after the first delithiation (cycle 1 at 5 V) and lithiation (cycle 1 at 0 V), and the samples after the second delithiation (cycle 2 at 5 V) and lithiation (cycle 2 at 0 V). For LPSC, data from cycle 2 at 2.3 V are shown instead of cycle 1 at 0 V because the latter sample was severely charged, resulting in low data quality. Judging from the other two electrolytes, the HAXPES spectra are similar for the two states. In addition, cycle 2 at 2.3 V is close to the first lithiation cycle (Q2 FY 2022 report) and therefore does not affect the analysis result.

The peak shifts due to surface charging were performed with reference to the carbon 1s peak position at 285 eV. HAXPES spectra were analyzed using CasaXPS. [1] The phosphorus 2p and sulfur 2p data and the fitting results are shown in Figure 1 and Figure 2, respectively. The lithium 1s, chlorine 2p, and bromine 3d spectra do not change much after delithiation, so only the corresponding spectra measured on LPSCl0.5Br0.5 samples are shown in Figure 3. The evolution of the charge state of each element is described hereafter.

The phosphorus 2p spectra of all three electrolytes are plotted in Figure 1, Task 3.6 - Figure with the colored shaded areas representing the fitted components. Each fitted component has 2p3/2 and  2p1/2  doublet  peaks  with  0.86 eV  separation.  In  the  pristine  stage,  the  phosphorus 2p3/2  peak  is ~ 132.6 eV for all three materials. After the first oxidation (cycle 1 at 5 V), a shoulder appears at higher binding energy, and the spectra are fitted with the original doublet (purple shading area) plus a new doublet with 2p3/2 peak at 133.2 eV (blue shaded area). The difference of 0.8 eV between the two components indicates very slight oxidation.  Comparing  HAXPES  with  previous  X-ray  absorption  spectroscopy  (XAS)  results  (Q1 FY 2023 report), the team can see that the higher energy peak corresponds to a distorted PS4 tetrahedra structure. The removal of lithium  from  the  structure  changes  the  oxidation  states  of  sulfur  atoms,  which  has  a  small  but observable effect on phosphorus atoms.

Figure 1b shows the concentration ratios between the two fitted components at different cycling states. The concentration of oxidized component decreases on lithiation, suggesting that the reaction is partially reversible. In  addition  to  the  decrease  in  quantity,  the  oxidized  phosphorus 2p  peaks  also  move  to  the  lower  binding energies, and the relative difference between the two doublets decreases from 0.8 eV to 0.5 eV. This suggests that the oxidation state of phosphorus becomes lower when lithium atoms are reintroduced into the system. The trend  of  the  2 nd cycle  is  similar  to  the  1 st cycle.  Comparing  the  three  electrolytes,  LPSBr  shows  the  least oxidation, indicating its high stability.

Task  3.6 -Figure  1.  (a) Phosphorus 2p hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (HAXPES) data and fits of the three argyrodite electrolytes. (b) Concentration ratios of the fitted  components.

Figure 2 shows the sulfur 2p spectra of the three electrolytes. The pristine spectra are fitted with 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 doublets separated by 1.18 eV. A very small amount of reduced sulfur signal is present in pristine LPSCl0.5Br0.5 sample, probably due to residual Li2S in the reagents. The oxidation state of sulfur in the pristine electrolyte is -2.  After  the  first delithiation,  a  new doublet  with  a  higher  binding  energy  of  ~ 1.6 eV  appears,  which is represented by the red shaded area. Comparing HAXPES with previous XAS results, the team sees that the higher energy peak corresponds to the formation of S-S bonds (Q1 FY 2023 report), with a change of oxidation state from -2 to -1.

The  reaction  is  partially  reversible  on  lithiation,  with  a  decrease  in  the  proportion  of  the  oxidized  sulfur (Figure 2b). The decrease in the area of oxidized sulfur is greater compared to that in the phosphorus spectra, suggesting more reversibility on the oxidation state. However, unlike the phosphorus spectra, the position of the oxidized sulfur 2p peaks does not change and remains 1.6 eV higher than the original sulfur 2p peak. The extent of oxidation of sulfur in LPSBr is also the least among all three.

Lithium 1s, chlorine 2p, and bromine 3d data are shown in Figure 3. For simplicity, only the spectra measured on LPSCl0.5Br0.5 electrolyte are shown as an example. Due to the low signal-to-noise ratio, the lithium 1s spectra are only fitted with a single peak and not analyzed for chemical states. As expected, the lithium 1s peak area decreases with delithiation and increases with lithiation. The chlorine 2p spectra are fitted with 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 doublet with 1.6 eV separation, and the bromine 3d spectra are fitted with 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 doublet with 1.05 eV separation. Although LiCl and LiBr were observed in XAS measurements (Q1 FY 2023 report), there is no significant change in chlorine 2p and bromine 3d HAXPES spectra because the oxidation states of chlorine and bromine do not change. Task  3.6 -Figure  3.  (a) Chlorine 2p, (b) bromine 3d, and (c) lithium 1s hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy results on LPSCl0.5Br0.5 electrolyte cycled to different states. In each plot, the gray dots represent measured data, black curves represent fits, and colored shaded areas represent the components used in the fits.

In summary, the team has resolved the changes in oxidation states of phosphorus and sulfur by analyzing the HAXPES spectra and have found that the oxidation of sulfur is more reversible than that of phosphorus. This is probably because the oxidation state of sulfur is mainly affected by its first neighbors lithium and sulfur, whereas the oxidation state of phosphorus is mainly affected by changes in its second neighboring lithium atoms. While local structural changes of sulfur appear to be reversible, the overall structure is not, as reflected by  the  persistence  of  the  oxidized  phosphorus 2p peaks  after  lithiation.  These  degraded  structures  on  the SSI will affect further cycling. This explains the different electrochemical profiles between the 1 st and 2 nd cycles reported in the second quarter of FY 2022. Furthermore, they have found that LPSBr is the most stable among the three electrolytes against delithiation. The quantitative and oxidation state information from HAXPES complements  the  local  structure  motif  information  from  XAS;  together,  they  provide  a  more comprehensive understanding of the delithiation process of argyrodite electrolytes.

Task 3.7 -Integrated Multiscale Model for Design of Robust, Three-Dimensional, Solid-State Lithium Batteries (Brandon Wood, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory)

Objective. This project is developing and applying multiscale, multiphysics models that connect composition, microstructure,  and  architecture  to  mechanical  integrity  in  three-dimensional  (3D)  solid-state  batteries (SSBs). The models integrate multiple computational methods, informed and validated through collaborations with complementary  experimental  efforts. The  project scope addresses three objectives: (1) develop multiphysics, multiscale chemomechanics models; (2) assess interface- and microstructure-induced mechanical failure thresholds; and (3) simulate chemomechanical evolution under battery operating conditions.

Impact. This project will deliver multiscale, multiphysics models that connect composition, microstructure, and architecture to mechanical integrity in 3D SSBs. The tools will be used to examine common interfaces in commercially viable  electrolyte  and  cathode  materials  and  to  provide  design  principles  for  maintaining mechanically robust operation. The modeling framework will address the shortcomings of existing modeling strategies that either lack coupling of the multiphysics nature of various processes active in 3D batteries or fail to  incorporate  processes  at  different  length  scales  to  understand  function.  Connections  will  be  made  to understand  the  limits  of  operability  and  to  co-optimize  ionic  conductivity  and  mechanical  robustness  in solid electrolyte-cathode matrix composites.

Approach. The project approach integrates atomistic, mesoscale, and continuum simulation methods to predict chemomechanical properties of interfaces in ceramic (Li-La-Zr-O, or LLZO) and halide-based solid electrolytes (SEs).  Both  internal  grain  boundaries  (GBs)  and  interfaces  with  LiCoO2  (LCO)  and  Ni-Mn-Co cathode materials are considered. The project is aligned along three tasks, each of which uses simulations to probe a different fundamental length scale relevant to the performance of 3D-SSB architectures. First, atomic-scale interfacial  properties  are  computed  using  density  functional  theory  (DFT)  and  machine  learning  (ML) approaches.  These  include  local  bond  strength  and  mechanical  response,  as  well  as  stress  distributions associated with formation of cracks. Second, using digital reproductions of 3D electrodes and electrolytes, the local stress distributions and stress hotspots in SEs and cathode-electrolyte composites are computed within a mesoscale model. Third, materials performance is coupled to cycling conditions within an operating device by incorporating phase-field models that can simulate rate-dependent fracture likelihood under cycling and extract microstructure-fracture-transport relationships.

Out-Year Goals. The team will focus on the following out-year goals: use ab initio methods to generate models for GBs and cathode-electrolyte interphases (CEIs); compute local bond strength and mechanical response of model  interfaces;  reconstruct  microstructures  of  electrodes  and  electrolytes  using  phase-field  models;  and develop a phase-field model for cathode-induced volume evolution on cycling.

Collaborations. This project collaborates with N. Adelstein from San Francisco State University on atomistic diffusion  modeling,  and  J.  Ye  from  Lawrence  Livermore  National  Laboratory  (LLNL)  on  3D  printing  of SSB materials. They also partner with T. Danner and A. Wachsman from University of Maryland (UMD) on properties of LLZO with varying densities and microstructures as part of the U. S.-Germany partnership on SSB research.

## Progress Report

## Improved  Chemomechanical  Model  for  Charge/Discharge  Process  of  a  Cathode  Active  Material Agglomerate

Previously, the team developed a mesoscale model to simulate the effect of microstructure on lithiation/delithiation-induced mechanical  stress evolution in the cathode active materials during the discharge/charge  processes.  The  focus  was  to  analyze  the  chemically  induced  mechanical  stress,  but  stress effects on lithium transport were not included. This quarter, the team extended the model to fully couple the mechanical  stress  and  lithium  transport  for  a  more  realistic  description  of  the  process.  Specifically, computational models were integrated to describe the interplay between the diffusion-induced stress and the stress-gradient  driven  transport  in  a  self-consistent  manner.  During  the  temporal  evolution  of  the  lithium transport simulation, the continually evolving local stress field and its effect on transport are computed using a numerically efficient algorithm.

Figure 1a illustrates the microstructural setup as an example. The team considered the lithiation of a model polycrystalline agglomerate (or particle) embedded within the LLZO SE matrix. To gauge the effect of stress on lithium transport, they performed comparative simulations with and without the stress-gradient term. For simplicity, isotropic elasticity was assumed for the cathode active material and SE with Young's moduli of 200 GPa and 150 GPa, respectively, and assuming an identical Poisson ratio of 0.3. The diffusivity of lithium was also assumed to be isotropic with no dependence on the local lithium concentration. GBs in the agglomerate were assumed to have a reduced diffusivity (0.05% of bulk) and modulus (30% of bulk), using the atomistic simulation results as a guide. A constant flux boundary condition was applied at the CEI. In addition, it was assumed  that  all  the  interfaces  remain  coherent  without  delamination  or  crack  formation  during  the lithiation process.

Figure 1b shows the time evolution of the depth of discharge (DOD) for the cases without and with the stress effect  on  lithium  transport.  The  corresponding spatial profiles of the lithium concentration and stress at the DOD = 45% are shown in Figure 1c/e and Figure 1d/f, respectively. The simulations clearly capture the stress effect, making the overall lithiation of the cathode particle become more sluggish. When the stress effect is considered,  the  lithium  distribution  in  the  cathode  agglomerate  is  more  uniform  (see  comparison  between Figure 1c  and  Figure 1d).  The  local  von Mises  stress  magnitudes  in  the  intercalated  grains  and  at  the heterointerface are also reduced (see comparison between Figure 1e and Figure 1f). The observed behavior (that is, the retardation of lithiation and the more uniform lithium distribution) can be rationalized as follows. The high  local  stress  in  the  intercalated  grains  creates  high  elastic  strain  energy  density,  which  increases  the resistance  against  further  lithiation  from  the  exterior  heterointerface,  while  simultaneously  promoting  the energetically favorable diffusion of segregated lithium into the unintercalated grains within the interior of the agglomerate. As a result, the lithium distribution becomes more homogeneous in the stress-diffusion coupled case than in the uncoupled counterpart. Interestingly, the corresponding mechanical stress hotspots are also somewhat alleviated, indicating the importance of facile diffusion in maintaining robustness against fracture during cycling.

Next quarter, the team will continue to refine the model by considering anisotropy in the diffusivity and elastic modulus and by employing a full suite of atomistically  derived  parameters  for  LCO  and  LLZO  to  further quantify  the  interplay  among  microstructure,  chemomechanics,  and  diffusion,  as  well  as  stress  hotspot evolution, during (de)lithiation cycles.

## ML Interatomic Potentials for Accelerated Atomistic Simulations

To  investigate  the  effect  of  dopant  segregation  at  LLZO  GBs  on  electrochemical  performance,  the  team continued their efforts to develop ML interatomic potentials for Al-, Ba-, and Ta-doped LLZO systems. They employed an iterative training approach by searching untrained feature space and sampling additional training data from molecular dynamics (MD) simulations using preliminary ML models trained on DFT calculations. Using these refined ML potentials, the team plans to evaluate propensities of dopant segregation, potential secondary phase formation, and ion transport kinetics at dopant-incorporated LLZO GBs. These activities are coordinated under the U. S. - Germany partnership for (1) multiscale modeling with the integration between atomic,  mesoscale  modeling  capabilities  at  LLNL  and  continuum-level  modeling  capabilities  at  ANL  and Deutsches Zentrum fÃ¼r Luft- und Raumfaurt (Germany) and  (2) theory-experiment collaboration regarding charge transport characteristics in doped LLZO with UMD, University of Michigan, and Forschungszentrum JÃ¼lich (Germany).

## Atomic-Scale Fracture Behavior of LLZO

The team used their previously trained and validated ML potential to perform MD simulations of crack tip propagation behavior in cubic LLZO. The simulation was structured into four major steps: (1) equilibrate bulk LLZO at 300 K under zero hydrostatic pressure in the MD simulation; (2) determine both yield hydrostatic and uniaxial  pressure  of  the  pre-equilibrated  LLZO  sample;  (3)  introduce  Griffith  cracks  into  the  equilibrated LLZO bulk sample, oriented along different crystallographic planes and under different boundary conditions; and (4) preload the cracked LLZO to its yield pressure under Mode-I loading, and perform MD simulations under  constant-volume  boundary  conditions.  During  steady-state  crack  propagation,  the  cleavage  plane, displacement field, and any potential lithium redistribution occurring at the crack surface are monitored.

4

Figure 2 outlines the primary work and findings from this quarter. Figure 2a depicts the schematic illustration of  LLZO  sample  preparation  and  crack  generation.  Figure  2b-d  shows  the  crack  propagation  path  under different boundary conditions. In Figure 2b, the sample is simulated with fully periodic boundary conditions and is preloaded hydrostatically to its yield point. Here, the crack consistently propagates along the {100} plane, resulting in a flat fracture surface. Comparable crack behavior can be found in Figure 2c, where the crack is initialized  at  the  free  surface  of  the  sample  and  uniaxially  preloaded  along  the  [010]  direction.  A  notable difference arises when the crack is introduced along the {1 1 0} plane and the sample is preloaded hydrostatically (or along the [1 1 0] direction for the free surface scenario); as shown in Figure 2d, the crack deviates from its original orientation and propagates along the {100} plane. This observation indicates the fracture anisotropy in single-crystal cubic LLZO and lower cleavage energy of the {100} plane. Figure 2e highlights local lithium redistribution along the cracking plane, where both Li-rich and Li-deficient regions are identified. Interestingly, during crack propagation, cubic-to-tetragonal phase transformation is observed in the vicinity of the crack, as shown Figure 2f. The goal of these simulations in coming quarters is to inform mechanical failure thresholds for  the  mesoscale  models,  which  can  then  be  coupled  to  the  computed  local  stress  distributions  and cycling profiles.

## Summary

The use of a metallic lithium anode is required for advanced battery chemistries like Li-ion, Li-air, and Li-S to realize dramatic improvements in energy density, vehicle range, cost requirements, and safety. However, use of metallic lithium with liquid and solid polymer or ceramic electrolytes has so far been limited due to parasitic solid-electrolyte interphase reactions and dendrite formation that eventually short circuit the battery. Adding excess lithium to compensate for such losses negates the high-energy-density advantage of a Li-metal anode and leads to further concern for battery safety. For a long lifetime and safe anode, it is essential that no lithium capacity is lost either (1) to physical isolation by roughening, dendrites, or delamination processes, or (2) to chemical isolation from side reactions. The key risk, and current limitation, for this technology is the gradual loss of lithium over the cycle life of the battery. To address these issues, there is need for a much deeper analysis of the degradation processes and new strategies to maintain a dense, fully connected lithium and a dendrite-free electrolyte  so  that  materials  can  be  engineered  to  fulfill  the  target  performance  metrics  for  electric  vehicle application, namely 1000 cycles and a 15-year lifetime, with adequate pulse power.

The efficient and safe use of metallic lithium for rechargeable batteries is then a great challenge, and one that has eluded research and development efforts for years. This project takes a broad look at this challenge for both solid-state batteries and batteries continuing to use liquid electrolytes (LEs). Electrolytes reported here include conventional LEs such as localized high-concentration electrolytes, gel type polymer-in-a-salt, composites of ceramic  polymer  phases,  common  and  novel  polymer  electrolytes,  and  both  oxide  and  sulfide  ceramic electrolytes.  Researchers  are  typically  working  toward  cycling  of  full  cells  with  relevant  and  balanced capacities using both thin lithium metal and anode-free configuration, prelithiation methods, and post-cycling observation of the disassembled cell components to assess stability of the Li-metal/ electrolyte interface.

## Highlights

The highlights for this quarter are as follows:

- The J-G. Zhang group at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory report a floatable conductive layer (FCL) on the copper current collector for anode-free lithium batteries. The typical FCL is ~ 1.5-Âµm thick and made of the carbon nanoparticles with a selected polymeric binder to tune its binding to copper substrate. The FCL coating has a weak binding to lithium; thus, lithium can be deposited underneath the protection layer with appropriate pressure control. This enables its long-term protection of copper substrate and high cycling stability in the anode-free configuration.
- Y. Cui's group at Stanford University had earlier developed a novel approach to develop a lithiated copper current  collector  using  a  dry  process.  Their  results  show  that  the  lithiated  copper  current  collector demonstrates  much  higher  first-cycle  Coulombic  efficiency  (CE)  when  tested  on  graphite  anodes. Experiments show that current collectors  with  longer  annealing  time  (with  lithium  metal)  enable  more lithiation. Results demonstrate the possibility of fine-tuning lithium capacities in current collectors and reaching first-cycle CEs close to 100% in diverse types of anodes.

## TASK 4 -METALLIC LITHIUM

## Team Lead: Jagjit Nanda, SLAC Stanford Battery Research Center

## Task 4.1 -Lithium Dendrite Prevention for Lithium Batteries (Wu Xu, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory)

Objective. The objective of this project is to enable lithium metal to be used as an effective anode in Li-metal batteries  with  good  thermal  stability  and  safety.  The  investigation  in  FY 2023  will  focus  on the  following aspects:  (1)  continuing  development  of  three-dimensional  (3D)  structured,  lightweight,  flexible  current collectors for Li-metal anode and Li-metal batteries, (2) developing a stable dual-layer (DL) as an artificial protection layer for Li-metal anode to be used as an effective anode in Li-metal batteries, and (3) obtaining mechanistic insight on Li-metal deposition/stripping behavior.

Impact. Lithium  metal  is  an  ideal  anode  material  for  next-generation,  high-energy-density,  rechargeable batteries. However, the application of Li-metal anode has been hindered by concern for safety and short cycle life. The safety concern regarding Li-metal batteries mainly arises from lithium dendrite growth and electrolyte flammability; the short cycle life is largely associated with the high reactivity of lithium metal with electrolyte and the lithium loss due to formation of a solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) and electrochemically inactive or 'dead' lithium during cycling. Although much progress has been achieved in suppressing lithium dendrites and increasing lithium Coulombic efficiency in liquid electrolytes in recent years, the intrinsic problems of Li-metal anode still exist. This fiscal year, the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) team will continue to develop 3D porous current collectors for Li-metal anode to suppress lithium dendrite growth, increasing the utilization of lithium metal and consequently enhancing the safety and cycle life of Li-metal batteries. The team will also develop artificial DLs to protect Li-metal anode and further investigate mechanisms affecting lithium deposition and stripping behaviors to lay the groundwork for future improvement of electrolytes (salts, solvents, and additives) for Li-metal batteries. The success of this project will increase safety and cycle life of lithium batteries  and  accelerate  market  acceptance  of  electric  vehicles  (EVs),  as  required  by  the  EV Everywhere Grand Challenge.

Approach. The approach will encompass the following areas: (1) continue development of current collectors with  3D structure  for  Li-metal  anode  to  suppress  lithium  dendrite  growth,  increase  lithium  utilization,  and extend cycle life of Li-metal batteries, (2) develop artificial protection layers on Li-metal anode to improve the cycling stability of Li-metal batteries [Li||LiNixMnyCo1-x-yO2 (NMC)], and (3) conduct mechanistic studies on lithium deposition behavior to lay the groundwork for future improvement of Li-metal batteries.

Out-Year Goals. The long-term goal of the proposed work is to enable Li-metal batteries with a specific energy of &gt; 350 Wh/kg (in cell level), 1000 deep-discharge cycles, 15-year calendar life, and less than 20% capacity fade over a 10-year span to meet the goal of the EV Everywhere Grand Challenge.

Collaborations. This project collaborates with C. Wang of PNNL on characterization by transmission electron microscopy;  Y.  Zhang  and  J.  Lee  of  Argonne  National  Laboratory  on  electrospinning  polyimide  (PI), polysulfone, and polycarbonate porous membranes; X. Meng of University of Arkansas on molecular layer deposition; and X. Shan and G. Xia of University of Houston on studying SEI formation using in situ reflection interference microscopy.

## Progress Report

This quarter, the properties of electrochemically deposited  lithium (EDLi) on heat-treated Cu@PI and bare copper substrates were further evaluated. EDLi || LiNi0.6Mn0.2Co0.2 (NMC-622) with the heat-treated Cu@PI demonstrates 80% of capacity retention after 180 cycles  at  C/10  rate  for  charging  and C/3  rate  for discharging  (1C = 4.5 mA cm -2 )  after  two  cycles  of  formation  at  C/10  in  the  range  of  2.8 V  to  4.4 V (versus Li/Li + )  (Figure 1a).  In  contrast,  EDLi||NMC-622  with  bare  copper  exhibits  only  51.5%  of  capacity retention under the same condition. The total mass of the cathode, separator, and EDLi was used to calculate the specific energy density of the EDLi||NMC-622 cells. EDLi||NMC-622 with the heated Cu@PI shows about 20% increase in specific energy (212.0 Wh Kg -1 ) compared to bare-copper-based EDLi||NMC-622 (178.9 Wh Kg -1 )  at  the  1 st cycle (Figure 1b). Figure 1c shows that the mass of Cu@PI is 14.5% of the bare copper. This result indicates that a Li-metal battery using a lighter 3D current collector made of Cu-coated PI nanomaterials can improve both cyclability and energy density of the batteries as compared to the similar batteries using bare copper as the anode current collector.

The  DL-protected  Li-metal  anode  was  also  further  investigated.  The  DL strategy  comprises  a  polymer composite bottom layer (CBL) having an ionic conductive material and a cross-linked polymer-based top layer (TL). To study the effect of the protection layer on Li-metal batteries, the Li || LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1 (NMC-811) coin  cells  using  the  bare  lithium  and  the  TL/CBL-coated  lithium  (TL@CBL@Li)  were  assembled  with  a polymer  electrolyte  separator  and  75 Î¼L  electrolyte  of  lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide - 1,2-dimethoxyethane - 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl-2,2,3,3-tetra-fluoropropyl  ether  (at  1:1.2:3  by  mol.).  At  a  current  rate  of C/2 for charging and discharging, the TL@CBL@Li||NMC-811 cells delivered a higher capacity retention of 73.4%  after  200 cycles  compared  with  the  bare  Li||NMC-811  cells  (60.1%)  (Figure 2a).  In  addition, TL@CBL@Li||NMC-811 cells delivered a higher capacity of 132 mAh g -1 with lower polarization compared with bare Li||NMC-811 cells (65 mAh g -1 ) after 200 cycles (Figure 2b). Figure 2c shows that TL@CBL@Li||NMC-811 cells  exhibit  improved  discharge  capacities  at  higher  charge  current  densities (C/2, 1C, 3/2 C). These results demonstrate that TL@CBL@Li could be a promising candidate to enhance the electrochemical performance of Li-metal batteries at higher current densities. Other strategies to achieve better performance of Li-metal batteries using a protection layer will be further investigated next fiscal year.

## Task 4.2 -Prelithiation for High-Energy Lithium-Ion Batteries (Yi Cui, Stanford University)

Objective. Prelithiation of high-capacity electrode materials is an important means to enable those materials in high-energy batteries. This study pursues three main directions: (1) development of facile and practical methods to increase first-cycle Coulombic efficiency (CE) of anodes, (2) synthesis of fully lithiated anode to pair with high-capacity, Li-free cathode materials, and (3) prelithiation from the cathode side.

Impact. Prelithiation of high-capacity electrode materials will enable those materials in the next generation of high-energy-density Li-ion batteries. This project's success will make high-energy-density Li-ion batteries for electric vehicles.

Approach. Silicon electrode film will be prepared by coating the slurry of silicon nanoparticles, carbon black, and  binder  mixture  on  copper  foil  through  a  doctor-blading  method.  The  silicon  electrode  film  will  be prelithiated by pressing a Li-metal foil on top of it and heating it in an argon glovebox for a certain time. Then, LixSi electrode film can be obtained by removing the redundant lithium foil through a peeling-off approach. The redundant lithium foil is reusable for the next prelithiation. The structure, morphology, and other properties can be analyzed by scanning electron  microscopy  (SEM),  transmission  electron  microscopy,  X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), etc. In the first year, the team aims to fabricate LixSi freestanding electrode film and improve its air stability. In the second year, the team aims to improve the electrochemical stability in full cells.

Out-Year Goals. Materials  containing  a  large  quantity  of  lithium  will  be  synthesized  for  pre-storing lithium ions inside batteries. Materials and processes will be developed to be compatible with battery electrode and cell fabrication. The first-cycle CE of anodes will be improved and optimized by prelithiation materials. Materials for prelithiation from the cathode side will be developed.

Collaborations. This  project  engages  with  the  following  collaborators:  BMR  principal  investigators; SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory: M. Toney (in situ X-ray); and Stanford University: W. Nix (mechanics).

## Progress Report

The high reversibility of graphite anodes led to development of Li-ion battery technologies. Overcoming the present challenges, including higher energy density, is essential for next-generation batteries. On the anode side, it  has  been  proposed  to  replace  graphite  anodes  (372 mAh/g)  with  silicon  anodes  (3579 mAh/g)  due  to significantly  higher  theoretical  capacities.  Even  though  Si-based  batteries  have  shown  high  potential  as high-energy li-ion batteries, they possess a critical issue-large capacity loss in the 1 st cycle. This phenomenon is mainly because of large volume expansion of silicon during lithiation and as a result, their initial CEs are lower  than  graphites  ranging  from  50%  to  80%.  In  this  respect,  additional  techniques  are  necessary  to supplement this capacity loss for development of high-energy Li-ion batteries.

Previously,  the  team  worked  on  various  prelithiation  methods  to  mitigate  irreversible  capacity  loss  by introducing lithium compounds. These materials provide extra capacity on both sides of Li-ion batteries for enhanced initial CE. High reactivity leads to degradation of reagents; thus, it is more challenging to prelithiate the anode side where more lithium is irreversibly lost. In this respect, they propose a new concept of storing lithium in the anode current collector, a dead weight, and possibly improving chemical stability of lithium during the process. In previous quarters, they have developed lithiated current collectors from dry methods and verified formation of new phases with various analysis such as XRD, XPS, and SEM.

With this current collector, the team's goal was to investigate the impact of additional lithium capacity on the initial  CE  of  graphite  anodes.  Based on structural changes to  copper lattices resulting from annealing,  they could observe successful infusion of lithium into copper unit cells. Consequently, they could also presume this new current collector  works  as  a  reservoir  for  an  additional  amount  of  lithium  inside  batteries.  To  test  its applicability in coin cells, they integrated graphite anodes onto the lithiated current collectors and tested their performance in half  cells  (Figure 1a).  When  they  first  cycled  bare  graphite  anodes  against  lithium  without lithiated current collectors, their initial CEs were ~ 83% (depicted as '0 hr' in Figure 1a). Then, graphite anodes were placed on top of the current collectors, and supplementary lithium was extracted during the first charging steps (Figure 1b). With 1-hour annealed samples, initial CEs of graphite anodes were ~ 93%, which was a 10% increase from bare graphite anodes. As a result, it was clear that lithiated current collectors can successfully supply an extra amount of lithium for anodes during the 1 st cycle  (Figure  1c).  Based  on  their  analysis  that samples with longer annealing time can store more lithium, they further investigated the changes of initial CEs with various current collectors. As they increased the annealing time from 1 hour to 2 hours and to 3 hours, they observed a gradual increase in initial CEs from 93% to 97% and to 106%, respectively. This result not only  supports  the  previous  data  but  also  exhibits  possibilities  of  fine-tuning  lithium  capacities  in  current collectors and reaching close to 100% initial CEs in diverse types of anodes. In conclusion, they postulate that this novel method of using current collectors as a lithium source might be beneficial for achieving high initial CEs in the next generation of lithium batteries.

## Task 4.3 -Anode-Free Lithium Batteries

(Ji-Guang Zhang and Xia Cao, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory)

Objective. The main project objective is to explore the feasibility of anode-free lithium batteries (AFLBs) for high-energy-density  energy  storage  systems.  An  AFLB  is  an  extreme  case  of  Li-metal  battery  and  Li-ion battery,  where  all  active  lithium  is  stored  in  cathode  in  the  as-assembled  batteries.  Because  of  the  many similarities  among  AFLBs,  Li-metal  batteries,  and  Li-ion  batteries,  extensive  experiences  and  approaches developed for Li-metal and Li-ion batteries can be applied to AFLBs. Likewise, new approaches and knowledge to extend the cycle life and calendar life of AFLBs can also be used for development of Li-metal and Li-ion batteries, thus accelerating the market penetration of Li-based rechargeable batteries.

Impact. The ever-increasing need for electric vehicles (EVs) continually pushes the boundary of high-density energy  storage  systems.  To  date,  the  state-of-the-art  Li-ion batteries  consisting  of  graphite  anode  and high-voltage  lithium  intercalation  cathodes  cannot  satisfy  the  energy  demand  from  these  applications.  By replacing graphite anode with Li-metal anode, the specific energy density of Li-metal batteries can increase by more than 50% because Li-metal anode has a much higher specific capacity (3820 mAh g -1 ) than that of graphite (372 mAh g -1 ).  To  further  increase  the  energy  density  of  lithium  batteries,  the  concept  of  AFLBs  has  been explored. An as-assembled or fully discharged AFLB consists of a cathode and an anode current collector (such as copper). All lithium source is stored in cathode. This cell design not only increases energy density of the battery, but also improves battery safety because no lithium metal is present in the battery in its as-assembled or discharged state. However, the cycle life of AFLBs is still very limited due to loss of active lithium during the cycling process. Therefore, there is an urgent need to understand the correlation between lithium Coulombic efficiency (CE), cathode CE, and electrolyte (including electrochemical properties and consumption), as well as lithium dendrite growth and the formation of 'dead' lithium, so that AFLBs and Li-metal batteries can be designed to achieve desired energy density and cycle life. In the end, the combination of these two efforts will accelerate the understanding and application of high-energy-density rechargeable batteries for EV applications.

Approach. This task will investigate the main factors affecting performance of AFLBs and identify solutions to enable long-term cycling and safety of these batteries. The lithium loss due to solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI)  formation  and  'dead'  lithium  generation  by  dendrite  growth  in  the  lithium  deposition  and  stripping processes  will  be  analyzed.  The  lithium  dendrite  suppressing  principles  and  strategies  for  both  liquid  and solid-state AFLBs, ranging from materials design (electrolytes, cathodes, and current collectors), cell fabrication, and operation controls (pressure, temperature, and cycling protocol) will also be investigated.

Out-Year Goals. The long-term goal of the proposed work is to enable lithium batteries with a specific energy of &gt; 350 Wh/kg (in cell level), 1000 deep-discharge cycles, 15-year calendar life, and less than 20% capacity fade over a 10-year span to meet the goal of the EV Everywhere Grand Challenge.

Collaborations. This  project  collaborates  with  the  following:  C. S. Wang  of  University  of  Maryland  on approaches to improve the CE of lithium cycling; C. M. Wang of Pacific Northwest National Laboratory on characterization by transmission electron microscopy / scanning electron microscopy (SEM); and Battery500 principal investigators on understanding and approaches to improve the calendar life of lithium batteries.

## Milestones

1. Quantify SEI formation and SEI dissolution at different voltages/temperatures. (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Identify  electrolytes  that  enable  a  lithium  CE  of  99.8%  and  formation  of  SEI layer  with  minimum SEI dissolution in the electrolyte. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Optimize anode substrate to minimize lithium loss. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Increase CE of AFLB to &gt; 99.8%, capacity retention of 80% for 100 cycles. (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

Last quarter, it was found that relatively high internal pressure in the AFLBs leads to more uniform and stable SEI layers formed on copper current collector and to better cycling stability; however, too high of a pressure may lead to more short circuiting. To further improve the performance of AFLBs, the team has designed a floatable conductive layer (FCL) on the copper current collector using a facile method. Many other protection layers reported previously can protect lithium deposition during the initial stages; however, these protection layers may be quickly damaged after a few cycles, and most lithium will be deposited on the top of the protection layer in the subsequent cycles. In comparison, the FCL coating has a weak binding to lithium, so lithium can be  deposited  underneath  the  protection  layer  with  appropriate  pressure  control.  This  enables  its  long-term protection of copper substrate. The typical FCL is ~ 1.5-Âµm thick and made of the carbon nanoparticles with a selected polymeric binder to tune its binding to copper substrate. Figure 1a is the schematic illustration showing how the FCL works during the lithium deposition and stripping processes under different internal pressures. A localized  high-concentration  electrolyte  (ES2)  has  been  used  as  the  electrolyte.  Figure 1b  shows  digital photographs of the FCL-coated copper (1) before and (2) after initial lithium deposition in the FCL-Cu || LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1 (NMC-811) cell, and (3) pressure indicating film showing a non-uniform pressure domain. In the edge region where a higher pressure was exerted, part of the lithium was deposited underneath the FCL coating (as shown by the exposed black FCL), while more lithium was deposited on top of the FCL (as shown in the white colored region). The SEM images in Figure 1c (1 and 2) show that porous FCL can be easily  detached  from  the  copper  surface;  the  cross-section  SEM  images  (3 and 4)  reveal  that  lithium  was deposited underneath the FCL at the high-pressure region (3), while thicker lithium was deposited on top of the FCL under low pressure (4).

(c) Scanning electron microscopy images of (c1)  the  surface  of  FCL  layer,  (c2)  cross-sectional  images  of  detachable  FCL  from copper  current collector,  after  lithium  deposition  under  (c3)  high  and  (c4)  low  internal  pressures,  respectively. The FCL-Cu||NMC-811 cell exhibits significantly improved cycling stability  (80%  of  capacity  retention  in 100 cycles)  as  compared  with  the  baseline  cells  (with  uncoated  copper  anode  current  collector)  with  low (1t, 59%) and high (2t, 72%) internal pressures, as shown in Figure 1d. In addition, more stable cycling CE has been demonstrated in FCL-Cu||NMC-811 cell compared to the baseline cells (Figure 1e). This result clearly

demonstrates that the stable Li/electrolyte interface minimizes the continuous lithium consumption during the long-term  cycling.  FCL  coating  and  cell  pressure  will  be  further  optimized  to improve  the performance  of anode-free pouch cells under uniform pressure.

## Summary

The collected work of the projects in this Task encompasses the following areas:

- Conducting focused fundamental research on the mechanism of 'shuttle effect' inhibition for rechargeable Li-S batteries.
- Developing electrode and electrolyte systems that can mitigate the 'shuttle effect' so low self-discharge and long cycle life can be achieved.
- Synthesizing sulfur composite materials with an emphasis on polymer sulfur composite materials.
- Developing creative electrode-making processes to improve processability and areal capacity; for example, polymeric sulfur composites may not be suitable for the traditional slurry casting process.
- Developing a novel SxSey cathode material for rechargeable lithium batteries with high energy density and long life, as well as low cost and high safety.
- Delivering an electrochemically responsive self-formed hybrid Li-ion conductor as a protective layer for Li-metal anodes, enabling them to cycle with high efficiency.
- Developing high-energy, low-cost Li-S batteries with long lifespan.

## Highlights

The highlights for this quarter are as follows:

- K. Amine's group at Argonne National Laboratory has designed a versatile and thin (~ 25 ï­ m) interlayer consisting of multifunctional active sites, with a goal to simultaneously regulate the lithium deposition process and suppress the polysulfides crossover. The interlayer contains a N-rich core part and wide-spread CoZn dual active sites within a unique yolk-shell framework (denoted as CoZn-YSIL). This quarter, the team demonstrated  that  a  Li-S  cell  with  the CoZn-YSIL  can  deliver  a  high  initial  specific  capacity  of 1327 mAh g -1 and an areal capacity of 6.90 mAh cm -2 at  0.1  C; it  can maintain a high areal capacity of 5.32 mAh cm -2 after 100 cycles, confirming that the CoZn-YSIL can effectively confine and catalyze the dissolved LiPSs to prevent side reactions with the Li-metal anode.
- D. Lu and L. Shi's team at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory proposed a novel strategy of introducing a liquid electrolyte (LE) reservoir additive into the electrode structure during fabrication, which can enhance electrolyte  infiltration  and  storage  to  facilitate  sulfur  conversion  reactions  and  cycling.  The  additive reservoir is a polymeric material that has high affinity with the ether-based LE. Before cell operation, the additive reservoir helps electrolyte infiltration into the electrode after electrolyte injection. During electrode wetting, the additive interacts with the LE, dissolves or swells, and forms a semi-solid interfacial layer that covers the active S/C particles along with other polymeric binder. With this approach, the sulfur cathode with a very low porosity of 30% can still deliver a large discharge capacity of ~ 1100 mAh/g under very lean electrolyte conditions, doubling the volumetric capacity of the sulfur cathode from 612 mAh cm -3 to 1262 mAh cm -3 .
- Y. Cui's team at Stanford University demonstrated the catalytic effect of a novel cobalt aerogel prepared by a hydrogen-substituted graphdiyne (HGDY)-assisted ultrafast sparking technique. Previous scanning transmission electron microscopy experiments revealed that single-atom cobalt sites are well dispersed on the HGDY support and should provide abundant active sites for enhancing the sluggish Li-S redox reaction

## Task 5.1 -Novel Chemistry: Lithium Selenium and Selenium Sulfur Couple (Khalil Amine, Argonne National Laboratory)

Objective. The project objective is to develop novel SxSey cathode materials and advanced liquid electrolytes for rechargeable lithium batteries with high energy density and long life, as well as low cost and high safety.

Impact. Development of a new battery chemistry is promising to support the goal of plug-in hybrid electric vehicle and electric vehicle applications.

Approach. The dissolution of lithium polysulfides in nonaqueous electrolytes has been the major contribution to the low energy efficiency and short life of Li-S batteries. In addition, insulating characteristics of both end members during charge/discharge (sulfur and Li2S) limit their rate capacity. To overcome this problem, sulfur or Li2S is generally impregnated in a carbon-conducting matrix for better electronic conductivity. However, this makes it difficult to increase the loading density of practical electrodes. It is proposed to solve these barriers using  the  following  approaches:  (1)  partially  replace  sulfur  with  selenium,  (2) nano-confine  the SxSey  in  a nanoporous conductive matrix, and (3) explore advanced electrolytes with suppressed shuttle effect.

Out-Year Goals. This new cathode will be optimized with the following goals:

- A cell with nominal voltage of 2 V and energy density of 600 Wh/kg.
- A battery capable of operating for 500 cycles with low capacity fade.

Collaborations. This  project  engages  in  collaboration  with  the  following:  C.  Sun,  W.  Xu,  and  X.  Zuo  of Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory (ANL), Y. Liu of the Center for Nanoscale Materials at ANL, and L. Cheng of the Materials Science Division at ANL.

## Progress Report

This quarter, the team has designed a versatile and thin (~ 25 ï­ m) interlayer consisting of multifunctional active sites,  with  a  goal  to  simultaneously  regulate  the  lithium  deposition  process  and  suppress  the  polysulfides crossover. The interlayer contains a N-rich core part and wide-spread CoZn dual active sites within a unique yolk-shell framework (denoted as CoZn-YSIL). Therefore, it can effectively regulate the lithium deposition even at high areal capacity and high current densities. More importantly, the strong binding ability of CoZn dual active sites and the N-rich framework can significantly suppress the detrimental chemical crossover during the long-term cycling.

As characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM),  the  CoZn yolk-shell spheres  (CoZn-YSs) exhibit  spherical  morphology,  and  the  size  of  the as-prepared CoZn-YSs is measured to be ~ 1.0 Âµm (Figure 1b). The transmission electron microscopy and  the  corresponding  energy  dispersive  X-ray spectroscopy data in Figure 1c further show that a typical yolk-shell structure with a ~ 400-nm diameter core part and a ~ 100-nm thick  shell structure can be clearly identified. Moreover, a N-containing framework was successfully constructed, which can improve the Li + affinity  of the  yolk-shell sphere.  Meanwhile,  the  widespread ZnCo active sites inside the yolk-shell spheres can effectively lower the lithium nucleation overpotential  and  enhance  the  lithium  deposition inside the yolk-shell spheres.

After the rolling-pressing process, the free-standing thin-film  CoZn-YSIL  was  successfully  fabricated. As shown in the top-view SEM image of CoZn-YSIL (Figure 1d), the as-fabricated CoZn-YSIL exhibited continuous and uniform surface features. In addition, as shown  in  the cross-section SEM image and the digital photograph of  the  CoZn-YSIL  (Figure 1e),  the  CoZn-YSIL demonstrated good mechanical strength. The thickness of the interlayer is only 25 Âµm, which is comparable with the commercial Celgard separator. To  further  confirm  the  existence  of  elementary Zn- and  N-containing  lithiophilic  sites  inside  the

The effectiveness of CoZn-YSIL interlayer has been evaluated in Li-S cells. The interlayer was placed on both anode and cathode side. As shown in Figure 2a, due to the severe side reaction between the Li-metal anode and dissolved polysulfides (LiPSs), the areal capacity of the bare Li-S cell without the interlayer quickly faded to 0.67 mAh cm -2 after  only  50 cycles;  further,  it  can  only  maintain  an  areal  capacity  of  0.17  mAh  cm -2 after 100 cycles.  By  contrast,  the  Li-S  cell  with  the  CoZn-YSIL  can  deliver  a  high  initial  specific  capacity  of 1327 mAh g -1 and  an  areal  capacity  of  6.90  mAh  cm -2 at  0.1  C;  it  can  maintain  a  high  areal  capacity  of

5.32 mAh cm -2 after  100 cycles,  confirming  that  the  CoZn-YSIL  can  effectively  confine  and  catalyze  the dissolved LiPSs to prevent side reactions with the Li-metal anode. Advanced characterization will be conducted next quarter to elucidate the working mechanism.

## Task 5.2 -Development of High-Energy Lithium-Sulfur Batteries (Dongping Lu and Lili Shi, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory)

Objective. The project  objective  is  to  develop  high-energy,  low-cost  Li-S  batteries  with  long  lifespan.  All proposed  work  will  employ  thick  sulfur  cathode  (â‰¥ 4 mg/cm 2 of  sulfur)  at  a  relevant  scale  for  practical applications. The diffusion process of soluble polysulfide out of thick cathode will be revisited to investigate cell  failure  mechanism  at  different  cycling.  The  fundamental  reaction  mechanism  of  polysulfide  under  the electrical field will be explored by applying advanced characterization techniques to accelerate development of Li-S battery technology.

Impact. The theoretical specific energy of Li-S batteries is ~ 2300 Wh/kg, which is almost three times higher than  that  of  state-of-the-art  Li-ion batteries.  The  proposed  work  will  design  novel  approaches  to  enable Li-S battery technology and accelerate market acceptance of long-range electric vehicles (EVs) required by the EV Everywhere Grand Challenge.

Approach. The project proposes the following approach: (1) to identify and address key issues of applying high-energy  sulfur  cathodes  including  materials,  binders,  electrode  architectures,  and  functional  electrode additives,  (2)  to  advance  the  mechanism  study  of  sulfur  cathode  and  electrolyte  by  using in situ / ex situ techniques and custom-designed hybrid cell setup, and (3) to verify effectiveness of the new approaches with coin/pouch cells by using high-loading electrodes (&gt; 4 mg/cm 2 ), limited lithium (&lt; 200% lithium excess), and lean electrolyte (electrolyte-to-sulfur, or E/S, ratio &lt; 4 ÂµL/mg).

Out-Year Goals. This project has the following out-year goals:

- Fabricate  Li-S pouch  cells  with  thick  electrodes  to  understand  sulfur  chemistry/electrochemistry  in environments similar to those witnessed in real application.
- Leverage the Li-metal protection project funded by the U. S. Department of Energy and Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) advanced characterization facilities to accelerate development of Li-S battery technology.
- Develop Li-S batteries  with  a  specific  energy  of  400 Wh/kg  at  cell  level,  1000  deep-discharge  cycles, improved  abuse  tolerance, and  less than 20% capacity  fade over a 10-year period to accelerate commercialization of EVs.

Collaborations. This  project  engages  in  collaboration  with  the  following:  E-Y. Hu  (Brookhaven  National Laboratory), M. Cai (General Motors), Y. Fu (PNNL), and Z. Liu (Thermo Fisher Scientific).

2. Investigate effects of cathode architecture on lithium plating/stripping and cell cycling stability at practical conditions and the mechanism behind. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
