4. Introduce secondary-phase electrolyte reservoir into the dense electrode to extend cell cycle &gt; 100 cycles in high loading electrodes (&gt; 4 mg/cm 2 ) at lean electrolyte conditions. (Q4, FY 2023; Complete)

## Progress Report

Fabricating  high-volumetric-energy  sulfur  cathodes  through  direct  calendering  often  leads  to  low  sulfur utilization rate and reaction kinetics, due to the reduced electrode porosity and tortuosity that hinder electrolyte infiltration and uptake. To overcome this challenge, previous methods have created low tortuosity vertically aligned channels by freeze drying, magnetic templates, or laser patterning, but at the cost of increasing electrode porosity. This quarter, the team proposed a novel strategy of introducing a liquid electrolyte (LE) reservoir additive into the electrode structure during fabrication, which can enhance electrolyte infiltration and storage to facilitate sulfur conversion reactions and cycling. The additive reservoir is a polymeric material that has high affinity with the ether-based LE. Before cell operation, the additive reservoir helps electrolyte infiltration into the electrode after electrolyte injection. During electrode wetting, the additive interacts with the LE, dissolves or swells, and forms a semi-solid interfacial layer that covers the active S/C particles along with other polymeric binder. With this approach, the sulfur cathode with a very low porosity of 30% can still deliver a large discharge capacity of ~ 1100 mAh/g under very lean electrolyte conditions, doubling the volumetric  capacity  of  the  sulfur  cathode from 612 mAh cm -3 to 1262 mAh cm -3 .

Micro - computed tomography (micro-CT) was used to analyze the structure of electrodes, both with and without the additive  (Figure 1).  The  baseline  electrode was  fabricated  by  mixing  the  S/C  active materials with a polymeric binder polyacrylic acid (PAA; 10 wt%). The additive-containing electrode, on the other  hand,  was  prepared  by  substituting 40%  of  PAA  with  the  additive  reservoir. In the baseline electrode, the presence and  distribution  of  PAA  binder  can  be identified  by  micro-CT  due  to  its  lower contrast  compared  to  S/C.  It  is  evident that  PAA aggregates  are  present  not  only on  the  surface  of  S/C  particles,  but  also within the voids/channels throughout the  electrode.  When  40%  of  PAA  was replaced by the polymeric additive, a similar electrode structure and component distribution were observed. This is because the added polymeric additive has a similar chemistry  to  PAA  and  thus  has  a  similar X-ray contrast. However, after rinsing the electrodes in LE [1 M lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide / 1,3dioxolane  /  1,2-dimethoxyethane  (LiTFSI/ DOL/DME)],  distinct  morphologies  were observed under micro-CT. To better compare the electrode components and their

Task  5.2 -Figure  1.  Micro -computed tomography characterization: sulfur electrodes without additive (a) before and (b) after rinsing in electrolyte; sulfur electrodes with additive (c) before and (d) after rinsing in electrolyte. (e)  Cycling performance of 30% porosity sulfur electrode with additive and comparison  with  baseline  electrodes  without  additive  at  50%  and  70% porosities, E/S = 10 mL/g S.

distribution, they color-coded the components based on their contrast (red: S/C; yellow: PAA; green: voids). It was observed that the PAA binder maintains its morphology within the electrode without additive even after contact  with  LE,  due  to  its  stability  against  the  solvent  or  electrolyte.  In  contrast,  rinsing  in  LE  causes

significant changes to the electrode with embedded additive. The original aggregates become fewer and smaller. This is because the used additive is partially soluble or can swell when exposed to LE due to its high affinity. As a result, this would generate a gel-hybrid interface on the S/C particle surface. After the electrode was dried, the additive was redistributed across the electrode framework but with a looser or more amorphous morphology, which could not be clearly detected by micro-CT. The high electrolyte affinity to electrolyte and morphology evolution would enhance electrode wetting and help to trap electrolyte within the electrode architecture.

By forming a gel-hybrid interface on S/C with additive, the team can achieve a balance between enhanced electrolyte  wetting  and  suppressed  polysulfide  shuttling  in  low-porosity electrodes.  Low-porosity sulfur electrodes have several advantages. First, they require less pore-filling electrolyte at a given E/S ratio, leaving more electrolyte for cell cycling. Second, they block polysulfide diffusion and shuttling. Third, they have a smooth surface that improves the reaction uniformity of lithium anode and delays lithium dendrite formation. To verify this, they prepared 30% porosity additive-containing electrodes and compared them with baseline electrodes at 50% and 70% porosities. Of note, the baseline electrode at 30% porosity can be cycled. As shown in Figure 1e, the 70% and 50% porosity electrodes both have a rapid capacity drop in the second cycle and the capacity  drops  to  &lt; 500 mAh/g  after  100 cycles.  For  the  additive-containing  electrode  with  even  very  low porosity of 30%, a high specific capacity of 1130 mAh/g can be obtained. Moreover, it shows a more stable cycling. After 100 cycles, the reversible capacity is still ~ 900 mAh/g. This study provides an effective approach to tackle the electrode wetting issue in low-porosity electrodes.

## Task 5.3 -Nanostructured Design of Sulfur Cathodes for High-Energy Lithium-Sulfur Batteries (Yi Cui, Stanford  University)

Objective. The charge capacity limitations of conventional transition metal oxide cathodes are overcome by designing optimized nano-architectured sulfur cathodes. This study aims to enable sulfur cathodes with high capacity and long cycle life by developing sulfur cathodes from the perspective of nanostructured materials design, which will be used to combine with Li-metal anodes to generate high-energy Li-S batteries. Novel sulfur nanostructures as well as multifunctional coatings will be designed and fabricated to overcome issues related to volume expansion, polysulfide dissolution, and the insulating nature of sulfur.

Impact. The  capacity and cycling stability of sulfur cathodes will be dramatically increased. This project's success will allow Li-S batteries to power electric vehicles and decrease the high cost of batteries.

Approach . The approach involves three main efforts:

- Advanced nanostructured sulfur cathodes design and synthesis, including (1) engineer empty space into sulfur cathode to solve the problem of electrode volume expansion, (2) develop novel sulfur nanostructures with multifunctional coatings for confinement of S/Li polysulfides to address issues of active materials loss and  low  conductivity,  (3) develop/discover  optimal  nanostructured  materials  that can  capture the polysulfide dissolved in the electrolyte, (4) develop space-efficiently-packed nanostructured sulfur cathode to increase volumetric energy density and rate capability, and (5) identify interaction mechanism between sulfur species and different types of oxides/sulfides, and find optimal materials to improve capacity and cycling of sulfur cathode.
- Structure and property characterization, including ex situ scanning electron microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis, and in operando X-ray diffraction and optical microscopy.
- Electrochemical testing, including coin cells and pouch cells as well as a set of electrochemical techniques.

Out-Year Goals. The  cycle  life,  capacity  retention,  and  capacity  loading  of  sulfur  cathodes  will  be  greatly improved (200 cycles with 80% capacity retention, &gt; 0.3 mAh/cm 2 capacity loading) by optimizing material design, synthesis, and electrode assembly.

Collaborations. This  project  collaborates  with  the  following:  BMR principal investigators; SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory: M. Toney (in situ X-ray); and Stanford University: W. Nix (mechanics) and Z. Bao (materials).

## Milestones

1. Designing and synthesizing single atom catalyst to facilitate Li-S conversion in all-solid-state Li-S batteries (ASSLSBs). (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Demonstrating ASSLSBs with designed single atom catalyst. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Exploring the working mechanism of single atom catalyst in ASSLSBs, experimentally and theoretically. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Enabling ASSLSBs with high capacity and high-rate ability. (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

Last quarter, the team explored the working mechanism of cobalt single atoms prepared by hydrogen substituted graphdiyne (HGDY) aerogel assisted ultra-fast sparking synthesis for ASSLSBs. With density functional theory calculations, they showed that the catalyst reduces the energy barrier of the rate limiting steps in the conversion between sulfur and the discharge product, lithium sulfide. This quarter, they explored how this cobalt single atom catalyst can enhance the rate performance of ASSLSBs.

Active  materials  for  sulfur  cathodes  were  prepared  in  the  same  manner  as  reported  last  quarter.  The  team infiltrates sulfur into the Co/HGDY network (S@Co/HGDY) with a 9:1 mass ratio of sulfur to Co/HGDY. As a control, they infiltrate sulfur into carbon black in the same 9:1 sulfur-to-carbon ratio. This active material is mixed with carbon black and poly(ethylene) oxide / lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulphonyl)imide (PEO@LiTFSI) binder with a mass ratio of 0.6:0.15:0.25. Polyimide infiltrated with PEO@LiTFSI is used as the solid polymer electrolyte (SPE).

Rate and cycling performance of sulfur cathodes with and without the Co/HGDY catalyst for ASSLSBs at 60Â°C are shown in Figure 1. After an initial activation cycle at 0.05 C, the S@Co/HGDY cathodes deliver greater capacity at 0.1 C, 0.2 C, and 0.5 C, compared to the S@HGDY cathodes. Notably, the S@Co/HGDY cathodes experience less capacity drop than S@HGDY cathodes when the rate is increased. Even without cobalt single atoms, the S@HGDY cathodes deliver greater capacity compared to the bare sulfur control cathodes at all rates studied.

The catalytic effect of cobalt single atoms enhances the cycling and rate performance of the sulfur cathodes, in addition to decreasing the amount of soluble sulfur species in the SPEs by porous HGDY. The capacity and cycling  stability  of  single-atom-enhanced  ASSLSBs  are  comparable  to  those  of  state-of-the-art  solid polymer-based ASSLSBs.

- To synthesize, optimize, and down select small organo-sulfur electrode for all solid-state Li-S batteries.
- To  investigate  the  interface  and  physical  compatibility,  for  example,  elasticity  between  the  small organo-sulfur electrode and solid-state electrolyte (SSE).
- To  develop  surface  protective  lithium  anode  so  it  can  be  compatible  with  polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) binder.
- To continue investigating the interaction of polysulfides in the cathode solid phase.

Impact. The results of this project will be used for development of technologies that will significantly increase energy  density  and  cycle  life  and  will  reduce  the  cost  of  beyond  Li-ion battery  systems.  This  will  greatly accelerate deployment of electric vehicles and reduce carbon emission associated with fossil fuel consumption and help in the direction of building the U. S.-based energy storage manufacture chains.

Approach. This project will encompass the following: (1) continue to investigate and improve the interphase between the sulfur (including organo-sulfur) cathode and the electrolyte, (2) continue to develop hosting and catalytic  materials  to  limit  the  migration  of  long-chain  polysulfide,  and  (3)  collaborate  with  Brookhaven National  Laboratory  (BNL),  continuing  to  investigate  the  sulfur  redox  reaction  in  the  solid  phase  taking advantage of synchrotron-based techniques at BNL and electrochemical analytical techniques at University of Wisconsin, Madison.

S. industrial collaborators at General Motors, Ford, Clarios, etc. The PI and co-PI also collaborate with scientists in China, Japan, and South Korea. ## Progress Report

The team reported the investigation of a novel bifunctional carbon host material in the past few quarters. When used as a sulfur hosting material, the carbon can catalyze the disproportionation of dissolved polysulfide ions to solid Li2S2 and elemental sulfur. In addition, a very uniform mesoporous structure was formed when the carbon was carbonized at 800Â°C (NC800) in comparison with that made at other temperatures.

This quarter, the team further investigated the electrochemical performance of an Li-S cell with the bifunctional carbons made with various carbonization temperatures. Figure 1a compares the cycling behaviors of the sulfur cathodes with various NC hosts. The cells were first activated at a low rate of 0.1 C for 2 cycles, and then cycled at  the  rate  of  0.5  C  between  the  range  of  1.7  V  and  2.9  V  for  100  cycles.  For  the  1 st cycle  at  0.5  C,  the S/NC800 delivered a discharge capacity of 919 mAh g -1 , which was higher than 647 mAh g -1 , 766 mAh g -1 , and 697 mAh g -1 delivered by the S/NC750, S/NC900, and S/NC950, respectively. After 100 cycles, the reversible capacities of the  S/NC800, S/NC750, S/NC900, and S/NC950 remained at 647 mAh g -1 , 439 mAh g -1 , 581 mAh g -1 , and 503 mAh g -1 , respectively. All the cells exhibited a satisfactory capacity retention around 70%, demonstrating the synergistic effect of porous  structures  and  doped nitrogen atoms in the NCs on mitigating  the  shuttle  effect and enhancing the cycling performance of the cells. Cells with  different  cathodes  were then cycled at various current densities from 0.1 C to 2 C to evaluate the rate capability of

the S/NC composites. As shown in Figure 1b, the S/NC800 displays the best rate performance among all the samples. The S/NC800 delivered an initial discharge capacity of 1410 mAh g -1 at 0.1 C. When the current rates were  increased  to  0.2C,  0.5C,  and  1C,  the  corresponding  reversible  discharge  capacities  reduced  to 786 mAh g -1 , 672 mAh g -1 , and 563 mAh g -1 , respectively. Even at a high rate of 2C, the S/NC800 still remained the highest specific capacity of 497 mAh g -1 among all the samples. As the current density was reduced back to 0.1C, the specific capacity of the S/NC800 recovered to 740 mAh g -1 , indicating good stability of the cathode. They  believed  that  the  NC800  could  better  catalyze  the  sulfur  redox  reaction  and  induce  a  homogeneous distribution of sulfide compounds deposition on the host carbon material. This hypothesis was supported by the comparison of the scanning electron microscopy images of the cycled cathode at a discharged state, as shown in Figure 1c-f. While the grape-shaped lithium sulfide deposited on the carbon hosts of NC750, NC900, and NC950, a smooth deposition of sulfides was formed on NC800, which was like a 'honey filled honeycomb' (referring to this project's third quarter report, in which a bee-hive mesoporous structure was

shown for NC800). The more uniform distribution of Li2S/Li2S2 on S/NC800 compared to other NCs, indicated that it underwent a homogeneous conversion process from S8 to Li2S/Li2S2 on the surface. These morphological changes may be ascribed to the polarity of the special N-containing groups formed on the surface of NCs, and the catalytic characteristics of NC in the disproportionation reaction of PS in the electrolyte during cycling. It was speculated that NC800 possesses a higher density of N-containing functional groups with higher polarity, evenly distributed on its surface. This results in more nucleation sites for Li2S/Li2S2, which are favorable to the electrochemical performance of the battery.

The utilization of a high sulfur loading cathode in Li-S battery is critical for improving energy density in the practical application of the battery. The S/NC800 cathode with a high sulfur loading of 5 mg cm -2 was made in a pouch cell (3 Ã— 2 inches, single side). The cycle result is shown in Figure 2a. The battery delivered an initial specific capacity of 742 mAh g -1 and a well retained specific capacity of 580 mAh g -1 after cycling at 0.2 C for 50 cycles, which demonstrates a stable and consistent cycling performance of S/NC800 cathode at a high sulfur loading  cathode.  In  addition,  the  nearly  unchanged  upper  plateau  of  the  charge/discharge  curves  shown  in Figure  2b  also  demonstrates  the  ability  of  NC800  to  mitigate  the  shuttle  effect  that  occurs  during  the cycling process.

## Task 5.5 -New Electrolytes for Lithium-Sulfur Battery (Gao Liu, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory)

Objective. The  project  objective  is  to  develop  new  electrolytes,  additives,  and  electrode  compositions  for Li-S battery with high ion-conductivity, stable toward polysulfide, and promoting the polysulfide affiliation with the electrode substrate to prevent polysulfide dissolution.

Impact. This  work will address the high cost and low energy density of Li-ion rechargeable batteries. The emerging Li-S batteries could feature both high energy density and low cost. This project enables applications of the low-cost, abundant sulfur element as a major chemical component for electrical energy storage. This project will develop new approaches for electrolytes and electrode compositions of Li-S rechargeable batteries.

Approach. This project aims to develop new electrolytes and additives for Li-S battery. The properties of the ideal electrolyte for sulfur electrode would be high ion conductivity, stable toward polysulfide, and promoting the polysulfide affiliation with the electrode substrate to prevent polysulfide dissolution. The project is designed to first understand the electrode substrate interaction with the polysulfides in different electrolytes. This will lead  to  better  understandings  of  the  polysulfide  nucleation  and  precipitation  mechanisms  in  common electrolytes. The second stage of the project will focus on chemically modifying the structures of the solvent and salt electrolyte molecules to increase electrolyte stability and ionic conductivity, to prevent polysulfide dissolution, and to promote polysulfide precipitation.

Out-Year Goals. The team will also investigate the contribution of Li-metal electrodes to overall Li-S battery performance and will develop methods to stabilize Li-metal surface.

Collaborations. This project collaborates with J. Guo and C. Zhu (Advanced Light Source / Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, LBNL), A. Minor (National Center for Electron Microscopy at LBNL / University of California, Berkeley), G. Nagy and W. Heller (Neutron National Science User Facility / Oak Ridge National Laboratory), and P. B. Balbuena (Texas A&amp;M University).

3. Fabricate both Li-metal anode and lithiated alloy anode, and sulfur cathode rechargeable Li-S batteries, and test cell performance. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)

## Task 5.6 -Strategies to Enable Lean Electrolytes for High Loading and Stable Lithium-Sulfur Batteries (Y. Shirley Meng, University of California, San Diego)

Objective. The  project  aims  to  develop  high-energy-density  (&gt; 500 Wh/kg)  and  low-cost  (&lt; 65 $/kWh) Li-S pouch cells.

Impact. The  project  focuses  on  addressing  the  fundamental  bottleneck  in  enabling  high-energy-density Li-S batteries. This has been identified as the need to reduce liquid electrolyte excess and enable high areal loading electrodes. The challenges are overcome via the use of a dense polymer - sulfur electrode composite, which significantly reduces electrode porosity in conventional C-S systems while improving capacity retention. These capabilities, combined with material scale-up by project collaborator Ampcera and pouch prototyping capability  using  thin  lithium  metal  by  collaborator  General  Motors  (GM),  will  result  in  breakthroughs  in next-generation  Li-S battery  chemistries  that  meet  the  energy  density  (&gt; 500 Wh/kg)  and  cost  goals (&lt; $65/kWh) of this project.

Approach. Novel electrode architectures using hexaazatrinaphthylene polymer - sulfur (HATN-S) composite electrode will be explored to reduce the porosity and increase the active loading of the composite electrode. Additionally,  advanced  electrolyte  systems  and  optimization  of  Li-metal anode  will  be  applied  to  further increase energy density of the Li-S pouch cell. If successful, the proposed HATN-S electrode should have less than 30% porosity with high areal capacities of &gt; 10 mAh cm -2 , which will enable lean electrolyte conditions &lt; 2 g/Ah -1 in the full Li-S pouch cell.

Out-Year Goals. The out-year goals involve demonstration of baseline cell chemistries with reduced cathode porosity  and  increased  cathode  areal  loading  pairing  with  limited  electrolyte  and  lithium  inventory.  The conventional electrode drying process (solvent evaporation) limits sulfur loading in the electrode, as higher loading leads to cracking. Thus, the HATN-S electrode will be prepared by optimizing the electrode architecture to increase sulfur loading and reduce electrode porosity. The electrolyte system will be optimized to reduce excessive lithium usage [low N/P ratio; that is, capacity ratio between anode (negative electrode) and cathode (positive electrode)] and improve cell stability.

Collaborations. Project collaborators include GM and Ampcera. This quarter, University of California, San Diego (UCSD), has fixed the synthesis issue of HATN / carbon nanotube (CNT) polymer-carbon composite, and Ampcera has conducted a 10-g batch trial with an improved yield of ~ 90%. GM has provided thin lithium metal (100 ï­ m), a conventional C-S cathode with a sulfur loading of 3.56 mg cm -2 , and the fabrication of pouch cells for this project.

## Milestones

1. Conduct  laboratory-scale  characterization  to  identify  limiting  factors  in  performance  and  to  establish mitigation strategies. (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Complete scalable fabrication of electrode materials. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Decrease cost of raw materials to meet the final goal of $68/kWh. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Optimize  HATN-S  composite  full  cell.  Achieve  large-scale  production  of  materials.  (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Introduction

The project objective is to develop high energy density (&gt; 500 Wh/kg) and low cost (&lt; $68/kWh) Li-S pouch cells. To achieve that, novel electrode architectures using the HATN-S composite electrode will be explored to achieve the low cathode porosity and high sulfur active loading of the composite electrode. Further, advanced electrolyte systems and the optimization of the Li-metal anode will be applied to increase the energy density of the  Li-S  pouch  cell.  If  successful,  the  proposed  HATN-S  composite  electrode  will  achieve  less  than 35% porosity, significantly decreasing electrolyte usage with high areal capacities of &gt; 10 mAh cm -2 , enabling lean  electrolyte  conditions  &lt; 3 g Ah -1 in  the  full  Li-S  pouch  cell.  This  quarter,  major  activities  included: (1) optimizing synthesis of HATN/CNT composite  by  Ampcera  and  electrode  validation  by  UCSD, (2) investigating  the  cycled  lithium  anodes  in  the  baseline  and  the  new  electrolytes,  (3) benchmarking  the full-cell electrochemical performance of the HATN/CNT-S cathode (&gt; 6 mAh cm -2 ) using their newly developed  electrolyte  with  low  electrolyte-to-sulfur  (E/S)  and  N/P ratios,  and  (4) fabricating  the UCSD C-S and HATN/CNT-S cathode sheets for pouch-cell assembly.

Specifically, Ampcera achieved a high yield of &gt; 85% of the monomer synthesis under optimized conditions (Q2, FY 2023). The as-prepared HATN monomer was validated by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and Fourier  transform  infrared  (FTIR)  before  shipping  it  to  UCSD  (Q2,  FY 2023).  The  estimated  cost  of  the HATN is ~ $500/kg based on the synthetic reaction. UCSD and Ampcera collaborated closely and found the solution to incomplete melting polymerization and insufficient post-washing by using a monomer-to-ZnCl2 powder mass ratio of 1:3 in a vertical vacuum annealing furnace (Q4, FY 2023). Following the success of the HATN monomer synthesis,  Ampcera  has  scaled  the  process  to  achieve  50-g  batches  and  10-g-size  batch production of the HATN/CNT composite. A few batches of samples were sent to UCSD for electrode validation. As a result,  the  polymerized  HATN/CNT from Ampcera shows a remaining problem of insufficient water washing to remove any acid residues that cause the current collector (aluminum) corrosion. This quarter, the post-mortem analysis of the lithium anodes cycled in the baseline and the new electrolytes were supplemented by using the cryogenic - focused ion beam (cryo-FIB) characterization tool. It is evident that lithium deposition remains bulky and uncorroded after extended cycling in the new electrolyte, which demonstrates the capability of  polysulfide  corrosion  inhibition  of  the  new  electrolyte.  By  using  the  new  electrolyte  (E/S ratio  of ~ 6 ï­ l mgsulfur -1 or electrolyte-to-capacity ratio of ~ 5 g Ah -1 ) and pairing with 100 ï­ m Li-metal foils received from their collaborators at GM, the full-cell electrochemical performance of as-prepared HATN/CNT-S cathode (&gt; 6 mg cm -2 ) has been benchmarked. It shows a high capacity retention rate of 70% after 150 cycles based on an initial capacity of 4.5 mAh cm -2 at  0.2 C. Further, the high-capacity HATN/CNT-S cathode presents the well-defined voltage profiles of Li-S batteries in their new electrolyte, showing a high specific capacity of &gt; 1000 mAh g -1 at 0.05 C under a low N/P ratio of ~ 2.6 and &gt; 5.5 mAh cm -2 at 0.1 C.

This quarter, GM was preparing for pouch-cell production. UCSD optimized slurry preparation and casting parameters such as solid ratio, stirring speed, and casting thickness. Due to the restriction of safe transportation, dry  pouch  cells  were  prepared  at  GM.  Three  different  kinds  of  cathodes  [UCSD C-S,  GM C-S,  and HATN/CNT-S cathodes (25 cm 2 ) with sulfur loadings of ~ 4.2 mg cm -2 ,  ~ 3.5 mg cm -2 ,  and  ~ 6.5 mg cm -2 , respectively] were paired with 100-Âµm lithium foil as anode. All the single-layered pouch cells were filled with electrolyte at UCSD and tested under a pressure of 150 KPa. Parallel cells will be tested, and more suitable connectors will be used to preclude the technical issues of the pouch-cell testing. Future endeavors also focus on  production  of multi-layered  pouch  cells  based on sufficient  electrode  materials  and the  GM  facility  for pouch-cell prototyping.

## Progress Report

## Decreased  Cost  of  Raw  Materials  and  Industrial  Synthesis  of  HATN/CNT  Composite  (Ampcera  &amp; UCSD)

Ampcera has secured a multi-kg supply chain for the triquinoyl hydrate and 3,4-diaminobenzonitrile precursors, which have been made available to UCSD and GM on request. Background infrared spectroscopy data of the precursor material is presented in a previous report. The cost of raw materials has been decreased dramatically to  $3000/kg  of  triquinoyl  hydrate  and  $4500/kg  of  3,4-diaminobenzonitrile  from  &gt; $20k/kg  of  those  from TCI and Sigma (Q3, FY 2023). Note that this is a price per kg at the current volumes the team purchases. The price per kg would decrease significantly in the future when the precursors are produced at larger volumes and purchased by the barrel or pallet. Therefore, based on future assumptions such as a precursor cost decrease of 90% ($300/kg and $450/kg), the estimated cost of the HATN is ~ $500/kg based on the synthetic reaction. Further,  considering  that  HATN  only  contains  13%  in  their  cathode  recipe  while  other  materials  like CNT (13%), Super P Â®  (5%), sulfur (64%), and binder (5%) are relatively inexpensive, compared to metal oxide chemistry cathode, it is promising to achieve the final goal of $68/kWh. Ampcera will continue working on the scaled synthesis of the HATN polymer and the HATN/CNT composite in coming quarters.

To date, Ampcera has sent six HATN/CNT samples to UCSD for evaluation (Trial-1, Trial-2, and Batches A-D).

The HATN/CNT composite from Trial-1 was washed using  a  truncated  washing  procedure  that  is  more scaleup-friendly  to  remove  the  ZnCl2  catalyst  and unreacted HATN monomer. However, severe corrosion was observed in the initial battery testing, indicating that a high degree of ZnCl2 was still present in the composite. This was confirmed using scanning

Task  5.6 -Figure  3.  Images of the polymerization setup (a) and a zoomed-in  view  of  the  hexaazatrinaphthylene  /  carbon  nanotube polymer composite product (b).

electron microscopy (SEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) measurements, and electrode casting (Q3, FY 2023).  The  HATN/CNT  composite  from  Trial-2  was  washed  using  the  washing  procedure recommended by UCSD, as summarized in Figure 4.

Task  5.6 -Figure  4.  Summarization of the hexaazatrinaphthylene / carbon nanotube washing procedure.

Briefly,  the  polymerized  HATN/CNT  composite  is  washed  in  deionized  (DI)  water  for  12 hours  at  room temperature as an initial washing step. The washed HATN/CNT composite is then vacuum-dried overnight at 150Â°C followed by hand crushing with mortar and pestle. The HATN/CNT composite is then milled using proprietary milling parameters to break down the particle size followed by a second vacuum drying overnight. The milled HATN/CNT composite is washed in 0.1 M HCl at 110Â°C for 12 hours followed by hot filtration to remove any residual ZnCl2 catalyst. Following another overnight vacuum drying, the composite is then washed in  trifluoroacetic  acid  (TFA)  for  12 hours  at  55Â°C  followed  by  hot  filtration  to  remove  residual  unreacted HATN monomer. A final washing step in hot DI water at 90Â°C for 12 hours is carried out to remove TFA and is followed by a final overnight vacuum drying step.

SEM and EDS results from the Trial-2 synthesis of the HATN/CNT composite are presented in Figure 5. SEM images of the pre-milled (that is, initial wash only) HATN/CNT composite are presented in Figure 5a-c, revealing particle sizes upward of 60-80 Î¼m. The EDS measurement spectra in Figure 5d show the presence of zinc and chlorine, indicating that the initial wash only is insufficient. The SEM images of the final HATN/CNT product  are  presented  in  Figure 5e-g,  revealing  a  significant  reduction  in  particle  size.  Moreover,  the EDS spectra  in  Figure 5h  are  absent  of  any  zinc  or  chlorine  peaks,  indicating  that  the  washing  procedure is/should be sufficient for removing the ZnCl2 catalyst. Unfortunately, corrosion was still observed in the initial battery cycling test of the Trial-2 HATN/CNT composite (Q3, FY 2023).

To  eliminate  the  corrosion  issues,  minor  modifications  to  the  HATN/CNT  polymerization  process  using feedback from UCSD were made. Moreover, to eliminate bias in the battery cycling analysis, batches were labeled as A, B, C, and D. Once feedback from the analysis is provided, details of the polymerization process will be disclosed. Batches A and C followed one polymerization process; Batches B and D followed another.

Furthermore, to confirm whether the corrosion originates from the washing procedure, Batches A and B were subjected to an initial DI water wash only. SEM and EDS data from Batches A-D are presented in Figure 6.

The  SEM  images  for  Batches  A  and  B  (Figure  6a/c)  demonstrate  the  large  particle  size  of  the  pre-milled HATN/CNT  composite  in  comparison  to  the  final  HATN/CNT  composite  product  (Batches  C  and  D  in Figure 6e/g). After milling, the D50 drops by nearly 75% to 4.46 Î¼m, with a narrowing of the distribution as indicated by the increase in

the q% value from 13.5% to 15%. Interestingly, when the HATN polymer alone is evaluated, the D50 drops even further to 2.02 Î¼m, indicating a potential increase in the hardness for the HATN/CNT composite.

This quarter, UCSD validated the HATN/CNT samples from Ampcera by the fabrication of HATN/CNT-S cathodes. The post-treatment of unwashed HATN/CNT (Batch A) was done at UCSD. Notably, two times of water washing must be conducted after the TFA treatment to confirm a neutral filtrate using pH paper. This suggests that TFA  residues were contained within the HATN/CNT  matrix  while it removes the HATN monomer. Another possibility is the agglomerated HATN/CNT composite was not ground well for efficient water washing. Thus, the well-washed HATN/CNT composite allows good HATN/CNT-S cathode fabrication through slurry preparation using the same slurry recipe (30% solid ratio), slurry casting, and vacuum drying (Figure 8b), which presents a similar sulfur loading of 6.2 mg cm -2 without aluminum foil corrosion and electrode  cracking.  Comparatively, the  HATN/CNT-S  cathode  based on the  washed  Ampcera  HATN/CNT composite  (Batch C)  features  minor  cracking  and  corrosion  issues  (Figure 8a).  Still,  it  is  much  better

than the previous trials of materials with severe corrosion issues (Q3, FY 2023). This demonstrates that the industrial synthesis of the HATN/CNT materials is only affected by the post-treatment; Ampcera and UCSD will work closely on addressing this final obstacle to fulfill the goal of low-cost Li-S cells.

## Post-Mortem Analysis of Lithium Anodes Cycled in Baseline and New Electrolytes (UCSD)

In the previous two quarters, GM C-S cathodes were used to validate the electrochemical performances in the baseline  electrolyte  and  the  new  electrolyte,  which shows  the  extended  cycle  life  of  Li-S  cells  in  the  new electrolyte  with  low  lithium  inventory  loss  quantified  by  titration  gas  chromatography  (Q3,  FY 23).  This quarter,  the  post-mortem analysis of lithium anodes cycled in the two electrolytes was conducted by using cryo-FIB-SEM, shown in Figure 9. The lithium anode cycled in baseline electrolyte sustains severe degradation and pulverization (Figure 9a), which is caused by the polysulfide corrosion in Li-S cells evidenced by uniform sulfur distribution and major sulfur peak in the accumulated EDS mapping (Figure 9b) and its corresponding spectra in Figure 9c. By sharp contrast, bulky lithium deposition is maintained after a long cycling process in the  new  electrolyte  (Figure 9d),  and  the  EDS  mapping  of  the  cryo-FIB  cross-section  shows  large  bulks  of unreacted lithium (Figure 9e). The EDS spectra (Figure 9f) show that the sulfur intensity is at the same level with oxygen representing the SEI species on lithium surface, further confirming that the polysulfide corrosion has been inhibited by using the new electrolyte.

## Updating the Full-Cell Electrochemical Performance of the High-Loading HATN/CNT-S Cathode in the New Electrolyte under Lean Electrolyte and Lithium Conditions (UCSD)

In the second quarter of this fiscal year, the high-capacity HATN/CNT-S cathode (no sulfur melt infusion) was reported (&gt; 10 mAh cm -2 , ~ 8.48 mgsulfur cm -2 ) with a stringently low N/P ratio of 1.85 using baseline electrolyte in coin-cell tests. This demonstrates the feasibility of the high areal capacity of the project's HATN/CNT-S cathode  for  the  third  budget  period.  It  was  evaluated  using  E/S  of  ~ 6 ï­ l  mgsulfur -1 at  0.25 mA cm -2 and 0.5 mA cm -2 . The areal current density of 0.25 mA cm -2 is equivalent to 0.17 C of LiFePO4 with the same active loading. It is shown that the HATN/CNT-S cathode presents high S-specific capacities (high sulfur utilization) of &gt; 1000 mAh gsulfur -1 under the lean electrolyte condition (Q3, FY 2023). It delivers a high initial areal capacity of 10.8 mAh cm -2 at 0.25 mA cm -2 , which keeps at 9 mAh cm -2 at 0.5 mA cm -2 . However, the corresponding baseline Li-S cells suffer from obvious polarization and relatively low Coulombic efficiency, which suggests severe degradation of electrodes. Therefore, last quarter, the as-prepared HATN/CNT-S cathode with a high sulfur loading of ~ 9.56 mg cm -2 was directly tested in the new electrolyte to inhibit the polysulfide corrosion. It shows  improved  rate  performance  of  the  HATN/CNT-S  cathode  at  current  densities  ranging  from 0.25 mA cm -2 to 1 mA cm -2 , presenting high areal capacities from ~ 10 mAh cm -2 to 6.5 mAh cm -2 , respectively. This demonstrates its applicability in high-energy-density Li-S pouch cells. Concerning the rate capability of the  Li-S  cells,  the  U. S. Department  of  Energy  suggested  lowering  sulfur  loading  to  a  moderate  level  of ~ 6 mAh cm -2 .  The  rate  performance  of  the  HATN/CNT-S  cathode  (~ 6.4 mgsulfur cm -2 )  was  evaluated  this quarter in the new electrolyte for benchmarking before fabricating the high-energy-density Li-S pouch cells in the third budget period. Figure 10a shows the voltage profiles of the HATN/CNT-S cathode with a low E/S ratio of  6 ï­ l  mgsulfur -1 from 0.05  C  to  0.2  C,  wherein  1C  is  1000  mA  g -1 .  It  delivers  a  high  specific  capacity  of &gt; 1000 mAh g -1 at a formation current density of 0.05 C and maintains a high specific capacity of 720 mAh g -1 at 0.2 C, showing well-defined charge-discharge plateaus. The HATN/CNT-S cathode presents good cycling stability under lean electrolyte and lithium conditions with a high capacity retention rate of 70% after 150 cycles based on an initial capacity of 4.5 mAh cm -2 at 0.2 C (Figure 10b). The cell capacity quickly decays to 50% after 200  cycles,  indicating  severe  electrode  degradation,  which  will  be  investigated  in  upcoming  quarters  to

provide insight into the root causes. The stringent cell testing conditions are promising for the feasibility of achieving high energy density of Li-S batteries. This quarter, single-layered pouch cells (SLPC) were fabricated based on the HATN/CNT-S with a moderately high sulfur loading of &gt; 6 mg cm -2 , which will be discussed next.

## Task 5.7 -New Engineering Concepts to High-Energy-Density Lithium-Sulfur Batteries (Prashant N. Kumta, University of Pittsburgh)

Objective. The major objectives of this project are to develop a Li-S pouch cell with a cell capacity &gt; 300 mAh with energy density â‰¥ 500 Wh/kg, â‰¥ 750 Wh/L with cycling over 1000 cycles @C/3 rate, cycle life of 1000 at C/3 and â‰¤ 20% fade in energy @ C/10-C/3, and â‰¤ $80/kWh. To achieve the proposed objectives, the following major  goals  will  be  successfully  attained  over  the  first  year  of  the  project:  (1)  identification  of  effective electrocatalysts and Li-ion conductors (LICs) lowering the activation barrier; (2) in situ synthesis of electrocatalysts and LIC dispersed complex carbon-based framework material and sulfur nanocomposite with sulfur content â‰¥ 90 wt%; (3) ~ 15 mAh/cm -2 areal capacity of sulfur electrode with sulfur loading â‰¥ 10mg/cm -2 ; (4) Li-containing structurally isomorphous alloy (Li-SIA) of ï‚³ 1000 cycles with 15 mAh/cm -2 areal capacity @C/3 rate; and (5) identification of optimal electrolyte compositions giving Li + conductivities ~ 10 -2 S/cm and polysulfide dissolution &lt; 1 ppm.

Impact. The  work  from  this  project  will  have  a  strong  impact  on  development  of  high-energy-density Li-S batteries.  The  results  of  this  work  will  lead  to  new  knowledge  on  identification  and  generation  of high-capacity  sulfur  cathodes  and  dendrite-free  Li-metal  anodes  using  scalable  synthesis  and  fabrication approaches.  Both  fundamental  and  applied  knowledge  will  be  gathered  from  the  study.  Systematic characterization will provide new scientific insights into the mechanisms contributing to the corresponding response in coin-cell and pouch-cell formats. Results of this work also will likely have an impact on other fields such as electrocatalysts for water splitting and fuel cells and other fields engaged in electrochemistry. Plans are also in place to engage underrepresented minority undergraduate students to gain research experience in various aspects of the project. With new materials identified as the project is executed, opportunities will emerge for filing invention disclosures and provisional/nonprovisional patent applications. The training and opportunities presented by this project to undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral research associates will foster  next-generation  work  force  training,  equipping workers  with  the  necessary  skillsets  to  transform the quality of life all over the globe by generating high-energy-density systems that can be deployed in electric vehicles as well as in laptops and cell phones including innumerable portable and wireless devices, opening the doors to a new green and sustainable energy environment improving overall quality of life.

Approach. Work involves executing a theory-driven study directed  at identification  of  electrocatalysts  for efficient conversion of polysulfides to Li2S during the forward discharge process and backward charge process to  elemental  sulfur  and  lithium.  Also,  first-principles  computational  approaches  will  be  applied  to identify solid-state LICs with conductivity &gt; 10 -4 S/cm. Employing expertise in the principal investigator's laboratory, suitable  low-temperature  (&lt; 240Â°C)  scalable  synthesis  techniques  will  be  used  to  generate  theoretically identified electrocatalysts and LICs. Low polysulfide solubility and stable solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) forming  electrolytes  will  then  be  prepared  from  commercially  available  solvents,  additives,  and  salts.  The effectiveness of the electrocatalysts and LICs to improve the polysulfide to Li2S transformation kinetics and the ability  to  achieve  the  targeted  specific  capacity  by  trapping  polysulfides,  including  desired  structural transformation during charging/discharging, will be assessed; accordingly, suitable modification of electrocatalysts  and  LICs will  be  performed  to  generate  the  ideal  microstructures.  Suitable modification,  if required, of lithium alloy as anode will also be performed by alloying with other metals to improve the Li-ion diffusivity  kinetics  and  the  Gibbs-Thomson  parameter.  The  scalable  approaches  developed  will  be  further refined to optimize sulfur utilization in the cathode, engineer the surface and bulk structure of the novel Li-SIA and lithium multicomponent alloy (Li-MCA) anodes to yield the desired areal capacity with optimal Coulombic efficiency (CE), and finally optimize the electrolyte structure to minimize and eliminate polysulfide dissolution with  desired  Li + conductivities.  Finally,  the  developed  systems  will  be  scaled  up,  fabricated,  and  tested  in pouch-cell configurations.

Out-Year Goals. The  following  goals  will  be  achieved  in  subsequent  years:  (1)  determine  optimal  cell component design parameters such as electrode thickness and porosity exhibiting minimal polarization while maintaining cathode capacity â‰¥ 1500 mAh/gsulfur, (2) demonstrate excellent cycle life of &gt; 1000 cycles with &gt; 80% capacity  retention,  (3)  electrochemically  test  cells  with  dendrite-free  Li-alloy  anodes  comprising Li-SIA and  Li-MCA  of  areal  capacity  of  ~ 15  mAh/cm 2 ,  (4)  electrochemically  test  cells  with  modified electrolytes at charge-discharge rages of C/3 as well as other C-rates of C/10-C/3, (5) fabricate &gt; 300-mAh pouch cell giving energy density greater or equal to 500 Wh/kg at C/3 rate and demonstration of acceptable performance at other C-rates of C/10-C/3, and (6) demonstrate cyclability of a minimum of 1000 charge/discharge cycles with &lt; 20% fade rate for operation in -40Â°C to +40Â°C temperature ranges, with temperature measured external to the pouch cell.

Collaborations. The project involves collaboration with G. E. Blomgran of Blomgren Consulting Services, Ltd.

3. Full-cell cyclability testing for 1000 cycles @ C/3 and complete evaluation at C/10 - C/3 current rates. (Q3, FY 2023; In progress, with completion expected in January 2024)
4. Electrode performance quantification in ~ 20-mm coin-cell configuration. (Q4, FY 2023; In progress with completion expected in January 2024)

## Progress Report

This quarter, the team used a combination of experimental and computational methods to study different aspects of the Li-S  battery  and  meet  the milestones  of  the  project.  Experimental  investigations were conducted to evaluate the electrochemical performance  of  the  carbon fiber mat - sulfur  (CFM-S) cathodes.  As  a  second  component  of  the  experimental research, the team also further explored the potential of MCAs reported in the previous quarters of FY 2023. In those reports, the team showed the potential of MCAs as dendrite-free  anode  materials  that  can  reversibly  cycle Li + and exhibit a stable areal capacity of 15 mAh cm -2 . This quarter, the focus of the team was to demonstrate the ability  of  the  MCAs  to  be  used  directly  as  current collectors for reversible lithium cycling while maintaining stability and preventing dendrite formation. In  addition  to  these  experimental  efforts,  they  also

## Electrochemistry of CFM-S Cathode

In  this  first  part  of  the  study,  research  work  was  focused  on  evaluating  the  electrochemical  performance of the CFM-S cathodes at higher C-rates in the standard electrolyte [1.0 M lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide,  2 wt% LiNO3  in  1,3-dioxolane (DOL) : 1,2-dimethoxyethane  (DME), 1:1 v/v].  The  CFM-S  cathode  mats  were  accordingly  prepared  by  simple  carbonization  of  electro-spun polymeric precursor followed by infusing sulfur into the CFMs by incipient wetting utilizing S-CS2 solution. The  process  briefly consisted of first  preparing  a  polymeric  mat  by  electrospinning  (e-spinning)  a 10% polyacrylonitrile (PAN) solution in dimethyl formamide solvent. E-spinning is used to create the fine fiber mats of a submicron diameter range from a polymer solution, and the characteristics of the mats can be tailored by modulating the e-spinning parameters. The e-spun PAN mat was then stabilized in an air atmosphere to induce cyclization of the polymeric chains followed by carbonization at 750Â°C in an inert atmosphere. The CFMs thus obtained were cut into the size of the electrode (1.26 cm 2 ) and were soaked in 10% S-CS2 solution to induce sulfur infusion and yield the CFM-S cathodes. Subsequently, these CFM-S cathodes were evaluated for their electrochemical performance utilizing the coin-cell configuration. The CFMs consisted of submicron size (&lt; 2 ï­ m) carbon fibers intertwined, forming a thick three-dimensional (3D) conducting carbon mat that was utilized as a binderless, free-standing sulfur confinement system. The binderless configuration offered by the CFM-S cathodes avoids the use of binder and solvent, thus bypassing the standard procedure of slurry coating  to  prepare  the  electrodes.  Moreover,  the  CFMs  are  electronically  conductive  and  exhibit  inherent N-doping in the carbon skeleton of the mats that can additionally serve to trap the Li-PSs and reduce their shuttling as well, thereby enhancing the overall electrochemical performance of the Li-S cells.

The  CFM-S  cathodes  with  a  range  of  areal  sulfur  loading  of  3.6-4.5 mg cm -2 were  assembled  in  coin-cell configuration and examined for their electrochemistry response in an electrolyte with a low electrolyte-to-sulfur ratio  of  5 ï­ L/mgsulfur.  Figure 1  shows the cycling performance of the Li-S coin cell utilizing the CFM-S as cathode with 3.6 mg cm -2 sulfur loading cycled at various current rates for 200 cycles. The cells were initially cycled at C/20 encompassing the formation cycles, which showed an initial specific capacity of 880 m Ah g -1 . After 10 cycles, the current rate was switched, and the cells were cycled at C/10 for the next 90 cycles. The specific capacity steadily increases after initial variation, possibly due to the electrolyte wetting issues, resulting in finally stabilizing the electrodes. After the stabilization of the CFM-S cathodes, the cells showed a specific capacity of ~ 1051 m Ah g -1 and exhibited stable cyclic performance. After 100 cycles at C/10 rate, the cells displayed  a  stable  reversible  capacity  of  ~  939 m Ah g -1 with  a  CE  of  99.8%,  exhibiting  an  extremely  low capacity fading of 0.1% per cycle. The cells show excellent redox reversibility with negligible PS shuttling, which can be attributed to the 3D carbon fiber structure and presence of N-moieties that serve to anchor the PSs and enhance their conversion to the desired redox species. The electrochemical performances of the cells were further evaluated at higher current rates (C/5) for another 100 cycles. At the higher C/5 rate, the cells showed an initial capacity of 864 m Ah g -1 and displayed stable cycling without any abrupt drop in capacity. The cells were thus cycled for 200 cycles at various current rates and still displayed a reversible specific capacity of 560 m Ah g -1 , demonstrating excellent cyclability of the CFM-S cathodes. Currently, efforts are under way to  incorporate  CFM  directly  onto  the  current  collectors  along  with  the  functional  electrocatalysts  (FECs) identified  by theoretical  computational modeling  and test  the  system  as  binderless  cathodes  with increased sulfur  loadings.  The  team  has  successfully  synthesized  the  FECs  that  were  identified  from  the  previously described computational studies. The FECs lower the activation energy of the rate-limiting step during the discharging  process  and  promote  faster  electro-kinetics  to  facilitate  maximum  utilization  of  sulfur  in  the CFM-S cathodes. The team is actively working on embedding the FECs within the CFMs; these findings will be reported in upcoming quarterly reports.

## Potential of PMCA3 Alloy as Current Collectors

As stated earlier, as a second component of the research work, the team also investigated the MCA system that serves  both  as  dendrite-free  anode  materials  and  as  current  collectors  to  enable  anode-free  testing  of  the Li-ion battery.  The  MCA  systems  are  structurally  isomorphous  to  lithium  metal  and  exhibit  a  similar body-centered  cubic  phase  with  optimal  interfacial  energy  that  prevents  lithium  dendrite  growth.  The

MCA systems  form  a  solid  solution  with  the  reacting  Li-ions  rather  than  simply  plating  over  it,  ensuring dendrite-free anode behavior.

The formation of a solid solution enables substantial lithium solubilization into the MCA alloy, causing minimal volume changes due to solid solution formation. This quarter, the team demonstrated the potential of a specific, MCA3 alloy to be used as the anode-free current collector for Li-S batteries. The MCA3 alloy was prepared by a simple and scalable high-energy ball-milling process.  The  electrochemical  performance  of  the synthesized MCA3  alloy was examined as an anode-free current collector using dense pellets in a coin-cell  configuration.  The  pellets  were  prepared by hot-pressing the 100% synthesized MCA3 alloy utilizing a pressure of 6750 psi and a temperature of 100Â°C for 5 hours to obtain dense pellets followed by their  electrochemical  testing,  as  shown  in Figure 2. The  dense  pellet  of  MCA3 alloy  (PMCA3)  with  a surface area of 1.32 cm 2 and areal loading of 137.8 mg cm -2 using Li-metal foil as the counter electrode was used  for  electrochemical  testing  utilizing  extremely lean  electrolyte  conditions  of  0.3 ï­ L/mg of  MCA3. A digital image  of the prepared dense pellet of PMCA3 is also presented in the inset of Figure 2. The PMCA3  cell  was  cycled  at  a  current  density  of 1 mA cm -2 with  an  areal  capacity  of  5 m Ah cm -2 . Figure 2  shows  the  electrochemical  performance  of the  PMCA3 cell displaying the  voltage  profiles  and cycling performance. The cells show a stable cycling

of Li-ions with reversible charge and discharge energy efficiency. The variations in the energy efficiency during initial cycles may be possibly due to SEI formation over the PMCA3 surface or the initial diffusion resistance for the Li-ions to form a solid solution with the MCA system. However, it should be noted that a stable SEI layer forms over PMCA3 after a few cycles, and thereafter, the cells exhibit a  CE of 100% for 193 cycles. The overpotential  of  the  cells  is  higher  in  the  initial  cycles  due  to  the  stable  SEI  formation,  which  reduces significantly after the initial stabilization cycles. The overpotential remains constant for more than 130 cycles and shows a negligible increase after 193 cycles. The PMCA3 cells therefore show excellent cycling stability as the cycled lithium forms a solid solution with the base current collector MCA composition at an optimal interfacial energy; further, the solid solution formation with the same crystallographic registry as lithium metal results in negligible volume change during cycling. These results thus highlight the potential of the MCA3 alloy to serve as dendrite-free current collectors, making it suitable for use in both prelithiated alloyed forms as well as part of an anode-free configuration in Li-containing systems functioning as cathodes. The MCA systems also possess  densities  over  50%  lower  than  conventional  copper  current  collectors,  making  them  appealing  as lightweight alternatives for current collectors. Studies are under way to overcome the initial diffusion barrier for Li-ion to form a solid solution and occupy the atomic sites in the PMCA3. Additionally, the team is also studying  the  Li-SIA  systems  to  be  used  as  anode  for  Li-S  batteries.  The  results  of  the  Li-SIA alloys  and PMCA3 as current collectors will be presented in upcoming quarterly reports.

## Effect of Electrolyte Additives on PS Solubility: Initial Computational Study

One approach to minimize the solubility of PSs in Li-S batteries would be identification of different electrolyte additives with the capability to suppress or, at least, to hinder rapid dissolution of PSs in the electrolyte during electrochemical  cycling.  For  these  purposes,  a  computational  study  was  conducted  along  the  lines  of Zhang et al. [1] that was initiated last quarter. The computational work took into consideration a model system containing DME/DOL solvent mixture that was used in all the experimental studies in Li-S batteries along with Li2S6, which is the most typical PS species encountered in the Li-S batteries.

The results obtained last quarter will be compared with those achieved this quarter to maintain continuity and facilitate  better  understanding  of  the  studies  conducted,  which  includes  the  computational  results  for determining  the  solubility  of  two  additional  but  typically  known  PSs,  namely,  Li2S4  and  Li2S8.  For  these calculations,  the  following  two-step  mechanisms  of  PS  dissociation  have  been  adopted:  (1)  formation  of individual species of Li + and LiSm -,  and (2) further dissociation of LiSm -into Li + and Sm 2(m = 4, 6, and 8 considered as the polysulfide order).

Thus, the solvation Gibbs free energy of species X (Li + , Li2Sm, LiSm -, Sm 2) in DOL and DME are determined as: Î”G*(X) = Î”GÂ°[X(DME/DOL)n] + Î”G*[X(DME/DOL)n] + nÎ”Gvap(DME/DOL), where Î”Gvap(DME/DOL) is the vaporization energies of DME and DOL available in the literature and n = number of solvent molecules in the cluster-continuum solvation method implemented in the Gaussian 09 software.

From the generally accepted point of view, the following thermodynamic convention has been utilized: a larger negative value would indicate the higher stability for the particular species in consideration, and therefore, correspondingly, would be indicative of higher solubility of the particular species in the specific solvent.

The calculated  solvation  energies  of  the  various PS  species  dissociated in  DME  and  DOL  are  collected  in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. It can be seen and construed from Table 1 that for Li2S6 PS, Li + and S6 2are very stable  species  resulting  from  the  dissociation  of  Li2S6;  thus,  they  are  the  most  prevalent  components  in DME solvent compared to other possible species, namely molecular Li2S6 and LiS6 -ions. Similar results were obtained for the dissolution of Li2S6 in DOL solvent, although the stabilities are to different extents. Compared to the calculated Gibbs free energy values, obtained for the DME solvent, the corresponding solvation energies

calculated for all the identical possible individual components of Li2S6 in the DOL solvent are much lower, indicating  lower  stability  for  all  the  individual  species  and,  therefore,  reflecting  an  inferior  dissolution  of Li2S6 in DOL solvent, although Li + and S6 2are still the predominant species prevalent in comparison to the molecular species of Li2S6 and LiS6 -,  respectively. These results taken collectively confirm that DME is the main solvent in the DME/DOL electrolyte mixture that is favorable for PS dissolution compared to DOL; thus, identification of an optimal ratio of DME/DOL would be beneficial from the PS dissolution point of view for evaluation in the experimental studies.

In addition, following the literature work [2] the team wanted to clarify whether Li2S4 or Li2S8 PSs are more stable in the electrolyte compared to the abovementioned Li2S6 species. This quarter, the team thus calculated the free energies of solvation of the different possible species resulting from the dissolution of Li2S4 or Li2S8 PSs in  DME/DOL solvent. Following similar calculations, it can be gleaned from Tables 1 and 2 that similar to Li2S6,  considered  previously,  Li2S4  and  Li2S8  PSs  are  also  dissociated  into  the  most  stable  and  prevalent components  of  Li + and  S4 2or  S 8 2in  both  DME  and  DOL  solvents.  It  is  also  important  to  notice  that  in DME solvent S8 2is more stable than S6 2, while S4 2is less stable in the solution than both S6 2and S8 2. The same trend is observed in the DOL solvent, although to a lower extent in line with DOL representing a solvent exhibiting inferior dissolution of PS species compared to DME.

Considering  the  above-described  energetics  of  S4 2,  S 6 2,  and  S8 2species  and  possible  disproportionation reaction of 2S6 2-â†’ S 4 2+ S8 2it  can  be seen that Î”G* for this reaction in DME and DOL is -4.25 kcal/mol and -3.44 kcal/mol, correspondingly. Due to the small energy values in both DME and DOL, an experimental detection of the simultaneous presence of S4 2, S6 2, and S8 2species in the electrolyte may therefore be difficult, which is also reported in the literature, corroborating the theoretical findings reported here. [2]

The next step of the present computation study will be consideration of various electrolyte additives to modify and passivate the anode and cathode electrodes (that is, the use of various chemical additives in the electrolytes that serve as electron donors with the promising potential to stabilize the lithium anode and the sulfur cathode) and study their corresponding effects on the solubility of PS species during the electrochemical cycling. The results of these studies will be reported in subsequent quarterly reports.

## Task 5.8 -Development of Lithium-Sulfur Battery Cells with High Energy Density and Long Cycling Life (Donghai Wang, Pennsylvania State University)

Objective. The project objective is to develop a new soluble-polysulfide-free sulfur cathode with a high sulfur content (&gt; 50 wt%) and high discharge specific capacity (&gt; 700 mAh g -1 ,  based  on  the  weight  of  the  whole cathode), and to demonstrate performance of the sulfur electrode at high electrode capacity (&gt; 7 mAh cm -2 ), low N/P ratio [&lt; 2; that is, capacity ratio between anode (negative electrode) and cathode (positive electrode)], and  low  electrolyte-to-sulfur  (E/S)  ratio  (&lt; 2.5 Î¼L mg -1 ).  Prototype  Li-S  pouch  cells  with  predicted  energy density  of  400 Wh kg -1 and  80%  capacity  retention  for  over  300 cycles  using  conventional  electrolyte  and Li-metal anodes with a protective layer developed by the team will be demonstrated.

Impact. This project aims to develop new sulfur composite active materials and functional polymer binders that enable polysulfide-free, high-performance, low-cost sulfur cathode. The use of these high-performance and low-cost sulfur cathodes, in turn, enables Li-S batteries with high energy density and long cycle life. Such Li-S batteries,  made  using  the  developed  cathodes  paired  with  a  Li-metal  anode,  can  lead  to  50% greater energy density  than  conventional  Li-ion batteries.  Meeting  the  technical  targets  will  potentially  develop high-energy-density  lithium  batteries,  promote  increased  adoption  of  electric  vehicles  (EVs)  and  plug-in hybrid EVs,  and  reduce  petroleum  consumption  in  the  transportation  sector  by  helping  battery-powered vehicles become accepted by consumers as a reliable source of transportation.

Approach. The overall approach will focus on synthesizing and optimizing a novel polysulfide-free sulfur composite active  material  and  functional  binders. Specifically,  approaches  to  realize  the  project  objectives include the following: (1) development  of  novel  polysulfide-free sulfur composite  active materials, (2) development  of  new  functional  polymer  binders  to  facilitate  Li + transport  and  trap  residual  lithium polysulfide;  and  (3)  diagnostics,  characterization,  theoretical  simulation,  and  cell  tests  on  the  developed materials in Li-S batteries.

Out-Year Goals. The out-year goals are as follows: (1) develop new sulfur composite active materials, and (2) conduct  characterization,  simulation,  and  performance  tests  on  material  and  electrode  levels.  The Go/No-Go Decision will  be  demonstration  of  Li-S  batteries  using  the  developed  sulfur  composite  active materials with an initial discharge specific capacity &gt; 600 mAh g -1 (based on cathode weight) at an areal capacity of 4 mAh cm -2 and E/S ratio &lt; 8 Î¼L mg -1 .

Collaborations. Pennsylvania State University will collaborate with the University of Illinois, Chicago, on theoretical simulation.

## Progress Report

This quarter, based on the team's previously optimized sulfur polymerized composite (SPC) derived active material and electrolytes for Li-S batteries, they developed and explored the electrochemical properties of a new  generation  of  sulfur  cathode  materials  denoted  as  SPC-2.  With  previously  optimized  carbonate-based electrolyte,  they  demonstrated  the  polysulfide-free  SPC-2  cathodes  with  an  initial  discharge  capacity  over 850 mAh g -1 (based on cathode weight) at current density of 200 mA g -1 under E/S ratio of 5. Moreover, to gain insights into the failure mechanism of sulfurized polyacrylonitrile (SPAN) cathode that is similar to their SPC-2, they conducted  X-ray  photoelectron spectroscopy  analysis for the  deeply  cycled  SPAN cathodes  in carbonate-based  electrolyte.  They  are  first  working  on  characterization  of  the  failure  mechanism  of  cycled SPAN materials.

They aimed to explore the dependence of the chemical composition evolution on the decayed electrochemical performances of SPAN cathode materials in carbonate-based electrolyte because it is important to the further optimization of high-performing, polysulfide-free SPC cathode materials. As shown in Figure 1a for the pristine SPAN cathode material sample, both the carbon 1s and sulfur 2p spectra suggest that the sulfur species were mainly accommodated in the sulfur cathode materials in forms of S-S/S-C groups (163.2/164.4 eV). The small amount of oxidized sulfur (167.2/168.4 eV) was observed in the sulfur 2p spectra, probably correlated to the pyrolysis procedure during the preparation. While after being cycled for over 750 cycles in the carbonate-based electrolytes, the SPAN cathode showed a severe capacity decay, and the capacity retention was below 30%. As shown in Figure 1b for the cycled SPAN cathode material sample, in contrast to the pristine SPAN sample, both the carbon 1s and sulfur 2p spectra indicated that most of the S-S/S-C groups irreversibly disappeared. This is probably  because  the  rearrangement  of  sulfur  species  on  charge  leads  to  formation  of  unbound  high-order lithium polysulfides in SPAN, which were then consumed by their reaction with the carbonate electrolyte.

## Summary

The Task objective is to develop rechargeable Li-O2 batteries with long-term cycling stability through in-depth research  on more  stable  electrolytes  and  highly  efficient  catalysts  for  air  electrodes,  protection  of  Li-metal anodes, and deeper understanding on the oxygen reduction reaction and oxygen evolution reaction mechanisms behind the electrochemical performance of Li-O2 cells.

## Highlights

The highlights for this quarter are as follows:

- The Argonne National Laboratory (ANL) team found that a Li-O2 battery can achieve 635 cycles (with a cut-off  voltage  of  4.0  V)  using  LiAl / reduced  graphene  oxide  (rGO)  as  the  catalyst  and  an  electrolyte composed of tetraglyme, lithium triflate, and the ionic liquid (IL) 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (EMIM-BF4). Without IL, LiAl/rGO still displayed good cyclability (460 cycles with a higher cut-off voltage of 4.6 V), although the overpotential was much larger than that with IL for the whole battery. These results illustrate that the IL probably protects the surface of LiAl that can be oxidized by purging with O2 gas.
- The ANL / University of Illinois, Chicago (UIC) team investigated the reaction pathways for LiO2 formation  by  density  functional  theory.  On  an  Ir-terminated  IrSnS3.6(100)  surface,  O2  binds  on  a di-iridium sulfur bridge site with a free energy of -1.85 eV. The formation of LiO2 is very exothermic with a reaction-free energy of -3.45 eV from adsorbed O2 on an Ir-terminated (100) surface. The formation of Li2O2 via LiO2 disproportionation is not favorable on three of the four surfaces, while the fourth surface is likely to be passivated as O2 dissociates.
- The UIC team synthesized a new Cu-based mid-entropy of a transition-metal-carbide catalyst and used it in a Li-CO2 battery system under an extremely pure CO2 atmosphere. The cells were able to operate for up to  1300 cycles  with  a  charge  potential  below  4.0 V.  Product  characterization  revealed  formation  of Li2CO3 during  discharge,  while  the  optimized  amount  of  redox  mediator  facilitates  creation  of  a solid-electrolyte interphase layer that promotes the long life of the battery. Structural and computational studies are under way for investigation of the reaction mechanisms.

## TASK 6 -LITHIUM-AIR BATTERIES

## Team Lead: Ji-Guang Zhang, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory

## Task 6.1 -Lithium-Air Batteries

(Khalil Amine and Larry A. Curtiss; Argonne National Laboratory)

Objective. This project will develop new cathode materials and electrolytes for Li-air batteries for long cycle life, high capacity, and high efficiency. The goal is to obtain critical insight that will provide information on the charge and discharge processes in Li-air batteries to enable new advances to be made in their performance. This will be done using state-of-the-art characterization techniques combined with state-of-the-art computational methodologies to understand and design new materials and electrolytes for Li-air batteries.

Impact. The  instability  of  current  nonaqueous  electrolytes  and  degradation  of  cathode  materials  limits performance of Li-air batteries. The project impact will be to develop new electrolytes and cathode materials that are stable and can increase energy density of electrical energy storage systems based on lithium.

Approach. The  project  is  using  a  joint  theoretical/experimental  approach  for  design  and  discovery  of  new cathode and electrolyte materials that act synergistically to reduce charge overpotentials and increase cycle life. Synthesis methods, in combination with design principles developed from computations, are used to make new cathode  architectures.  Computational  studies  are  used  to  help  understand  decomposition  mechanisms  of electrolytes and how to design electrolytes with improved stability. The new cathodes and electrolytes are tested in Li-O2 cells. Characterization, along with theory, is used to understand the performance of materials used in the cell and to make improved materials.

Out-Year Goals. The out-year goals are to find catalysts that promote discharge product morphologies that reduce charge potentials and to find electrolytes for long cycle life through testing and design.

Collaborations. This project is engaged in collaboration with K. C. Lau (University of California, Norridge) and with K. Glusac and R. Shahbazian-Yassar (University of Illinois, Chicago).

X-ray diffraction  (XRD)  analysis  for the  Li-O2  cell with and without the IL has been carried out to characterize the discharge product. ## Task 6.2 -Lithium Oxygen Battery Design and Predictions (Larry A. Curtiss / Anh Ngo, Argonne National Laboratory; Amin Salehi-Khojin, University of Illinois, Chicago)

Objective. The project objective is to develop new materials for Li-O2 batteries that give longer cycle life and improved efficiencies in an air environment. New electrolyte blends and additives will be investigated that can reduce clogging and at the same time promote the cathode functionality needed to reduce charge overpotentials. New cathode and anode materials will be investigated that can work in conjunction with the electrolytes to improve cycle life in the presence of air components.

Impact. Li-air batteries are considered  as  a  potential  alternative  to Li-ion batteries for  transportation applications due to their high theoretical specific energy. The major issues with the existing Li-O2 systems include  degradation  of  the  anode  electrode,  reactions  with  air  components,  clogging  of  the  cathode,  and electrolyte instability. Thus, this project is using a comprehensive approach to improve cycle life and efficiency through developing new materials for electrodes, anodes, and electrolytes that work in synergy.

Approach. The experimental strategy is to use cathode materials based on two-dimensional transition metal (TM)  dichalcogenides  that  the  team  has  found  to  be  among  the  best  oxygen  reduction  reaction  / oxygen evolution  reaction  catalysts.  These  cathode  materials  will  be  combined  with  new  electrolyte  blends  and additives that work in synergy to reduce charge potentials and increase stability of the Li-air system. Density functional theory (DFT) and ab initio molecular dynamics simulations are used to gain insight at the electronic structure level of theory of the electrolyte structure, and function both in bulk and at interfaces with the cathode, anode, and discharge product. The team is using classical molecular dynamics to obtain understanding at longer length and time scales of processes occurring in the electrolyte and growth mechanisms of discharge products. They will also utilize a high-throughput (HT) screening strategy based on experiment and theory to develop a large  database  of  properties  and  outcomes  of  electrolyte  combinations  that  can  be  analyzed  using  machine learning to predict electrolytes and additives with the best performance.

Out-Year Goals. The out-year goals are to find electrolytes that give high capacities and long cycle life in an air atmosphere using HT screening.

Collaborations. This project engages in collaboration with R. Assary, J. G. Wen, and S. Tepavcevic of Argonne National  Laboratory;  B. Narayanan  of  University  of  Louisville;  T. Li  of  Northern  Illinois  University;  and F. Khalili-Araghi and R. Klie of University of Illinois, Chicago.

## Progress Report

Li-air batteries are considered strong candidates for high-energy-density storage systems for electric vehicles. However, high charge potentials and low current rates are two major drawbacks that hinder these batteries from actual use as batteries. These issues necessitate discovery of novel electrocatalytic processes to significantly enhance the formation and decomposition of the products during battery cycling. The team synthesized a new porous dichalcogenide catalyst with bridging TM active sites. Iridium was chosen as the TM as its nanoparticles have  previously  been  shown  to  be  effective  in  producing  LiO2  as  a  discharge  product  with  a  low  charge potential.  The  performance  of  this material  for  use  in  Li-O2  batteries  was  studied  and  found to  result  in  a LiO2 discharge product with good cycling performance at a high current density and high capacities. This was reported  previously  along  with  computational  studies of  the  structure  of the  bulk  and  surfaces  likely  to  be involved in the discharge and charging of the cells to be used for further modeling of the reaction mechanisms. This quarter, the team presents the results of DFT studies of the reaction mechanism occurring on the surfaces of the new IrSnS3.6 catalyst used in the Li-O2 batteries. The calculations reveal a new mechanism for formation of LiO2 that involves a di-iridium sulfur bridge (DISB) site where O2 is strongly bound for oxygen reduction and that results in strongly bound LiO2 preventing disproportionation from being energetically favorable.

The team investigated by DFT the reaction pathways for LiO2 formation through one (Li + + e -) transfer and Li2O2 production via either LiO2 disproportionation or the second (Li + + e -) transfer to LiO2 on four surfaces of IrSnS3.6.  The  reaction  free  energies  were  calculated  to  determine  whether  LiO2  or  Li2O2  formation  will  be favored.  The  adsorption  energies  of  O2,  LiO2,  and  Li2O2  were  calculated  on  both  Sn-terminated  and Ir-terminated  IrSnS3.6(100)  surfaces  to  get  the  free  energy  of  each  step.  On  an  Ir-terminated  IrSnS3.6(100) surface, O2 binds on a DISB site with a free energy of -1.85 eV (see Figure 1a). Due to the strong adsorption of the O2 bond, length increases from 1.23 angstroms in the gas phase molecule to 1.38 angstroms in the adsorbed molecule.  The  most  stable  adsorption  geometry  of  LiO2  indicates  that  the  DISB sites  are  highly  favorable adsorption sites for this species, as well (see Figure 1b). A close-up structure of O2 on the DISB site is shown in Figure 1d. A close-up structure of LiO2 on the site is shown in Figure 1e from a different perspective. The formation  of  LiO2  is  very  exothermic,  with  a  reaction-free  energy  of  -3.45  eV  from  adsorbed  O2  on  an Ir-terminated (100) surface. Due to the strong LiO2 adsorption at the DISB site, Li2O2 formation (Figure 1c) is not favorable either by LiO2 disproportionation, which is uphill by 3.51 eV, or by a subsequent (Li + + e -) transfer reaction  to  form  Li2O2,  which  is  slightly  uphill,  as  shown  in  the  energy  profile  in  Figure  1f.  A  schematic illustrating the involvement of the DISB site in the LiO2 reaction is shown in Figure 1g.

The  surface  reaction  calculations  on  IrSnS3.6(100)  surfaces  demonstrate  that  the  formation  of  Li2O2  via LiO2 disproportionation is not favorable on three of the four surfaces, and thus the reaction is likely to stop at LiO2 on those surfaces. The fourth surface is likely to be passivated as O2 dissociates. The disproportionation to Li2O2 is unfavorable because of the strong binding of LiO2 on the DISB sites of IrSnS3.6. Since the surface sites will likely all get covered with LiO2, the continued growth of LiO2 in the absence of open DISB sites probably occurs because of the formation of an LiO2 structure that promotes continued LiO2 growth. The team has investigated the reason for the reactivity of the DISB site that suppresses LiO2 disproportionation. Iridium metal is known to react strongly with O2 and cause dissociation. However, the d-band center of iridium in IrSnS3.6 is -1.67 eV, which is higher than metallic iridium (-2.11 eV), so that nondissociative O2 adsorption does not  occur  on  the  DISB  sites.  The  effectiveness  of  the  DISB  sites  for  LiO2  growth  over  Li2O2  growth  can probably be attributed to the Sabatier principle, with appropriate O2 binding strength on the IrSnS3.6 surface instead of too strong O2 binding, which would result in dissociative adsorption, and too weak O2 (and LiO2) binding, which would result in the disproportionation of LiO2 to Li2O2.
