## Task 6.3 -Development of a High-Rate Lithium-Air Battery Using a Gaseous CO2 Reactant (Amin Salehi-Khojin, University of Illinois, Chicago)

Objective. The  main  objective  of  this  project  is  to  develop  a  novel  strategy  to  enable  operation  of Li-CO2 batteries at high capacity and high rate with a long cycle life. The experiments will be performed in both Swagelok and pouch cells. In the former case, the team will use: (1) a novel co-catalyst system comprised of inexpensive and earth-abundant transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) materials that work in synergy with ionic liquid (IL) - based electrolytes to enhance efficiency of reactions during discharge and charge processes, (2)  a  solution-based  catalyst  (redox  mediator,  or  RM)  to  reduce  charge  overpotential  and  increase  energy efficiency  of  the  battery,  (3)  high-porosity  cathode  electrodes  to  increase  electrode  surface  area,  gas permeability,  stability,  electrical  conductivity,  and  lifetime  of  battery  operation,  and  (4)  solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer to protect the anode against oxidation without affecting the ionic transport of Li + species in the system. At the pouch-cell level, the team will design and construct a stackable pouch cell to deliver a capacity of &gt; 200 mAh.

Impact. Li-air batteries are considered  as  a  potential  alternative  to Li-ion batteries for  transportation applications due to their high theoretical specific energy. Most work in this area focuses on use of O2 as the reactant. However, newer concepts for using gaseous reactants (such as CO2, which has a theoretical specific energy  density  of  1,876 Wh/kg)  provide  opportunities  for  further  exploration.  This  project  will  produce  a thorough understanding of key chemical and electronic parameters that govern the operation of Li-CO2 batteries in  realistic  conditions.  Achieving  the  project  objectives  will  generate  a library  of  fundamental  properties  of TMD- and IL-based electrolytes with the most promise for Li-CO2 battery applications. The methodologies employed, and the insight generated, will also be valuable beyond advancing the field of Li-CO2 batteries.

Approach. The above targets will be achieved through an integrated approach based on materials synthesis, testing, characterization, analysis, and computation. The team will synthesize catalysts and test them in cells along with developing new electrolytes and additives. These cathode materials with new electrolyte blends and additives will work in synergy to reduce charge potentials and increase  battery stability. Density functional theory (DFT) and ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations will be performed to understand battery operation and make predictions of new materials for the Li-CO2 battery.

Out-Year Goals. The out-year goals are to find novel two-dimensional catalysts and IL-based electrolytes that give high capacities and long cycle life in a CO2 atmosphere.

Collaborations. This project collaborates with L. A. Curtiss (Argonne National Laboratory), F. Khalili-Araghi (University of Illinois, Chicago, or UIC), A. Subramanian (UIC), and Z. Huang (Stockholm University).

## Milestones

1. Testing  and  analysis  of  four  synthesized  alloy  catalysts  in  a  Swagelok  cell  with  CO2  as  reactant.  (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Stability of TMD alloys in presence of electrolyte. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed).
3. Characterization of a Li-CO2 battery using selected TMD alloys by experiment and computations. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed).
4. Evaluation of four RMs for use with catalysts. (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

Previously, the team reported the effect of the type of chalcogenide (tellurium versus sulfur) on the electronic and catalytic properties of the catalysts (Sb0.67Bi1.33X3). Further characterization of the Li-CO2 battery with transmission electron microscopy (TEM), electron energy loss spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) and Raman spectroscopy, revealed that the product is Li2CO3 and carbon, formed from a four-electron reaction. DFT and AIMD studies were used to provide insight into the role of the IL (1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate, or EMIM-BF4) used in the electrolyte. It  was  found  that  a  coupled  cation-electron  charge  transfer  process  facilitates  the  carbon  dioxide  reduction reaction and that the concentration of IL in the electrolyte controls the number of participating CO2 molecules in reactions. The combination of these key factors was found to be crucial for successful operation of the Li-CO2 battery  at  a  high  current  rate  of  1 mA/cm 2 for  up  to  220 cycles.  A  submitted  publication  on  this  work  is under review.

This quarter, a new Cu-based mid-entropy catalyst was synthesized by a chemical vapor transport technique. The catalyst was exfoliated using probe sonication and then coated on carbon cloth cathode. A Switchlok cell was used for the battery cycling experiments, as it allows better control of gaseous reactant. More specifically, assembly of the cells was performed inside a glovebox, which was then followed by direct purging with pure CO2 gas,  thus  ensuring  the  absence  of  any  air/O2  traces  in  the  cells.  As  preliminary  experiments,  various electrolyte blends were tested using different ILs such as 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium nitrate (EMIM-NO3), EMIM-BF4,  and  1-methyl-3-octylimidazolium  hexafluorophosphate  (OMIM-PF6).  The  results  showed  that EMIM-BF4 gives marginally better cycling stability, so it was chosen for the subsequent experiments. Also, tests with different SnI2 RM concentrations were performed, revealing that the optimum RM concentration is at 0.008M.

To  determine  the  electrochemical  behavior  of  the  catalyst,  cyclic  voltammetry  (CV)  and  linear  sweep voltammetry (LSV) experiments were performed. The CV plot in Figure 1a shows the catalyst redox peaks at 2.38 V and 3.52 V, respectively, indicating the reversible reduction and oxidation reactions. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements in Figure 1b depict the charge transfer resistance

To  investigate  the  performance  of  the  new  catalyst, galvanostatic  cycling  experiments  were  carried  out  in  a  Switchlok-type  cell  under  pure CO2.  As  seen  in Figure 1c, the battery was able to operate for 1300 cycles at current density of 0.2 mA/cm 2 and capacity of 0.1 mAh/cm 2 .  Furthermore,  it  could  operate  up  to  500  cycles  for  current  densities  of  0.2  mA/cm 2 and 0.4 mA/cm 2 at the capacity of 0.2 mAh/cm 2 (Figure 1d/e). On all occasions, the charge potential never exceeded the value of 4.0 V, which matches the project objective this year. It is worth noting that, comparatively, at current  density  of  0.2  mA/cm 2 and  capacity  of  0.2  mAh/cm 2 ,  the  battery  without  SnI2  could  only  last  for ~ 200 cycles. However, the charge and discharge potentials were similar to those of the battery with SnI2. This indicates  that  SnI2  does  not  have  the  traditional  role  of  RM  in  reducing  the  charge  potential,  but  rather participates in formation of an SEI layer that protects the lithium anode and extends the life of the battery. Figure 1f shows the consistency of the battery when applying different current densities (from 0.1 mA/cm 2 to 0.4 mA/cm 2 and then back to the initial value) at the capacity of 0.4 mAh/cm 2 . No significant voltage deviation was  observed  after  26  hours  of  battery  operation  at  different  current  densities,  which  demonstrates  the robustness of the cathode and electrolyte pair during the process.

To identify the discharge products, a wide range of characterization techniques was utilized including X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectroscopy. The XRD patterns performed at different cycles (Figure 2a) reveal formation  of  Li2CO3  (PDF  #22-1141)  during  discharge  and  its  decomposition  during  charge.  Additionally, Raman spectroscopy was performed using nickel foam cathodes to eliminate the background presence of carbon (Figure 2b). The results after discharge reveal peaks located at 1088 cm -1 corresponding to Li2CO3, as well as at 1335 cm -1 and 1560 cm -1 corresponding to D and G carbon, respectively. After charge, no relevant peaks are found, verifying decomposition of the discharge products and reversibility of the process. To rule out a parasitic electrochemical  reactions  effect  induced  by  the  electrolyte,  discharge  product  characterization  was  also performed under argon atmosphere. As shown in Figure 2c, there are no Li2CO3 related peaks detected after discharge. To further elucidate the reaction mechanism, DEMS was employed. The results in Figure 2d reveal that only CO2 is detected as gaseous product during charge process (no CO or O2), which is consistent with formation Li2CO3 through the mechanism:

Electrolyte  stability  throughout  the  battery  cycling  was  also  evaluated  using  nuclear  magnetic  resonance spectroscopy.  As  seen  in  Figure 2e,  the  electrolyte  peaks  remain  unchanged  even  after  500 cycles,  which definitely has a major contribution to the long-term efficiency of the battery. The electrochemical redox stability of the electrolyte was also determined by LSV experiment (Figure 2f), where it is evident that there are no peaks related to the reaction of electrolyte within the region of 1 V to 4.5 V. The two peaks located at 3.8 V and 4.25 V  are  attributed  to  the  SnI2  and  specifically  the  I -/I 3 -(reversible)  and  I3 -/I2  (irreversible)  transitions, respectively. In fact, only the I -/I 3 -transition is observed inside the working voltage range of this work (below 4 V), which is important for the reversibility of the reactions that occur within the anode-electrolyte-cathode assembly. These results further verify that there are no parasitic electrochemical reactions; thus, the catalytic activity can be solely attributed to the reaction of CO2.

The  SEI  layer  formed  on  the  anode  surface  at  different  cycles  was  analyzed  with  X-ray  photoelectron spectroscopy; results are shown in Figure 3a-c. In the tin spectrum, two major peaks were observed at 486.4 eV (tin  3d5/2)  and  494.8  eV (tin  3d3/2),  attributed  to Sn-O  bond.  The  peak  observed in  the oxygen spectrum at 531.7 eV, also implies the existence of Sn-O bond. Finally, no peaks were detected in the iodine spectrum, which  indicates  protection  of  the  anode  due  to  the  tin  layer.  To  further  verify  the  SEI  layer  formation, EIS measurements were performed at different cycles (0, 5, 10, 20, 50). As evident in Figure 3d, the Rct values of the battery increase during cycling, reaching ~ 121 â„¦ after 50 cycles, which indicates the gradual formation of the protective SEI layer on the anode.

The structure and morphology of the catalyst is also being studied. Due to complicated characteristics of the mid-entropy catalyst, thorough TEM investigation under different angles as well as XRD simulations are under way. These results will be used by the computational group for the DFT calculations to clarify the reaction pathways and mechanisms.

In summary, a new Cu-based mid-entropy of transition-metal carbide catalyst was synthesized and used in a Li-CO2 battery  system  under  extremely  pure  CO2  atmosphere.  The  cells  were  able  to  operate  for  up  to 1300 cycles with a charge potential below 4.0 V. Product characterization revealed formation of Li2CO3 during discharge, while the optimized amount of RM facilitates creation of an SEI layer that promotes long life of the battery. Structural and computational studies are under way for investigation of the reaction mechanisms.

## Summary

Sodium-ion batteries require investigations to identify optimal electrode materials, electrolytes, separators, and binders  to  reach  full  potential.  The  BMR  program  will  therefore  have  a  dedicated  effort  directed  toward identifying Na-ion battery materials that have potential value for vehicle applications. Progress on these projects this quarter is described in this report.

## Highlights

The highlights for this quarter are as follows:

- The Argonne National Laboratory team developed and applied an AlF3 coating onto the prototype cathode material,  P2-Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2,  via  an  atomic  layer  deposition  process.  The  electrochemical  stability (between 2.0 V and 4.3 V versus sodium metal) was increased, and capacity retention was improved from 45% loss to only 15% loss over 30 cycles.
- The Brookhaven National Laboratory team successfully completed the in situ x-ray diffraction and ex situ soft x-ray absorption spectroscopy for P3-Na0.75Li0.08Cu0.25Mn0.66O2 to understand its structural evolution, redox mechanism, and surface chemistry during electrochemical cycling.
- The Lawrence  Berkeley  National  Laboratory team  discovered  that  sodium  nonatitanate  shows  better thermal stability when heated to 700Â°C in argon, compared to air atmosphere. On the 2 nd cycle, this material gives a capacity of &gt; 200 mAh/g.
- The Pacific Northwest National Laboratory team has studied the mechanism of sodium stripping/plating on different current collectors as well as the  solid-electrolyte interphase / cathode-electrolyte interphase on the anode/Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode using in situ transmission electron microscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy.

## TASK 7 -SODIUM-ION BATTERIES

## Team Lead: Xiao-Qing Yang, Brookhaven National Laboratory

## Task 7.1 -Exploratory Studies of Novel Sodium-Ion Battery Systems (Xiao-Qing Yang and Enyuan Hu, Brookhaven National Laboratory)

Objective. To meet the challenges of powering plug-in hybrid electric vehicles and battery electric vehicles, new rechargeable battery systems with high energy and power density, low cost, good abuse tolerance, and long calendar and cycle life need to be developed. The primary objective of this project is to develop new advanced synchrotron-based  material  characterization  techniques  and  apply  these  techniques  to  study  the  new rechargeable  battery  systems  beyond  the  Li-ion batteries,  namely  the  Na-ion battery  systems  for  electric vehicles (EVs).

Impact. The results of this project will be used for developing technologies that will significantly increase the energy density and cycle life and reduce the cost of beyond Li-ion battery systems. This will greatly accelerate deployment of EVs and reduce carbon emission associated with fossil fuel consumption and will help in the direction of building U. S.-based energy storage manufacture chains.

Approach. This project will use synchrotron-based in situ X-ray diagnostics such as in situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) and in situ X-ray absorption (XAS) tools, combined with transmission electron microscopy, scanning transmission  electron  microscopy,  and  transmission  X-ray  microscopy  imaging  techniques  developed  at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) to evaluate the new materials and redox couples to obtain in-depth understanding  of  the  reaction  mechanisms  of  these  materials,  aiming  to  improve  existing  materials  and  to provide guidance for new materials and new technology development for Na-ion battery systems.

Out-Year Goals. The out-year goal is to complete synchrotron-based XRD, XAS, and resonant inelastic X-ray scattering (RIXS) studies of new cathode materials of P3-type Na0.75Li0.08Cu0.25Mn0.66O2 for Na-ion batteries.

Collaborations. The  BNL  team  has  been  closely  working  with  top  scientists  on  new  material  synthesis at Argonne National Laboratory, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, and Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, with U. S. industrial collaborators at General Motors and Johnson Controls, and with international collaborators.

## Milestones

1. Complete  electrochemical  characterization  of  P3-type  Na0.75Li0.08Cu0.25Mn0.66O2  cathode  material.  (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Complete in situ hard XAS  studies  on  P3-type Na0.75Li0.08Cu0.25Mn0.66O2 to investigate the charge compensation mechanism and local structural changes. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Complete in  situ XRD  and ex  situ soft  XAS  (sXAS)  studies  on  P3-type  Na0.75Li0.08Cu0.25Mn0.66O2  to understand the evolution of structure and interphase during cycling. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Complete ex situ RIXS studies on P3-type Na0.75Li0.08Cu0.25Mn0.66O2 to study the oxygen redox behavior in this material. (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

The milestone for this quarter is complete. In previous quarters, the team used a series of characterization tools to identify the charge compensation mechanism below 4.1 V for P3-Na0.75Li0.08Cu0.25Mn0.66O2. This quarter, they used resonant inelastic X-ray scattering mapping (mRIXS) to study the redox mechanism above 4.1 V. Hard XAS is the conventional tool for studying redox mechanism, and the copper K-edge XAS data are shown in Figure 1a. They indicate that the spectrum of the 4.1 V sample is almost the same as that of the 4.6 V sample. This suggests the high-voltage redox is complicated and may not be based on the copper cations. An alternative tool such as sXAS was employed for characterization. For sXAS, the data in total electron yield (TEY) mode is surface-sensitive and therefore not capable of revealing the redox mechanism in the bulk. In contrast, the sXAS in total fluorescence yield (TFY) mode can probe the bulk region and therefore is a more suitable tool than TEY in studying the redox mechanism. In TFY data, a clear difference is noticed between the spectrum of the 4.1 V sample and that of the 4.6 V sample. Compared with the spectrum of the 4.1 V sample, there is a clear enhancement in fluorescence yield at ~ 531 eV in the spectrum of the 4.6 V sample. In TFY mode, only the number of emitted photons is counted; further, the kinetic energies of those photons are not recorded. As a result, the obtained information is limited and may not facilitate deciphering complicated redox mechanisms. A more advanced technique, mRIXS, which registers the kinetic energy of each emitted photon, provides much richer information and is proven to be an effective tool in studying complicated redox mechanisms in battery materials. Through collaborating with scientists from Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, the mRIXS experiment is done at the Advanced Light Source; results are shown in Figure 1c. The vertical axis corresponds  to  the  excitation  energy,  which  has  the  same  meaning  and  the  same  range  as  that  used  for sXAS studies. The horizontal axis corresponds to the kinetic energy of emitted photons. The color contour indicates the number of photons at each coordinate on the two-dimensional mapping (with specific excitation energy and specific emission energy). Brown is the strongest, followed by yellow, green, and blue. Clearly, when the excitation energy is ~ 531 eV, a sharp emission feature at 523.5 eV is distinguished at an excitation energy of 531 eV in mRIXS. Based on previous theoretical calculations in the literature report, the enhanced emission in this energy region originates from decay channels that are caused by the oxidation of oxygen anions. Such a feature can also be clearly seen in Figure 1d, which integrates the energy-dependent photon emission spectra at excitation energy ~ 531 eV. This is the reason there is an enhancement in the TFY spectrum of the 4.6 V sample.

Based on studies in FY 2023, the team can conclude that the redox mechanism in P3-Na0.75Li0.08Cu0.25Mn0.66O2 is based on both copper and oxygen. Below 4.1 V, it is the copper redox corresponding to Cu 2+ to Cu 3+ , with the possible forming of Zhang-Rice Singlet, as explained in the previous quarter's report. Above 4.1 V, it is oxygen redox corresponding to O 2to O -. Such activation of oxygen redox increases the discharge capacity with ~ 35 mAh/g capacity above 4.0 V and an overall capacity of ~ 130 mAh/g capacity in the voltage window of 4.1 V to 2 V. While multiple issues remain to be addressed for oxygen-redox-active cathodes, as is the case for Li-ion  battery  cathodes,  the  benefits  of  increasing  capacity  and  voltage  may  still  make  oxygen  redox  an interesting topic to investigate.

## Task 7.2 -Development of a High-Energy Sodium-Ion Battery with Long Life (Chris Johnson and Khalil Amine, Argonne National Laboratory)

Objective. The project objective is to develop a high-energy Na-ion battery with long life. Moreover, the battery chemistry should utilize low-cost materials. The energy density target is 200 Wh/kg and/or 500 Wh/L, wherein the anode and cathode capacity targets are 600 mAhg -1 and 200 mAhg -1 , respectively.

Impact. A Na-ion battery on par with the energy density of a Li-ion battery can have a high impact in the transportation sector with the assumption that the cost is significantly below $85/kWh and that the battery pack provides  a  300-mile  range.  The  consumer  is  not  concerned  about  the  battery  chemistry  employed  if  these metrics can be met. Development of these battery chemistries will situate the United States in a strong position as relates to new low-cost energy storage systems beyond lithium ion.

Approach. In a team approach, the Na-ion battery group will create a versatile Na-ion battery chemistry with beneficial advantages such as low cost, safety, recycling, and sustainability of materials used. The team will work synergistically so that the final design is the culmination of advances in phosphorus carbon composites mated with optimized lead or other highly dense metalloids, such as tin and/or antimony and derivatives thereof, for the recyclable anode. Synthesis and optimization of such blended composite anodes will be conducted in parallel to diagnostic characterization of structures, phase formation, and cycling stability. Cathode work will begin at the end of the first year and will involve gradient cathodes consisting of Fe-Mn compositions, as well as intergrowths of layer stacking sequenced oxides. If resources allow, the team also will attempt to stabilize cathode  surfaces  using  atomic  layer  deposition  (ALD)  methods,  particularly  for  the  benefit  of  staving  off dissolution  of  manganese  and  iron / electrolyte  reactivity.  Electrolytes  will  be  partly  procured  from  H. Li at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL).

Out-Year Goals. The state-of-the-art Na-ion battery in the literature has now been surpassed by this team, but performance is still too low for commercialization. Thus, the goal is to move forward and continually invent the most superior Na-ion battery chemistry that can compete worldwide through work output from this project.

Collaborations. Researchers from PNNL who are developing electrolytes for Na-ion batteries will provide this project with formulations to test with the various electrode combinations  investigated at Argonne National Laboratory.

## Milestones

1. Development of concentration gradient layered oxide cathode with 130 mAh/g and stable cycle life of &gt; 200 cycles. (Q4, FY 2022; Completed)
2. Developing Ni-based or Fe/Mn-based cathodes with &gt; 180 mAh/g and &gt; 80% retention after 100 cycles. (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Developing novel electrolytes for the Ni- and Fe/Mn-based cathodes to achieve 2Ã— improved stability. (Q2, FY 2023; Delayed)
4. Surface  coating  for  Co-free  layered  cathodes  to  achieve  a  reversible  capacity  of  &gt; 130  mAh/g  after 200 cycles. (Q3, FY 2023; In progress)
5. Fabricating full cell / pouch cell using optimal layered cathodes and phosphorus or Na-metal anode with high areal capacity of 3 mAh/cm 2 and stable cycle life. (Q4, FY 2023; In progress)

## Progress Report

Addressing the limited cycling stability of P2-type layered oxide cathodes remains a paramount challenge in advancing  the  performance  of  Na-ion  batteries.  The  decay  in  capacity  is  predominantly  attributed  to  the unwanted severe phase transitions,  prominently  occurring  at  both  high-voltage  and  low-voltage  thresholds. Additional degradations are initiated on the particle surface, originating from metal dissolution, migration, and oxygen loss, among other factors, collectively contributing to a decline in battery performance. Previous studies and  strategies  have  underscored  the  significance  of  bulk  cation  substitution,  illuminating  its  efficacy  in mitigating  the  impacts  of  severe  phase  transitions  inherent  in  the  high-voltage  and  low-voltage  cycling  of P2-type layered materials. In addition to this, the exploration of surface coatings as a protective mechanism for cathode  surfaces  has  been  an  area  of  intensive  research.  However,  a  distinct  disparity  is  observed  when comparing the well-documented advantages of surface coatings on Ni-Mn-Co - based Li-ion battery cathodes to their impacts on the earth-abundant, manganese-based Na-ion battery cathodes. The latter presents a complex scenario, replete with unresolved queries and uncertainties.

In the team's attempts to reproduce the results reported in various studies, where enhanced capacity and cycle performance were observed with Al2O3 surface coating on P2-type layered cathodes, they discovered that the effectiveness of the coating layer is highly influenced by the coating process and the quality of the baseline cathode materials. Sodium transition metal (TM) oxides are sensitive to moisture and air, and thus the coating process  can  introduce  significant  modifications  to  the  cathode  surface  if  not  meticulously  controlled.  The amount of surface residual sodium species can also impact the quality and effectiveness of the final coating product. Consequently, precise control over the coating process and a detailed analysis of the surface coating chemistry are essential to unravel the true role of the surface coating layers on the performance of sodium cathode materials.

Figure 1 shows the example of AlF3 coating applied on P2-Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 (NNMO) cathode particles via the ALD method. Unlike the conventional Al2O3 ALD process where water is one of the reactants, the ALD process for AlF3 does not require water for the process, and the surface of the sodium TM cathode remains inert during the entire coating process. The ALD-AlF3-coated NNMO samples exhibit a slight decrease in the first discharge capacity.  However,  the  coating  significantly  improves  capacity  retention,  as  shown  in  Figure 1d.  The bare-NNMO samples shows steep capacity decreases during the initial ~ 10 cycles, and the capacity decay slows down after ~ 15 cycles. In contrast, ALD-AlF3-coated cathodes exhibit a linear but slow capacity drop during the entire cycling period tested. It is presumed that the initial capacity decay of the bare cathode is attributed to the severe surface damages, which are effectively suppressed by surface modification. However, it  seems that the surface coating layer cannot completely eliminate the bulk structural transition and related degradation of the cathodes. These preliminary results underscore the necessity for precision and accuracy in not only the application but also in the subsequent evaluation of the coating's chemistry and its impacts on cathode performance.

Task  7.2 -Figure  1.  (a-c) Voltage profiles and (d) capacity retention of the bare and ALD-AlF3 coated Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 cathode materials; voltage ranges of 2.0-4.3 V versus sodium; current density of 15 mAh/g for (a-c) and 100 mAh/g for (d).

As an important note, the capacity of NNMO jumps to nearly 235 mAh/g when the electrode discharge cutoff voltage is lowered to 1.5 V versus sodium metal (Figure 2). The team's plan is to adjust the cutoff voltages

carefully  with  a  doped  and  coated  NNMO  that  also  replaces  nickel  for  copper  to  maximize  capacity  and minimize expensive/non-plentiful elements. ## Task 7.3 -Tailoring High-Capacity, Reversible Anodes for Sodium-Ion Batteries (Marca M. Doeff, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory)

Objective. The project objective is to understand the role that vacancies, surface defects, and bulk structure play in determining electrochemical properties of high capacity, stepped layered titanate anodes.

Impact. Although several suitable cathode materials for Na-ion batteries exist, there are few suitable  anode  materials  due to  low  potential instabilities.  Sodium  titanate  anodes  are  a  promising  class  of materials  for  this application.  The  electrochemical  properties  can  be  manipulated  through  structural  and surface modifications.

Approach. The  structure  and  surface  properties  of  candidate  stepped  layered  titanates  will  be  modified through  manipulation  of  synthetic  parameters.  Materials  will  then  be  characterized  electrochemically  and physically  to  understand  the  role  that  surface  defects,  vacancies,  and  bulk  structure  play  in  determining electrochemical behavior.

Out-Year Goals. The out-year goal is to achieve development of an electrode that can deliver 225 mAh/g at C/3 rate with good capacity retention (80% or better) for 100 cycles.

Collaborations. The team collaborates with beam line scientists at Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Lightsource (SSRL) and the Advanced Light Source at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.

1. Select best titanate for optimization in full-cell configurations. (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Complete full-cell testing. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)

4. Conduct ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy experiments, in situ X-ray diffraction (XRD), and X-ray absorption experiments. (Q4, FY 2023; Delayed due to closure of SSRL)

## Progress Report

SSRL is back online after an extended shutdown; however, because of high demand, it is difficult to schedule the team's planned experiments. Thus, some milestones  are  delayed.  This  quarter,  further  work  was  carried  out  on NNT (NaTi3O6(OH) ïƒ— 2H2O), which the team found in previous studies to be a good candidate as an anode material for Na-ion batteries. The material is made hydrothermally  and  then  dehydrated.  The  electrochemical  properties  are strongly dependent on details of processing and electrode fabrication. Much better results are obtained when carboxymethyl cellulose is used as the binder rather than polyvinylidene (di)fluoride. Their previous work showed that the material was thermally stable to about 600Â°C when heated in air. The thermal treatment results in an irreversible loss of water, a shifting of the titanate layers (Figure 1), and a shrinkage in the c -axis by 12%. [1]

This quarter, the team investigated the effect of atmosphere on the thermal and electrochemical  behavior  of  NNT.  Interestingly,  the  material  appears  to  be somewhat more thermally stable when heated under argon compared to air (Figure 2);  for  example,  the  layered  structure  is  maintained  at  700Â°C  under argon, whereas decomposition to tunnel compounds occurs at this temperature in  air.  While  there  are  some  differences  in  the  XRD  patterns  among  the samples, it is clear that the layered structure is maintained.  The needle-like morphology is also maintained, although the samples processed under argon appear to become somewhat shorter and thicker.

For  materials  processed  under  air,  the  best  performance  was  obtained  for NNT treated  at  500Â°C,  with  higher  treatment  temperatures  leading  to  a

## Task 7.4 -Electrolytes and Interfaces for Stable High-Energy Sodium-Ion Batteries (Phung M. L. Le, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory)

Objective. The  Na-ion  battery  is  a  potential  alternative  energy  source  for  electric  vehicles  (EVs)  and  grid applications due to the low cost and the natural abundance of sodium. However, their energy density is still lower  than  that  of  commercial  Li-ion  counterparts.  A  promising  solution  toward  higher  energy  is  using high-voltage or high-energy-density cathode materials or replacing the insertion-type anodes in Na-ion batteries such as carbons with ultra-thin sodium metal (1,166 mAh g -1 and -2.71 V versus standard hydrogen electrode potential) to fabricate Na-metal batteries; another promising solution is exploring the concept of anode-free sodium batteries (AFSB). Either approach requires a good electrolyte to stabilize performance of the Na-ion cell to maintain long cyclability through the formation of stable solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) on the anode and formation of cathode-electrolyte interphase (CEI) on the cathode. In addition, flammability of electrolyte also leads to safety concerns. Therefore, there is also an urgent need to develop safer and more stable electrolytes to enable applications in severe conditions (high potential, high temperature). To reach this goal, a fundamental understanding of the nature of the dynamic interface between electrode and electrolyte is critical. The sluggish redox kinetics also remain challenging for high-power applications and must be improved.

Impact. This  project  will  develop  new  electrolytes  to  enable  long  cycle  life  and  safe  operation  of Na-ion batteries.  If  successful,  the  resulting  improvements  in  energy,  life,  and  safety  will  provide  a  solid contribution to the understanding of fundamental scientific questions and the development for Na-ion battery technology and promote its practical application as a competitive alternative to the current Li-ion batteries and greatly reduce the cost of energy storage systems for EVs.

Approach. This project will continuously focus on different electrolyte compositions (salt/solvent/additive) and  will  explore  the  electrolyte/electrode  interphases  using  hard  carbon  (HC)  as  anode  and  the  low-cost cathodes available in the market, with the aim to be cost-effective for future manufacturing of Na-ion batteries and  to  compete  with  Li-ion  market.  For  high-energy Na-ion batteries,  Prussian  blue  and  white  cathode (Na2Fe2(CN)6) and NaNi0.4Fe0.2Mn0.4O2 (NFM) will be selected because of the high capacity and operational voltage (150 mAh/g and 3.4 V). For sodium batteries with extremely long cycle life, a polyanionic cathode (Na3V2(PO4)3  (NVP)  will  be  continuously  used  because  this  material  is  highly  stable  and  standard  for fundamental studies on anode-free sodium cell. Based on the cathodes available in market, the project will focus on developing a high-performance electrolyte to enable high-energy-density Na-ion batteries that are highly safe and have a long cycle.

Out-Year Goals. This project will select electrolyte compounds and identify formation of interfacial SEI layer on HC and CEI layer-on-layer oxide cathode and its effect on electrode materials. It will also guide electrolyte optimization and improve Coulombic efficiency of sodium deposition/stripping to be more than 99%.

Collaborations. This project will collaborate with leading scientists at Argonne National Laboratory, Lawrence Berkeley  National  Laboratory,  and  other  organizations  in  the  field  of  cathode  and  anode  materials  for Na-ion batteries.  It  will  also  collaborate  with  C. Wang  and  M. Engelhard  of  Pacific  Northwest  National Laboratory for transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy characterization.

## Milestones

1. Develop nonflammable and safe electrolytes based on fluorinated solvent, new sodium salt, and polymer matrix for cathode materials (that is, Prussian blue and white, NFM). (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Investigate the thermal, physical, and chemical properties and the redox stability of developed electrolytes. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)

3. Study  different  factors  (electrolyte  composition,  current  collectors,  cycling  protocol,  and  temperature) affecting the efficiency of the sodium stripping/plating process and cycling performance of AFSB. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Characterize CEI/SEI interphase properties in optimized electrolyte to probe the underlying mechanism of cycling stability of Na-ion batteries and AFSBs. (Q4, FY 2023; Completed)

## Progress Report

This  quarter,  the  team  primarily  explored  the  formation  of  interfacial  layers  in  the  AFSBs  to  probe  the underlying  mechanism  of  cell  stability.  As  reported  earlier,  the  stabilization  of  AFSBs  cycling  depends significantly on the protocol of cycling and the pre-treatment of current collector anodes as well as cathode. To understand the effect of different factors (such as current collector type, pre-treatment, and cycling protocol), in situ / ex situ TEM and cryogenic plasma focused ion beam scanning electron microscopy (cryo-PFIB-SEM) have been applied for the AFSB cells.

Figure 1 shows images of initial deposition of sodium in ether-based electrolyte LPH-03 (electrolyte code) on different current collectors (copper, C@Cu, and C@Al) characterized by cryo-PFIB-SEM. It seems that the plated sodium metal on the copper current collector is dense and agglomerated to form large grains within the irregular shapes. In sharp contrast, the deposited sodium is porous, with a long whisker-like microstructure connected on the C@Cu that form some holes while the larger whiskers tend to form the homogenous, dense, and  large  sodium  nodules  deposited  on  the  C@Al.  These  differing  morphologies  can  be  explained  by  the distribution of electronic charge and the nature of the current collector, which directly influence the formation and  nucleation  process  of  sodium  dendrite.  The  deposited  sodium  with  irregular  shapes  or  a  whisker-like microstructure can result in a large pin hole when stripping, leading to fragile electrical connection and easy formation of 'dead' sodium. Therefore, it could be expected that the growth of sodium dendrite is slower on C@Al than on the other current collectors.

Task  7.4 -Figure  1.  Cryogenic  plasma  focused  ion  beam  scanning  electron  microscopy  of  sodium  morphology  after  an  initial plating at 1.0 mA/cm 2  on different current collectors (left to right: copper, C@Cu, and C@Al) at the magnification of 2 Âµm and 500 nm in ether-based electrolyte LPH-03 (NaPF6 salt concentration &gt;  1 M).

In situ TEM was also conducted to understand the sodium growth and nucleation in the plating/stripping process at 2.5 V without the presence of the electrolyte to reveal the effect of the current collector itself. As shown in Figure  2,  the  behavior  of  sodium  growth  is  very  distinct,  as  in  the  direction  of  sodium  formation  and morphology. In case of C@Cu or C@Al, the sodium grows directly on the carbon layer and merges into it. Figure 3 indicates the sodium growth rate on the normalized surface area in the plating process. The sodium growth on C@Cu seems much faster than on the other substrates after a certain time, while the first sodium chunk was observed at 5 seconds for copper substrate (Figure 2). In sharp contrast, on C@Al, the sodium grows very slowly during the plating process, with the lowest rate compared to other substrates, which can be expected with the lowest dendrite formation. This result is very consistent with the cryo-PFIB-SEM data in Figure 1 and with the collected electrochemical data indicating that the sodium free-cell C@Al||NVP achieved longer cycle life than the other AFSBs.

Specifically, the CEI formed at the thickness of 9 nm consists of sodium, oxygen, phosphorus, and fluorine, indicating the organic/inorganic based components. ## BATTERY CONSORTIA INTRODUCTION

This section covers the following consortia, with their lead affiliations identified in parentheses:

- Cathode-Electrolyte Interphase (CEI) Consortium

(J. Xiao, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory)

The goal of the CEI Consortium is to develop a platform to quickly identify, understand, and tackle key challenges  of  CEI  relevant  to  realistic  Li-ion  batteries  by  integrating  different  scientific  tools  and expertise from various laboratories and universities. The consortium examines the interfacial reactions between  cathode  and  electrolytes  at  high  voltages,  which  critically  dictate  the  observed  cell performances. The capabilities developed and integrated within the consortium also directly support the  Earth-abundant  Cathode  Active  Materials  (EaCAM)  Consortium  and  the  Cation  Disordered Rocksalt (DRX+) Materials Consortium, which both focus on cathode materials development.

- Cation Disordered Rocksalt (DRX+) Materials Consortium (G. Ceder, University of California, Berkeley)

The DRX+ Consortium aims to develop high-energy, high-rate Ni-free and Co-free cation disordered rocksalt (DRX) cathode materials based on manganese as a cost-effective, earth-abundant, and safe redox-active  element.  Specifically,  Gen1-DRX  achieving  650 Wh/kg  at  100 mA/g  for  at  least 100 cycles will be optimized and scaled up. Gen2-DRX achieving at least 700 Wh/kg at 100 mA/g for 300 cycles will be developed through the application of functional coatings on Gen1, incorporation of electrolyte improvements, and further compositional and morphological refinements. Gen3-DRX with very high specific energies between 850 Wh/kg and 1100 Wh/kg will be explored by introducing partial disorder in the structure.

- Earth-Abundant Cathode Active Materials (EaCAM) Consortium (J. Croy, Argonne National Laboratory)

The long-term objectives of the EaCAM Consortium are the discovery and development of mechanistic insights, novel materials, new processes, and design strategies, as well as dissemination of information, that enable cathode compositions based 100% in earth abundant, sustainable chemistries. The ultimate goal will be synthetic control of pre-determined particle designs, local ordering, integrated structures, dopant site-selectivity, and primary and secondary morphologies, including monolithic architectures, of high-energy earth-abundant cathode active materials. Such advancements would contribute greatly to  lowering  cost  and  increasing  sustainability  of  next-generation  technologies  for  transportation applications and beyond.

- Battery500 Consortium Program: Innovation Center for Battery500

(J. Liu, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory; Yi Cui, Stanford University)

The overall goal of the Battery500 Consortium is to increase the energy density of advanced lithium batteries to beyond what can be achieved in today's state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries. The consortium aims to increase the specific energy (up to 500 Wh kg -1 ) and achieve 1,000 charge/discharge cycles, with cost reduction of the cells to significantly less than $100 per kWh -1 . This goal directly addresses the  U.  S.  Department  of  Energy  priority to  achieve  a  carbon-free  electricity  sector  by  2035  and  to decarbonize the transportation sector by developing and manufacturing the next-generation, high-energy, low-cost batteries to enable a wide deployment of electric vehicles in the marketplace.

## â–ª Battery500 Solid-State Battery Seedling Projects

(Lead Institute: Pacific Northwest National Laboratory)

The Battery500 Consortium Phase I effort (FY 2017 -FY 2021)  made significant progress, successfully  demonstrating  prototype  350 Wh/kg  Li-metal  pouch  cells  with  600  stable  cycling  by developing and integrating innovative technologies. In Phase 2 (FY 2022 - FY 2026), the Consortium continues  to  move  toward  the  ultimate  goal  of  500 Wh/kg  (cell  level).  During  this  phase,  the U. S. Department  of  Energy  awarded,  under  the  auspices  of  the  Battery500  Consortium,  nine Solid-State Battery Seedling projects to pursue innovative research focusing on novel materials and their optimization and integration into high-energy-density batteries with the potential to meet the target of 500 Wh/kg and 1,000 cycles. This report provides an overview and the current progress for each of the Solid-State Battery Seedling projects.

## Cathode-Electrolyte Interphase (CEI) Consortium (Jie Xiao, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory)

Objective. The goal of the Cathode-Electrolyte Interphase (CEI) Consortium is to develop a platform to quickly identify,  understand,  and  tackle  key  challenges  of  CEI  relevant  to  realistic  Li-ion  batteries  by  integrating different  scientific  tools  and  expertise  from  various  laboratories  and  universities.  The  CEI Consortium examines the interfacial reactions between cathode and electrolytes at high voltages, which critically dictate the observed cell performances. The capabilities developed and integrated within the CEI Consortium also directly support  the  Earth-abundant  Cathode  Active  Materials  (EaCAM)  Consortium  and  the  Cation  Disordered Rocksalt (DRX+) Materials Consortium, which both focus on cathode materials development.

Impact. The CEI Consortium will identify and address fundamental challenges in stabilizing CEI to accelerate research and development of cathode materials such as Ni-rich Ni-Mn-Co (NMC; polycrystal and/or single crystal  in  this  consortium),  disordered  rocksalt  (DRX+ Consortium),  and  Mn-rich  (EaCAM Consortium) cathode  materials.  The  knowledge  gathered  from  the CEI Consortium  will  not  only  be  utilized  to  enhance CEI properties, but it will also provide guidelines for designing compatible electrolytes and stabilizing cathode materials at high voltages.

Approach. All hypotheses and new discoveries from the CEI Consortium will be cross validated in coin cells assembled and tested at industry relevant conditions to ensure the consortium is tackling real world challenges for battery industry. Each laboratory under this consortium has at least one university partner, most of which are from Minority Serving Institutions or underrepresented groups. Through collaborative research between laboratories  and  universities,  the  CEI Consortium  will  cultivate  future  scientists  and  engineers  in  battery research, development, and demonstration and support the U.S. Department of Energy on workforce retraining in energy storage.

Out-Year Goals. The out-year goal is to establish a database of baseline performances of model cathodes and electrolytes  to  be  used  under  this  consortium to  benchmark  full  research  progress.  Both  half-coin-cell  and full-coin-cell assembly and testing protocols will be developed.

Collaborations. Collaboration among consortium team members will be well coordinated by Pacific Northwest National  Laboratory  (PNNL).  The  CEI Consortium  has  three  focused  groups:  (1) model  cathode materials, (2) electrolyte, and (3) characterization &amp; modeling. The lead of each focused group will work with the principal investigators (PIs) of the corresponding group for periodical information and materials exchange. The three groups will have joint biweekly meetings and quarterly reviews.

## PNNL and University of Washington: Storage Study of NMC-811 in Different Environments

In the second quarter, PNNL started storage tests of commercial NMC-811 in different environments including argon, N2, dry air (0.1% relative humidity, 20Â°C), ambient environment (33% relative humidity, 20Â°C), pure CO2,  a  mixture  of  CO2  and  H2O  (~ 70%  relative  humidity,  20Â°C),  and  a  mixture  of  argon  and  H2O (~ 70% relative humidity, 20Â°C). It was found that as long as moisture (H2O) exists, surface morphology change will happen, even after one day of storage. They then focused on storage of NMC-811 in ambient environment, dry air, and N2 to identify a cost-efficient solution for long-time storage of Ni-rich NMC. Figure 1 compares the surface evolution of NMC-811 after storing in ambient air (Figure 1a1-a3), dry air (Figure 1b1-b3), and nitrogen (Figure 1c1-c3) for various timeframes. In ambient air with 33% relative humidity, after only one day surface particles readily appear, with noticeable population on NMC-811 (Figure 1a1), while in dry air (Figure 1b1) or N2 (Figure 1c1), the surface of NMC-811 polycrystals is still 'clean.' After five days, an increased number of impurities on NMC-811 particles is seen (Figure 1a2). After 10 days in ambient environment, it seems  the  surface  impurities  grow  and  merge  into  bigger  particles  (Figure 1a3).  Polycrystalline  NMC-811 stored in dry air (Figure 1b2-b3) or N2 (Figure 1c2-1c3) still displays no change after being stored for 5 or 10 days.

The observation of the morphological change on NMC-811 surfaces in different gases is consistent with the electrochemical performance of the stored NMC-811 (Figure 2). In N2, after even one month of storage, the capacity variation is minimal, if any, from NMC-811, which still delivers &gt; 200 mAh/g discharge capacity after 30 days of storage. In dry air with 0.1% humidity, the capacity of NMC-811 shows slightly more variation than that stored in N2, but they remain close regardless of the storage time. It is in the ambient environment that NMC-811 capacity  continues  to  decrease  during  storage  and  becomes  &lt;  200  mAh/g  after  only  five  days. Development of surface impurities on NMC-811 stored in ambient environment mainly involves growth of

## INL - Brown  University:  Optimized  Ceria  Coating  Layer  on  NMC-811  Improves  Electrochemical Performance of Ni-Rich Cathode Materials

The  INL  team  successfully  prepared  ceria  coating  on  the  surfaces  of  NMC-811  powders  by  atomic  layer deposition (ALD). As reported last quarter, according to X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results, in as-synthesized ceria coating, oxygen vacancies still exist due to the presence of Ce 3+ . The growth per cycle by ALD for ceria coating is evaluated to be ~ 0.06 nm/cycle. Therefore, this quarter, ceria (CeO2-x) layers with different  thicknesses  (2 nm  and  4 nm)  have  been  grown  on  NMC-811  powders.  The  electrochemical performances of coated NMC-811 are evaluated with coin cells in comparison with bare NMC-811. Notably, the mass  loading of active materials for all of the cathodes is controlled to be  ~ 10 mg/cm 2 for consistent comparison.

Li/NMC-811 half coin cells are used first for testing (Figure 3a). The upper cutoff voltage (UCV) is 4.4 V versus  Li/Li + .  The  constant  charge  rate  and  discharge  rate  are  C/10  and  C/3,  respectively.  Localized high-concentration  electrolyte  was  used  to  ensure  the  Li-metal  anode  is  stable  during  initial  assessment  of NMC-811.  It  is  found  that  NMC-811  covered  by  2-nm-thick  ceria  shows  higher  specific  capacity  and Coulombic efficiency (CE) than bare NMC-811. Because of sufficient lithium inventory at the Li-metal anode side, the CE value can reflect the reversibility of cathode structures and the interface. Higher CE in the Li-metal half  cell  with  coated  NMC-811  suggests  improved  electrochemical  stability  of  CEI  at  high  voltage  (for example, 4.4 V).

In addition, graphite/NMC-811 full coin cells are also tested in carbonate-based electrolyte with a cutoff voltage of 4.3 V, using the baseline electrolyte recommended by this consortium. The constant charge / discharge rates are both C/3 for full coin cells. As shown in Figure 3b, NMC-811 coated with 2-nm-thick ceria layers greatly outperforms the others in terms of specific capacity and cyclability in full coin cells as well. The bare NMC-811 electrode exhibits the worst cycling performances. The thicker ceria coating would lead to higher charge transfer resistances at the interface, leading to poorer rate performances.

Oxygen vacancies exist in as-synthesized ceria (CeO2-x) layers due to the presence of Ce 3+ . To further reveal the  roles  of  oxygen  vacancy  in  ceria  layers,  the  coated  NMC-811  powders  will  be  annealed  at  elevated temperatures in dry air to remove oxygen vacancy through the oxidation process from Ce(III) to Ce(IV).

## Highlights of Focused Group 2

The highlights this quarter include the following efforts:

- Argonne National Laboratory (ANL) gained new mechanistic insight into the decomposition of ethylene carbonate  (EC)  at  potentials  relevant  to  practical  CEIs  and  expanded  their  studies  toward  other commercially relevant solvents.

## ANL and Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University: New Insights to Understand Decomposition Process of EC at High Potentials and Implications on CEI Stability

This quarter, the team continued the deep-dive study into the mechanisms of oxidation of EC at potentials relevant to CEI processes in Li-ion cathodes. To evaluate inherent stability without confounding effects from simultaneous and competing processes involving fluorinated salts and redox-active oxide surfaces, they used a simplified model system in the presence of LiClO4 salts on Pt(111) surfaces.

The team continued developing a design to conduct electrochemical oxidation and measure 1 H nuclear magnetic  resonance  (NMR)  simultaneously.  They have the first iteration in situ cell  design  and have collected  control 1 H  and 13 C  spectra  with  it.  The design needs improvement for in situ measurements next quarter. Meanwhile, ex situ NMR spectroscopy was conducted on samples after EC oxidation above 4 V. In addition to signals ascribed to super-acidic protons reported in previous quarters, they have now confirmed the assignment of 1 H peaks at 6.9 ppm

CEI -Figure  5.  Proposed mechanisms  of  initial EC  oxidation  (a) and  observed  temporal  evolution  of  products  of  oxidation  in 1 H  nuclear magnetic resonance (b).

and 6.6 ppm to a radical cation due to a pure electron transfer path (Figure 5a, Path A). Another peak at 5.3 ppm was assigned to the formation of the neutral radical in a proton-coupled electron transfer (Path B). So far, they have not encountered evidence for the two-electron/two-proton Path C. These intermediates have been found to be dynamic and convert to vinylene carbonate (VC, blue) as the electrolyte is aged ex situ (Figure 5b, orange and  purple  data).  They  have  made  significant  progress  in  monitoring  the  proton  abstraction  reaction  and dehydrogenation of EC to VC. All new species are relevant and have also been observed in LiPF6 electrolytes.

In parallel, a fluorine-free electrolyte [1.3 M LiClO4 in EC / ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC), 3:7 w/w] and the Gen1 electrolyte (1.0 M LiPF6 in EC/EMC, 3:7 w/w, with 2 wt% VC; CEI consortium baseline) were used to validate the influence of proton for cell performance. To separate the role of H + from the effect of other products from EC oxidation, such as the radicals above, the team devised a procedure where H2 is bubbled through pristine electrolyte held at 3 V versus Li + /Li 0 . At these potentials, the electrolyte is stable, but H2 is oxidized to H + . Different concentration levels were introduced before evaluation of the electrochemical performance in full NMC-622/graphite coin cells. In all cases, the presence of H + led to abnormal voltage profiles in initial cycles. Preliminary evidence also points to lower capacity and faster fading in the presence of H + .

The team has expanded their target list to other solvents that are relevant to the commercial batteries, comparing the activity of two electrolyte salts, LiClO4 and LiPF6. They found that across the series, LiPF6 showed an increased  stability;  based  on  the  previous  report,  they  speculate  that  it  is  likely  due  to  remediating  of

## Focused Group 2: Electrolyte

electrogenerated  protons.  They  have  also  expanded  the  electrode  substrates  to  two  forms  of  carbon,  to gradually introduce complexity in their studies. Carbon C65, a common component in commercial batteries, decomposes  electrolytes  at  lower  potentials  even  than  their  Pt(111)  models.  As  part  of  designing  new electrolytes for the high-voltage batteries, they have analyzed the effect of substitution at the -CH2 sites in EC. Particularly, they observe that the introduction of electron-withdrawing fluorine in the EC ring (fluoroethylene carbonate, difluoroethylene carbonate) pushes the onset of oxidation higher, compared to lower oxidation for electron-donating CH3 (for example, propylene carbonate).

Lastly,  the  team  at  Virginia  Tech  has  worked  to  lower  the  calcination  temperature  of  LiNiO2  (LNO)  to investigate the relationship of temperature with the evolution of morphology from two precursors, Ni(OH)2 and NiO.  The  team  started  the  process  using  Ni(OH)2  nanosheets  with  dominant  (111)  facets,  which  could  be converted to NiO with morphology retention. The high surface area allowed conversion to LNO at a much lower  temperature  than  other  precursors,  but  the  morphology  quickly  lost  facet  selectivity.  The  team  is investigating the balance between forming LNO and morphology control.

## SNL; University of Chicago; and University of California (UC), Irvine: Discovery that Borate Additives have a Beneficial Effect on Cell Performance in Conventional Alkylcarbonates but are Unnecessary for Stable Cycling in LGEs

NMC-811  full  cells  exhibit  accelerated  capacity  fade  above  â‰ˆ 4.3 V  in  Gen2 electrolyte.  Open  cell configurations, where the electrolyte does not directly contact the particle surface, were equilibrated at a series of potentials, and XPS was performed to characterize the surface chemistry operando .  As hypothesized, the amount of Li2CO3 initially increases with increasing voltage, presumably via vapor phase transport of organic electrolyte species to the cathode surface, where it is oxidized. Above 4.3 V, this carbonate decomposes, leaving surface  lithium  oxide  species  remaining.  The  decomposition  should  occur  via  vapor  phase  production  and transport  of  CO  and  CO2,  in  strong  agreement  with  earlier  differential  electrochemical  mass  spectrometry results. These results suggest that an alternative CEI chemistry should be developed to enable cycling in a larger voltage window. They do not, however, provide insight into the mechanism for capacity fade. In future work, the  team  will  controllably  introduce  CEI  formation  and  decomposition  reaction  products  into  full  cells  to investigate their various roles in capacity fade.

A series of four Li-borate salts was evaluated for ability to stabilize the CEI on NMC-811 under high-loading (~ 15 mg/cm 2 ) half-cell conditions. These borate salts are differentiated by their electrooxidative stabilities and chemical  functionalities and are thus  intended to direct unique  CEI formation  onset potentials and structure/chemistry. When cycled under high voltage conditions (4.6 V upper cutoff versus Li/Li + , Figure 6), three of the borates [CB11H12 -, B(OCH(CF3)2)4 -, and B(C2O4)2 -] significantly improve the capacity  retention  at  50 cycles  compared  to  the  additive-free  baseline, 1 M LiPF6/3:7 EC:EMC (Gen2). The most oxidatively stable anion of the series, BF4 -, showed worse capacity retention than the baseline, demonstrating the importance of borate instability in stabilizing the CEI in Gen2. XPS measurements of cycled NMC-811 cathodes reveal that each additive directs the CEI toward a unique chemical composition. Notably, the highest performing additive, B(C2O4)2 -(86% retention), is most adept at minimizing carbonate solvent and PF6 -anion decomposition based on minimization of C-O and P-F character within the CEI. The team's results suggest  that  borate  salts  combining  moderate  oxidative  stability  with inorganic (aprotic) chemical functionality are best suited for Gen2 CEI stabilization on high-voltage NMC cathodes. Future work will incorporate transmission electron microscopy based CEI structure characterization  and  extend  this  investigation  to  include  an  exemplar Mn-based disordered rock salt (DRX) cathode.

## SLAC: Optimized Recipes to Control Lithium Content in the Growth of Films Based on LiAlxOy by ALD to Improve High-Voltage Battery Operation

The main SLAC team goal is to develop a foundational understanding of the CEI for high-voltage cathode systems and guide the rational manipulation of interfacial chemistry and structure. They are pursuing this goal from  three  approaches:  (1)  interphase  characterization  using  cryogenic  electron  microscopy  (cryo-EM), (2) electrolyte  design,  and  (3)  electrolyte  surface  modification.  They  have  developed  cryo-EM  for  cathode characterization; ongoing efforts on cryo-EM are mainly focused on three-dimensional tomography protocol development. The electrolyte design is focused on new solvent design toward high-voltage battery operations. For the surface modification part, they have studied the corrosion mechanism of the aluminum current collector using  ALD  coatings  and  its  impact  on  performance  as  a  first  step.  They  have  also  previously  developed ALD coatings for NMC cathodes for improving high-voltage battery operations.

This  quarter,  they  optimized  the  Li-containing  ALD  film  recipe:  LiAlxOy.  Given  the  key  role  of  lithium stoichiometry on film quality, Li + ion transport, growth rate, and film stability, they systematically studied short and long Li-precursor pulse processes and studied film characteristics using XPS.  They also optimized the number  of  ALD  cycles  required  to  obtain  improved  performance  in  the  battery.  They  have  completed

preliminary testing in Li||NMC cells up to 4.3 V versus Li/Li + in baseline LP40 electrolyte using a 50 mA/g (C/3) rate for fast throughput screening (Figure 8). Figure 8a shows the most optimized cycling performance obtained with short Li-precursor pulses; Figure 8b shows results obtained with long Li-precursor pulses. The long exposure process results in 61.9% capacity retention after 60 cycles, and the short exposure process results in 42.8% capacity retention after 60 cycles; these are both higher than for bare cathode (10.9% after 60 cycles). These results show that their optimized LiAlxOy coating is promising and can cause significant improvement during high-voltage battery operations. Note that for long Li-precursor exposure processes, a smaller number of ALD cycles is required for significant performance improvement.

The team plans to test their best-performing coating (long Li-exposure, 3-12 cyc ALD) in consortium-declared baseline conditions. Moreover, they plan to characterize the CEI using XPS and cryo-EM to understand the characteristics that caused performance improvement. Eventually, they will study their coating in high-performance fluorinated ether solvent-based electrolytes.

## BNL and SBU: Completed HAXPES Characterization of Interfaces from Cycled NMC-811

The goal of this effort is to discover new fundamental insights into the CEI through a synergistic approach integrating operando characterization of CEI parasitic heat with advanced spectroscopic approaches to gain new fundamental insights regarding CEI formation and evolution.

CEI -Figure 9. Entropic heat flow determination of NMC-811/Li coin cells. Entropic heat flow versus x (LixNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2) for the (a) 1 st  cycle from 3.0 V to 4.1 V, (b) 1 st  cycle from 3.0 V to 4.3 V, (c) 3 rd  cycle from 3.0 V to 4.1 V, and (d) 3 rd  cycle from 3.0 V to 4.3  V.

One focus area this quarter was analysis of entropic heat flow associated with CEI formation of Li/NMC-811 cells assembled and cycled in two voltage ranges (3.0-4.1 V and 3.0-4.3 V) for three cycles at a C/10 rate. When the entropic heat flow is negative this indicates that heat is being released due to a thermodynamically favorable process and as such indicates that the entropy of the system is increasing, while when the entropic heat flow is positive, the entropy of the system is decreasing. During the first charge, the entropic heat flow is initially negative but becomes positive after 0.1 equivalents of lithium are removed (Li0.9NMC-811), suggesting that the entropy of the system is initially increasing but then quickly starts decreasing during delithiation (Figure 9a/b). The heat flow becomes progressively more positive until it peaks at Li0.7NMC-811. The heat flow remains positive  until  the  cell  is  charged  to  4.1 V (Li0.33NMC-811);  however,  when  the  NMC  is  delithiated  to

Li&lt;0.25NMC-811, the entropic heat flow changes sign to negative and remains negative through charge to 4.3 V (Li0.17NMC-811). During discharge 1 (Figure 9a/b), the changes in entropy are generally mirrored, indicating a reversible process, where the entropic heat flow is positive until the material is lithiated to Li0.4NMC-811 and then negative for the remainder of the discharge, once again peaking at around Li0.7NMC-811. The changes in cycle 3 (Figure 9c/d) are very comparable, which confirms the entropic reversibility of the system.

A second focus area was HAXPES collected on post NMC-811 cathodes recovered from Li/NMC-811 cells after  100Ã—  cycles  at  C/2  rate,  with  measurements  collected  in  both  the  discharged  and  charged  states.  The HAXPES data from cycle 1-3 formation was discussed last quarter. Consistent with the formation cycling data, M-O and PVDF bonds are more apparent at higher beam energy, reflective of deeper probe depth (Figure 10a). A  greater  relative  intensity  of  C-O  species  post-100Ã—  cycles  compared  to  post  formation  was  observed, suggesting formation of a thicker CEI over extended cycling (Figure 10b). The appearance of the C-O species after 100 cycles at the two voltage windows was similar. At fluorine 1s, the cathodes cycled between 3.0-4.1 V showed a comparably greater evolution of the LiF component with &gt; 2Ã— higher atomic concentration in the discharged state relative to the cathodes cycled between 3.0-4.3 V (Figure 10c).

## LLNL and SFSU: Performed DFT Simulations to Compute Potential Energy Profiles of EC Degradation to  VC  as  a  Function  of  Applied  Electrode  Potential,  Where  the  Predicted  Onset  Potential  of EC Decomposition Agreed Well with ANL's Experimental Measurement

The goal of this effort is to identify key features that can lead to the degradation and formation of secondary phases at the CEI. To achieve this goal, the team will focus on tight coupling between multiscale modeling and multimodal characterization to probe the structure and chemistry of the CEI and its impact on Li-ion transport. They will start by examining propensities of electrolyte decomposition at the CEI using quantum mechanical simulations, followed by atomistic modeling of CEI formation by incorporating machine-learning methodologies. Through direct simulation and comparison with experiment of the spectroscopy signatures of key  degradation  products  observed  at  the  CEI,  they  will  identify  the  atomic  structure  and  composition  of CEI components. Finally, they will investigate how microstructural features of the CEI affect Li-ion transport using a multiscale modeling approach.

This quarter, the team initialized new collaborative activity with PNNL on understanding the origin of steplike crack  formation  in  cycled  SC  LiNi0.76Mn0.14Co0.1O2.  Based  on  local  stress  distribution  analysis  from  a two-dimensional quasi-static micromechanics model, they propose a two-step mechanism to account for the nucleation  and  propagation  of  steplike  cracks  along  the  (001)  and  (101)  facets.  Consistent  with  previous observation, the  (001)-oriented incubation  cracks  tend  to  nucleate  during  delithiation  of  LNO  (as proxy  of layered Ni-rich NMC) due to O3 â†’ O1 phase transformation. On the other hand, their simulation results suggest the (101)-oriented cracks would develop between two neighboring (001) cracks due to local stress buildup during the re-lithiation process (cycling). Over time, percolation of cracks can occur, leading to mechanical breakdown of NMC single crystals.

They continued efforts to examine the thermodynamic propensity of EC decomposition on the LNO surfaces. To determine the most stable surface structures, they calculated the surface energies of (104), (110), (100), and (101) facets and identified that the (104) and (110) surfaces are the most stable surfaces, with a surface energy of 0.69 J/m2 and 1.86 J/m2, respectively. To further investigate EC adsorption on these surfaces, they performed a grid search to identify the most favorable adsorption site and orientation of the EC molecule. It is found that EC prefers to be adsorbed on the (110) surface as expected due to its more reactive nature (higher surface energy).  Subsequently,  they  explored  different  decomposition  pathways  of  EC  on  LNO  (104)  and  (110) surfaces, following either the ring-opening or H + -abstraction mechanism. Their results reveal that both reactions are thermodynamically unfavorable due to the large reaction energies observed. Next quarter, they will compare these results with simulations performed on LixNiO2 surfaces (different charged states) and evaluate the impact of surface defects or dopants (manganese and cobalt).

Continuing collaboration with the ANL / University of Illinois, Chicago team, they performed grand canonical DFT simulations to compute potential energy profiles (shown in Figure 11) of EC degradation towards VC on a model Pt(111) surface as a function of applied electrode potential. Their results show that EC is predicted to bind  favorably to  Pt(111)  surfaces  at  electrode  potentials  between  3-6  V  versus  Li/Li + .  Once  bound  to  the surface,  EC  readily  undergoes  H-abstraction  to  produce  an  intermediate  EC-H  species,  either  a  hydrogen

CEI -Figure  11.  Voltage-dependent potential energy profiles showing degradation of ethylene carbonate toward vinylene carbonate on Pt  (111)  surface.

adatom or a dissolved proton following a proton coupled electron  transfer  reaction.  Once  the  intermediate EC-H species  is  formed,  the  conversion  to  VC  is  thermodynamically  favorable  at  all  potentials  between 3-6 V versus  Li/Li + .  Overall,  the  predicted  onset  potential  of  EC  decomposition  agrees  well  with  the experiment measurement.

## LBNL  and  Virginia  Tech:  LBNL  published  work  ('Li-Mn-O  Li-Rich  Cation  Disordered  Rock-Salt Cathode Materials Do Not Undergo Reversible Oxygen Redox'); Virginia Tech Progressed on Studying TM Dissolution/Redeposition Processes in NMC Using an Operando XFM Technique

LBNL has now fully staffed the project and has decided to focus on interfacial processes leading to manganese dissolution  in  DRX  and  DRX-related  cathodes.  Model  materials  are  Li1.167Mn0.7Ti0.133O1.8F0.2  (LMTOF), Li1.2Mn0.625Nb0.175O1.95F0.05  (LMNOF),  'Li4Mn2O5'  (LMO)  and  spinel-modified  Li4Mn2O5  (LMOs ).  These materials vary not only in their chemical makeup but also in their physical and electrochemical characteristics, although  they  are  all  rock  salt  phases.  For  example,  LMTOF  is  made  by  a  solid-state  reaction  and  has micron-sized particles, whereas LMO is made by reactive ball-milling and is nanometric. LMTOF and LMNOF undergo reversible O-redox processes at high potentials, whereas LMO evolves oxygen during the first charge to high potentials. Oxygen in LMOs appears to be much less prone to evolution than in LMO. These differences should allow the team to understand what factors are most important in determining what leads to manganese dissolution.  Initial  experiments  will  focus  on  manganese  dissolution  in  LMO  using  XPS  and  STEM-EDS, comparing it to NMC-811.

Part of the work at LBNL will be directed toward understanding the CEI of thin-film DRX cathodes. These thin-film cathodes will be prepared by pulsed laser deposition, which yields a uniform, flat, and thin layer. This allows  study  of  the  electrochemistry  and  interfacial  properties  in  the  absence  of  other  components  such  as conductive carbon and binder, thus allowing them to deconvolute processes involving these from that arising from the active material alone. CEI chemistry as a function of state of charge (SOC) will be studied using a suite of spectroscopic and microscopic tools.

Virginia Tech focused on analyzing the operando XFM data collected at ANL on NMC-9055. Specifically, they looked at the behavior of the 4.5 V hold that experienced large amounts of TM redeposition from the nickel, cobalt, and manganese (Figure 12). For each pixel, they matched the initial intensity at the beginning of the redeposition period to its change in fluorescence intensity over the redeposition period. They then plotted this data as a function of initial intensity. This allowed them to visualize where the nickel, manganese, and cobalt were redepositing on the cathode. Notably, manganese and cobalt showed a preference to redeposit on the  low  fluorescence  intensity  (lower concentration)  regions  of  the  cathode.  Conversely,  nickel  shows redeposition  on  the  higher intensity  regions  of the  cathode.  This  suggests  that  nickel  may  have  a  different driving force for redeposition than manganese and cobalt.

The team chose the surface sensitive NEXAFS (TEY) as their main technique to track the relevance between the observed decay and the formation of CEI components. Samples are measured at discharged state, 3.6 V. As shown in Figure 13b, they start to observe the emergence of Mn 3+ and Mn 2+ features around the 20 th cycle, and this trend continues with cycling, along with the concurrent decay of Mn 4+ species. This indicates that Mn3O4, which is believed to be the main reduction product of LMO and electrolyte, is forming and accumulating during cycling. Using linear combination fitting, they calculate that the oxidation state of the LMO surface drops from 3.5 + (1 st ) to 2.83 + (60 th ), as shown in Figure 13c. They believe that the manganese dissolution in LMO may be associated  with  the  dynamics  of  an  altered  LMO  surface  (possiblyMn3O4),  including  the  dissolution  and redeposition of the altered layers.

## Cation Disordered Rocksalt (DRX+) Materials Consortium (Gerbrand Ceder, University of California, Berkeley)

Objective. This project aims to develop high-energy, high-rate Ni-free and Co-free cation disordered rocksalt (DRX)  cathode  materials  based  on  manganese  as  a  cost-effective,  earth-abundant,  and  safe  redox-active element. Specifically, Gen1-DRX achieving 650 Wh/kg at 100 mA/g for at least 100 cycles will be optimized and scaled up. Gen2-DRX achieving at least 700 Wh/kg at 100 mA/g for 300 cycles will be developed through the  application  of  functional  coatings  on  Gen1,  incorporation  of  electrolyte  improvements,  and  further compositional and morphological refinements. Gen3-DRX with very high specific energies between 850 Wh/kg and 1100 Wh/kg will be explored by introducing partial disorder in the structure.

Impact. DRX and related materials are well positioned to address resource limitations and cost concerns posed by use of nickel and cobalt in traditional Ni-Mn-Co (NMC)-based cathodes. This promising sustainable cathode technology can potentially scale Li-ion batteries to multiple TWh annual production at low cost.

Approach. Technical approaches span from materials development to electrode fabrication optimization:

- Develop  high-voltage  electrolytes  specifically  optimized  for  the  DRX  materials  being  pursued  in  the consortium. Investigate additives as well as solvent and salt modifications to enable more stable cycling of Gen1 and Gen2 cathodes at high voltage.
- Apply inorganic and carbonaceous coatings to the DRX surface for protection and creation of electronic pathways in cathode composites with low carbon content. Develop, evaluate, and optimize an effective, scalable process of creating carbonaceous conformal coatings on DRX powder materials.
- Evaluate  synthesis  approaches  and  conditions;  optimize  composition  and  morphology  of  Gen1-DRX. Scale up the synthesis to produce the larger quantity of materials needed in the consortium.
- Explore partially disordered Mn-based materials as high-energy, high-rate cathodes made with scalable synthesis methods. Investigate in detail the structure and synthesis pathways of these metastable materials, leading to materials with &gt; 1000 Wh/kg.
- Improve  DRX electrode  fabrication  by  lowering  carbon  content  and  optimizing  particle  size  and morphology of components. Establish optimal voltage limits and cycling protocols for DRX cathodes.

Out-Year Goals. DRX cathodes that match or exceed the performance metrics of the current state-of-the-art NMC-based cathode materials will be delivered. Gen1-DRX will be optimized and scaled up. Gen2-DRX will be developed. Development of Gen3-DRX will be initiated.

Collaborations. This  multiorganizational  consortium  effort  includes  the  following  participants:  Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL); University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB); Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL); Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL); Argonne National Laboratory (ANL); and SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory.

## DRX Scale-Up Using Solid-State Synthesis

Most DRX materials are synthesized via classical solid-state synthesis methods around 700-1100Â°C followed by  high-energy  ball milling. This  can  result  in  poorly  controlled,  inhomogeneous,  non-ideal  particle morphologies and distributions. Additionally, understanding of how the solid-state process limits the solubility of fluorine in high Mn-content DRX materials is limited. Last quarter, the team learned that high-temperature synthesis  with  moderate  holding  time  (1000Â°C  for  4 hours)  produces  a  low-F  DRX  material  with  trace LiF impurities.  As  a  result,  the  ANL  Materials  Engineering  Research  Facility  (MERF)  team  modified  the solid-state synthesis protocol with lower temperature calcinations (900Â°C) and longer holding times to produce DRX materials with higher F-content, while also minimizing LiF impurities.
