## Task 1: Synthesis and Scale-up

ZrO2 in 500-mL jars at 100 RPM using Retsch Planetary Ball Mill PM 400. The rotation speed was increased from previous batch syntheses to further decrease precursor size and encourage more fluorine incorporation. Several calcinations were done with ~ 40 g of precursor at a time, as loose powders to not deviate from optimal calcination  conditions  obtained  last  quarter.  Calcinations  were  done  at  900Â°C  for  12  hours  under  argon atmosphere. The calcined DRX material batches were combined and subsequently ball-milled at 400 RPM in an organic solvent for 4 hours without any carbon, resulting in nano-size primary particles (Figure 1c). Figure 1a shows X-ray diffraction (XRD) of the final product, which clearly shows the DRX phase (Fm-3m). 19 F nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy ( 19 F-NMR) was done on this material to qualitatively measure the F-content (Figure 1b). Compared to the previous scale-up batch, the current batch shows significant improvement in terms of fluorine incorporation into the DRX structure. However, compared to LMTF-2622 synthesized in small scale, the F-content of the current batch is still lower. Thus, fluorine incorporation remains a challenge and requires further investigation. Particle size analysis on the scale-up materials was also performed. Interestingly, this current batch of DRX material showed a narrower size distribution compared to that of the previous batch (Figure 1d). Differences in calcination temperatures may produce DRX materials with different mechanical properties. This may influence the rate of nano-sizing during the ball-milling process. In any case, a narrow distribution is beneficial for more uniform material properties at the particle level.

The phase progression during solid-state synthesis of DRX materials was further investigated at SLAC. Using in situ X-ray powder diffraction, the team is able to observe changes to the crystalline phases as the material progresses from precursors, through intermediate phases, and finally forms the DRX endpoint. By tracking this phase progression, their data sheds light on the formation mechanism of the DRX material. Experiments were conducted at Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Lightsource BL2-1 using an Anton Paar furnace integrated onto the beamline for solid-state synthesis. Precursors were prepared according to protocols previously developed by the DRX team and heated under flowing argon with powder diffraction data collected continuously during the annealing process. They conducted in situ measurements during synthesis of several DRX compositions, Li1.2Mn0.4Ti0.4O2, Li1.2Mn0.5Ti0.3O1.8F0.2, LMTF-2622, and Li1.1Mn0.8Ti0.1O1.9F0.1. Several crystalline intermediates  were  observed  for  all  compositions  during  heating,  as  seen  in  Figure  2.  These  intermediates appear to be the same for all compositions although the details of the various transformation temperatures and the crystal structures for these intermediates is still to be determined.

## Development of Aqueous Co-Precipitation Synthesis Method

Building on previous work, the team attempted to synthesize the LMTF-2622 baseline cathode material using the developed aqueous co-precipitation method. Preliminary synthesis was done using a 1 L Taylor Vortex Reactor  by  mixing  water-soluble  manganese  and  titanium  reagents  with  NaOH  and  ammonia  to  form  a Mn0.70Ti0.30-hydroxide precursor, based on inductively coupled plasma (ICP). This precursor is Mn-deficient from the ideal Mn0.75Ti0.25-hydroxide precursor. Further optimization studies will be carried out to obtain the ideal  transition  metal  (TM)  stoichiometry.  Figure 3a  shows  the  XRD  pattern  of  the  resulting  hydroxide precursor,  which  displays  broad  and  weak  peaks  related  to  Mn3O4  (I41/amd).  A  previously  synthesized Mn0.50Ti0.50-hydroxide  precursor  was  shown  to  have  an  amorphous  structure  with  less  Mn3O4  impurities. Manganese-rich  hydroxides  are  air  sensitive  and  readily  oxidized.  The  higher  Mn-content  as  well  as  the inherently nano-sized nature of DRX precursor primary particles (Figure 3b) leads to the rapid formation of Mn3O4. It is not clear if manganese atoms oxidize and segregate from titanium completely to form Mn3O4 or titanium exists partially within the Mn3O4 structure.

The DRX hydroxide precursor was mixed with LiOH anhydrous and LiF before being calcined at 700Â°C, 800Â°C, and 900Â°C for 12 hours under argon atmosphere. XRD patterns of the calcined materials are also shown in Figure 4a. Calcination at 700Â°C produced a mixed phase of LiMnO2 (Pmmn) and DRX (Fm-3m) structure, whereas the 800Â°C and 900Â°C calcinations produced a single-phase DRX structure. Compared to previous calcinations on Mn0.50Ti0.50-hydroxide precursor, this higher manganese precursor requires higher calcination temperature to form the pure DRX phase. Increased particle growth is also observed when increasing calcination temperature (Figure 4b). Similar to the solid-state synthesis route, LiF was used as the source of fluorine. To investigate whether fluorine is retained in the bulk, scanning electron microscopy / energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy  were  done  on  the  900Â°C  calcined  sample.  Figure 3c  shows  Spot#1  with  the  appearance  of well-distributed  fluorine  in  the  particle,  which  initially  suggests  successful  fluorination  in  this  material. However, Spot#2 shows the presence of localized fluorine hotspots. This suggests that the fluorine is unevenly distributed and may exist as an impurity phase on the surface that may be too small to detect in XRD. Follow-up studies  using in situ XRD  during  calcinations  and  F-NMR  will  be  pursued  to  better  understand  the synthesis mechanism.

## Development of Combustion Synthesis Method

The team at ORNL developed a combustion synthesis route to produce Mn/Ti-based DRX powders. Briefly, this method involves heating an aqueous solution containing oxidizing reagents (for example, metal nitrates) and a fuel (for example, glycine) to its autoignition temperature. After the combustion reaction, powders were further heat treated (up to 1000Â°C under argon) to increase the crystallinity and grain size. While the results shown here are for gram-scale batches, the process is scalable and capable of producing large quantities (kg+) of crystalline powders.

This route was used to prepare several DRX oxides and oxyfluorides where the Mn/Ti molar ratio was either 5/3 or 7/1. Figure 4a shows powder XRD data for a material with the nominal composition Li1.2Mn0.5Ti0.3O1.95 (assuming Mn 3+ /Ti 4+ valence states and 2.5% anionic vacancies), which was heated to 1000Â°C for 4 hours. In addition to the desired DRX phase, Rietveld refinement indicates the presence of monoclinic secondary phase(s) (for example, Li2TiO3 and/or Li2MnO3). It should be noted that Li2TiO3 and Li2MnO3 are isostructural, and due to the similar X-ray scattering power of Mn 4+ and Ti 4+ , these two phases are difficult to distinguish with the present dataset. While the oxide synthesis yielded a mixture of phases, an oxyfluoride powder with the nominal composition  Li1.25Mn0.5Ti0.3O1.95F0.05  was  nearly  phase-pure  DRX  after  heat  treatment  at  1000Â°C  (see Figure 4b). A  similar trend was observed for Mn-rich powders  including Li1.2Mn0.7Ti0.1O1.85 versus Li1.35Mn0.7Ti0.1O1.85F0.15 (see Figure 5). These intriguing results suggest that fluorine incorporation stabilizes the DRX phase due to formation of different intermediates during heating.

The effect of synthesis temperature on DRX phase formation was also explored. Since the combustion route involves atomistic mixing of precursors in solution, the DRX phase can be formed at much lower temperatures (for example, 800Â°C; see Figure 4c) compared to traditional solid-state reactions (typically 900-1000Â°C). The lower temperature of the combustion route is advantageous for two key reasons: decreasing energy requirements

to synthesize high purity materials, and potentially providing more intimate control over the final powder's stoichiometry by reducing Li/F loss, which is problematic at temperatures â‰¥ 900Â°C. To further explore this topic, preliminary in situ XRD data were collected to assess the onset temperature for DRX phase formation in the Li1.25Mn0.5Ti0.3O1.95F0.05 powder (see Figure 6). These data indicate that DRX phase formation begins as early as 700Â°C, and the phase-purity increases to 73.1(12) wt% after 10-minute heating at 800Â°C. It should be noted  that the  refinement  values  reported  here  serve only  as  a  semi-quantitative  metric,  and more  detailed compositional analysis (for example, ICP and fluorine ion-selective electrode) is under way. Nonetheless, these results indicate that the combustion route enables DRX phase formation at lower temperatures and shorter times compared to conventional solid-state routes.

While the initial cycles exhibit a sloping voltage profile, extended cycling yielded a plateau ~ 3 V versus Li/Li + due to formation of the spinel-like phase that is well-known for Mn-rich DRX phases. The material also showed good cycling stability with negligible fade over 30 cycles (testing is in progress).

Overall,  the  scalable  combustion  synthesis  route  is  capable  of  producing  high-purity,  high-performance Mn/Ti-based  DRX  oxides  and  oxyfluorides. ## Highlights of Task 2

The highlights for this quarter are as follows:

- New localized high-concentration electrolytes (LHCEs) with the formulation of LiFSI-xDMC-yTTE (LiFSI, lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide; DMC, dimethyl carbonate; TTE, 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl-2,2,3,3-tetrafluoropropyl ether) were developed and evaluated. LHCEs with less DMC content were identified as most promising for high-voltage DRX cathodes.
- Detailed characterization revealed the unique properties of the CEI layer formed between the DRX cathode and the new LHCE (ED04). In contrast to what is observed in the baseline electrolyte (ED01), this CEI enables effective protection of the DRX cathode.
- Completed high-voltage stability evolution on EC-lean electrolytes with three additives (Q4 milestone). TMSPa was identified as the most promising in stabilizing the cathode surface while maintaining good cycle life and capacity retention.

## Characterization of LHCEs

Last  quarter,  DRX  electrodes  after  100 cycles  in  a  conventional  electrolyte  of  1 M LiPF6  in  EC-DMC (1:2 by wt.) (ED01) and an LHCE of LiFSI-2DMC-0.2EC-3TTE (by mol) (ED04) were characterized using solid-state  NMR  and  soft  X-ray  absorption  spectroscopy  (sXAS).  This  quarter,  the  PNNL team  performed microstructural and chemical composition analyses using scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and  electron  energy  loss  spectroscopy  on  these  cycled  DRX  electrodes,  with  results  shown  in  Figure 8. Comparison of the STEM images in Figure 8a-c reveals that the DRX electrode cycled in baseline electrolyte (ED01) becomes cracked and porous (Figure 8b), while that cycled in LHCE (ED04) shows fewer cracks and less porosity (Figure 8c).

## Task 2: Electrolytes

In addition, as shown in Figure 8d-f for the electronic structures of the pristine and two cycled electrodes in both ED01 and ED04, a slight oxygen loss and a reduction of manganese are observed near the surface of the pristine  DRX  electrode.  The  high  energy  shift  for  fluorine  (F)-K  suggests  the  fluorine  in  complex  form (Figure 8d), which likely comes from the PVDF binder used in the electrode. A thick fluorine, oxygen, carbon (not shown) containing structure is obvious on the surface of the DRX electrode cycled in ED01. Moreover, a significant reduction in manganese compared to the pristine (~ 1.1 eV peak shift) and a much broader O-K peak are observed in the DRX electrode cycled in ED01. The manganese reduction and the chemical change of DRX penetrate to the bulk region in DRX cycled in ED01. In the case of DRX cycled in ED04, the fluorine, oxygen, carbon (not shown) containing complex structure is very thin, a gradient of manganese reduction is observed, and the bulk closely mimics the pristine state. Furthermore, manganese on the surface of DRX cycled in ED04 is less reduced than that on DRX cycled in ED01. The results demonstrate that the CEI layer formed in  the  LHCE  (ED04),  as  contrasted  with  that  in  the  baseline  electrolyte  (ED01),  can  effectively  protect DRX electrode. The result based on microstructural features captured by the STEM is consistent with the results of ssNMR and sXAS. Meanwhile, the PNNL team extended the cycling stability test of ED01 and ED04 in Li||DRX half cells in the voltage range of 2.0-4.8 V. As shown in Figure 9a, Li||DRX cells with ED04 deliver much higher capacity and more stable cycling than with ED01, having a capacity retention of ~ 75.5%, as compared with ~ 21.2% for ED01, after 200 cycles.

New LHCEs with the formulation of LiFSI-xDMC-yTTE (where 1.6 â‰¤ x â‰¤ 5, 1 â‰¤ y â‰¤ 3) were tested in Li||DRX half cells in the voltage range of 2.0-4.8 V with the purpose of finding the optimal electrolyte formulation for DRX cathodes.  These  LHCEs  were  coded  as  ED05  to  ED19.  The  DRX  electrodes  were  prepared  by  the LBNL team (Y. Fu and V. Battaglia) using the second batch of Argonne DRX powders (Li1.2Mn0.6Ti0.2O1.8F0.2). The preliminary cycling results for the new electrolytes show that higher content of DMC (x &gt; 2) is not good for the cycling performance, and hence they focused on LHCEs with lower DMC content, ED05 - ED07 and ED17 - ED19. The cycling stability of Li||DRX cells with these electrolytes and ED01 and ED04 are presented in Figure 9b/c. As shown in Figure 9b, for the 1 st cycle charge and discharge voltage profiles, ED01 shows a discharge capacity of 184.5 mAh/g at 10 mA/g, with the first Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 58.7%. However, the LHCEs (ED04 - ED07, ED17 - ED19) show slightly higher discharge capacities compared with ED01, with ED17 delivering the highest discharge capacity of 202.6 mAh/g and first CE of 61.6%. At the current density of 20 mA/g for charging and discharging, Li||DRX cells with these LHCEs deliver higher capacities than those with the conventional electrolyte (ED01). The CEs at this current density (20 mA/g) are within the range of 95% - 98%. In addition, Li||DRX cells with ED17 show the highest capacity and the most stable cycling  compared  with  those  of  other  electrolytes.  More  duplicated  cells  are  being  tested  to  confirm  the exceptional cycling performance observed for ED17. Overall, the obtained results suggest that LHCEs with less DMC content are promising for high-voltage DRX cathodes.

## Simulations to Elucidate Degradation Mechanisms involving Reactive Oxygen

Using density functional theory (DFT), the team has pursued mechanistic explanations for the decomposition of common carbonate-based electrolytes at Li-ion battery positive electrodes. In recent years, it has been widely reported that oxygen in the singlet excited state ( 1 O2) is responsible for decomposing EC solvent molecules via a chemical oxidation reaction. While this is consistent with the observation of O2 evolving from high-voltage positive electrodes (including some DRX materials) at potentials &gt; 4.2 V, they do not believe that explanations based  on 1 O2  are  plausible.  Figure 10a  shows  elementary  mechanisms  for  the  two  most  commonly  cited reactions between EC and 1 O2: a single-step concerted reaction forming hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and VC and an addition-elimination reaction yielding  water  and  1,3-dioxolane-2,4-dione.  DFT  calculations  at  the Ï‰B97X-V/def2-TZVPPD/SMD level of theory predict that these reactions both have high free energy barriers (âˆ†G â€¡ &gt;&gt; 1 eV),  suggesting  that  they  will  be  extremely  slow  under  normal  battery  operating  conditions. However, their calculations suggest that the superoxide radical (O2 -1 ) can more easily react with EC (Figure 11b),  particularly  through  a  nucleophilic  substitution.  Further  computational  studies  examining reactions between EC and oxygen anions-including superoxide as well as peroxide (O2 -2 )-are ongoing. They are  also  collaborating  with  B. McCloskey's  group,  which  is  performing  experiments  aiming  to  detect decomposition products for reactions between EC-based electrolytes and superoxide/peroxide species.

## Outgassing of EC-Lean Electrolytes with Three Additives

The team examined three battery additives [lithium bis(oxalato)borate (LiBOB), TMSPa, and FEC], and studied the H2, Me3SiF, and CO2 outgassing that occurs from each cell over the first eight cycles, noting that any Me3SiF evolution is specific to TMSPa cells. In Figure 11, H2 and Me3SiF evolution are multiplied by a factor of 10 for easier viewing. They added 3 wt% of these additives to 1.5 M LiPF6 in an EC lean electrolyte (15 vol% EC, 85 vol% DMC) and tested them in Li||DRX cells with LMTF-2622C-1 DRX (Li1.2Mn0.6Ti0.2O1.8F0.2) supplied from  ANL.  The  DRX  was  mixed  with  C65  and  PVDF in  a  70:20:10  ratio  and  had  very  similar  loading (Â± 0.1 mg) across all samples. The LiBOB additive showed the worst performance with continuous capacity fade, a result that is surprising given the typical use of LiBOB to promote cathode stabilization. TMSPa is an additive that scavenges F -ions and reacts to form Me3SiF, a gas that can be detected. The first peak shows the most Me3SiF evolution, but repeated cycles show minor continuous evolution at high voltages. FEC shows small, low-voltage (~ 4.2 V) CO2 evolution during charge, likely the reduction of FEC. This reduced product likely forms H2 at high voltages during later cycles, with H2 evolution slowly increasing over cycling. All cells observed similar small O2 evolution ~ 4.6 V on their 1 st cycle (not shown), indicating that O2 evolution was not impacted  by  additive  inclusion.  It  should  be  noted  that  this  DRX  batch  (LMTF-2622C-1)  has  different CO2 outgassing behavior than other DRX tested, with the onset voltage being higher than other DRX material, and total CO2 outgassing being higher. The origin of this different behavior is still being investigated. In the end, among all additives characterized, TMSPa appears to be the most promising in stabilizing the cathode surface  while  maintaining  good  cycle  life  and  capacity  retention;  they  will  continue  to  characterize TMSPa-containing  cells  to  understand  this  performance  improvement  next  quarter.  This  completes  this quarter's milestone.

## Highlights of Task 3

The highlights for this quarter are as follows:

- Investigated the impact of carbon nanotube (CNT) weight fraction in DRX cathode performance.
- Tetrahydrofuran  (THF)  was  identified  as  a  better solvent for the synthesis of graphene-wrapped polyethylenimine (PEI)-coated DRX.

This quarter, they investigated the impact of use of CNTs at different weight fractions relative to the active material. The binder content was essentially held constant around 10%. The work presented here is on the first batch  of  DRX  supplied  by  ANL.  Note  that  the  team  initiated  work  on  the  second  batch  received  and  is anticipating a third batch in early October. In Figure 12a, the capacity versus cycle number for batch 1 for three loadings of carbon (8%, 10%, and 15% by weight) is presented. Clearly, the electrode with the highest level of carbon, 15 wt%, demonstrates the best cycling performance. One sees that the capacity at a charge-discharge current of 20 mAh/g starts at ~ 189 mAh/g, rises to 194 mAh/g by the 15 th cycle, then experiences a fairly linear decline to 172 mAh/g by the 100 th cycle. Figure 12b provides the voltage profiles for the first 15 cycles and additional profiles for cycles 50, 75, and 100. Overall, one sees that the voltage curve is evolving from the 1 st cycle. The interpretation is that during the entire time of cycling, the material's structure is changing from rock salt to partial spinel, otherwise referred to as Î´ -phase. It appears that early on the change in structure is leading to slightly more capacity between 2 V and 4.8 V. After this initial capacity rise from structure change, they begin to see impedance rise in the Nyquist plots shown in Figure 12c, and the associated capacity loss in Figure 12a. A close inspection of the impedance rise points to three time regimes. The first is the mid-frequency region that ranges from 1 Hz to 1000 Hz. This impedance is typically associated with charge transfer resistance. The second time regime of impedance rise is between 0.005 Hz and 0.2 Hz.  They believe that this rise  of impedance could be due to the development of a barrier layer on the CNTs and active material. The third source of impedance rise is below 0.003 Hz and could be attributed either to slower solid-state lithium diffusion or longer diffusion pathways. [Disclaimer: Since the impedance is taken at 60% depth of discharge (DOD) based on the initial capacity, the impedance is being taken at an ever-lower DOD as the capacity declines after the first 15 cycles. Charge transfer and diffusion can be SOC dependent in crystalline materials, thus the increase in resistance could be due to the changes in Li-ion fraction in the material with cycling.]

## Computational Framework for Mn-Based DRX Modeling

This quarter, the team studied the driving force and kinetics for the phase transformation of the high Mn-content (Mn &gt; 0.6 f.u.) DRX oxides with a general formula of Li-Mn-Ti-O. The phase transformation originates from the DRX and forms a new partial spinel-type ordering phase (Î´ phase) during the electrochemical cycling. Through DFT calculations  and  the  nudged-elastic band (NEB) method, they established the design guidelines  for  Li-rich  and Mn-rich compositions  that  combine  high  energy density, high rate capability, and good cyclability.

The results in Figure 15 confirm that a larger Ti 4+ content leads  to  a  lower  driving  force  (less  negative  ES-EÎ³),  and  the  manganese  content  directly  affects  the thermodynamic driving force for transforming to the Î´ phase.

Additionally, the team formulated a computational framework to model the intercalation voltage profiles of DRX materials, counting the complex disordered structures and multiple redox behaviors. They introduce an approach that combines sparse regression to construct cluster-expansion Hamiltonian and semi-grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations to sample the energies of charge-balanced ionic configurations. These techniques are applied  to  DRX oxyfluoride Li1.3-xMn0.4Nb0.3O1.6F0.4  to  predict  its  voltage  profile  with lithium intercalation. Figure 16a presents the simulated profile (green dots), which agrees well with experimental data (green solid line).  Figure 16b shows the content of redox-active species during the intercalation, which provides a clear demonstration  of  the  manganese  and  oxygen  contributions  to  the  redox  potential  as  a  function  of  lithium content.  The  methods  developed  here  for  DRX  cathodes  will  be  useful  for  modeling  other  complex  ionic materials with multiple redox-active species and a disordered structure.

## Earth-Abundant Cathode Active Materials (EaCAM) Consortium (Jason Croy, Argonne National Laboratory)

Objective. The long-term objectives of this program are the discovery and development of mechanistic insights, novel  materials,  new  processes,  and  design strategies,  as  well  as  dissemination  of  information, that  enable cathode  compositions  based  100%  in  earth  abundant,  sustainable  chemistries.  The  ultimate  goal  will  be synthetic control of pre-determined particle designs, local ordering, integrated structures, dopant site-selectivity, and primary and secondary morphologies, including monolithic architectures, of high-energy earth-abundant cathode active materials (EaCAM). Such advancements would contribute greatly to lowering cost and increasing sustainability of next-generation technologies for transportation applications and beyond.

Impact. Prioritizing earth-abundant elements in the search for new technologies has direct and positive impacts across the three pillars of sustainable development (social, economic, and environmental sustainability) and will  substantially  accelerate  progress  toward  diversifying  supply  chains,  increasing  sustainability,  and broadening the portfolio of storage technologies. In addition, the space of exploration related to the complex integration of structure types, local- and long-range, as well the correlations to synthesis-structure-property relationships, is large. It is expected that detailed investigations in this space will lead to new insights and directions in advanced design and synthesis of cathode active materials. Furthermore, new approaches to oxide surface stabilization, including electrolyte formulations, will be developed.

Approach. The  EaCAM team will  build  on its  considerable  experience  in  areas  of  critical  importance  to advance project goals. Focused areas of collaboration, across the consortium, will be established to gain insight on complex synthesis-structure-property relationships that govern materials properties from the atomic-scale to electrode-level  performance.  Atomistic,  electrochemical,  and  techno-economic  modeling  will  be  combined with  synthesis/processing,  advanced structural/chemical characterization,  and  electrochemical  analysis  to establish mechanistic models of performance and degradation across length scales. Mn-based cathodes will serve as the initial platforms to explore the complex and broad space of EaCAM design related thereto.

Out-Year Goals. The out-year goal is for Mn-rich (&gt; ~ 50%) cathode materials that can achieve 250-300 Wh/kgcell for ~ 1000 cycles at C/3.

Collaborations. The  EaCAM  Consortium  is  a  collaboration  among  seven  national  laboratories:  Argonne National Laboratory (ANL), National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL), Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, Idaho National Laboratory, and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. Eight universities are represented through embedded graduate students.

## Effects of Calcination Temperature on Structure and Performance of LxS Cathode-Oxides

This fiscal year, the EaCAM program began an investigation of a newly reported, cobalt-free cathode material, designated  LT-LMNO  (LT-LiMn0.5Ni0.5O2),  which  has  a  predominant,  cubic-close-packed  lithiated-spinel structure, interspersed with layered and rock salt domains. The team refers to this new class of lithiated-spinel cathodes  with  coexisting  layered  and  disordered  rock  salt  domains  as  LxS  materials;  they  are  typically synthesized at a relatively low temperature (LT, for example, 400Â°C). Their experimental observations indicate that LT-LMNO is stable at this temperature, whereas heating LT-LMNO at elevated temperatures induces a transition  of  this  multicomponent  structure  toward  the  slightly  disordered,  high-temperature  (HT)  layered phase,  HT-LMNO,  in  which  there  is  ~  11%  disorder  of  the  lithium  and  transition  metal  (TM)  ions  in

## Focus Area 1: Design and Synthesis of EaCAM

alternate layers when prepared at ~ 850Â°C. They believe that these temperature-driven phase transitions and the structural interplay between the lithiated-spinel layered and rock salt domains exert a profound influence on the local structure and, consequently, on the electrochemical properties of these composite electrodes. Motivated by the prospect of gaining critical insights into the intricacies of these temperature-induced phase transitions, as well as local order/disorder, work this quarter focused on synthesis of a series of LMNO materials at various calcination  temperatures.  The  primary  objective  is  to  scrutinize  these  phase-transitions  and  the  impact  of structural correlations on electrochemical behavior.

The X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) and corresponding structural refinements reveal that the LMNO LxS electrode  materials  display  continuous  topotactic  transitions  between  the  cubic  and  layered structural components, the extent of which is dependent on the synthesis temperature; see Figure 1a-e. A notable parabolic  trend  in  the  electrochemical  properties,  evident  in  Figure 2a-d,  is  a  direct  consequence  of  the perturbation  of  the  three-dimensional  (3D)  Li-ion  diffusion  channels  and,  on  heat  treatment,  an  increased ordering  of  the  lithium  and  TM ions  in  the  layered  two-dimensional  (2D)  channels.  The  remarkably  high capacity (~ 230 mAh/g) of LT-LMNO compositions calcined at 400Â°C (LMNO400), is attributed to  (1) the presence  of  ordered  3D Li-ion  diffusion  channels  and  (2) the  structural  stability  of  the  lithiated-spinel component. In contrast, LMNO500-700 samples exhibited inferior performance, which the team attributes to highly disordered layered domains that are generated at intermediate temperatures, thereby impeding Li + -ion diffusion. The gradual shift from a highly disordered to a more ordered layered structure occurs above 700Â°C, thereby  promoting  2D Li +\_ ion  diffusion  and  enhancing  electrochemical  performance,  as  observed  for  the LMNO800-LMNO900 samples. These findings highlight the opportunity to tailor novel electrode structures with lithiated-spinel and layered components. To this end, future research will focus on improving performance of LxS electrodes by optimizing calcination procedures and making compositional adjustments.

The Focus Area 2 highlights for this quarter are as follows:

- The mechanisms of O-O dimer formation at high states of charge (SOCs) are shown to be dependent on the 3D structure of the 60%-LiMn0.5Ni0.5/40%-Li2MnO3 (Li1.17Ni0.25Mn0.58O2) material.

## Influence of Domain Structure on Low SOC Impedance

The team has shown in previous reports from ab initio molecular dynamics simulations that the rate of formation of  oxygen  dimers  is  faster  in  the  'ribbon  model,'  describing  a  more  ordered  domain  structure,  than in  the 'staggered model' with less coherence. Using oxygen dimer bond length, they were able to track the formation of  peroxide,  superoxide,  and  dioxygen  species.  Preliminary  data  show  differences  in  the  mechanisms  of formation of oxygen dimers. The ribbon model seems to undergo a rapid formation of superoxide to dioxygen (Figure 3a), whereas in the staggered ribbon model the superoxide species seems to be more stable (Figure 3b). This is an indication of a possible reversibility in the staggered ribbon case.

## Model Systems

To  investigate  the  effects  of  fluorination  on  LMR  oxides,  the  team  previously  synthesized  a  series  of Li1.2Ni0.2Mn0.6O2-xFx (x = 0, 0.01, 0.025, 0.05; denoted as LNMO, LNMO-F1, LNMO-F2.5, and LNMO-F5, respectively)  single  crystal  samples  using  LiF-KF  as  the  fluorine  source.  All  samples  adopted  the  same octahedron particle morphology with predominately (012) surface facets. Synchrotron XRD analysis confirms the absence of LiF impurities, whereas a LiMn2O4-type spinel phase was found in all F-LNMO samples, with higher fluorine content promoting the formation of more spinel secondary phases. This quarter, they employed X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy (sXAS), and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) to analyze the elemental and chemical distributions in this series of samples. The study aims to probe the distributions covering the entire range from surface to bulk, with the XPS probing roughly 2 nm on the top surface, sXAS in the total electron yield (TEY) mode and fluorescence yield (FY) mode probing ~ 5 nm  surface  and  50 nm  subsurface  regions,  respectively, and  the  EELS  technique  combined  with focused ion beam lithography probing both surface and bulk regions. Figure 5a/b shows the fitted manganese 2 p and manganese 2 s XPS spectra. For LNMO, surface manganese cations are  at  4+.  The  presence  of  lower valence  Mn 3+ cation  was  detected on  all  F-LNMO crystals,  with  its content  increasing  with  increasing fluorination levels. The nickel oxidation state, on the other hand, remains  unchanged for  all  LNMO and F-LNMO  samples. On  the fluorine 1 s XPS  spectra,  a  broad peak centered ~ 684 eV was visible on  LNMO-F2.5  and  LNMO-F5, suggesting the presence of fluorine on the sample. This value is much

They further evaluated Mn 3+ distribution by  estimating  its  content  from  principle component  analysis  of  the  collected  spectra  (Figure 5e). The surface to bulk distribution of manganese oxidation state in the LNMO-F5 crystals was further examined by the scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) - EELS integrated spectroscopy. Figure 6 shows the manganese L 3 / L 2-edge EELS spectra, collected in the (102) surface region of 1-31 nm and the bulk region of 120-820 nm. The peak area ratio between the L 3-edge and L 2-edge on the manganese spectra is typically used to  determine  the  valence  of  manganese  cations. It  is  clear  that  the  MnL 3 / L 2 peak  area  ratios,  near  the (102) surface region, Figure 6a, are broadly higher than that in the bulk region (Figure 6b), consistent with an overall higher Mn 3+ cation content near the surface. The gradient distribution in Mn 3+ content is also confirmed, with the highest content detected near the top surface and lowest content in the bulk region. The results further reveal the particle-level gradient distribution of Mn 3+ concentration from surface to bulk of the F-LNMO crystals. Their attempt to spatially resolve fluorine distribution, however, was unsuccessful. In the STEM-EELS analysis, the detected fluorine signals fall into the noise level due to low concentration. In the STEM - energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis, on the other hand, the FK edge signal overlaps with the MnL edge signal in F-LNMO, resulting in difficulties in deconvoluting the signals.

Overall, detailed characterization reveals that in  LNMO  single crystals,  the  surface  is  enclosed with a thin layer of spinel LiNixMn2-xO4 (x &gt; 0.5), whereas the bulk remains a layered structure.  On  fluorination,  there is a concentration gradient of Mn 3+ whose  content  decreases from the top surface to the subsurface region of the F-LNMO  particle.  This  can  be attributed to formation of Ni-enriched LiNixMn2-xO4-yFy (x &gt; 0.5) where Mn 3+ is generated on charge  compensation.  Less Mn 3+ is present in the subsurface, while bulk manganese remains at 4+, suggesting a 'spinel-layered' structure  where  domains  of  the LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 spinel  phase  are integrated into the native layered framework in the bulk.

## Observation of Delamination

When  spinel  LNMO//Li  half  cells  were  cycled  under  a  high  upper  cutoff  voltage  (UCV)  of  4.95  V  with low-EC electrolyte (1.0 M LiPF in EC:EMC 1:9), a delamination issue was observed after only 10 cycles of discharging  at  different  rates.  The  cycling  condition  was  aggressive  (4.95 V  compared  to  the  regular 4.8 V UCV) to exacerbate the dissolution process. Subsequent to delamination, etched dents were observed in the aluminum current collector of the cathode-electrode film. The delamination phenomenon was attributed to formation  of  acidic  electrolyte  decomposition/hydrolysis  products  and  consequent  etching  of  the  electrode materials and current collectors.

## Comparison of Vessels for Soaking Test: Glass versus Polyethylene (PE) Vials

It  is  well  documented that Gen2 (1.2 M LiPF6 EC:EMC 3:7 wt) is not stable when exposed to moderately elevated  temperatures  in  glass or  PE  vials. Particularly,  not  only  the  hydrolysis  products  from PF6 -[OPF3, OPF2OH, OPF(OH)2] are observed, but the secondary products through the reactions with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) [OPF2OMe, OPF(OMe)2, OPFOMeOH, and OPF2(OCH2CH2OMe), etc.] were also detected. These secondary products were also found to appear later in the stage of decomposition. As depicted in Figure 8, when Gen2 was stored in a glass vial, peaks of DMC and diethyl carbonate were observed due to transesterification

(Figure 8a), and its 19 F NMR spectra showed late-stage electrolyte decomposition of OPF2(OCH2CH2OMe) (compound 2) and OPF2OMe (compound 3) dominating its decomposition products (Figure 8b/d). However, when  Gen2  was  stored  in  a  PE  vial,  only  peaks  for  EC  and  EMC  in  its 1 H  NMR spectra  were  observed (Figure 8c). In addition, only one decomposition product, OPF2(OH) (compound 1), was based on 19 F NMR analysis (Figure 8d). As depicted in Figure 8b, the presence of fluoroborate species, namely OPF2(OH)-BF3 at -149.5 ppm and BF4- at -156.4 ppm in the 19 F NMR spectra, provided additional confirmation of the direct involvement of borosilicate in the side reactions. The peak assignments presented in Figure 8 were based on documented chemical shifts for existing oxyfluorophosphates and their J-coupling constants.

## Additive Effects in Mitigating TM Dissolution

To  address  the  severe  electrode/electrolyte  interaction  between  LNMO  and  the  electrolyte,  as  well  as  the delamination issue encountered in the aged LNMO cells, soaking tests and electrochemical cycling tests of LNMO in the presence of additives were carried out. In these tests, 3 wt% of each selected additive was added to Gen2 as the soaking solutions for the LNMO electrodes in a glass vial (to exacerbate dissolution) under the same conditions. Out of 10 additives tested (Figure 7), seven of the additives could prevent the delamination of LNMO electrodes and three soaked electrolytes [tris(trimethylsilyl) phosphite, LiDFOB, and p-toluenesulfonyl isocyanate  (PTSI)  containing  samples]  did  not  show  any  obvious  color  changes,  implying  a  depressed electrolyte  decomposition.  Especially  with  the  use  of  LiDFOB  and  PTSI,  the  Gen2  electrolytes  were  still colorless, with no electrode delamination observed after soaking.

As shown in Figure 10, both LiDFOB and PTSI showed minimal NMR peak shifting, suggesting that they effectively reduced manganese dissolution. Vinylboronic anhydride pyridine complex also showed relatively small NMR peak shifting; however, it failed to prevent delamination, and electrolyte color change during the soaking test was observed. The team found that LiDFOB was exceptionally effective in reducing manganese dissolution,  with  almost  no  nickel  and  aluminum  present  in  the  soaked  electrolyte.  ICP-MS  showed  the manganese dissolution to be 3033 Î¼g/g in soaked electrolyte with LNMO; yet, with the presence of LiDFOB, the manganese dissolution reduced to only 10 Î¼g/g.

## Fully Fluorinated Carbonate Electrolytes Mitigate TM Dissolution and Deposition

In  the  team's  previous  study,  the  effect  of  electrolyte  solvents  on  LMR  performance  was  investigated  by replacing the carbonate solvent with fluorinated analogs. Among all electrolytes tested, the fully fluorinated carbonate electrolyte, employing  both fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC)  and methyl 2,2,2-trifluoroethyl carbonate (FEMC), offered the best cycle life (Figure 11). To further understand the superior performance of this all-fluorinated electrolyte, TMs dissolved in the electrolyte and deposited on the anode were quantified through ion chromatography (IC) and ICP-MS, respectively.

EaCAM -Figure  11.  Specific discharge capacity (a) and Coulombic efficiency (b) of Gen2 and fluorinated carbonate electrolytes.

IC analysis of harvested electrolytes (diluted 50 times) was performed through a Dionex ICS-6000 series system (Figure 12). Manganese and nickel were detected in the diluted electrolyte samples, eluting at 3.6 minutes and 9.3 minutes, respectively. The peak at 2.5 minutes was assigned to be  copper, which corresponds to anode current  collector  corrosion.  Calibration  curves  were  generated  to  quantify  manganese  and  nickel  contents; results are summarized in Figure 13. The quantification results indicate that FEC/FEMC has the lowest amount of both manganese and nickel in the electrolyte. Interestingly, a much higher amount of nickel than manganese was  detected  in  this  electrolyte.  The  amount  of  nickel  in  the  non-fluorinated  or  the  partially  fluorinated electrolytes varied between 9 Âµg and 10 Âµg, while the amount of manganese varied between only 0.13 Âµg to 0.17 Âµg.

Harvested graphite anodes from the cycled cells were analyzed as well using ICP-MS for manganese and nickel content. Results are displayed in Figure 14. Manganese deposited on the graphite anode with non-fluorinated or partially fluorinated electrolytes varied between 9 Âµg and 12 Âµg, while nickel varied between 3 Âµg and 4.5 Âµg. TM deposition on the graphite anode was effectively mitigated by the all-fluorinated, FEC/FEMC electrolyte, resulting in smaller amounts of both manganese and nickel in graphite anodes. From both the IC results and the ICP results (Figures 13 and 14), it appears that manganese is more likely to deposit on the anode, while nickel is more likely to stay dissolved in the electrolyte, suggesting different mechanisms of dissolution/deposition in these systems.

Based on the quantification results of TMs in the electrolyte and in the anode, the improved cycling performance of  FEC/FEMC  was  ascribed  to  its  effective  suppression  of  TM  dissolution  and  deposition.  Additionally, manganese was found to be more likely to deposit on the graphite anode than nickel. A better comprehension of  how  the  electrolyte  impacts  TM  dissolution  and  deposition  is  still  needed.  Spectroscopy  studies  of electrolytes  are  in  progress  to  gain  further  understanding  of  the  relationship  between  solvation  and TM dissolution. Surface characterization will be performed on the formed anodes and cathodes to understand the  effects  of  electrolytes  on  cathode/anode  electrolyte  interphase  (cathode-electrolyte interphase  /  solidelectrolyte interphase; CEI/SEI) compositions.

## Thermal Stability of LMR-NM Oxide

The team used DSC to examine thermal stability of the LMR-NM  oxide  (0.3Li2MnO3Â·0.7LiMn0.5Ni0.5O2).  Note that to obtain full capacity, the LMR-NM electrode needs to  be  activated  by  charging  it  to  a  high  cut-off  voltage (4.7 V in this case). In this work, they intend to study how the activation process affects  the thermal stability of the material. They prepared LMR-NM/Li (half) cells containing  the  Gen2 + 1 wt% LiDFOB  electrolyte  and cycled them using the protocol shown in Figure 15. Note that the cells first undergo three 'wetting' cycles between 2.5-4.4 V before being cycled in the 2.5-4.7 V range at C/20 rate.  Figure 15  shows the  activation  plateau  in  the Cycle 4 charge profile: samples obtained for DSC studies from this cycle are labeled 4.4Vb (just before activation) and  4.7Vb  (1 st activation).  They  also  examined  samples from  cycle  6:  these  are  labeled  4.4Va  and  4.7Va  in Figure 15. For the measurements, electrode coatings were scraped off the current collector; studies were conducted with and without addition of fresh electrolyte.

As  is  well  known,  the  nonaqueous  electrolytes  are  the major  contributor  to  thermal  runaway  of  Li-ion  batteries  due  to  their  chemical  reaction  with  delithiated cathodes. In the presence of the electrolyte, not only does thermal behavior of the delithiated cathode become complicated, but the heat generated also increases by an order of magnitude. To preclude the electrolyte effect, the DSC studies were first carried out without additional fresh electrolyte (Figure 16). A small heat bump before 200Â°C (highlighted with a blue circle) that is seen for all the samples can be assigned to CEI decomposition: note that CEI refers to electrolyte decomposition products on the cathode. In addition, a major heat peak is seen between 220Â°C and 300Â°C regardless of the final voltage; this peak could be from a phase change in the oxide, possibly a layered to spinel structure transformation. The samples charged to 4.4 V show similar peak locations

## Aging Study of LMR-NM / LTO Cells

Electrochemical  tests  were  conducted  on  cells  containing  LMR-NM cathodes  and  LTO anodes.  Both  the positive and negative electrodes used in the studies were fabricated at the ANL Cell Analysis, Modeling, and Prototyping  facility.  In  the  present  study,  the  positive  electrode  had  a  43-Âµm-thick  coating  with  92 wt% 0.3Li2MnO3Â·0.7LiMn0.5Ni0.5O2 (LMR-NM),  4 wt%  carbons  (including 0.05 wt% single-walled carbon nanotubes), and 4 wt% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) on a 20-Âµm-thick aluminum current collector. The negative electrode had a 68-Âµm-thick coating with ~ 92 wt% LTO, 3 wt% C45 carbon, and 5 wt% PVDF binder, on a 10-Âµm-thick copper current collector. The cells also contained Gen2 + 1 wt% LiDFOB electrolyte and Celgard 2500 separator. The voltage ranges in the standard electrochemical test protocol were modified to make them  appropriate  for  these  studies.  This  protocol  includes  three  (initial)  wetting  cycles  (before  activation) between  1.95-2.87 V,  two  activation  cycles  between  1.2-3.13 V  range,  and  subsequent  C/3  aging  cycles between  1.20-2.93 V.  These  ranges  were  determined  by  comparing  reference  electrode  data  between  cells containing graphite and LTO anodes. Note that the LTO electrode potential is 1.55 V versus Li/Li + ; hence, at 2.93 V and 3.13 V in LMR/LTO cell, the LMR-NM cathode is at 4.48 V and 4.68 V versus Li/Li + , respectively.

Representative  data  from  tests  conducted  at  30Â°C  are  shown  in  Figure 18.  After  activation,  the  initial cell capacities (Figure 18a) in the 1.2-3.13 V and 1.2-2.93 V ranges are ~ 250 mAh/g-oxide and ~ 237 mAh/g-oxide, respectively. The capacity fades during the cycle; at the end of 100 cycles, the fade is ~ 4%,  which  is  much  smaller  than  the  capacity  fade  (13%)  for  similar  cells  with  graphite  anodes.  The mechanisms  associated  with  capacity  fade  in  the  LTO  cells  are  under  investigation.  Data  obtained  with electrodes  harvested  from  the  cells  indicate  that  the  fade  is  associated  with  the  LTO anode  and  not  the LMR-NM cathode.  The  cell  impedance  (Figure 18b)  barely  changes  during  the  cycles.  Note  that  the  cell impedance varies from ~ 30 â„¦-cm 2 (at  2.24 V; cathode at 3.9 V versus Li/Li + )  to  ~ 56 ohm-cm 2 (at  2.78 V; cathode at 4.33 V versus Li/Li + ) and ~ 150 â„¦-cm 2 (at 1.8 V; cathode at 3.35 V versus Li/Li + ).

EaCAM -Figure  18.  Capacity fade (a) and impedance rise (b) of cells with LMR-NM cathodes and LTO anodes.

Capacity-voltage profiles from a representative LMR/LTO cell cycled in the 1.2-2.93 V range are shown in Figure 19a. The profile changes observed during cycling reflect structural changes in the LMR oxide; observe that the changes are most significant initially (see difference between cycle 6 and cycle 30) and are smaller during the later cycles. These profiles changes are better seen in the differential capacity profiles (Figure 19b). Relatively broad charge peaks at 1.88 V, 2.22 V, and 2.78 V and discharge peaks at 2.75 V, 2.16 V, and 1.79 V are observed after the initial cycles (see  cycle 6 data). The difference in peak locations  for the charge  and discharge profiles reflects the voltage hysteresis in the cell. On cycling, new peaks appear at 1.7 V and 1.56 V in the charge and discharge profiles, respectively, while intensities of the higher voltage peaks decrease. These profiles capacity transfer from the higher to lower voltages resulting in cell voltage fade. This voltage fade, along with the gradual capacity fade, lowers specific energy of the cell during electrochemical cycling.

## Calendar Life Studies of LMR-NM Cathodes Paired with Graphite Anodes

This  quarter,  the  team  continued  to  work  on  assessing  calendar  life  of  0.3(Li2MnO3)â¸±0.7(LiMn0.5Ni0.5O2)  / graphite cells [1.2 M LiPF6 in EC:EMC (3:7 in wt%, Gen2) electrolyte] using established protocols. While a standard protocol consists of 5 hybrid pulse power characterizations (HPPC) with aging cycles, they introduced an  extra  voltage  hold  after  the  first  HPPC  to  assess  the  impact  of  voltage  hold  on  the  electrochemical performance of the cells.

In Figure 20a, the capacity retentions of LMR/graphite cells are presented with and without voltage holding at 4.4V. The cell without voltage holding retains 90.60% of its capacity after cycles. With a 200-hour voltage hold,  the  retention  drops  to  88.17%.  Extending  the  hold  to  800 hours  further  decreases  it  to  84.08%.

Figure 20b/c depicts the current distribution and capacity gains during the voltage hold. Generally, the current response combines reversible (charging) and irreversible (parasitic reactions) processes. Reversible processes result from continuous charging, adding capacity during the initial voltage hold as the current decreases. After about 100 hours, as shown in Figure 20b/c, the cell stabilizes at a constant SOC, and irreversible reactions become  dominant.  Irreversible  reactions  primarily  occur  at  the  surface  and  involve  processes  such  as irreversible Li + ion loss and excessive SEI/CEI formation. Further investigation will aim to pinpoint the cause of capacity retention decreases during the voltage hold. Moreover, this study indicates that prolonged voltage holds  can  identify  an  optimal  duration  without  harming  the  calendar  life  of  the  LMR/graphite  system. Subsequent research will explore various voltage values and different electrolyte systems.

EaCAM -Figure  20.  (a) Capacity retention of LMR/graphite cells with and without voltage hold. (b) Current response measured during voltage hold. (c) Achieved capacity during voltage hold.

The  team  also  conducted  a  study  on  the  cycle  life  and  calendar  life  of  LMR/graphite  cells  at  elevated temperatures (50Â°C), as depicted in Figure 21. Results indicated a decrease in cycle retention to 59.17% when cycled at 50Â°C. Adding a voltage hold (4.4 V for 200 hours) at 50Â°C further reduced cycle retention to 46.68%. Figure 21a clearly highlights a significant decrease in capacity retention during the voltage hold at elevated temperature conditions. Figure 21b compares the current responses of the cells during voltage holds at both 30Â°C  and  50Â°C.  Higher  currents  were  measured  during  the  voltage  hold  at  50Â°C,  indicating  an  increased presence of irreversible reactions at the electrode surface. As discussed in this report, excessive side reactions lead to formation of thick SEI or CEI.

To examine whether the reduced capacity retention observed at higher temperatures was due to electrolyte depletion in the cell, the team reconstructed cells using electrodes obtained from two cells: one from a cell cycled at 50Â°C and the other from a cell subjected to additional voltage holding at 50Â°C. Fresh electrolyte was used in this reassembly process. Figure 21c illustrates the specific capacity changes of the cells after reassembly with the new electrolyte. The results showed no increase in capacity for both cells with the fresh electrolyte. In fact, there was a slight decrease in deliverable capacity, likely due to minor material loss during the disassembly process. These findings confirm that the decrease in capacity retention at elevated temperatures was not caused by  electrolyte  depletion.  Future  studies  should  investigate  other  potential  factors  contributing  to  capacity decreases. This research will involve surface investigations using XPS and evaluating lithium loss from the cathode by reassembling cells with a harvested cathode and lithium metal.

## Solid-State NMR studies on LMR-NM Oxide

Lithium local environments of the pristine 0.3Li2MnO3Â·0.7LiMn0.5Ni0.5O2 (LMR-NM) cathodes and structural changes with cycling were studied by 6 Li solid-state NMR in the past quarter. The solid-state NMR effort within the thrust focuses on in-depth structural and compositional characterization of LMR-NM materials before and after cycling/aging to understand the changes the material goes through and to study if changing electrochemical cycling parameters (cycling conditions/electrolyte additives) can effect/mitigate irreversible structural changes and  surface  compositions.  The  changes  in  lithium  local  environments  on  cycling  were  studied  with  the following samples: after formation, after activation, after 200 cycles, and after relithiation of the aged electrode in a half-cell configuration.

As shown in Figure 22, the pristine LMR-NM material shows a combination of different lithium-6 peaks due to the composite nature of the material. The peaks within the 400-1000 ppm and 1200-1500 ppm regions can be assigned to lithium in lithium layers and to lithium in TM layers, respectively. Consistent with previous studies and data for the pristine Li2MnO3 (LMO) structure, peaks at 1450 ppm and 720 ppm are from lithium within  LMO-like domains,  whereas  the  remaining  peaks  are  lithium  environments  within  Mn-Ni layered domains.

After three formation cycles, before the material is activated, the composite structure remains intact, with the same lithium-6 peak positions as observed for the pristine sample. However, the changes in peak intensities observed with the normalized data suggest not all lithium is being reinserted into the lattice, in agreement with the 83% efficiency observed in this voltage window, indicating the presence of lithium loss mostly from lithium in  the  TM layer  and  LMO-like  domains.  After  the  material  is  activated,  a  profound  loss  of  order  and/or reordering in the material is observed as indicated by disappearance of LMO-like ordering peaks, with severe broadening of the overall spectrum and peak shifts toward lower frequencies. These new lithium peak positions can be assigned to a mixture of different lithium environments, such as lithium in tetrahedral sites, adjacent to vacancies and dumb-bell type and spinel-like lithium environments. With further cycling, more lithium loss is observed with peak intensity decreases; however, no obvious change is seen for a peak shift or formation of new lithium environments. The sharp peaks at 0 ppm observed for the cycled materials are due to the presence of  diamagnetic  lithium  environments  within  the  electrolyte  and  electrolyte  decomposition  products.  The irreversible structural changes and source of the lithium loss after 200 cycles were studied with relithiation of the aged cell. Unlike the irreversible structural changes observed after the activation processes, the NMR data reveal  that  almost  all  the  lithium  lost  during  aging  is  restored  back  to  the  new  structure  that  was  formed immediately after the activation.

## X-Ray Nano-CT Images of Oxide Cathodes

Last quarter, the team showed X-ray nano-CT images of the LMR cathodes and the variety of sub-particle features observed such as Ni-segregation, voids, and cracks. Throughout this quarter, they continued to focus on quantifying the statistics of these features within particles. This work is ongoing, and they will provide an update for 0.3Li2MnO3Â·0.7 LiMn0.5Ni0.5O2 (LMR-NM) next quarter. In parallel, they have been exploring the morphological  evolution  of  LiNixMn2-xO4  (LMNO)  and  LiNiO2  (LNO)  samples  from  ANL  and  how  their morphology changes during electrochemical formation and following synthesis under different conditions.

For LMNO, the particles were imaged before and after formation, as shown in Figure 23. The particle size distribution was shown to be narrow around an average value of 8-Âµm diameter and with a sphericity of ~ 0.85, showing that the particles are very close to being ideal spheres. The average particle diameter increased after formation to ~ 9-Âµm diameter, and the average sphericity also increased to ~ 0.9. It was also observed that some of the LMNO particles contained dense cores of high metallic content, as shown in Figure 23a by the red arrows. Ongoing work will focus on quantifying the presence of dense cores and the fraction of particles that contain them. They will also explore the change in morphology of the particles and whether the core-shell structure changes throughout the cycle life of the electrodes.

The team is also helping provide insight into how changing the partial pressure of oxygen during LNO synthesis impacts particle morphology at both the particle level and internal grains. They completed the analysis at the particle level, as shown in Figure 24, where they stitched numerous nano-CT volumes together to acquire a high number (&gt; 850 for each sample) of particles for statistical significance in their analyses. They showed that while the mean diameter of particles remains similar with increasing oxygen percent, the mean particle volume increased by around 30%. Particles became more elongated with increasing partial pressure of oxygen. Next quarter, they will start processing electron backscattered diffraction (EBSD) data of sub-particle architectures to elucidate how the differing synthesis conditions affect the sub-particle grain structures.

## Electron Microscopy Updates

In building on previous collaborations in other projects, the NREL team is communicating with Thermo Fisher Scientific to partner for improving the capabilities for fs-laser milling through coin-cell batteries to expose intact  cross-sections  of  the  cell  stack.  This  collaboration  previously  identified  the  impact  of  different electrolytes on lithium metal cycling, where regions of dry SEI, gas bubbles, degraded separators, and electrode morphology changes were observed in 0.5-mm cross-sections. In using this technique, which will be installed at  NREL  in  the  last  quarter  of  FY 2024,  the  team  can  provide  insights  on  the  cathode  interface  with  the electrolyte, which is challenging to obtain when the cells are removed from the stack and analyzed individually. This will build into the work produced by C. Liao at ANL in addition to cryogenic (cryo) focused ion beam / SEM and liftouts for cryo-transmission electron microscopy analysis of the CEI and electrolyte additives.

Since the NREL GEM graduate student intern completed her imaging at the end of July 2023, the team has been looking forward to hosting another student intern for this project. They are building a collaboration with Northern Arizona University's Â¡MIRA! Program so that they can subcontract an intern to work on image and data analysis for spring of 2024. This student would contribute to multiple efforts at NREL for machine learning and  image  segmentation  for  tracking  cathode  particle  cracking  and  the  particle  strain  analysis  using SEM and EBSD (Figure 25). Depending on the student's expertise and interests, they will explore work on multipeak deconvolution of time-resolved spectroscopy datasets.

Last quarter, the NREL team worked on sample preparation of the 0.3Li2MnO3 ïƒ— 0.7 LiMn0.5Ni0.5O2 (LMR-NM) cathode  electrodes,  with  the intention  of  comparing  different  grain  boundaries  (GBs)  at  different  lithiation states. The goal of this work is to identify ion transport pathways in relation to nanoscale strain gradients that can  cause  cathode  particle  cracking  and  performance loss.  Therefore,  the team  is learning  the  methods  for four-dimensional (a 2D pixel array image of a sample region to produce a 2D diffraction pattern at each pixel) STEM; a team member traveled to the Basic Energy Science Molecular Foundry's National Center for Electron Microscopy to learn the analysis routines and collect datasets from their microscope for an initial dataset. The completion of the Spectra 200 STEM installation at NREL in the first quarter of FY 2024 will enable this data to be acquired at NREL in the future. Initial mapping of the cathode particles in the electrode was conducted in the SEM with Raman spectroscopy to target particles with more strain. This was followed by EBSD mapping of the particle to identify a disorientation GB. Using the py4DSTEM toolkit, the results indicate that there is compressive strain at the GB along with fluctuations in the strain value across the GB. This work will continue to gain more information on the correlation between lithiation state and GBs where cracks are forming. This nanoscale strain mapping is building NREL's multi-scale analysis capabilities to correlate to the scanning probe and nano-CT capabilities.

## Advanced Characterization of Cycled LNMO

Last quarter, the team reported the void formation and their direct correlation with the capacity fading in spinel compounds of the LNMO. This quarter, they report phase transformation characteristics at the primary particle surface  and  CEI layer  formation  during  cycling  of  the  LNMO  cathode. Phase transformations  occur  at the primary particle surfaces on battery cycling. As illustrated in Figure 26a, the particle surface of the pristine sample features a Mn3O4-like structure with a thickness of ~ 1.1 nm, followed by a ~ 1.4-nm cation inter-mixing region in which lithium is partially replaced by nickel and/or manganese. After 100 cycles, the thickness of the surface reconstruction layer increases, as shown in Figure 26b; the surface reconstruction region features a very top layer of rock-salt roughly ~ 1.4-nm thick and a sublayer of a Mn3O4-like structure of ~ 5.1 nm, followed by a cation inter-mixing region of ~ 2 nm in thickness.

It would be expected that with increased cycling number, the thickness of the surface reconstruction layer will increase, as observed for layer-structured oxide cathodes. However, it is interesting to note that after 200 cycles, as compared with that after 100 cycles, the surface reconstruction layer becomes thinner, which is typified by a  rock-salt  structure  of  ~ 0.9 nm  and  a  sublayer  of  Mn3O4-like  structure  of  ~ 1.7 nm,  as  shown  in

Figure 26c. This observation likely indicates two competing interfacial processes. One is the interface between the bulk spinel lattice and surface reconstruction layer that migrates toward the particle interior with progressive cycling. The other is the interface between the cathode particle surface and electrolyte, which controls material dissolution. Cation  dissolution  during  cycling  has been  extensively  investigated  for  the  high-voltage  spinel cathode. It would be expected that the dissolution rate of the spinel in the electrolyte is constant. However, as the phase transition is facilitated by oxygen loss, the propagation speed of the phase transition front in the bulk lattice depends on the thickness of the phase transition layer. Apparently, an initially thin phase transition layer could lead to a fast inward migration of the phase transition front, causing a thick phase transition layer (after 100 cycles); on extended cycling (200 cycles), cation dissolution into electrolyte may decrease the thickness of this layer.

EaCAM -Figure  26.  (a-c) Lattice structural features of the primary  particle surface. Scanning transmission electron microscopy -high-angle annular dark field (STEM-HAADF) images obtained at the primary particle surface of the (a) pristine, (b) 100-cycle, and (c) 200cycle samples. (d-f) Magnified images together with the structure model in the same crystal orientation, where the Mn3O4-like and rock-salt structures can be distinguished by different atomic  arrangements,  as  indicated  by  the  STEM-HAADF  image  intensities  plotted  for  the (d) pristine, (e) 100-cycle, and (f) 200-cycle samples.

Formation of a stable CEI layer is generally noted to be a critical factor for extending the lifetime of Li-ion batteries. The primary particle surfaces of the pristine, 100-cycle, and 200-cycle samples have been investigated by  STEM-EDS  elemental  mapping,  as  illustrated  in  Figure  27.  A  CEI  layer,  containing  the  electrolyte constituents phosphorus and fluorine, is observed on the primary particles following 100 cycles and 200 cycles, as shown in Figure 27b/c. A higher intensity phosphorus signal is found in the CEI after 200 cycles, as compared

to that after 100 cycles, suggesting that the CEI becomes more pronounced with progressive cycling. Fluorine is also involved in the CEI formation. Even though fluorine is more challenging to study by STEM-EDS because of  its  low  atomic  number  and  the  closely  overlapping  fluorine  K-edge  and  manganese  L-edges,  the comparatively wider peak widths at the F-K edge side conclusively indicate the existence of fluorine. Oxygen is also observed in the CEI areas. Taken together, the STEM-EDS data suggest the presence of LixPFyOz, LixPFy, or  LiF  in  the  CEI  layer.  This  CEI  layer  may  impact  the  electrochemical  performance  in  different  ways depending  on  the  actual  phase,  either  positively  protecting  the  cathode  by  preventing  further  interactions between the cathode and electrolyte or negatively hindering lithium transport.

## Battery500 Consortium Program: Innovation Center for Battery500 (Jun Liu, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory; Yi Cui, Stanford University)

Objective. The overall goal of the Battery500 Consortium is to increase the energy density of advanced lithium batteries to beyond what can be achieved in today's state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries. The consortium aims to increase the specific energy (up to 500 Wh kg -1 ) and achieve 1,000 charge/discharge cycles, with cost reduction of  the  cells to  significantly less than  $100 per kWh -1 .  This  goal  directly  addresses  the  U. S.  Department of Energy (DOE) priority to achieve a carbon-free electricity sector by 2035 and to decarbonize the transportation sector by developing and manufacturing the next-generation, high-energy, low-cost batteries to enable a wide deployment of electric vehicles (EVs) in the marketplace.

Impact. Battery500 will develop next-generation lithium battery technologies that will significantly increase energy density, improve cycle life, and reduce cost. This will greatly accelerate deployment of EVs and reduce carbon emission associated with fossil fuel consumption. The consortium will utilize first-class expertise and capabilities in battery research in the United States and develop an integrated and multidisciplinary approach to accelerate development and deployment of advanced electrode and electrolyte materials in commercially viable high-energy batteries. The advances made  in this consortium will also benefit improvement of current Li-ion battery technologies. This project will provide tremendous opportunities for students  and  scientists  for  battery-related  training  that  will  enhance  the  workforce  for  the  United  States  to maintain global leadership in the battery research and development field.

Approach. This  project  focuses  on  the  two  most  promising  battery  chemistries:  Li-metal  anode  with high-voltage/high-capacity metal oxide cathodes like LiNixMnyCo1-x-yO2 (NMC), and lithium metal with sulfur cathodes. The project focus is to design novel electrode and cell architectures to meet the 500 Wh/kg goal. The consortium will work closely with battery/material manufacturers, suppliers, and end users / original equipment manufacturers in the United States to ensure the technologies being developed by this project are well aligned with industry needs, poised for transitioning to real production, and helpful in securing the supply chain in the United States.

Out-Year Goals. The  out-year  goals  are  to  improve  cycle  life  of  the  Li||NMC  pouch  cell  with  400 Wh/kg energy density and cycle life of &gt; 200, and to fabricate and test the pouch cells with 450 Wh/kg energy density and cycle life of &gt; 100.

Collaborations. Collaboration among consortium team members will be well coordinated by the leadership team, which also includes four keystone project leads and co-leads along with principal investigators at all member institutions. Collaboration with the community outside of this consortium and with industry will be facilitated by the executive committee and the advisory board.

## Milestones

1. Initiate baseline evaluation in small-cell format for C/S chemistry. Develop single-layer pouch cell (SLPC) for sulfurized polyacrylonitrile (SPAN) chemistry. (Q1, FY 2023; Completed)
2. Define voltage regimes leading to least capacity loss in high-Ni NMC, using electrochemistry and thermal loss. (Q2, FY 2023; Completed)
3. Complete SLPC fabrication and testing protocols for NMC and sulfur system and prepare for sharing with Battery500 and industry. (Q3, FY 2023; Completed)
4. Demonstrate feasibility of 350 Wh/kg Li-metal pouch cell with up to 800 cycles. Demonstrate 450 Wh/kg pouch cells with 250 cycles. (Q4, FY 2023; In progress)

## Progress Report

## Keystone Project 1: Materials and Interfaces

## Highlights of Keystone Project 1

The highlights for this quarter are as follows:

- The  University  of  Texas  (UT),  Austin,  team  investigated  a  series  of  localized  high-concentration electrolytes (LHCEs) with various cost-effective novel diluents. It is unveiled that both the physiochemical and chemical properties of dilutes can affect the electrochemical performance through tuning the viscosity of the electrolyte and interphase chemistry of both the Li-metal anode and LiNiO2 (LNO) cathode. More importantly, certain diluents can reduce the outgassing at high voltages by tuning the cathode-electrolyte interphase (CEI) and enhancing the thermal stability of Li-metal anode, resulting in better safety performances.
- The  Pacific  Northwest  National  Laboratory  (PNNL)  team  further  improved  the  long-term  cycling performance of Li||NMC batteries using LHCEs with a new diluent DB, by about 30% over the current baseline LHCE with 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl-2,2,3,3-tetrafluoropropyl ether (TTE) diluent in coin cells. The DB-1 electrolyte leads to a thinner and denser lithium deposition than the baseline electrolyte. The reason is possibly due to formation of more inorganic components in the solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer in DB-1. They developed new electrolytes for Li||S cells by utilizing a dual- or tri-solvent system to form a series of moderately solvating electrolytes to control the amount of dissolution of polysulfide species in the electrolyte  and  improve  the  overall  cell  cycle  life  and  stability  with  both  S/C  composite  cathode  and Li-metal anode.
- The  Stanford  University  team  developed  a  new  solvent,  F2DEM.  This  electrolyte  showed  reduced overpotential  and  slightly  increased  lithium  Coulombic  efficiency  (CE)  over  the  previously  reported F5DEE-based electrolyte.
- The  University of Maryland  (UMD)  team  further developed the lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiFSI) / M1 electrolytes, where all ether groups were removed by chemical modification. The optimized LiFSI/M1 electrolytes were demonstrated with high anodic stability of &gt; 5.3 V in Li||Al half cells and kept a high lithium reversibility with superior lithium CE of &gt; 99.7%. They also developed a modified LHCE for  SPAN  cathode  which  leads  to  flat  and  dense  lithium  deposition  morphology  and  improved electrochemical stability.
- Pennsylvania State University (PSU) developed new carbonate-based electrolyte for Li||NMC batteries and electrolyte with new solvent and additive for Li||S batteries. Both electrolytes promoted much more uniform lithium deposition, which enabled fewer side reactions, higher CE, and much longer cycling performance and improved cycling stability than the baseline electrolytes. The new additive in the Li-S electrolyte could change the kinetics of polysulfide reactions and promote Li2S dissolution, which eliminates the sulfur loss after cycling.

## Comparing  Stability of  NMC  Coatings  Prepared  using  N-Methyl-2-pyrrolidone  (NMP)  versus Ultraviolet (UV) Curing

The Binghamton University team compared the technology of coating lithium nickel manganese cobalt oxide (NMC) cathode by NMP solvent and NMP-free ultraviolet (UV) curing. UV curing technology is particularly attractive  for  electrodes  manufacturing  because  this  innovative  approach  can  dramatically  increase  the processing speed and eliminate the harmful NMP, along with the associated drying and recovery systems, which significantly reduce cost, environmental concerns, and energy consumption. A DOE funded effort with Miltec, Argonne National Laboratory, and  Oak Ridge National Laboratory to develop and demonstrate high-speed electrode  coating  with  UV  curing  technology  indicated  that  the  manufacturing  cost  of  an  electrode

could be reduced 80-85% and that the total cost of the electrode including the material costs could be reduced 25% by using UV. They demonstrated that 90/5/5 cathode coatings could be UV cured at 100 meters/minute with good  capacity retention and gave  the equivalent performance  as conventional electrodes with polyvinylidene (di)fluoride (PVDF) binder. However, a major limitation was identified: namely the maximum practical coating thickness is 50 Âµm or 10 mg/cm 2 loading  at  any  speed,  because  of  the  limited  penetration power of UV. This would thus require multilayer coatings to achieve higher thickness/loading. Although shown to be viable, this would complicate processing and cost. It is thus concluded that UV coating is not a practical approach for the thick electrodes needed to obtain the 500 Wh/kg goals for the Battery500 consortium. The Binghamton team therefore does not plan to experimentally pursue this approach further.

## Developing LHCEs for High-Ni Cathodes

The UT Austin team systematically investigated four novel cost-effective diluents in LHCEs and compared their  performances  in  cells  with  LNO  cathode  and  Li-metal  anode.  As  shown  in  Figure 1.1a,  diluents investigated here are five fluorinated ethers, including TTE, 1H,1H,5H-octafluoropentyl 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl ether (OTE), 2,2,2-trifluoroethyl 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl ether (TTEE), 1,1,1,3,3,3-hexafluoro-2-(fluoromethoxy) propane (HFP), and ethyl 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl ether (ETE). The LHCEs were prepared by diluting the high-concentration electrolyte [LiFSI : 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) = 1:1.2 in molar] to 1.5 M with these diluents, which are denoted hereafter as LHCE-TTE, LHCE-OTE, LHCE-TTEE, LHCE-HFP, and LHCE-ETE, respectively.  Figure 1.1b  shows  the  impact  of  solvation  between  LiFSI  and  DME,  as  evidenced  by  the C-O-C stretching mode of DME in Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy. After the addition of salt, the C-O-C  peak  shifts  from  free DME  (1125 cm -1 )  to  solvating  DME  (1075 cm -1 ).  With  an  increase  in  salt concentration, a greater number of DME molecules engage in solvation with the salt, leading to an increase in the intensity of the solvating DME peak. Notably, the solvating C-O-C peak remains after the addition of diluents. Figure 1.1c shows the high-voltage stabilities of the electrolytes by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). The LHCEs demonstrate a decent high-voltage stability up to 4.6 V, which is a substantial improvement over the traditional ether-based electrolytes. Figure 1.1d shows that LHCE-OTE displays the highest CE of 99.81%. All  the  other  LHCEs  also  exhibit  exceptional  CEs  of  &gt;  99.38%,  which  are  much  higher  than  those  with LP57 (91.37%). The results indicate that the lithium stripping/plating process exhibits good reversibility, which can be attributed to the high stability of the interphases. Interestingly, although LHCE-OTE shows the highest CE, it also exhibits the highest overpotential during the test. Figure 1.1e shows the cycling performance of the electrolytes in Li||LNO half-cells. The cell with LP57 suffers from severe capacity degradation, dropping from 207 mA h g -1 to 134 mA h g -1 after 200 cycles, corresponding to a capacity retention of only 64.6%. In contrast, all cells cycled in the various LHCEs exhibit superior cycling performances. The discharge capacity of the cells at the 250 th cycle follows the order of LHCE-TTEE (190 mA h g -1 ) &gt; LHCE-ETE (182 mA h g -1 ) &gt; LHCEHFP (180 mA h g -1 ) &gt; LHCE-TTE (175 mA h g -1 ) &gt; LHCE-OTE (170 mA h g -1 ). The capacity retention of the cells after 250 cycles is quite similar for the LHCEs: LHCE-HFP (88.0%) &gt; LHCE-TTEE (87.1%) = LHCEETE (87.1%) &gt; LHCE-TTE (87.0%) &gt; LHCE-OTE (85.1%). Figure 1.1f shows that all the LHCE cells exhibit significantly smaller impedance growth when compared to the LP57 cell. In addition, Figure 1.1h depicts the discharge capacities of the anode-free cells. The discharge capacity of the cell with LP57 drops rapidly below 60 mA h g -1 after 50 cycles. In contrast, the anode-free cells with LHCEs still maintain a decent capacity of &gt;125 mA h g -1 . Moreover, LHCEs also demonstrate a higher CE (&gt; 98%) during cycling than LP57 (97.5%), indicating  a  higher  lithium  utilization  efficiency  enabling  a  more  stable  SEI.  The  rate  capabilities  of  the electrolytes were tested in Li||LNO cells (Figure 1.1g). LHCE-OTE shows the worst rate performance, with a 5C discharge capacity of only 81 mA h g -1 . However, the discharge capacity recovers back to 246 mA h g -1 when  the  discharge  rate  returns  to  0.1C.  On  the  other  hand,  cells  with  LHCE-ETE,  LHCE-TTEE,  and LHCE-HFP exhibit excellent rate performance, with a discharge capacity exceeding 193 mA h g -1 even at a 5C rate.  Overall,  TTEE,  HFP,  and  ETE  are  better  diluents  for  LHCE  than  TTE  and  OTE,  which  may  be attributed to the better kinetics enabled by their low viscosity.
