Post-mortem X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the cycled Li-metal anodes and LNO cathodes was carried out to investigate the composition and structure of the SEI and CEI. Figure 1.2a shows the atomic concentrations of carbon, oxygen, fluorine, sulfur, and nickel at the Li-metal anodes and LNO cathodes with different sputtering times. The SEI layer formed in LP57 electrolyte is more organic-rich than those formed in LHCEs. Especially after sputtering, the carbon content decreases to ~ 20% for the LHCEs, but only by ~ 5% for LP57; in contrast, the fluorine content increases by ~ 6% for the LHCEs, but only ~ 2% for LP57. This indicates that LHCEs can help build an inorganic-rich SEI inner layer and an organic outer layer. Moreover, LHCE-OTE has a significantly higher fluorine concentration, suggesting that fluorine comes from the decomposition of both the bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (FSI) anion and the OTE solvent molecule. The other LHCEs have similar atomic concentrations with comparable fluorine and sulfur contents, implying that most of the fluorine in the SEI is salt-derived and the contribution from diluent decomposition is relatively small. Unlike the SEI, the CEI has a more organic inner layer and a more inorganic outer layer. The CEI also contains more organic species (~ 60%) than the SEI (~ 50%), with significantly higher fluorine content (~ 20%) than sulfur (~ 2%) and nitrogen (~ 1%), indicating that most of the fluorine in the CEI is from the PVDF binder and the diluents rather than from the FSI anions. Moreover, LHCE-OTE and LHCE-ETE have higher sulfur contents in the outer layer of CEI, indicating a higher percentage of LiFSI salt decomposition compared to that with LHCE-TTE, LHCE-TTEE, and LHCE-HFP. Figure 1.2b shows the thermal stabilities of Li-metal anode with various  electrolytes  evaluated  with  differential  scanning  calorimetry.  The  endothermic  peak  at  180Â°C corresponds to the melting of lithium metal, and the exothermic peak corresponds to reactions between lithium metal and electrolytes. Such exothermic reactions of LP57 begin at 125Â°C with a large heat release of 4836 J g -1 . However,  the  lithium  metal  in  LHCEs  demonstrates  much  better  thermal  stability,  as  evidenced  by  a significantly lower heat release in the order of LHCE-ETE (540 J g -1 ) &lt; LHCE-OTE (577 J g -1 ) &lt; LHCE-HFP (647  J  g -1 )  &lt;  LHCE-TTEE  (703  J  g -1 )  &lt;  LHCE-TTE  (776  J  g -1 ).  Moreover,  the  temperature  of  the  main exothermic event is significantly delayed to 225Â°C compared to that with LP57 (125Â°C). Figure 1.2c shows the quantitative gas evolution of Li||LNO cells during the 1 st cycle by online electrochemical mass spectrometry. The generation of CO2, CO, and O2 occurs around the same time, indicating a coupling between the formation of each species. The released O2 is believed to originate from the lattice oxygen of the layered oxide cathode at a high state of charge (SOC) where Ni 4+ is highly unstable. Furthermore, the released singlet oxygen 1 O2 is highly  chemically  reactive  and  will  react  with  electrolytes  to  form  CO  and  CO2.  The  total  amount  of  gas generated with different electrolytes follows the trend of LP57 (204 Î¼mol g -1 ) &gt; LHCE-HFP (157 Î¼mol g -1 ) &gt; LHCE-ETE (142 Î¼mol g -1 ) &gt; LHCE-TTE (138 Î¼mol g -1 ) &gt; LHCE-TTEE (89 Î¼mol g -1 ) &gt; LHCE-OTE (71 Î¼mol g -1 ).  In  the LHCEs, a well-passivated CEI is formed on the surface of the electrodes, suppressing further gas generation, as evidenced by the significant reduction in off-gassing compared to that with LP57. The total amount of gas generation among the LHCEs has a noticeable difference, indicating that the diluent can participate in tuning the chemistry of the CEI and thereby affecting the off gassing.

The morphologies of deposited Li-metal anodes were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and XPS. Better cycling stability and more lithium reserve found in the cells with DB-based electrolyte could be attributed to the formation of more inorganic components (such as Li2O, LiF, Li-N, and Li2S) in the SEI layer (Figure 1.4e-h), which are very effective in improving the cycling stability of Li-metal batteries.

## Tuning Molecular Structure of Ether Solvent to Boost Electrochemical Performance

The Stanford team continued to work on tuning the molecular structure of ether-based  electrolytes  to  further  boost  their  performance  in  Li-metal batteries. Following the fluorinated 1,2-diethoxyethane (FDEE) series, a novel electrolyte is developed by changing the backbone structure to 1,2-diethoxymethane  (DEM)  and  reducing  the  degree  of  fluorination.  The resulting solvent (F2DEM) features an acetal backbone with one fluorine on each  end  of the  DEM  structure  (Figure 1.5).  The  acetal  backbone  is incorporated  to  weaken  the  chelation  effect  commonly  observed  with  the 1,2-diethoxyethane (DEE) system. This would allow for weaker coordination of  the  solvent  to  the  lithium  cation,  resulting  in  less  solvent-populated solvation  structure,  ultimately  leading  to  more  stable  salt-derived  SEI.  To ensure cathode stability, fluorine atoms are also incorporated on both ends of

Battery500 -Figure  1.5. Molecular design of F2DEM.

the DEM. Through backbone engineering and fluorination, F2DEM demonstrates excellent stability against the anode, as well as improved oxidative stability and conductivity.

To  demonstrate  the  potential  of  F2DEM,  its  transport  properties  are  first  examined.  Compared  to  the 2M LiFSI / DEM and 1.2 M LiFSI / F5DEE (1.2 M is chosen due to lower LiFSI salt solubility of F5DEE), 2 M LiFSI / F2DEM shows the highest ionic conductivity (Figure 1.6a). The high ionic conductivity is also manifested  in  the  low  overpotential  of  2 M F2DEM  compared  to  F5DEE  (Figure 1.6b).  This  reduced overpotential can greatly enhance the energy efficiency of batteries based on F2DEM.

Battery500 -Figure  1.6.  (a) Ionic conductivity of 2 M F2DEM, 2 M DEM, and 1.2 M F5DEE measured with Celgard 2325 separator in SS||SS cells. (b) Li||Li symmetric cells cycled at increasing current densities (1 mA cm -2  to 8 mA cm -2 ) and 3 mAh cm -2  capacity. The cells are cycled 10 times under each current density.

The Stanford team then investigated the F2DEM performance in Li||Cu half cells to assess its stability with the lithium anode. The average lithium CE was determined by the Aurbach method and found to be 99.53 Â± 0.03% for F2DEM, outperforming F5DEE (99.46 Â± 0.01%) and DEM (99.19 Â± 0.07%) in previous tests. Furthermore, the team corroborated these observations through long-term cycling of Li||Cu half cells. Long-term cycling revealed rapid activation for F2DEM (fewer cycles required to reach 99% CE), indicating minimal capacity loss during the initial cycles, making it highly suitable for anode-free cells with limited lithium supply. The average  CE  of  F2DEM  in  cycles  5-50  (99.44%)  remained  higher  than  that  of  F5DEE  and  DEM  (both  at 99.29%). Harsher testing conditions (1 mA cm -2 plating, 0.4 mA cm -2 stripping, 2 mAh cm -2 capacity) further corroborate  the  superior  cycling  stability  of  F2DEM  with  a  higher CE  over  250 cycles  compared  to F5DEE and DEM.

Considering  the  modified  solvation  environment  and  addition  of  electro-withdrawing  fluorine  atoms  in F2DEM molecules, an improved oxidative stability of F2DEM is expected when compared to DEM. To confirm this enhancement, LSV on the three distinct electrolytes was conducted. As depicted in Figure 1.7d, the team observed a leakage current with an onset voltage of ~ 4 V for F2DEM, surpassing the 3 V observed with DEM.

In the case of F5DEE, featuring a higher degree of fluorination, it unsurprisingly exhibited an even higher onset voltage of ~ 4.5 V. This pattern aligns well with the hypothesis that an increased degree of fluorination enhances oxidative stability.

Battery500 -Figure  1.7.  (a) Coulombic efficiency (CE) measurements of the three electrolytes based on the modified Aurbach method. (b)  Li||Cu CE of all three electrolytes. The cells were cycled at 0.5 mA cm -2 for  1  mAh  cm -2   and  stripped  to  1  V  at  0.5  mA  cm -2 .  (c)  Li||Cu  CE  over  250  cycles  under  fast  plating (1 mA cm -2 ) and slow stripping (0.4 mA cm -2 ) conditions. (d) Linear sweep voltammetry in Li||Pt cells. The leakage currents of the three electrolytes were measured by sweeping up to 7 V at 1 mV s -1 .

The performance of 2 M F2DEM was further assessed in Cu||LFP anode-free pouch cells, with a voltage range from 2.5 V to 3.65 V. Various charging and discharging rates were implemented to fully assess the pouch cell performance of F2DEM (1C = 200 mA or 2 mA cm -2 ). Under all conditions, 2 M F2DEM showed a higher capacity utilization and a slower capacity loss compared to the reference electrolytes (Figure 1.8). Especially under C/2 charge and a slower C/5 discharge rate, significant improvement in discharge capacity and CE was observed in F2DEM. This is the more demanding condition since it has been reported that slower discharge than charge can lead to higher surface area lithium morphology. However, this is also the condition that can best resemble the real-life battery charging and discharging condition. The improvement seen in F2DEM under a slower discharge rate potentially indicates that F2DEM can facilitate the formation of a more stable SEI.

In summary, F2DEM, a monofluorinated ether electrolyte, enhances the CE and cycling stability in Li-metal batteries.  This  is  due  to  the  acetal  backbone's  excellent  compatibility  with  the  lithium  anode,  as  well  as enhanced oxidative stability with monofluorine substitution. Future studies on further enhancing the cathodic stability of F2DEM would be essential, especially for application in high-voltage NMC-811 full cells.

## Developing New Electrolytes for High-Voltage Cathodes

To improve the high-voltage stability and make the electrolytes compatible with the NMC-811 cathode, the UMD team further developed the LiFSI/M1 electrolytes, where all ether groups were removed by chemical modification. The optimized LiFSI/M1 electrolytes were demonstrated with high anodic stability of &gt; 5.3 V in Li||Al half cells and kept a high lithium reversibility with superior lithium CE of &gt; 99.7%. Both 4.5 mAh cm -2 20-Î¼m-Li||NMC-811 coin cell and 90 mAh homemade SLPC showed stable cyclability with &gt; 83% capacity retention for over 300 cycles under the Battery500 cycle protocol. Furthermore, the team also demonstrated the success  cycle  of  Li||NMC-811 cell  at  an  ultrahigh  voltage  of  4.7 V  for  &gt; 200 cycles  with  a  high  capacity retention of &gt; 80%. The continuous investigations on LiFSI/M1 electrolytes for practical Li||NMC-811 cell are updated below.

The high stability of LiFSI/M1 electrolytes on both the Li-metal anode and NMC-811 cathode enables cycling high-energy electrodes with areal loadings beyond the practical requirement of ~ 5 mAh cm -2 .  As  shown in Figure 1.9, the 10 mAh cm -2 NMC-811 was paired with 50 Î¼m lithium to assemble the full cell and to evaluate electrolyte stability. With controlled electrolyte injection of ~ 5g (Ah) -1 , the high areal loading coin cell was able to cycle at a high rate of 0.3C for 200 cycles with &gt; 99.9% CE (Figure 1.9a), which delivers the scheduled milestone for this quarter. A high capacity of &gt; 90% was retained after 200 cycles, demonstrating the excellent compatibility of LiFSI/M1 electrolytes with both the lithium anode and the high-loading NMC-811 cathode. The overpotential barely changed along the cycling, indicating that robust and high Li + conductive interphase films were formed on both electrodes (Figure 1.9b).

Attention will also be given to the  wetting issues of the electrolytes and the long-cycle performance of the Li-free NMC-811 cells.

Furthermore, the UMD team developed another high-voltage electrolyte by molecule screening. The screened new electrolyte allows the formation of inorganic SEI from the solvent reduction. The inorganic feature of SEI can be realized by the joint contribution from solvent and anion decomposition. It is also worth noting that the designed electrolyte does not contain conventional cyclic molecules to avoid ring-opening polymerization and the accumulation of organic compounds in the interphase. Considering its inherent benefit in oxidation stability, high-voltage Li-metal batteries with long-term cycling stability and fast cycling rate can be expected.

The mechanically strong SEI with minimum organic components enables the high efficiency (99.4%) and stability of Li-metal anode under a high current density (1.5 mA cm -2 ) and deep cycling conditions (4.5 mAh cm -2 ).

## Developing New Carbonate-Based Electrolyte for NMC

The PSU team continued evaluation of the newly formulated carbonate-based electrolyte in Li||NMC-811 full cells.  The  areal  capacity  of  NMC-811 cathode was 4.3 mAh/cm 2 ,  and  the  thickness  of  Li-metal  anode  was 50 Âµm.  After  two  formation  cycles  at  0.1C  for  charge/discharge,  the  tested  cells  were  charged  at  C/3  and discharged at C/3 between 2.8 V and 4.4 V. As shown in Figure 1.13, the Li||NMC-811 full cell with the new carbonate-based electrolyte delivers improved cycling stability with 80% capacity retention after 218 cycles. In contrast, the cell with the baseline electrolyte of 1 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate / diethyl carbonate (EC/DEC) (v/v = 1:1) with 15 wt% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) and 1 wt% lithium difluoro(oxalate) borate results in a fast decay and an 80% retention after 180 cycles only. These results confirm that the new carbonate-based electrolyte is effective in maintaining stable electrochemical performance, even at high charge voltages (4.4 V), compared to the standard carbonate electrolyte.

The  new  electrolytes  were  developed  with  a  range  of  concentrations  of

## Development of Electrolytes for SPAN Cathodes

The UMD team continued the study of a modified LHCE that is compatible with both Li-metal anode and SPAN cathode  (Figure 1.18).  Due  to  improved  electrochemical  stability,  this  electrolyte  is  less  consumed during the long cycle of Li||SPAN full cells, resulting in better cyclability under a lean electrolyte condition of 5 g (Ah) -1 , compared to the TTE-based LHCE (Figure 1.18). Note: the solvating solvent is not DME.

Battery500 -Figure  1.18.  Electrochemical performance of modified LHCE compared to TTE-based LHCE in (a) Li||Cu half cells and (b) Li||SPAN full cells at lean electrolyte condition of 5 g (Ah) -1 .

This  quarter,  the  UMD  team  performed  post-mortem  analyses  to  clarify  the  source  of  improvements. SEM images (Figure 1.19a) revealed that the lithium deposited in TTE-based LHCE was nodule-like but rather non-uniform with a scattering of lithium dendrites.  Meanwhile, lithium deposited in the  modified LHCE electrolyte exhibits flat and dense morphology with relatively large (~ 10 Î¼m) and faceted particles. This difference can be attributed to the fact that the SEI formed in the modified LHCE was richer in robust inorganic

compounds, such as LiF and Li3N (Figure 1.19b), suggesting a more favorable decomposition of the FSI anion. Similarly, the CEI formed in the modified LHCE is also more inorganic-rich than that formed in TTE-based LHCE, as evidenced by the negligible non-binder-derived carbon content and the high ratio between stable fluorine  (LiF)  versus  organic/metastable  fluorine  (C-F/S-F).  The  superior  interphase  results  in  better electrochemical stability of the modified LHCE compared to the TTE-based counterpart, which in turn leads to more electrolyte retention, as confirmed by quantitative 1 H nuclear magnetic resonance analysis (Figure 1.19c), and better cyclability with fewer electrolytes.

## Keystone Project 2: Electrode Architecture

## Highlights of Keystone Project 2

The highlights for this quarter are as follows:

- The University of California, San Diego (UCSD) team successfully enhanced the cycling stability of the high-S content SPAN material, often denoted as CS SPAN, achieving over 650 mAh g -1 electrode  capacity, which surpasses standard SPAN material. By integrating conductive additives composed of a mixture of carbon nanotube (CNT) and polyacrylic acid (PAA)-based binder, preliminary tests show a capacity as high as 800 mAh g -1 electrode.  XPS revealed the beneficial impact of SPAN in transitioning long-chain sulfur to short-chain sulfur, optimizing battery performance.
- The UT Austin team investigated  a  solvent-free  dry-processing  method  to  fabricate  high-sulfur-loading cathodes. Cathodes with extremely high sulfur loading of 8 mg cm -2 were compared when employing the slurry-processing  and  dry-processing  methods.  Despite  its  lower  initial  capacity  compared  to  the slurry-processed  electrode,  the  dry-processed  electrode  successfully  maintains  a  mechanically  robust cathode  architecture  throughout  cell  cycling,  resulting  in  superior  cycle  life  with  only  a  1 wt% polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) binder content. The lower initial capacity of the dry-processed electrode is attributed to the dense electrode architecture with low porosity, caused by the layer-by-layer stacking of powdered materials without solvents and an application of pressure through a cylindrical roller during the PTFE binder fibrillation process.
- The University of Pittsburgh (U-Pitt) team examined catalyst candidates to promote electrocatalysis of the rate limiting step for Li2S formation during discharge in Li-S batteries and will be continuing efforts to validate computational results.
- The Texas A&amp;M University team noted that simulations show the electrolyte solvent DME creates more di- and tri- sulfides in SPAN systems, while dimethyl carbonate (DMC) creates short polysulfide segments. They also found that the electrolyte salt LiFSI mediates the electrochemistry of the SPAN reaction.
- The University of Washington (UW) team found that electrolyte chemistry has a greater effect on CE in Li-metal batteries than current collector architecture. Identifying best performing electrolytes will follow.

The goal of Keystone 2 is to design, model, fabricate, and characterize the effect of electrode architecture on the electrode and cell performance in support of reaching the project goal of 500 Wh kg -1 cell specific energy. Research conducted include the understanding and optimization of high loading electrodes; three-dimensional (3D) lithium anode architectures with and without surface chemical modification; synthesis and optimization of  SPAN  cathode;  and  development  of  high-capacity  sulfur  composites.  Research  highlighted  this  quarter includes:  improvements  in  cycling  stability  of  a  SPAN  composite  cathode  with  higher  capacity  than SPAN (UCSD); demonstration of a solvent-free dry-processing method of fabricating electrodes  with high sulfur  loading  (UT  Austin);  computational  studies  to  identify  catalysts  for  the  Li-S  reaction  (U-Pitt); computational analysis  of the  effect  of  electrolyte  on  the  surface  lithiation  of  SPAN  (Texas  A&amp;M); and  a comparison of the effect of current collector architecture and electrolyte chemistry on CE (UW).

## Improve CS SPAN Cathode Cycling Stability

This  quarter,  the  UCSD  team  continued  to  focus  on  enhancing  cycling  stability  of  a  high-S content SPAN material, often denoted as CS SPAN. This effort is essential to improve efficacy of CS SPAN batteries.

Last quarter, the team successfully synthesized CS SPAN. Evaluations at the electrode level revealed that the CS SPAN displays a promising capacity exceeding 650 mAh g -1 electrode. This value surpasses the typical SPAN  capacity of 550 mAh  g -1 electrode. However, certain limitations were observed with the CS SPAN material, notably cycling stability and performance at an areal loading of higher than 1 mg cm -2 . Addressing  these  challenges,  this  quarter  the  team  focused  work  on  improving  cycling  stability  and  areal loading  of  CS SPAN.  This  is  achieved  by  integrating  a  conductive  additive  composed  of  CNT  and

a  PAA-based  binder.  Figure  2.1a/b  illustrates  the  battery's  cycling  stability.  With  over  3 mg cm -2 in  areal loading, the electrode shows &gt;150 cycles of stable cycling. Impressively, during the initial cycles, the electrode reaches  a  capacity  of  close  to  800 mAh g -1 electrode,  a  performance  that  rivals  the  best  S-based  electrodes (including those made of elemental sulfur).

## High-Loading Li-S Batteries with Solvent-free Dry-Electrode Processing

This quarter, the UT Austin team investigated an industrially viable, solvent-free dry-processing method to produce high sulfur loading cathodes, utilizing PTFE  binder fibrillation. The traditional electrode manufacturing process involves  mixing  active  materials  and  conductive  agents  with  a  polymeric  binder  in

solvents, followed by casting the slurry onto the current collector. However, the slurry-processing method has inherent limitations when achieving high sulfur loading cathodes due to several factors, such as binder migration and capillary stress generated during the solvent-drying process, which weakens the mechanical integrity and electrochemical performance  of  the electrode. Unlike  the slurry-processing method,  the solvent-free dry-processing  method  utilizes  only  solid  powders  and  binders  to  create  free-standing  electrode  films.  By eliminating the solvent evaporation step, the dry-processing method avoids the above-mentioned issues and allows  for  production  of  extremely  thick  electrodes  without  cracking.  Figure 2.3a demonstrates  the  dry electrode  fabrication  procedure.  A  mixture  of  sulfur/Ketjenblack Â®   composite  (S/KB),  multiwalled  carbon nanotubes, Super P Â® , and PTFE powders were low-energy ball-milled for 8 hours in a mass ratio of 80:9.5:9.5:1. The powder mixture was processed into electrode sheets by shearing forces under heated conditions at 80Â°C, and  then  laminated  onto  an  aluminum  current  collector  to  be  used  as  the  cathode.  The  surface  of  the dry-processed electrodes and slurry-processed electrodes with high sulfur loadings of 8 mg cm -2 are compared by SEM in Figure 2.3b/c. Figure 2.3b reveals that the dry-processed electrode maintains a uniform and flat surface across the entire cathode. The fibrillated PTFE exhibits effective adhesion to the S/KB composite and carbon, ensuring  a well-integrated architecture without  any  major  defects  or  cracks.  Contrarily, the slurry-processed electrode displays pronounced irregularities and a convoluted surface topology, as shown in Figure  2.3c.  It  seems  that  the  considerable  capillary  stress  generated  during  solvent  evaporation  leads  to formation of severe cracks on the surface, resulting in such nonhomogeneous electrodes. Some portions of the active materials and carbon are loosely attached, making them prone to detachment even with slight agitation. Cross-sectional SEM images are also compared between the dry-processed electrode and the slurry-processed electrode in Figure 2.3d/e. Figure 2.3d shows an impressive consistent thickness (~ 97 Âµm) of the dry-processed electrode, whereas the slurry-processed electrode displays a considerable inconsistency in electrode thickness, as seen in Figure 2.3e. The SEM images reveal that the dry-processed electrodes form a much more uniform and denser electrode compared to the slurry-processed electrode.

Battery500 -Figure  2.3.  (a) Schematic of dry electrode fabrication procedure.  Surface  scanning  electron  microscopy  (SEM)  images  of  the (b)  dry-processed  electrode  and  (c)  slurry-processed  electrode.  Crosssectional  SEM  images  of  (d) dry-processed  electrode and  (e)  slurryprocessed electrode. The sulfur loading is 8 mg cm -2 .

Figure  2.4a shows the cycling performances  of  the  high  sulfur loading  slurry-processed  and  dry-processed electrodes.  The  slurry-processed  electrodes  with  sulfur  loadings  of  7  mg  cm -2 and  8  mg  cm -2 exhibit  rapid capacity decay, resulting in poor cycling stability with only 37% and 7% capacity retention, respectively, after 80 cycles.  In  sharp  contrast,  the  dry-processed  electrode  with  a  high  sulfur  loading  of  8 mg cm -2 shows  a remarkably different cycling trend. Despite its relatively lower initial capacity (651 mA h g -1 ) compared to the slurry-processed electrodes (1,098 mA h g -1 ), the cell demonstrates a stable cycling performance over 80 cycles with 79% overall capacity retention. To investigate the superior cycling stability of the dry-processed electrode compared to the slurry-processed electrode, the cycled cathode surfaces were imaged with SEM. Figure 2.4b shows that the dry-processed electrode maintains good mechanical integrity without major cracks, whereas the slurry-processed electrode exhibits pronounced cracks and deep crevices (Figure 2.4c).

Based on the cell cycling data, two questions can be raised: (1) Why does the dry-processed electrode exhibit a lower initial capacity compared to the slurry-processed electrode? (2) Could the disparity in cycling stability observed  between  the  dry-processed  and  slurry-processed  electrodes  be  primarily  attributed  to  electrode fracturing? The elevated initial capacity of the slurry-processed electrode implies the production of an increased quantity of polysulfides, potentially accelerating the degradation of both the cathode and the anode. Therefore, verification  is  needed  to  determine  whether  the  extent  of  electrode  cracking,  based  on  different  electrode processing methods, is indeed the primary cause for the varying capacity decay trends.

As widely known, sulfur cathodes need to maintain a certain level of porosity to provide space for filling them with electrolyte, establishing interconnected Li-ion transfer pathways between particles, and aiding the redox reaction of sulfur. Furthermore, the reaction mechanism of Li-S batteries involves the dissolution and deposition of polysulfides, heavily depending on the degree of electrolyte penetration into the electrode to wet the active material and carbon. When electrode porosity decreases significantly, the electrolyte might not reach the active material  properly,  causing  insufficient  Li-ion  supply  and  poor  polysulfide  dissolution  and  nucleation.  As previously  mentioned,  dry-processed  electrodes  exhibit  a  dense  and  less  porous  structure  compared  to slurry-processed electrodes. The limited active surface area could hinder the continued reaction of polysulfides in the electrolyte, resulting in a reduced overall capacity of the dry-processed electrode.

To investigate whether electrode porosity is the main factor influencing initial capacity, cell performance was evaluated under the same electrode volume condition by equalizing the overall thickness of the dry-processed and slurry-processed electrodes to 97 Âµm at a sulfur loading of 8 mg cm -2 . The dry-processed electrodes were used as is, while the slurry-processed electrodes underwent a calendering process to reduce their thickness.

To assess the calendering effect on the electrode, resistances of the cells were measured with electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), as shown in Figure 2.4d . The calendering process of slurry-processed electrode appears to enhance electrode conductivity by improving inter-particle contact and ensuring optimal electronic contact between the active material and the current collector. For dry-processed electrode, since the electrode is initially constructed from stacked powdered materials without solvents, significantly fewer void spaces lead to the lowest cell charge-transfer resistance. Furthermore, the dry-processed electrode employed a mere 1 wt% of PTFE binder content, consequently increasing the carbon content within the electrode and yielding superior conductivity compared to the slurry-processed electrodes.

The performance of the cells is compared between the slurry-processed and dry-processed electrodes with the same  electrode  thickness  in Figure 2.4e. As  seen,  the  initial  capacities  became  similar  after  matching  the thickness  of  both  electrodes  (711 mA h g -1 for  the  dry-processed  electrode,  and  693 mA h g -1 for  the slurry-processed  and  calendered  electrode).  The  convergence  of  the  initial  capacities  between  the  two electrodes, achieved by calendering the slurry-processed electrode to reduce overall electrode porosity under the same electrode thickness condition, suggests that electrode porosity plays a dominant role in influencing cell initial capacity. Thus, the lower initial capacity of the dry-processed electrode appears to stem from the self-calendering effect during the PTFE fibrillation process, which leads to a less porous electrode architecture.

The cell performance data presented in Figure 2.4e also provides insights into the second question raised above: Is the difference in cycling stability between the dry-processed electrode and the slurry-processed electrode related to electrode cracking? The similar initial capacities of both electrodes suggest comparable amounts of active polysulfide generation in the Li-S system. While the dry-processed electrode exhibits stable capacity retention  over  50  cycles,  the  slurry-processed  and  calendered  electrodes  demonstrate  rapid  capacity  decay starting  from  the  10 th cycle.  Considering  that  all  cell  components  are  the  same  and  the  amount  of  active polysulfide generated is similar, the only distinguishable factor is the different types of electrodes applied. Thus, such a difference in cycling performance can be attributed to the different architectures of the cathodes. Under high sulfur loading conditions, the inadequate mechanical stability of the slurry-processed electrode results in cathode pulverization, leading to a loss of electronic contact in the active material, whereas the dry-processed electrode retains its contact with a well-integrated electrode architecture. Based on the cell cycling performance at the same electrode thickness, it seems that the occurrence of electrode cracking, depending on the processing method, has a direct impact on cell cyclability.

## Theoretical  Modeling  and  Identification  of  Functional  Electrocatalysts  Promoting  Li2S2  to  Li2S Conversion in Sulfur Cathode

One of the ongoing research areas undertaken by the U-Pitt team is focused on computational studies. The team utilized theoretical modeling to improve the conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S, an essential process for enhancing the specific capacity of experimentally designed S-cathodes in Li-S batteries. They utilized the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) to simulate the kinetic and thermodynamic properties of this conversion reaction, with  the  primary  focus  directed  at  overcoming  the  kinetic  barriers  involved.  The  study  was  continued  by applying the climbing nudged elastic band method to determine activation barriers, with computations executed using the projector-augmented wave method. The team successfully identified several functional electrocatalysts that displayed promising potential to promote the desired conversion reaction.

Results  from  the  first  half  of  this  fiscal  year  indicated  that  Cat38  is  an  optimal  functional  electrocatalyst, demonstrating a relatively low kinetic activation barrier of 0.26 eV (Figure 2.5a). This finding instigated further exploration last quarter into identifying other potential functional electrocatalysts, resulting in identification of Cat72 from Group XIII (Figure 2.5b), exhibiting even lower kinetic barrier values of 0.25 eV.

Battery500 -Figure  2.5.  Potential  energy  profiles  of  Li2S2 â†’Li 2S+S*  reaction  for  the  various  multicomponent functional electrocatalysts systems considered in this research study.

Group  XIV  and  XV  (Figure 2.5c/d),  which  represent  an  amalgamation  of  primary  anionic  elements  from Groups II, XI, III, and XII along with binary metals from Groups VII and XIII, yielded even lower kinetic barriers.  The  best  performing  functional  electrocatalysts  from  this  group,  Cat77  and  Cat82,  demonstrated effective kinetic activation barriers of 0.23 eV and 0.25 eV, respectively, averaging ~ 0.28 eV, which represents an improvement over the performance of the previously identified (1) Cat38 with a low kinetic activation barrier of  0.26 eV from the lower group of functional electrocatalyst systems shown in Figure 2.5a, and (2) Cat72

shown in Figure 2.5b with an activation barrier of 0.25eV. It can also be noted that Cat38 is the lowest from the group of functional electrocatalysts, showing an average kinetic barrier of ~ 0.3 eV while the other functional electrocatalysts in the same group have an average kinetic barrier of ~ 0.5 eV. On the other hand, Cat72 is the lowest from the group of functional electrocatalysts shown in Figure 2.5b, also exhibiting an average kinetic barrier of ~ 0.3 eV.

In  conclusion,  through  extensive  computational  modeling,  the  U-Pitt  team  has  identified  several  promising functional  electrocatalysts  (Cat38,  Cat72, Cat77,  and Cat82)  that  enhance  the  conversion  of  Li2S2  to  Li2S. Despite these achievements, ongoing research is aimed at discovering improved functional electrocatalysts that will  exhibit  even  lower  kinetic  barriers  to  improve  the  S-cathode  specific  capacity.  Ongoing  experimental studies have been successful at generating Cat38 in situ within the sulfur cathode. Subsequent quarterly reports will provide updates on the experimental studies designed to validate these theoretical findings.

## Computational Analysis of Effects of Electrolyte on Lithiation of SPAN

The Texas A&amp;M team employed ab initio molecular dynamics simulations to understand the electrolyte's role in the interfacial lithiation of SPAN material. They compared the solvation effects of DMC and DME electrolyte systems. DME poses strong solvation and stabilization to polysulfide, which results in a higher likelihood for SPAN to experience S-S cleavage and yield disulfides and trisulfides to enter the electrolyte phase. On the other hand, the weaker solvation effects of DMC create a favorable environment for generating short polysulfide fragments, and that is reflected in the average polysulfide chain length evolution, as well. In addition, they also found that  the  electrolyte  salt,  LiFSI,  is  not  simply  the  charge  carrier  and  source  materials  of  SEI.  It  also mediates the electrochemistry of SPAN reduction by forming semi-covalent Li-O bonds, and the lithium is also electrostatically  bonded  with  sulfides  that  are  leaving  the  SPAN structure  (Figure 2.6).  As the  free  energy profile shows, such a LiFSI-mediated S-S cleavage reaction is driven by electron transfer with an energy barrier below 3 kcal/mol.

## Comparison of Effect of Current Collector Architecture and Electrolyte Chemistry in Li-Metal Cells

The UW team continued investigating 3D-structured current collectors for Li-metal anodes in Li-metal cells, specifically considering whether current collector structure or electrolyte chemistry dominates effects on CE. Half cells of lithium versus either copper foil or copper foam (MTI Corp, 180 Î¼m) were assembled with four electrolytes: an LHCE (labeled as LHCE) consisting of a 1:1.2:3 molar ratio of LiFSI,  DME, and TTE; an ether-based electrolyte (labeled as LiTFSI) of 1 M LiTFSI in a 1:1 ratio of DME and DOL; an electrolyte (labeled as F4) of 1.2 M LiFSI in F4DEE (in the family of fluorinated-1,2-diethoxyethane molecules); and an electrolyte  (labeled  as  F5)  of  1.2 M  LiFSI  in  F5DEE  (in  the  family  of  fluorinated-1,2-diethoxyethane molecules). Cells were cycled using a modified Aurbach protocol consisting of eight formation cycles of plating at 0.4 mA/cm 2 up to 4 mAh/cm 2 and stripping at 0.4 mA/cm 2 to 1 V, plating of a reservoir of 4 mAh/cm 2 of lithium at 0.4 mA/cm 2 ,  followed by 150 shallow plating/stripping cycles at 0.4 mA/cm 2 up to 0.5 mAh/cm 2 , with a final strip to 1 V at 0.4 mA/cm 2 . CE was determined from the capacity of the initial reservoir, the number and capacity of the shallow cycles, and the capacity of the final strip.

Figure 2.7 compares the average CE of cells with each combination of current collector  and  electrolyte.  No  current collector architecture consistently shows improved CE across all electrolytes,  nor  does  any  electrolyte show  markedly  greater  CE  for  both current collectors. From these data, the team  theorizes  that  electrolyte  has  a greater impact on CE  than current collector architecture.

The  team  performed  EIS  to  examine what electrical and electrochemical properties change during cycling for the different substrates and electrolytes. Figure 2.8 displays the EIS spectra for sample cells  of  either  a  copper  foil  or copper  foam  substrate  with  either  the

## Keystone Project 3: Cell Fabrication, Testing, and Diagnosis

## Highlights of Keystone Project 3

The highlights for this quarter are as follows:

- The PNNL team developed a methodology using design of experiments (DoE) to systematically explore the interactions and trade-offs among the intertwined cathode factors (active material, binder, conductor) and process variables.
- The GM team initiated binder alternative investigation to replace the carboxymethyl cellulose - styrenebutadiene  rubber  (CMC-SBR)  system.  Multilayer  pouch  format  cells  based  on  previously  optimized components were fabricated and tested.
- The Idaho National Laboratory (INL) team studied the impact to life and failure modes caused by multiple different calendar conditions using SLPCs. Calendar aging of less than 1% capacity fade over 18 months was observed by the INL team when testing under practical operation conditions.

The goal of the Keystone 3 is to integrate the material and electrode architecture from Keystones 1 and 2 to full-cell design, fabricate the pouch-format cell with the component developed in Keystones 1 and 2, evaluate the  single  and  multilayer  pouch-format  cells  and  diagnose  the  failure  mechanism  of  the  pouch  cells.  This quarter, the Keystone 3 team completed two milestones: develop multilayer pouch-format cell fabrication and testing for optimal C/S cathode chemistry; and report processing, characterization, and quality control / quality assurance protocols for 20-g/batch scale SPAN materials for the Battery500 team's use in investigations. The PNNL team initiated a DoE work on interactions and trade-offs among the intertwined cathode and process variables. The GM team focused on an alternative binder solution to replace the current CMC-SBR system. GM also fabricated and tested a multilayer pouch-format cell with a previously identified electrode formulation. The INL team looked into the impact from different calendaring conditions to the cell life and failure mode using SLPCs for Li-NMC chemistry.

## Cathode Factors and Process Variables Study

In development of Li-S pouch cells, the PNNL team works with other consortium teams and focuses on cathode materials development, electrode optimization and processing, and performance evaluation in both coin and pouch cells. This quarter, to address the complex challenges associated with sulfur electrode processing,  the  PNNL  team  developed  a  methodology  using DoE to  systematically  explore  the  interactions  and  trade-offs among the  intertwined  cathode  factors  (active  material,  binder, conductor) and process variables. This study examines the impact of  input  factors  on  electrode  properties  and  electrochemical performance  and  identifies and estimates interaction effects between the factors. Further, these estimates were extended using

Battery500 -Table  3.1.  Screening factors in design of experiments for sulfur electrode formulation and processing.

the  empirical  model  developed  to  predict  factor  combinations  that  would  lead  to  improved  performance. Through the DoE methodology, the team can accelerate development and optimization based on a downselected set of screening experiments, and ultimately achieved improved cell performance under both high-loading and lean electrolyte conditions.

Taking  electrode  formulation  study  as  an  example,  twelve  different  sulfur  electrodes  were  fabricated  and processed.  Of  the  64  possible  combinations  for  the  four  electrode  factors  (percentage  of  PAA  binder, polyethylene glycol dimethyl ether additive, carbon nanofiber (CNF) conductor, and LiOH additive) and the two processing factors [cathode thickness reduction via calendering, and E/S ratio of electrolyte], 24 coin cells were assembled. Note, sulfur mass loading is &gt; 4 mg/cm 2 for all the cells used in the study. Figure 3.1 shows

the specific capacity and median voltage versus cycle number for each coin cell for the first 15 cycles. While long-term cycling performance is important for identifying promising combinations of cathode, anode, and electrolyte, the goal of this screening experiment is rather to focus on the optimal cathode and processing. For this reason, cell performance of the first 15 cycles was compared to identify positive and negative effects from factors and interactions, and sufficient to observe meaningful differences between the cathodes. For ease of comparison,  graphs  are  divided  by  sub-plot  factors:  (1)  densely  calendered  with  flooded  electrolyte (E/S = 10 mL g -1 S), (2) densely calendered and lean electrolyte (E/S = 4 mL g -1 S), (3) porous calendering and flooded electrolyte, and (4) porous calendering and lean electrolyte. From the electrochemical data, preliminary comparisons and conclusions can be drawn. When electrolyte is flooded, after the two formation cycles, no cells exhibit higher than 900 mAh g -1 in discharge capacity. This is primarily due to the increased dissolution of soluble lithium polysulfide species in the presence of an excess amount of electrolyte that affects reversibility of  sulfur  species  available  for  repeated  electrochemical  reactions.  With  lean  electrolyte  conditions,  the discharge capacity observed for the coin cells has the highest range, including the best performing cells and the worst  performing  cells.  For  both  lean  and  flooded  electrolyte  conditions,  the  given  degree  of  calendering (5-20% reduction) did not have a significant impact on specific discharge capacity. Average voltage was more variable under lean electrolyte conditions, while it was more consistent across all cells when electrolyte was flooded. Average voltage informs the electrochemical reactions occurring within the cell and has significant impact on the power of the cell.

Through  the  DoE  approach,  significant  interaction  terms  can  be  identified.  For  example,  the  interactions between CNF and LiOH have apparent effects on specific discharge capacity, charge transfer resistance, and electrode resistivity (detailed data not shown here). Specifically, when the amount of LiOH is low, there is a minimal difference in the effect of CNF on the specific capacity. However, when LiOH is high, the effect of CNF is quite different, with larger amounts leading to improved performance. A similar effect is shown in the electrode resistivity, where high LiOH and high CNF lead to the lowest overall resistivity, while high LiOH and low CNF lead to the highest resistivity. Effects on charge transfer resistance are unclear due to the wide and  overlapping  range  of  values  in  each  subset.  These  results  may  be  partially  explained  by  other  system variables  that  exhibit  dependency  on  LiOH  and  contribute  to  electrode  resistance.  For  example, increasing LiOH simultaneously decreased the nitrogen-doped integrated KB / sulfur loading of the cathodes and increased porosity.  This  could  be  a  result  of  the  increased  slurry  viscosity  caused  by  the  LiOH:PAA interaction  that extends polymer chains, requiring more solvent to solvate PAA. This in turn contributes to

In addition, a slight interaction was uncovered between LiOH and CNF that also added to higher mass loadings when both components were set to their high values. One explanation is that when CNF and LiOH are both high, the effects of increased porosity and reduced active material due to high LiOH are outweighed by the CNF, so the overall resistance remains low. ## Binder Alternative with Electrode Formulation Study

This  quarter,  the GM team focused  on  optimizing  the  sulfur  electrode  formulation  with  binder  alternative investigation. As reported last quarter, electrode formulation using PAA-co-acrylamide binder has shown high cycle stability over 100 cycles and maintaining a capacity of 800 mAh/g. While using this binder outperformed cells with CMC-SBR in coin cells, large charge-discharge polarization was observed in the single layer (0.1 Ah) pouch cell.  One  approach  under  investigation  is  the  cathode  processing  protocol  to  achieve  homogeneous slurry; another approach is a recommendation by PNNL to use Li-PAA or PAA binder and explore feasibility for  roll-to-roll  electrode  fabrication.  Figure  3.2  shows  electrochemical  performance  of  C/S  electrodes  with Li-PAA as binder. Both charge/discharge profiles and cycle life show a stable capacity of 900 mAh/g over 80 cycles with CE of 90%. Similar to electrode formulation with PAA-co-polymer, the capacity increases and becomes stable  after  10-20  cycles,  which  could be  due  to  increase  in  wettability  of  active  material  during cycling.  For  the  next  step,  the  team  will  develop  roll-to-roll  electrodes  using  PAA  and  Li-PAA  binder  to evaluate the performance of pouch cells.

## Performance of Multilayer Pouch Cells

This quarter, several multilayer pouch cells (0.7 Ah and 1 Ah) were fabricated and tested by the GM team. Baseline C/S electrodes with CMC-SBR as binder formulation were developed using roll-to-roll process for use in pouch cells. The average cathode loading was 3.5 mg-S/cm 2 .  In  Figure 3.3, charge/discharge voltage profiles and cycling performance of 0.7 Ah pouch cells are presented. The initial pressure was set at 10 psi using  metal  plate  fixtures  that  were  also  monitored  at  the  end  of  cycling.  Figure 3.3a/b  compares  the performance  of  pouch  cells  using  standard  electrolyte  1 M  LiTFSI  and  2  wt%  LiNO3  (DOL:DME)  and 0.6 M LiTFSI and 2.4 wt% LiNO3 (DOL:DME), respectively. Both pouch cells showed a similar discharge capacity of about 1200 mAh/g in the first cycles. In Figure 3.3a, the discharge voltage profile represents a more sluggish polysulfide conversion, which may be due to the higher concentration of LiTFSI in the electrolyte. This behavior was consistent with their SLPC results. Figure 3.3c represents a pouch cell that delivered similar capacity  but  showed  rapid  decay  over  cycling.  This  is  also  shown  in  Figure 3.3d  where  all  cells  maintain

capacity up to 10 cycles; however, the decay is more significant for the third cell. Figure 3.3e/f depicts the pressure mapping of pouch cells once the capacity started decaying. Both cell 1 and 2 (Figure 3.3e) showed pressure increase to 70 psi while cell 3 (Figure 3.3f) only showed pressure increase to 25 psi. However, the nonuniform pressure distribution shown for cell 3 clearly indicates a possible cause for the rapid capacity decay. These results suggest that gas generation in Li-S pouch cells has severe impact on cycling stability, which needs to be addressed.

## Calendar Condition Impact on Cell Failure Modes

The INL team has looked at the impact on calendar life and failure modes under different conditions using SLPCs. The study includes a suite of conditions at different SOCs, temperatures, pressures, and voltage hold conditions using Li||Li[Ni0.8Mn0.1Co0.1(NMC-811)]O2 and LHCE.  Specific conditions include varying SOC (70% and 100%), temperatures (25Â°C and 45Â°C), pressures (10 psi and 50 psi), and operational modes (open-circuit voltage,  OCV;  constant voltage,  CV).  For  the  most  moderate  and  most  likely  to  occur  in application setting (OCV, 70% SOC, 25Â°C, and 10 psi) over 18 months, less than 1% capacity fade has been observed (Figure 3.5). For this condition, the calendar life is conservatively projected at 31 months based on the quantity of lithium remaining on the negative electrode as determined in a post-test analysis. Additional conditions including the use of high temperature (45Â°C), 100% SOC, and at CV have shown promise, which can be used as testing routes to accelerate aging and guidance for future charge protocol development. As with cycle aging, applied pressure helps mitigate dendritic growth and increases the calendar life of the  Li-metal

## Keystone Project 4: Cross-Cutting Efforts

## Highlights of Keystone Project 4

The highlights for this quarter are as follows:

- The BNL team identified CsNO3 as an effective additive for Li-metal electrolyte and studied the mechanism of  how  it  protects  the  Li-metal  anode.  They  found  that  CsNO3  leads  to  an  SEI  that  has  CsFSI  as  the dominating inorganic components and FSI-derived oligomers as the dominating amorphous components.
- The  UT  Austin  team  conducted  an  investigation  to  understand  the  influence  of  transition-metal  (TM) crossover on the distribution of SEI on  Li-metal anode through advanced, high-resolution 3D chemical analysis with time-of-flight secondary-ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMS). It is found that the presence of these TMs on the anode induces heterogeneities in both SEI formation and lithium deposition.
- The  Texas  A&amp;M  team,  through  collaboration  with  PNNL,  analyzed  the  electrical  behavior  of  the SEI formed on the Li-metal anode for four different electrolytes relevant to the Battery500 Consortium. They  also developed a new  methodology  to characterize simultaneous events occurring during SEI formation and growth and simultaneous plating or stripping during cell cycling.
- The SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory team worked in collaboration with the UT Austin team and performed  transmission  X-ray  microscopy - X-ray  absorption  near-edge  spectroscopy  (TXM-XANES) studies for LNO cathodes at three SOCs to understand the complex interaction of key elements such as cobalt, manganese, and aluminum for use in the rational design of Ni-rich cathodes. The SLAC team also carried  out in  situ atomic  force  microscopy  (AFM)  measurements  of  the  SEI  nanomechanics  for  four electrolytes of interest to Li-metal batteries. In addition to the traditionally reported property of Young's modulus, they collected  quantitative  measurements  of SEI  viscoelasticity  using  an indentation  protocol incorporating both indentation and constant force hold segments.
- The  UCSD  team  worked  together  with  GM  and  used  titration  gas  chromatography  (TGC)  and High-Performance  Liquid  Chromatography - Ultra  Violet  Spectroscopy  (HPLC-UV)  to  quantify  the lithium and sulfur inventory loss in Li-S batteries during cycling and during calendar aging.

## Identification of CsNO3 as Electrolyte Additive and its Protection Mechanism

This quarter, the BNL team identified CsNO3 as an effective additive for Li-metal battery electrolyte and studied the mechanism of how it protects the Li-metal anode. CE of lithium plating and stripping (Figure 4.1a) was obtained  in  Li||Cu  cells  following  the  method  proposed  by  the  PNNL  team  for  the  baseline  electrolyte (1.5 M LiFSI in DME) and electrolyte with CsNO3 additive. The electrolyte with CsNO3 additive has a higher CE (99.46%) than the baseline electrolyte (99.11%) in the Li||Cu cell, as shown in Figure 4.1a. This indicates an enhanced stability of the Li-metal anode in the CsNO3-containing electrolyte. Li-metal cells were constructed with  a  Li-metal  anode  and  an  NMC-811  cathode  to  evaluate  performance  of  the  baseline  electrolyte  and electrolyte with CsNO3 additive. As shown in Figure 4.1b, using the baseline electrolyte, cells can maintain stable cycling for up to 70 cycles under mild conditions (250-Î¼m-thick lithium, 9 mg/cm 2 cathode). However, a  rapid  capacity  drop  is  observed  afterward.  In  contrast,  the  electrolyte  containing  the  CsNO3  additive significantly improved cyclability of the cell. Over 70% capacity retention was maintained even after 300 cycles (Figure 4.1b). As CsNO3 is used only in small amounts, CsNO3-containing electrolyte is expected to inherit the high ionic conductivity of DME-based electrolyte. This is shown in Figure 4.1c. Both the baseline electrolyte and  the CsNO3-containing  electrolyte  exhibit  ionic  conductivities  that  are  twice  as  high  as  the  commercial electrolyte based on LiPF6 and carbonates. Based on the lithium metal protection capability and the high ionic conductivity of CsNO3-containing DME based electrolyte, it may potentially offer great opportunity for cycling the  Li-metal  cell  using  fast  charge-discharge  rate.  Figure  4.1d  shows the  high  rate  cycling  performance  of Li-metal cells using high-loading NMC-811 and low N/P ratio. The cells first went through two formation cycles at C/10 rate and 5 cycles at C/5 rate and then were cycled at 1C rate corresponding to 4 mA/cm 2 . Even under harsh conditions (50-Î¼m-thick lithium foil, 21 mg/cm 2 NMC-811 cathode, N/P ratio = 2), the cell using

electrolytes  with  the  CsNO3 additive  maintains  more  than  80%  of  the  initial  capacity  after  200 cycles (Figure 4.1d/e). In comparison, the cell using the baseline electrolyte experienced a quick loss of capacity within 20 cycles.

The BNL team went further to study the interphase formation mechanism of both the baseline electrolyte and the CsNO3-containing electrolyte. XRD and pair distribution function (PDF) techniques, which offer insights into  both  the  crystalline  and  amorphous aspects of the interphase, were employed. The XRD pattern of the anode interphase resulting from the baseline electrolyte is shown in the upper panel of Figure 4.2a. Thanks to the  high  quality  of  synchrotron  XRD, Rietveld  refinement  can  be  carried  out  reliably.  It  has  typical  anode interphase components such as LiH, Li2O, and nanocrystalline LiF that result from electrolyte decomposition. In  sharp  contrast,  the  anode  interphase  resulting  from  the  electrolyte  with  CsNO3  additive  is  completely different, as shown in the lower panel in Figure 4.2a. Instead of Li2O and LiF, CsFSI is the dominant inorganic species in the anode interphase. Detailed Rietveld refinement indicates that there are two kinds of CsFSI present,

one being cis-CsFSI (major) and the other being trans-CsFSI (minor). They have similar crystal packing modes but differ in the arrangement of atoms in the FSI anion. The formation of CsFSI may not consume electrons from the circuit compared with the formation of Li2O and LiF, both of which do consume electrons. As a result, CsFSI formation may be favorable for improving CE. While XRD data reveal the crystalline components in the anode  interphase,  PDF  data  provide  information  on  the  amorphous  phases  (Figure 4.2b).  For  the  baseline electrolyte, the first PDF peak is attributed to the presence of S=O, S-F, or S-N bonds (around 1.5 Ã…) that belong to  species  resulting  from  FSI  anion  decomposition.  The  calculated  structure  and  PDF  pattern  of  a  model compound Li2(FSI(-F))2 (-F means one fluorine atom is lost from the FSI anion) are shown for illustration. The first PDF peak is asymmetric and has some intensity in the lower r region, suggesting the presence of some shorter bonds that are likely carbon-based bonds such as C-O, C=O, and C-C. These bonds belong to species such  as  DME  oligomer  that  result  from  solvent  decomposition.  The  calculated  structure  and  PDF  data  of DME oligomer are also shown. Other PDF peaks can be well accounted for by the presence of interphase components such as lithium metal, LiH, Li2O, and LiF. The peak at 2.0 Ã… can only be assigned to those related to  the  inorganic  species  such  as  LiH,  Li2O,  and  LiF.  Its  relatively  strong  intensity  suggests  that  there  are abundant inorganic species in the anode interphase formed by the baseline electrolyte decomposition. Following the same analysis method, the lower panel of Figure 4.2b suggests that the amorphous phase resulting from FSI anion decomposition has dominant percentage in the anode interphase formed by electrolyte containing CsNO3 additive.  The  predominant  inorganic  species  in  the  anode  interphase  is  CsFSI,  with  minimal  to  no presence of Li2O or LiF. The significant difference in anode interphase components may be caused by the solvation structure, which is influenced by the presence of Cs + cation. In the baseline electrolyte, due to the relatively  small  size  of  the  Li + cation  and  the  strong  solvation  interaction  between  DME  solvent  and  the Li + cation, FSI anions have small chance of entering the solvation sheath and participating in the interphase formation. When the Cs + cation is present, its large size (Li + radius: 0.59 Ã…; Cs + : 1.67 Ã…) greatly weakens the solvation interaction between the DME solvent and Cs + cation. As a result, more anions can enter the solvation sheath and contribute to the interphase formation. Such formed interphase contains both FSI anion derived amorphous components and CsFSI inorganic species, which is robust and capable of extending long cycle life.

## Role of TM Crossover on SEI Formation in Li-Metal Cells

This quarter, the UT Austin team conducted an investigation to understand the influence of TM crossover on the  distribution  of  SEI  products  through  advanced,  high-resolution  3D  chemical  analysis  with  TOF-SIMS. TM crossover is well known to induce greater SEI decomposition on graphite, but only limited studies have focused on its effects on lithium metal. In particular, maintaining uniform coverage of the SEI on Li-metal anode is important. It is postulated that the crossed-over TMs from the cathode will affect SEI formation and lithium deposition, which are two processes that are critical to Li-metal battery performance. TOF-SIMS is one of  the  most  powerful  techniques  to  understand  the  distribution  of  the  SEI components,  as  it  enables  the identification, localization, and relative quantification of products within the anode SEI at a high 3D spatial resolution. The systems investigated in this work are Li-metal anodes from Li | LP57 or high-voltage electrolyte (HVE) |  LiNi0.7Mn0.25Al0.05O2  (NMA-70)  half  cells,  which  have  been  cycled  to  an  upper  cutoff  voltage  of 4.6 V versus  Li/Li + for  500 cycles  to  induce  significant  TM  dissolution.  LP57  is  composed  of  1 M LiPF6 dissolved in a binary solvent system of EC and ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC) with 2 wt% of vinylene carbonate as an additive. The HVE was prepared with a binary solvent system of EC:EMC (3:7) by weight that is first saturated with 3 M LiPF6 salt, followed by adding the diluent TTE to lower the overall concentration of LiPF6 from  3 M to  1 M  and  retain  the  solvated  salt-solvent  clusters  in  solution.  3  vol%  FEC  was  added  to  this electrolyte as an additive. A series of secondary-ion (SI) fragments of interest were selected, representing the most  commonly  found  degradation  products  formed  in  the  SEI.  In  this  analysis,  organic  electrolyte decomposition products are represented by C2HO -, inorganic salt decomposition products by LiF2 -and PO2 -, redeposited/bulk lithium with Li2 -, and deposited TMs by Ni -. They first highlight the influence of deposited TMs on the localization of SEI components in the LP57 electrolyte, relatively quantify TM dissolution in the LP57  and  HVE  electrolyte,  and  then  provide  quantitative  measures  of  spatial  heterogeneity  between  SEI components in the LP57 and HVE systems. Figure 4.3a/b shows a series of views of the measured Ni -, PO2 -, C2HO , Li2 -, and LiF2 -fragments from the SEI of the Li-metal anode. Brighter regions represent locations with higher SI yield. The value of the SI yield is directly proportional to the concentration of the species detected within the SEI. Figure 4.3a presents the through-plane X-Y views of the 3D renderings for the Ni -, PO2 -, C2HO -, and LiF2 -fragments. Qualitatively, it is clear that the spatial distributions of common electrolyte degradation products closely follow the spatial distribution of Ni -.  This  is  confirmed  within  a  large,  100 Âµm  Ã— 100 Âµm analysis region, as well as for a series of X-Y planes extending deeper into the SEI. Figure 4.3b presents the total-yield maps of the Ni -to Li2 -SI fragments to investigate the effects of these TMs on lithium deposition. The  total-yield  maps  are  two-dimensional  projections  that  are  calculated  from  a  through-plane  sum  of  all X-Y views of the 3D renderings. Comparison of these maps reveals that there is a greater amount of lithium metal at locations with the lowest concentrations of TMs. In essence, the presence of these TMs on the anode is revealed to induce heterogenous SEI formation, as well as lithium deposition. Figure 4-3c/d shows the relative quantification of deposited nickel for two different electrolytes, LP57 and HVE, to investigate the influence of the electrolyte on the degree of TM crossover. It is highlighted in Figure 4.3c that there is a pronounced effect of the electrolyte on the amount of deposited nickel found on the cycled anodes. Figure 4.3d provides the results from integrating the SI yield profiles for various SI fragments. The typical shape of the SI yield profiles is an asymmetric bell curve. The integration of each SI fragment was conducted between the crossing depths at 0.6 of its maximum from the SI yield profile. A magnitude higher concentration of nickel was found to have been deposited onto the anodes cycled in LP57 than that in HVE. Furthermore, greater amounts of organic/inorganic decomposition products are also detected for the LP57 electrolyte than for the HVE. The exacerbated degree of electrolyte  decomposition  is  primarily  attributed  to  differences  in  the  deposited  nickel,  as  dissolved  and deposited TMs are well known to serve as catalytic centers for electrolyte decomposition.

Figure 4.4  presents  results  from  an  analysis  to  quantify  heterogeneity  between  the  spatial  distributions  of different SI fragments. To quantify the degree of heterogeneity between the chemical maps of different species of interest, they look at the net squared deviation (NSD) between these maps. The maps were smoothed with a 2-point interpolation applied to the profiles in the X and Y directions prior to calculation of the squared deviation maps. The squared deviation map between two chemical maps is simply the squared difference between the two maps range-normalized. A normalization with the range was necessary to account for differences in the baseline values between different fragments of interest. These squared deviation maps are calculated between each two fragments of interest [F1 and F2, where Fi = (C2HO -, LiF2 -, Li 2 -, PO2 -, or Ni -), with i = 1, 2]. The NSD is then calculated from the total sum of the squared deviations at all points.

Figure 4.4a/b shows the NSD matrix for the five fragments of interest (C2HO -, LiF2 -, Li2 -, PO2 -, or Ni), that is color-coded based on magnitude of the NSD. A larger NSD (yellow) indicates a lower similarity between the maps of two fragments. As expected, the values in Figure 4.4a for the NSD calculated for LP57 between the Ni , PO2 -, LiF2 -, and C2HO -spatial maps are low (black), supporting the strong positive correlation between the distributions of TMs and SEI decomposition products. On the other hand, the NSD of the Li2 -map to the other fragments  Ni -,  PO2 -,  LiF2 -,  and  C2HO -are  high  (yellow),  confirming  that  lithium  metal  is  preferentially deposited separately with respect to the other SEI species at Li-anode surface. Interestingly, a similar trend is observed for the HVE in Figure 4.4b, but the values of the NSD between the Li2 -map and the other fragments Ni ,  PO2 -,  LiF2 -,  and  C2HO for  the  HVE  are  noticeably  lower  than  those  for  LP57.  Additionally,  the HVE exhibits higher values of the NSD between the Ni -, PO2 -, LiF2 -, and C2HO -spatial maps, which reveals mild differences between their individual distributions on the surface of Li-metal anode. Subsequently, it is believed that the concentration of deposited TMs for the anodes cycled in HVE may not be high enough to induce a strong localization of individual SEI components, which allows them to be dispersed across different regions  of  the  anode  (Figure  4.3c/d).  Overall,  the  higher  amount  of  nickel  dissolution  and  crossover  from cathode  to  anode  in  the  LP57  electrolyte  compared  to  that  in  the  advanced  HVE  leads  to  a  more  severe localization of SEI formation and lithium deposition onto Li-metal anode in LP57.

## Theoretical Characterization of SEI Composition, Morphology, and Electrical Properties

The Texas A&amp;M team, through collaboration with PNNL, analyzed the electrical behavior of the SEI formed on  the  Li-metal  anode  using  four  different  electrolytes.  The  PNNL  group  carried  out  current-voltage measurements of each of the SEI samples that were also fully characterized with various techniques regarding chemical  composition,  morphology,  and  lithium  plating/stripping  morphologies.  They  used  first-principles simulations  to  study the  initial  formation  and  growth  of  the SEI  for  the  four  electrolyte  formulations.  The calculated SEI structures were used as input to evaluate the conductance behavior of each sample using ab initio methods. Figure 4.5 shows a schematic description of the theoretical approach. The predicted conductance and differential conductance as a function of bias voltage were in excellent agreement with the PNNL experimental measurements. As a result, the team was able to provide new insights into the role of electrolyte chemistry on the SEI structure, composition, thickness, and electrical behavior, which were all correlated to cell performance. Results were published in Nature Energy .

## New Theoretical Tools for Understanding SEI Evolution and Electrochemical Cycling

The Texas A&amp;M team developed a new methodology to characterize the simultaneous events occurring during SEI formation and growth and simultaneous plating or stripping during cell cycling. The novel method is based on a kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) scheme. All possible reactions, diffusion, or other events are incorporated, and at each step the kinetically favorable reaction or physical event takes place, triggering a dynamic motion and describing the surface evolution. The illustration of Figure 4.6 shows that simultaneous plating, stripping, and electrolyte decomposition reactions are included in the 'reactions catalog.' In conjunction with the ab initio analysis, the KMC method is a useful tool for evaluating new electrolytes, effects on lithium morphologies, and many other scenarios that enhance understanding at the cell level. An article has been prepared for publication.

## Morphological and Chemical Distribution Studies on LNO Cathode at Various SOCs

The Weker group at SLAC, in collaboration with UT Austin, performed ex situ X-ray measurements using beamline 6-2  to  collect data  from  Ni-based  cathodes  (LiNiO2,  LiNi0.95Co0.05O2,  LiNi0.95Mn0.05O2,  and LiNi0.95Al0.05O2) cycled at UT Austin at three SOCs. The goal is to understand the complex interaction of key elements such as cobalt, manganese, and aluminum for use in the rational design of Ni-rich cathodes and to

observe the influence of these dopants on the electrochemical performance of the LiNiO2 cathodes. All samples were measured using TXM to observe the morphology and XANES to obtain chemical information at the nickel K-edge energy. The characterized cathodes were vacuum dried (120Â°C), calendered, and punched into 12-mm round disks. Electrodes were then assembled in 2032 coin cells and charged at a C/10 rate to 73% and 87% SOC. A pristine cathode was characterized as a reference point. Figure 4.7 shows the transmission images taken at the nickel energy K-edge of the LiNiO2 cathodes. The TXM images show spherical morphology particles of LiNiO2 with an average particle size of ~ 12 Âµm. The spherical shape remains after removal of the lithium ions. However,  some  cracks  are  observed  (blue  arrows)  in  the  cycled  particles,  which  likely  result  from  the charging process.

Battery500 -Figure  4.7.  Transmission X-ray microscopy  (TXM) images  above nickel K-edge  (8350  eV)  of  the LiNiO2 cathodes at (a) pristine state, (b) 73% state of charge (SOC), and (c) 87% SOC. The blue arrows point to cracks in the LiNiO2 particles.

The  chemical  composition  and  local  valence states of elements can be determined by combining  TXM  with  X-ray  spectroscopy.  By probing the absorption edge of a specific element (nickel K-edge for this analysis) with the appropriate X-ray energy, it is possible to visualize  the  distribution  of  different  chemical species or to  monitor  elements as they are reduced  or  oxidized.  Beamline 6-2  at  Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Lightsource combines spectroscopy and microscopy to obtain data with both  energy  and  spatial  dimensions,  providing excellent  capabilities  to  observe  and  study  the chemical and morphological information of the Ni-based cathodes.  Figure 4.8a-c  shows  the variation  of  the  energy  edge  position  for  the LiNiO2 cathode in its pristine state, at 73% SOC, and at 87% SOC, respectively. The edge energy positions, as indicated by color, do not vary much within the electrode, but there is variation between  the  pristine  and  the  charged  cathodes. ## In Situ Measurements of the SEI Nanomechanics

To better understand the mechanical properties of the SEI and what role it plays in cell cycling, the W. Chueh and Z. Bao groups at Stanford/SLAC collected in situ measurements of the SEI nanomechanics (Figure 4.9a) for four electrolytes of interest to Li-metal batteries. In addition to the traditionally reported property of Young's modulus, this study collected quantitative measurements of SEI viscoelasticity using an indentation protocol incorporating  both  indentation  and  constant  force  hold  segments.  To  enable  the  robust  comparison  of SEI mechanical properties across different electrolytes, samples were prepared by electrodepositing lithium onto copper in four electrolytes. These electrolytes consisted of a conventional carbonate electrolyte (CCE) composed of 1 M LiPF6 in a 1:1 EC and DEC solvent; a low concentration electrolyte (LCE) with 1 M LiFSI salt  in  DME;  a  high  concentration  electrolyte  (HCE)  with  4 M  LiFSI  salt  also  in  DME;  and  LHCE  with 1 M LiFSI salt in a 1:3 ratio of DME to TTE, a partially fluorinated ether solvent. The first comparison of interest is the influence of salt choice on modulus by comparing SEI in CCE to SEI in other electrolytes. Second, the impact of solvation structure was

investigated by comparing LCE where lithium is primarily solvated by DME molecules  to  HCE  and  LHCE where the solvent structure incorporates  both  salts  and  solvents. Finally, by including electrolytes across a broad range of cycling performance, these experiments enable investigation into relationships between the mechanical properties of the SEI and the viability of the corresponding electrolyte for commercial Li-metal batteries. To maximize  robustness  of  comparison between the various electrolytes, samples were prepared by plating lithium metal at low current densities to produce samples with locally smooth and flat morphologies, as shown by the SEM images in Figure 4.9b. Between the low plating current of 0.25 mA/cm 2 and the pressure  applied  by  the  coin  cell,  all electrolytes, including the CCE, produced morphologies that were locally flat,  as  shown in Figure 4.9c, consistent  with  the  SEM  images  as well  as  prior  literature.  Within  the locally flat regions of these images, as shown in Figure 4.9d, mechanical measurements  were  then  performed by  indenting  the  AFM tip  into  the SEI that covers the lithium metal

surface and recording the force response and the indentation depth, as shown in Figure 4.9d. Surface roughness, extracted from locally planar regions is listed below each high-resolution image. The roughness values, between 2 nm and 10 nm, likely contribute to some of the spread in the data but are generally lower than the indentation depth, allowing for interpretable mechanical measurements.

In  addition  to  the  traditional  approach  and  withdrawal  segments  plotted  in  color,  the  measurement  also incorporated a hold with quasi-static force plotted in black. To better visualize how these two measurements form a traditional stress-strain curve, the measurements are plotted parametrically in Figure 4.10b/c, showing the approach segment, from which the elastic properties are calculated, as well as the hold and withdrawal segments that contain information about the inelastic properties of the SEI. The force curve also shows visible hysteresis due to inelastic contributions to the mechanical properties, which is also evidenced by the small amount of creep during the constant force hold.

To enable easy comparison of the pooled measurements from different electrolytes, the mean of the individual measurements is plotted superimposed for each electrolyte (Figure 4.10d). Comparing the measured moduli in this study to the solvation structures proposed in literature supports the hypothesis that solvation structure plays a substantial role on SEI modulus. SEI formed in the CCE electrolyte, where lithium is primarily solvated by carbonate solvent molecules, shows a different  modulus  from  SEI  derived from  LCE  where  lithium  is  solvated by  DME molecules, which is in turn different  from  HCE  and  LHCE  that have  similar  solvation  structures  of DME and FSI anion aggregates. However, despite the correlation between  the  SEI modulus  solvation structure, the relationship between modulus and performance is much less clear.  As  observed in prior literature, lithium metal deposited in CCE has a wiry  and  uneven  morphology  even when  compared  to  the  LCE,  despite measurements here showing a higher modulus. Because lithium morphology plays a substantial role in cyclability this also results in a substantially  lower  CE  in  the  CCE than the LCE, once again despite the higher  modulus  of  the  SEI  in  CCE. This  deviation  from  the  previously reported trend is less surprising given the relatively low SEI moduli reported here, since mechanical suppression of Li-metal plating by a layer that is both thin and soft is unlikely to occur. ## Quantification of Lithium and Sulfur Inventory Loss in Li-S Batteries

Previously, the UCSD team reported calibration data for quantifying dissolved elemental sulfur and methylated polysulfides CH3SxCH3 (x âˆˆ {2,8}) through a proposed methodology involving semi-preparative HPLC-UV and inductively coupled plasma - mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). This quarter, preliminary data on conventional C/S systems after 1 st discharge, 1 st charge, and after two formation cycles are discussed.

For this analysis, the UCSD team has used C/S cathodes with 3.5-4 mg cm -2 sulfur loading from GM. The coin cell is assembled with lean electrolyte (E:S = 8) and thin lithium foil (100 Âµm). The electrolyte used in this report is 1 M lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) in DOL:DME (1:1 v/v) with 2 wt% LiNO3 (baseline). The Battery500 formation cycles protocol was followed. Near real-time derivatization is performed by  washing  the  lithium  chip  with  derivatization  solution  (methyl  triflate)  and  then  putting  all  other  cell components into it. After washing, the lithium foil is taken to quantify the remaining lithium metal using TGC, and the cathode from the coin cell is taken into another volumetric flask to quantify the sulfur left on the cathode using  HPLC-UV.  HPLC-UV  is  performed  for  the  derivatized  mixture  to  quantify  methylated  species  and dissolved sulfur.

the  cells  were  stopped.  (b)  High-performance  liquid  chromatography -ultraviolet  data  of  derivatized  polysulfide solution after 1 st  discharge (red), 1 st  charge (blue), and two formation cycles (green).

In the Li-S battery, the expected behavior, according to theoretical charge transfer, is that all elemental sulfur should convert to Li2S on cell discharge and revert to elemental sulfur on charging. But, as discussed in the literature, all polysulfides consistently persist in the system. HPLC-UV curves of derivatized species, illustrated in  Figure  4.11a/b, clearly  show  that  there  is  little  to  no  sulfur  left  in  the  electrolyte  when  the  cell  is  fully discharged. Qualitatively, the amount of polysulfides increases when the cell is charged back. This is because the equilibrium shifts toward sulfur. They could get all the sulfur back in different forms after one cycle. As expected at the charged state, the sulfur  peak  is  present  after  two  formation  cycles.  Still,  all  other polysulfides are also present, which represents that not all polysulfides are converted to elemental sulfur. To achieve this quarter's milestones, they also performed similar analysis after 50 cycles and 100 cycles. After 50 cycles and 100 cycles, almost 70% of sulfur was lost in Li2S, Li2S2, SEI, and CEI. They could only account for ~ 46.1% of sulfur in polysulfide form as direct quantification after 1 cycle. About 53.9% of sulfur was considered Li2S, Li2S2, SEI, and CEI.

The UCSD team also looked at whether the SPAN cathode produces any  polysulfides  by  quantifying  polysulfides  by  HPLC-UV.  They observed  (Figure 4.12)  that  the  SPAN  cathode  did  not  show  any polysulfide peaks and hence it is evident that the working mechanism
