## Quantifying Lithium Inventory in Li-S Batteries during Calendar Aging

The self-discharge of Li-S batteries is mostly due to diffusion and reactions of sulfur and polysulfides at the anode-electrolyte  interface.  For  this  study,  the  UCSD  team  used  a  5-electrode  layer  pouch  cell  with  lean electrolyte (E:S = 5) and thin lithium foil (N:P = 2). They have compared two types of electrolytes for this study: moderately polysulfide solvating electrolyte, and weakly polysulfide solvating electrolyte. Last quarter, lithium inventory in Li-S cells after 24 hours, 7 days, and 30 days resting when no electrochemical operation is performed was quantitively measured by TGC methodology. They learned that the amount of lithium in the moderately solvating electrolyte is decreasing at a faster rate compared to the weakly solvating electrolyte. The difference  in  Li 0 inventory widens  as  the  resting  period  duration  increases.  In  the  moderately  solvating electrolyte, a portion of the Li 0 inventory dissolves in the electrolyte as long-chain lithium polysulfides, while the rest is transformed into electrochemically poor active short-chain polysulfides, such as Li2S. In this report, the team would like to extend a similar study in pouch cells that have gone through electrochemical operations. After cycling, they expect to observe inactive Li 0 as well as active Li 0 . Consequently, there arises a necessity for developing quantification methodology to distinguish active and inactive Li 0 in the Li-S System.

Previously, they had reported a novel chemical analytical methodology to quantitively distinguish the active Li 0 from inactive Li 0 in cycled Li-metal batteries. Biphenyl/tetrahydrofuran (BP/THF) solution is employed to dissolve the active Li 0 through complexation but also to preserve the completeness of SEI that encapsulates the inactive Li 0 . ## Battery500 Solid-State Battery Seedling Projects (Lead Institute: Pacific Northwest National Laboratory)

The  Battery500  Consortium  Phase  I  effort  (FY 2017  -  FY 2021)  made  significant  progress,  successfully demonstrating prototype 350 Wh/kg Li-metal pouch cells with 600 stable cycling by developing and integrating innovative  technologies.  In  Phase  2  (FY 2022 - FY 2026),  the  Consortium  continues  to  move  toward  the ultimate goal of 500 Wh/kg (cell level). During this phase, the U. S. Department of Energy awarded, under the auspices of the Battery500 Consortium, nine Solid-State Battery Seedling projects to pursue innovative research focusing on novel materials and their optimization and integration into high-energy-density batteries with the potential to meet the target of 500 Wh/kg and 1,000 cycles. This report provides an overview and the current progress for each of the Solid-State Battery Seedling projects.

## Progress Report

Blocking Lithium Metal Dendrites in Solid Electrolytes with Ion-Exchange Induced Residual Stresses (Brian W. Sheldon and Yue Qi, Brown University)

## Objective/Approach

This project is designed to improve integration of solid electrolytes (SEs) in Li-metal batteries. It is proposed that introducing residual compressive stresses in an outer surface layer of the SE can prevent lithium filament growth. The approach focuses on inducing these residual compressive stresses by ion-exchanging lithium with larger iso-valent ions. This research uses well-integrated experiments and modeling to explore two SEs: cubic garnet and argyrodite. Various possible elements for ion exchange will be evaluated with an integrated modeling approach  starting  from  the  atomistic  scale.  The  most  promising  candidates  will  then  be  investigated  in experiments that include three areas: (1) development of effective ion exchange methods, (2) measurements of the resulting residual stresses, and (3) electrochemical cycling, including measurements of the critical current density (CCD).

## Progress

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were used to determine the stable sites occupied by the larger isovalent  cations  {Na + ,  Ag + ,  and  K + }  (referred  to  as  IX  species),  by  sampling  their  exchanges  with  Li + on 14 octahedral and 7 tetrahedral sites in Li-La-Zr-O. Occupancy of the larger octahedral sites is preferable for all three, in contrast to Li + which prefers tetrahedral sites (~ 0.2 eV). [1-2]

For the lowest energy ion-exchanged configurations, the ion-exchanging energy, ð¸ð‘“ ( ð¾) , was evaluated as a function of the chemical potentials for Li + and IX + . A wide range of precursors was investigated, including the pure metals, sulphate, fluoride, chloride, oxide, nitrate, nitride, hexafluorophosphate, tetrafluoroborates, and chlorates.  An ð¸ð‘“ ( ð¾) range  of  0 ~ 0.3 eV  corresponds  to  a  3~5%  ion  exchange  concentration  at  1100 K (representing an upper experimental limit for temperature). The salts in this range are AgNO3 ( ð¸ð‘“ =  .27 eV) , Ag3PO4 (0.22 eV), AgClO4 (0.24 eV), and Na3PO4 (0.29 eV). Specifically, for silver ion exchange, AgNO3 was recommended.

Initial experiments focused on KCl  and  K2SO4  at temperatures up to 800Â°C.  The  K2SO4  caused Li-La-Zr-Ta-O degradation.  Treatment  with  KCl  alone  was  initially  promising  at  cycle  capacities  of 0.1-0.25 mAh/cm 2 , but were less impressive at higher capacities. More recent experiments instead focused on AgNO3 at 220Â°C-480Â°C. AgNO3 melts below 220Â°C, and thermally decomposes to silver at 480Â°C. A specimen held at 220Â°C for 50 hours had a CCD of 2.5 mA/cm 2 , compared to 0.5 mA/cm 2 for typical control samples. Other samples with different AgNO3 exposure conditions also had reproducible CCDs above 1 mA/cm 2 , and

the  X-ray  diffraction  sin 2 Î¨  method  for  these  materials  shows  that  the  treatments  produce  significant compressive stress. Additional experiments are in progress to demonstrate reproducibility of these results.

## Development of Thin, Robust, Lithium Impenetrable, High-Conductivity, Electrochemically Stable, Scalable, and Low-Cost Glassy Solid Electrolytes (Steve Martin, Iowa State University)

## Objective/Approach

The  project  objective  is  to  develop  new  Li + -conducting  mixed  oxy-sulfide  nitride  (MOSN)  glassy  solid electrolytes (GSEs) that are impermeable to lithium dendrites, have high conductivities, are scalable through low-cost  glass  manufacturing,  are  chemically  and  electrochemically  stable,  and  will  enable  low-cost, high-energy-density  all-solid-state  lithium  batteries  (ASSLBs).  The  ASSLBs  constructed  from  these  new GSEs will meet and exceed all program objectives: usable specific energy @ C/3 â‰¥ 350 Wh/kg, calendar life of 15 years,  cycle  life  (C/3  deep  discharge  with  &lt;  20%  energy  fade)  of  1000,  and  cost  â‰¤  $100/kWh.  The MOSN mixed glass former glasses used for the GSEs in this project were developed in previous work to have the necessary thermal stability and high ionic conductivity for successful use as a drawn-film electrolyte. In this project, glass chemistry will be tuned for even more desirable properties, by investigating structure-property relationships and testing variations in glass chemistry.

## Progress

This quarter, new GSE compositions were studied, particularly glasses in the Li2S - SiS2 - Li x SiO2+1/2 x system. Some glasses in these systems present high conductivities near 10 -3 (Î© cm) -1 , and high thermal stability, with working ranges up to 160Â°C, nearly 40Â°C higher than previously studied compositions. Further work is being done to confirm these results and to estimate the viscosity and crystallization behavior of these compositions to determine if one of them may be worth scaling up to ~ 200 g to draw into a thin film. Furthermore, significant effort  has  been  placed  into  the  thin-film  drawing  process  on the  LiSiPSO glass in the Li2S - SiS2 - LiPO3 system. The process is still being optimized; however, significant progress has been made. One ~ 200 g sample of the LiSiPSO glass has been cast into a preform and loaded into the draw tower. While the first five film drawing  attempts  yielded  only  no  film,  the  sixth  attempt  yielded  a  small  amount  ~ 40  cm 2 of  film  that  is ~ 300 Î¼m in thickness. The remaining glass from the preform will be remelted and recast into another preform and then pulled into film to continue optimizing the process to generate thinner, higher quality films. The work done already in this process has helped to show how recyclable these glasses are, with the preform able to be melted and remelted several times with no significant property changes. This allows the team to optimize the film drawing conditions without needing to synthesize kilograms of glass every few weeks. Work will continue next quarter to optimize the drawing conditions and characterize the thin films that are generated.

## Collaboration

This  project  collaborates  with  S. Kalnaus  and  G. Veith  (Oak  Ridge  National  Laboratory,  ORNL),  Y. Cui (Stanford University), A. Sendek (Avionics), and T. Yersak (General Motors).

## Developing Materials to Enable High-Energy-Density Cathode and Stable Lithium Anode for Solid-State Lithium -Sulfur Batteries (Donghai Wang, Pennsylvania State University)

## Objective/Approach

The project objective is to solve interfacial problems of the sulfur and lithium electrodes in Li-S all-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) to enable the following: (1) sulfur cathodes with &gt; 1000 mAh g -1 discharge specific capacity at high sulfur loading (â‰¥ 4 mg cm -2 ), high sulfur content (â‰¥ 50 wt% in the cathode), and deep discharge rate (C/3)  for  more  than 1000 cycles;  (2) lithium  anode  with  long  cycle  life  &gt; 300 cycles  at  â‰¥ 1 mA cm -2 ;  and (3) Li-S ASSBs  with  a  predicted  specific  energy  density  of  400 Wh kg -1 .  The  approaches  will  focus  on developing  new  liquid  phase  synthesized  SEs,  solvent-assisted  sulfur cathode  fabrication,  and  novel electron/ion transport enhancers for sulfur cathodes and a functional mixed ion-electron conductive (MIEC) interlayer  for  lithium  anodes.  It  will  be  accompanied  by  in-depth  electrochemical  and  spectroscopic characterization at both the material and electrode levels and computational analysis using molecular dynamics (MD), DFT, and machine-learning protocol.

## Progress

This quarter, the team worked on fabricating Li-S ASSBs with additives and MIEC interlayers for Li-metal anodes. Specifically, they have identified a sulfide additive for sulfur cathode, which could potentially promote electron and ion transport. By adding ~ 10 wt% of the additive, the discharge capacity of the sulfur cathode with 50 wt% of sulfur and areal sulfur loading of 2-3 mg cm -2 using 75Li2SÂ·25P2S5 solid-state electrolyte (SSE) was  significantly  improved.  In  detail,  the  sulfur  cathode  with  the  additive  exhibited  improved  discharge capacities of ~ 1248 mAh g -1 at  0.1 C and ~ 1207.017 mAh g -1 at  0.3 C, meeting this quarter's milestone. In contrast, the sulfur cathode without the additive merely delivered poor discharge capacity below 850 mAh g -1 at 0.1 C and 0.3 C.

Furthermore, the team has also prepared an MIEC interlayer composed of functionalized carbon black with a nanolayer coating by the atomic layer deposition technique. By employing this interlayer between the current collector (for example, copper foil) and SSE (for example, Li6PS5Cl), the Coulombic efficiency (CE) of lithium plating/stripping  can  reach  over  98%.  The  galvanostatic  lithium plating/stripping  performance  is  tested  in symmetric cells using the interlayer-coated lithium foil as the electrode. Cycling life can reach over 100 hours at  0.1 mA cm 2 .  They  have  also  worked  on  preparing  other  interlayers  by  optimizing  the  component  of functionalized carbon and combining ion transport agents. The electrochemical performance evaluation and optimization of the prepared interlayers are in progress.

They also worked on synthesizing SSEs with high ionic conductivity via the liquid-phase method. Compositions of targeted SSEs and potential reaction media (solvents) for the reactions have been identified. Next quarter, they will focus on synthesizing and characterizing the SSEs.

## Collaboration

This project collaborates with A. Ngo of University of Illinois, Chicago.

## Scalable Noble-Metal-Free Interlayer Design for Sheet-Type Dendrite-Free Solid-State Lithium Metal Batteries (Yan Yao and Zheng Fan, University of Houston)

## Objective/Approach

This  project  comprises  a  three-pronged  approach  to  understand  the  working  mechanism  of  a  MIEC-type composite  interlayer,  develop  a  scalable  noble-metal-free  interlayer,  and  integrate  such  an  interlayer  into sheet-type pouch cells with optimized performance. The team expects to complete two deliverables by the end of this project: (1) rationale design and scalable fabrication of noble-metal-free interlayers for all-solid-state Li-metal batteries, and (2) an experimentally validated electro-chemo-mechanics framework for the MIEC-type interlayer.

## Progress

The team's primary focus this quarter was to develop methods to produce finely mixed Mg-C composites. Prior to scalable processing, they investigated the impact of different carbon sources on interlayer properties through electrochemical characterization and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis. Among the carbon sources tested, Super C65 emerged as a promising candidate, outperforming carbon nanofiber or Ketjenblack Â® , enabling 2.8 mA cm -2 stripping  and  plating  current  density  at 30Â°C.  The  tests  underscored  that  the  choice  of  carbon source  significantly  determines  the  binding  energy  of  lithium  within  the  lithiated  interlayer,  resulting  in different transport properties, cell overpotential, and rate performance. To ensure the uniform dispersion of magnesium  in  the  carbon  matrix,  they  developed  two  scalable  approaches:  mechanical  mixing  and electrochemical plating.

In the mechanical mixing approach, the team utilized a planetary mixer to homogenize magnesium nanopowder, carbon, binder (polyvinylidene fluoride), and solvent. They optimized the milling media, slurry solid content, and  mixing  sequence  to  improve  film  quality  of  the  tape-cast  films.  A  large-area  Mg-C  composite  film (7 cm Ã— 15 cm) was prepared, with uniform thickness (18 Â± 2 Âµm), smooth surface (root mean square roughness of 1.6 Âµm), and low pinhole density (less than 0.1% area fraction). Both top-view and cross-sectional images demonstrate the uniform distribution of magnesium within the carbon matrix.

In  the  electrochemical  plating  approach,  the  team  electrochemically  deposited  magnesium  into  a  tape-cast porous  carbon  interlayer  using  phenyl  complex  electrolytes.  When  they  incorporated  the  as-prepared Mg-C interlayer into an anode-free solid-state cell, they observed negligible overpotential and lithium plating in  between  the  interlayer  and  current  collector,  confirming  the  facile  lithium  transport  capability  of  the interlayer.

## Collaboration

This project collaborates with J. Lou of Rice University and with H. Tu of Rochester Institute of Technology.

## Thin Composite Solid Electrolyte for Lithium Metal (Chunsheng Wang, University of Maryland)

## Objective/Approach

The project goal is to develop 50-Âµm to 80-Âµm SEs and interphases that enable ASSBs to reach up to an energy density of 500 Wh/kg at C/3 rate with a cycle life of 1000, a calendar life of 15 years, and cost of &lt; $100/kWh. During the initial period, the team will focus on synthesis, characterization, and optimization of Li-P-S-Cl/Polymer-In-Salt (LPSC-PIS) and Li9N2Cl3-PIS thin (50-80 Âµm) composite electrolytes.

## Progress

Void  Suppression  Capability  (VSC). The  concept  of  VSC  was  introduced  to  assess  the  performance  of Li-based  anodes  in  solid-state  batteries  (SSBs).  MD  calculations  highlighted  that  the  surface  diffusion coefficients of lithium and LiMg are significantly higher than those in the bulk material, emphasizing the need to enhance the specific surface and grain boundary (GB) areas.

Li-Mg-La Alloy. A Li-Mg-La alloy was developed to enhance diffusivity due to refined grain size. The addition of Mg-La not only acted as nuclei for lithium crystallization but also facilitated grain size reduction. The optimal grain  size  for  the  Li-Mg-La  alloy  was  observed  to  be  within  the  range  of  5-10 Î¼m.  By  fine-tuning  the composition, the LiMgLa anode was optimized, with the Li97.5(MgLa)2.5 configuration (Mg/La = 97/3 wt%) exhibiting  the  best  battery  performance.  This  configuration  delivered  a  peak  stripped  capacity  exceeding 4 mAh cm -2 at 0.1 mA cm -2 .

Dynamic Void Formation Process. The team simulated the dynamic void formation process at the Li|LLZTO interface during the Li-stripping phase using a mesoscale phase-field method. Their simulations indicated that maintaining lithium utilization at ~ 70% of full depletion capacity is crucial for stable cycling. Experimental validation demonstrated the battery's stability over 30 cycles at a current density of 1 mAâˆ™cm -2 and a capacity of 0.5 mAhâˆ™cm -2 , aligning closely with their simulation, achieving a viable VSC of 0.5.

Increase  of  Lithium  Dendrite  Suppression  Capability. The  team  prepared  a  Li7N2I-Mg  interlayer  with gradient  electronic  conductivity  to  increase  the  lithium  dendrite  suppression  capability of  Li//Li  cells  with Li6PS5Cl SE. An 18.5 Âµm LNI-25%Mg interlayer enables Li4SiO4@NMC-811/LPSC/Li full cells with an areal capacity of 2.2 mAh cm -2 to be charged/discharged for 350 cycles at 60Â°C with capacity retention of 82.4%. The mechanism of improved performance was investigated.

## Collaboration

This  project  collaborates  with  the  following  organizations:  Navitas  Systems;  University  of  California,  San Diego; and Saft America.

## Optimizing Cathode Architecture for Solid-State Lithium Metal -Sulfur Batteries (Eric Wachsman and Gibson Scisco, University of Maryland)

## Objective/Approach

The project  objective  is to  optimize  the  cathode  architecture  to  enable  500 Wh/kg  solid-state  Li-S  cells by incorporating  recently  developed  MIEC  garnets  in  the  electrode  structure  and  tailoring  their  structure  to minimize mass while maximizing ionic and electronic transport to enable higher loading cathodes for higher cell energy density.

## Progress

This quarter, the team made progress in three target areas: three-dimensional (3D) printing of MIEC garnet structures, full Li-S cells, and modeling of the solid-state Li-ion battery system.

The team achieved 3D printing of MIEC inks this quarter. These inks displayed longer viscoelastic recovery time, which is less favorable when printing columns but is acceptable for grid and raster structures. Next quarter, the  MIEC  ink  formulation  will  be  optimized  to  reduce  the  elastic  recovery  time  to  allow  for  3D  printed structures to be implemented with sulfur-cathode based full cells.

An all-solid-state cell with sulfur and carbon nanotube cathode and Li-metal anode was prepared; however, it had too high of an impedance without using a catholyte. In addition, sulfurized polyacrylonitrile (SPAN) and

Li-metal liquid cells (no garnet) with 1 M lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide in 1:1 1,2-dimethoxyethane / 1,3-dioxolane were  also  prepared  to  verify  the  quality  of  the  SPAN.  Initial  discharge  capacity  of 2023 mAh/g S  based  on  the  sulfur  content  of  the  SPAN  was  observed.  This  is  higher  than  theoretical 1670 mAh/g S, indicating long charging issues or side reactions that are being investigated.

A new one-dimensional (1D) electrochemical model was implemented in MATLAB. Building on previous work by this  group,  this  transient model  simulates  a galvanostatic  cycle  of  a  1D  MIEC  cell-tracking  the concentrations  of  lithium  ions  and  electrons  throughout  the  cathode  and  electrolyte,  as  well  as  the electrochemical potential over time. The finite element model is being tested and scaled up to 3D. Because the microstructures of the 3D printed electrodes in question are relatively simple when compared to most porous electrodes, the model can be run on a near continuum of hypothetical cells that are procedurally generated, as well as real-life cells whose geometries are characterized at the university.

Development of High-Energy-Density All-Solid-State Lithium Batteries Enabled through Optimized Electrochemical Interface and Engineering Cell Designs (Deyang Qu, University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee)

## Objective/Approach

The  objective  of  this  work  is  to  demonstrate  a  high-capacity  and  long-cycle  all-solid-state  lithium  battery (ASSLB) by the end of the project. It will be demonstrated in a cell without excessive external pressure (force) applied; no heavy pressure fixture is needed. The team aims to achieve these goals through several approaches:

- Investigation of the interfaces in an ASSLB.
- 3D elastic cathode design. They will fabricate an integrated and elastic thick cathode / SSE structure to mitigate the loss of the electrochemical accessible surface area due to slow Li-ion diffusion in the SSE or the void space created by a cathode volume change.
- Flexible electrolyte-SSE assembly. They will make a modular electrode / SSE assembly. Premanufactured modular cells can be assembled into a battery in a series and/or parallel manner.
- High aspect-ratio battery design (HARB). The innovative HARB design aims to eliminate all heavy fixtures to maintain excessive external pressure.

## Progress

Since the project's inception, the team has been pursuing investigations in five areas:

- Interface  and  Volume  Change. They  have  developed  an in situ electrochemical  optical  diagnostic technique capable of visualizing dendrite growth at a cross-section. In addition, they have designed fixtures for  monitoring  volume  changes  under  constant  pressure  conditions  as  well  as  pressure  changes  under constant volume conditions.
- Distinction between Ionic and Electronic Conductivity. In a liquid electrolyte, the exclusive carriers of electric charge are ions. Conversely, in SSEs, either ions or electrons can serve as conduits for electrical charge  transport.  In  the  context  of  an  ASSLB,  it  is  crucial  for  the  primary  charge  carriers  to  be predominantly ions; otherwise, the cell could short-circuit or suffer from high self-discharge. To address this, they have conducted alternating current impedance and direct current tests using various solid-state electrochemical  cell  configurations  with  the  objective  of  establishing  a  reliable  and  straightforward diagnostic method.
- Flexible SSE and Cathode assembly. The team now can make flexible SSE and cathode: 50 Î¼m SSE and over 100 Âµm cathode (sulfur cathode). Good performance was demonstrated.

- Developing  a  Surface  Coating  to  Inhibit  Chemical  Interaction  between  Polytetrafluoroethylene Binder and Lithium Anode. This  involves  creating  a  thin  (&lt; 10 Âµm)  conductive  polymer  film  on  the lithium anode surface, which effectively acts as a barrier, preventing direct contact between the lithium anode and the flexible SSE film. This conductive polymer is synthesized in situ from monomers on the lithium anode.
- Bi-polar ASSLB. The team  successfully  created  a  two-layer  bi-polar  cell  (4 V),  which  demonstrated  a promising cycle life of 30 cycles and a high cathode capacity of 500 mAh/g. This capacity is equivalent to 1000 mAh/g when compared to a sulfur cathode in a single-cell configuration.

## Collaboration

The  principal  investigator  collaborates  with  several  research  groups  within  the  Battery500 Consortium, including Brookhaven National Laboratory, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, University of Washington, West Virginia University, Cornell University, North Texas University, Millipore Aldrich, and Advano. These collaborations form a crucial part of the research landscape, enabling exchange of knowledge and resources to drive scientific progress and innovation within the consortium.

Stable Sulfide-Based Anode-Free and Anode-Limited All-Solid-State Lithium Battery (Puru Jena, Virginia Commonwealth University; David Mitlin, University of Texas at Austin; and Hong Fang, Rutgers University)

## Objective/Approach

The  project  objective  is  to  develop  high-performance  sulfide-based  anode-free  and  anode-limited ASSBs, designated  as  AF-ASSBs  and  AL-ASSBs, respectively.  To  overcome  challenges  that  limit  AF-ASSBs  and AL-ASSBs,  the  team  will  incorporate  three  innovative  aspects  they  recently  developed:  (1) stabilize  the Li-SE interface by incorporating reactive oxides (for example, ZnO) into the sulfide SEs to inhibit void and dendrite formations; (2) introduce electrochemically stable lithiophilic intermetallics (for example, Li2Te) onto the  'empty'  current  collector  to  template  the  electrodeposition/electrodissolution  of  lithium  metal;  and (3) further enhance cell performance by exploiting new theoretically developed argyrodite-type cluster-based SEs with enhanced ionic conductivity and stability. Their research will be performed in a synergetic, iterative process,  with  theoretical  modeling/simulation  advancing  experiments,  and  experiments  driving  theory.  As needed  throughout  the  project,  they  will  work  with  their  collaborators  on  cryogenic  microscopy,  Li-metal evaporation, synchrotron methods, and commercial ASSB guidance and third-party testing.

## Progress

Sulfide SEs, for example, the lithium argyrodite (LPSC), are primarily synthesized in labs using fine precursors such  as  Li2S,  LiCl,  and  P2S5,  with  meticulous  synthetic  procedures  involving  milling  and  sintering.  This approach  can  produce  SEs  with  a  uniform  distribution  of  particle  sizes  and  well-controlled  morphology. However, such processes are labor-intensive, with only a few grams of SE per batch, which cannot meet the scale-up demand for producing SEs. On the other hand, compared to lab-scale synthesis, the current commercial production of SEs in large scale often yields with unregulated particle sizes and non-uniform distributions, which can affect their electrochemical performance.

This quarter, the team explored preparation of LPSC SEs using a wet ball-milling method that allows easy production in large scale. With controlled parameters during ball milling, they found that the as-synthesized SEs  exhibit  significantly  enhanced  electrochemical  stability  and  cycling  performance.  To  understand  the mechanisms behind these improvements, they carried out characterizations on the bulk and interface properties of the prepared SEs, including ionic conductivity, CCD, and electrodeposition behavior. Besides investigating

particle size and distribution in the GB by ball milling, they are also conducting research on the atomic-level origin  of  the  improved  interface  performance.  Interface  models  of  LPSC-Li  were  built  and  optimized. MD simulations on these interfacial models containing different levels of defects are in progress. Experimental measurements, including  nuclear  magnetic  resonance (NMR)  spectroscopy,  are  also under  way  to  quantify studied defects in the samples to corroborate theoretical results.

## Collaboration

This project collaborates with J. Watt, Center for Integrated Nanotechnologies at Sandia National Laboratories; G. Veith, ORNL; J. Nanda, SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory; and P. Zhang, Solid Power.

## Molecular Ionic Composite Solid Electrolytes for Long-Cycling and High-Voltage Lithium-Metal Batteries (Louis Madsen and Feng Lin, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University)

## Objective/Approach

This project aims to develop SSBs based on a recently developed class of SEs based on a highly rigid and charged double-helical polymer. These molecular ionic composite (MIC)  electrolytes offer desirable electrochemical and mechanical properties that promise to overcome the limitations of conventional SEs such as ceramics and conducting polymers. This project entails three main objectives: (1) designing, fabricating, and optimizing MIC electrolyte membranes (~ 20 Î¼m thickness) with widely tailorable chemical composition and morphology;  (2) fabricating  interfaces  and  composite  cathodes  to  improve  CCD  and  reduce  interfacial resistance  on  both  anode  and  cathode  sides;  and  (3) achieving  full  integration into pouch  cells  along  with detailed electrochemical, synchrotron X-ray and advanced NMR measurements. This project aims to deliver MICs to enable Li-metal batteries with &gt; 500 Wh/kg specific energy and â‰¥ 80% retention after 1000 cycles with C/3 deep discharge, 15 years calendar life, and â‰¤ $100/kWh.

## Progress

This quarter, the team has systematically tuned the composition of the MIC electrolyte with new functional and non-volatile additives to improve cycling stability of high-voltage, lithium batteries. Based on their findings of the  degradation  mechanism  of  MIC electrolytes  under  electrochemical  cycling  (to  be  published)  by  X-ray synchrotron  analyses,  they  are  incorporating  new  additives  to  tailor  the  electrode/electrolyte  interphases, enhance interfacial  durability  over  long-term  cycling,  and  increase  cycling  rate  capability.  They  tested  the performance of Li/Li symmetric cells and Li/MIC/LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1 cells with an MIC incorporating a new neutral  molecule  additive  (to  be  announced  pending patent  disclosure).  These  cells  display  higher  limiting current  densities  compared  to  that  of  the  traditional  MIC  electrolyte  (0.95 mA/cm 2 versus  0.35 mA/cm 2 at 60Â°C), indicating more stable interphase formation and enhanced ion transport. Cycling stability (at C/3 rate) improved  with  the  additive  (94%  versus  83%),  as  well  as  higher  average  CE  (99.8%  versus  98.7%), demonstrating that large further increases in rate capability are in store for MIC electrolytes, and with minimal processing complexity.

In addition, the team is investigating a new fabrication technique to create solid MIC electrolytes with improved mechanical  properties  (in  particular,  strength  and  toughness)  compared  to  those  obtained  from  their  now standard film-casting process. By adding lithium salt + ionic liquid solutions to a  poly(2,2â€²-disulfonyl-4,4â€²benzidine terephthalamide) hydrogel precursor (patent submitted last year under the team's previous Vehicle Technologies  Office  project),  they  convert  the  hydrogel  into  a  dry  solid  MIC.  This  uses  substantially  less volume of volatile solvents than their existing film-casting method and creates a more robust film. The challenge now is to obtain thin films with comparable planarity and thickness to the existing casting method.

## Collaboration

The team had no direct collaborative results this quarter. However, they continue to collaborate regarding topics of this project with T. Dingemans at University of North Carolina, R. Colby at Pennsylvania State University, D. Nordlund at SLAC, and a few others whom they worked with on the previous project.
